The public holds negative views on how the U.S. military effort against ISIS is progressing [4, 9]. Specifically, most Americans think the U.S. effort against Islamic militants in Iraq and Syria is going "not too well" or "not at all well" [1].

However, despite these assessments, a significant majority believes in the ultimate success of the U.S. and its allies. Two-thirds (66%) now say they think the U.S. and its allies will either definitely or probably succeed in their campaign against Islamic militants in Iraq and Syria [2].  ![There was an 11 point increase from July to December in the percentage of people who believed the U.S. and its allies would succeed in their campaign against Islamic militants in Iraq and Syria.](image1)

This positive outlook has increased by 11 points since July, from 55% to 66% [2]. This shows an uptick in the view that the U.S. and its allies will ultimately be successful [4].

Even though views on the current military effort against ISIS is going remain negative, more people have an optimistic outlook for the ultimate success of the U.S. and its allies in their fight against ISIS in 2015.

According to the Pew Research Center's survey conducted from July 18 to September 30, 2013, there is a difference between internet and broadband adoption among men aged 65 and older. The survey found that the percentage of men aged 65 and older who use the internet is  $65\%$ ![Men aged 65+ using internet](image3), while the percentage of men aged 65 and older who have broadband at home is $53\%$ ![Men aged 65+ using broadband at home](image2).

To find the gap between internet usage and broadband adoption, we can subtract the broadband percentage from the internet usage percentage:

$65\% - 53\% = 12\%$

Therefore, the gap between internet use and broadband adoption at home for men aged 65 and older is $12\%$.
```float
0.12
```
The gap between male 65+ age group who use internet and broadband at home is 0.12.

In December 2015, 35% thought the campaign was going very or fairly well, compared to 30% in July 2015.

![The number of people who believe the US military effort against ISIS is going well has increased from July to December 2015.](image4)

Overall, perceptions of the U.S. military campaign against ISIS became more positive from July to December 2015.

The perceptions about the relationship between Islam and violence have largely remained consistent, with political polarization influencing these views [1]. A survey from December 2015 indicates that 46% of Americans believe Islam is more prone to encourage violence among its followers, while 45% disagree, showing a division in public opinion [4].

Notably, opinions vary across age groups. While 32% of individuals aged 18-29 think Islam encourages violence more than other religions, a larger percentage, 51% of Americans aged 65 and older, share this view [2]. This age-related difference, however, has narrowed since the fall of the previous year [2].

![Americans are divided about whether they see Islam as more likely than other religions to encourage violence among its believers](image4)

The ideological divide is significant and growing. Approximately 77% of conservative Republicans believe that Islam is more likely to encourage violence, whereas 73% of liberal Democrats think Islam is no more likely to encourage violence than other religions [7].  The partisan gap regarding whether Islam encourages violence has reached a historic high [8]. A significant 68% of Republicans think Islam promotes violence more than other religions, while only 30% of Democrats share this view, marking a decrease from 42% in September 2014 [8].

![The partisan divide over whether Islam encourages violence is now as wide as it has ever been](image5)

In summary, views on whether Islam encourages violence more than other religions have remained relatively stable overall but have become increasingly polarized along political lines, with significant differences in opinion between Republicans and Democrats.

Most Americans are familiar with the idea that automation could affect many jobs, and they generally think it's realistic [7]. Fully 85% of the public has heard or read about this, with 24% saying they've heard or read "a lot" about it [7]. Around 77% consider the idea at least somewhat realistic, and one in five find it extremely realistic [7].

![One-in-five Americans find concept of machines doing most human jobs in the future to be extremely realistic](image1)

However, Americans express more worry than enthusiasm about automation technologies [9].  Specifically, 72% express worry compared to 33% enthusiasm about robots and computers doing many human jobs [9].  This concern is further highlighted by the fact that Americans are roughly three times as likely to express worry (67%) than enthusiasm (22%) about algorithms making hiring decisions without human involvement [9].

![The bar graph illustrates that the majority of Americans worry more than feel enthusiastic about robots and computers that can do many jobs currently done by humans](image4)

Those who have heard more about the concept find it more realistic and are more enthusiastic [6].  Nearly half (48%) of Americans who have heard a lot about this concept find it extremely realistic that machines might one day do many of the jobs currently done by humans [6].  Those with higher awareness express greater enthusiasm about the idea that machines might do many human jobs [2]. Those already impacted by automation are more likely to find it realistic and see greater job risks [5].

![Those who have heard a lot about the concept consider it more realistic and have higher enthusiasm levels](image5)

Overall, Americans are familiar with the idea of automation impacting jobs, consider it realistic, but express more worry than enthusiasm, anticipating more negative than positive outcomes.

The public is generally in favor of policies that limit the use of machines in the workforce and support human workers [5, 6]. Most Americans feel there should be limits on how many jobs businesses can replace with machines [3, 7].

For example, 85% of Americans favor limiting machines to performing dangerous or unhealthy jobs [3, 9, 10]. ![Americans favor limiting machines to dangerous or unhealthy jobs.](image4)

Moreover, many support policies that bring human beings more fully into their operations [5]. The public is divided on whether the government or individuals should be responsible for providing for displaced workers [4]. Although more than half of the public would not want to ride in a driverless vehicle today if given the opportunity [1]. The public generally supports limiting the number of jobs businesses can replace with machines and restricting machines to dangerous jobs.

Republicans are more optimistic than Democrats regarding job availability [3]. According to the text, currently, $71\%$ of Republicans say there are plenty of jobs available, compared with $53\%$ of Democrats [3]. The image also shows a similar divide in perceptions of job availability. ![Republicans are more likely to say plenty of jobs are available.](image1)
The image shows 71% of Republicans and 53% of Democrats believe plenty of jobs are available. Additionally, [10] suggests that views of local job opportunities are among the most positive in both parties as at any point in the last two decades.

Republicans are more likely than Democrats to perceive that there are plenty of jobs available in their communities.

In both parties, increasing shares want leaders to ‘stand up’ to opposition [3]. Most Democrats want party leaders to “stand up” to Trump [8].
![The percentages of Democrats wanting their leaders to "stand up" to Trump increased from 63% in January 2018 to 70% in January 2019.](image3)
Among Republicans, the share saying Trump should stand up to Democrats has increased from 40% a year ago to 51% currently [6].
![The percentages of Republicans wanting their leaders to "stand up" to Democrats increased from 40% in January 2018 to 51% in January 2019.](image5)
The percentage of both Republicans and Democrats wanting their leaders to stand up to the opposition increased from January 2018 to January 2019.

Latino Democrats and Republicans have contrasting views on whether people acknowledge the existence of racial discrimination. According to the survey, a majority of Latinos believe it's a significant problem when people fail to see racial discrimination where it truly exists [1]. However, this view is more pronounced among Democrats than Republicans [4].

Specifically, a substantial majority of Latino Democrats and Democratic leaners, about 73%, identify the lack of recognition of racial discrimination as a major issue. ![73% of Latino Democrats and leaners consider the lack of recognition of racial discrimination as a major issue.](image3) By contrast, a majority of Republicans and Republican leaners, around 62%, are more concerned that people perceive racial discrimination even when it doesn't exist [6]. Latino Democrats (75%) are more likely than Latino Republicans (36%) or Latino independents and nonpartisans (56%) to say that people not seeing racial discrimination where it really does exist is a bigger problem for the country [10]. The perception of racial discrimination varies significantly between Latino Democrats and Republicans, with Democrats more concerned about the lack of recognition and Republicans more concerned about false accusations.

According to the Pew Research Center, multiple factors contribute to the underrepresentation of women, blacks, and Hispanics in STEM jobs [2, 5]. A lack of encouragement to pursue STEM from an early age is considered a major reason for the underrepresentation of both women and blacks and Hispanics, with $39\%$ of Americans believing this affects women and $41\%$ believing this affects blacks and Hispanics [5]. ![Major reasons for underrepresentation in STEM jobs.](image5) Additionally, limited access to quality education is seen as a significant barrier, with $42\%$ of Americans citing this as a major reason for the underrepresentation of blacks and Hispanics [6].

People employed in STEM jobs are more likely to cite the lack of access to quality education $(52\%\ \text{vs}.\ 42\%)$, lack of encouragement to pursue subjects at an early age $(45\%\ \text{vs}.\ 40\%)$, and lack of Black and Hispanic role models working in the field $(32\%\ \text{vs}.\ 27\%)$ as major reasons for the underrepresentation of these groups in STEM jobs [1]. Moreover, experiences of discrimination at work is more prevalent among blacks in STEM, as $62\%$ report facing discrimination due to their race or ethnicity, compared to $44\%$ of Asians, $42\%$ of Hispanics, and $13\%$ of whites [10]. This is further substantiated by the fact that a substantial $72\%$ of blacks in STEM believe that discrimination in recruiting, hiring, and promotions is a major factor contributing to the underrepresentation of blacks and Hispanics in these jobs [7].

The major reasons for the underrepresentation of women, blacks, and Hispanics in STEM jobs include lack of encouragement, limited access to quality education, and experiences of discrimination.

Most Americans and those with STEM postgraduate degrees view K-12 STEM education similarly, but STEM postgraduate degree holders are more critical. Most Americans give average or lower marks to K-12 education generally, K-12 STEM education specifically [3]. Likewise, most Americans rate K-12 STEM education as average or worse compared with other developed nations, so, too, do those with an advanced degree in STEM [8].

However, there are differences in the specific ratings: Only $13\%$ of those with a STEM postgraduate degree rate K-12 STEM education as above average, while about half $(51\%)$ say the U.S. is below average [9].  In contrast, $27\%$ of adults with some college or less education give K-12 STEM education in the U.S. the same rating [9].

![Only 13 percent of STEM postgraduate degree holders rate K-12 STEM education as above average.](image4)

The public has a more favorable view of K-12 STEM education in the U.S. compared to other developed countries, with a quarter considering it above average [4]. Still, opinions diverge among STEM postgraduate degree holders, as only $13\%$ believe K-12 STEM education is above average [1]. Most Americans view K-12 STEM education as average or below that of other developed nations [10].

![A quarter of Americans consider K-12 STEM education in the U.S. to be at least above average compared with other developed countries.](image5)

While both groups are critical, STEM postgraduate degree holders tend to have a more negative perception of K-12 STEM education compared to the general public.

From 2004, European early-stage companies have experienced an entrepreneurial boom that has led them to scale faster and accrue more value sooner than before [10].  However, visibility on European VC Funds for investors is highly limited and prejudiced by the poor quality of published industry fund statistics in Europe [5].

Looking at the investment amounts shows contrasting trajectories between Europe and the US across different investment stages. ![Seed investments in Europe remained relatively flat between 2004 and 2009, while First, Second, and Later stage investments initially increased but then declined.](image2)

On the other hand, the average capital invested prior to exit in the USA is significantly higher than in Europe. ![The average capital invested prior to exit is substantially lower in Europe compared to the USA, indicating greater capital efficiency in European ventures.](image4)  This is because the scarcity of VC money in Europe has driven up capital efficiency, approximately 70 percent higher than in the US [1].

The median investments in Europe remained relatively flat or declined across various stages from 2004 to 2009, while the U.S. saw significantly higher capital invested prior to exit compared to Europe.

The category that contributes the most to the number of transactions is Fashion, Footwear & Accessories, while Mobile, Tablets & Accessories contribute the most to the gross margin value in online retail.

The levels of confidence and likelihood are determined by the chapter author teams through expert assessment and consensus, considering the available literature, the quality and quantity of evidence, and the level of agreement across different studies [5].

The assessment of confidence in a finding considers the type, amount, quality, strength, and consistency of evidence, as well as the degree of expert agreement, ranging from low to very high confidence [9]. `![Confidence levels range from low to very high based on evidence and expert agreement.](image2)`

Likelihood language describes the probability of an event occurring, based on statistical analysis, model results, or expert judgment [7]. Likelihood statements have specific probabilities associated with them, ranging from very unlikely (less than or equal to 1 in 10 chance) to very likely (greater than or equal to 9 in 10 chance) [3]. `![Likelihood is expressed probabilistically, ranging from very unlikely to very likely.](image3)`

Confidence and likelihood levels are based on the expert assessment and consensus of the chapter author teams [5]. `![People in outdoor clothing are standing in a crowd.](image1)`

In summary, the levels of confidence and likelihood are evaluated through expert assessment and consensus, based on the quality and quantity of evidence, and the level of agreement across studies [5].

Views on the ethical standards of political parties and whether they are too extreme vary across different educational and political affiliation groups.

A quarter of the public thinks neither the Republican nor Democratic Party has high ethical standards, while 47% believe this applies to one but not the other [6]. Combining views of both  political parties on ethics, a  quarter of the public says  “high ethical standards”  describes  neither  the  Republican Party nor the  Democratic Party;  $47\%$   say it  describes one party but not  the other; and  $17\%$   say the  description applies to both [6].
![Views of both parties regarding ethical standards among the public.](image4)

Critiques about ethical standards extend to both parties, with 41% of Americans believing the GOP has high ethical standards and 42% saying the same about the Democratic Party [8]. Just  $41\%$   of Americans say  the GOP has high ethical standards, while a  nearly identical share   $\left(42\%\right)$   say this about the  Democratic Party [8]. This is further highlighted in image2, which shows that 41% think the Republican Party has high ethical standards, while 42% think the same of the Democratic Party.
![Public opinion on ethical standards and extremity of Republican and Democratic parties.](image2)

There are differences in the perception of how extreme each party is, as more people view the Republican Party as "too extreme" (48%) compared to the Democratic Party (42%) [9]. More continue to view the Republican Party as “too extreme”   $(48\%)$   than say this about the  Democratic Party   $(42\%)$ [9].

However, these views are deeply divided along partisan lines. Overwhelming shares (more than 80%) of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents, as well as Democrats and Democratic leaners, say their own party has good policy ideas, but less than a quarter say this describes the opposing party [4].  Similarly, while only about two-in-ten Republicans or Democrats think their own party is "too extreme," about three-quarters in each party think the other party can be described this way [4]. This is corroborated by Image3, which shows that views are divided along partisan lines.
![Voter affiliation percentages in the Democratic and Republican parties based on various demographics.](image3)

The perception of ethical standards and extremism in political parties is divided, influenced significantly by partisan affiliation and, to some extent, educational attainment.

The public has similar views of the Republican and Democratic parties in assessments of their policy ideas and ethical standards [10]. However, more Americans view the Republican Party as "too extreme" than the Democratic Party [10].

Combining views of both political parties on ethics, a quarter of the public says "high ethical standards" describes neither the Republican Party nor the Democratic Party [6]. ![A quarter of the public believes that neither the Republican nor Democratic Party has high ethical standards.](image1)

Critiques about ethical standards also extend to the two parties: Just 41% of Americans say the GOP has high ethical standards, while a nearly identical share (42%) say this about the Democratic Party [9]. ![Similar percentages of Americans believe the Republican and Democratic parties have high ethical standards.](image3)

Opinions about the traits of the two parties continue to be deeply divided along partisan lines [7]. Overwhelming shares (more than 80%) of both Republicans and Republican-leaning independents and Democrats and Democratic leaners say their own party has good policy ideas, while less than a quarter say this describes the opposing party [7]. Similarly, while only about two-in-ten Republicans or Democrats think their own party is “too extreme,” about three-quarters in each party think the other party can be described this way [7].

Independents are significantly more likely than partisans to say neither party has “high ethical standards" [1]. About a third of independents (34%), including equal shares of Republican leaners and Democratic leaners (33% each) say neither party has high ethical standards [1]. By comparison, only about two-in-ten Republicans (19%) or Democrats (18%) say this [1].

Among those with at least a college degree, 31% say “high ethical standards” does not describe the GOP or the Democratic Party [8]. By comparison, fewer of those with some college experience (26%) or a high school degree or less education (20%) think neither party has high ethical standards [5].

Perceptions of ethical standards and extremism differ slightly between the Republican and Democratic parties, with the Republican Party being viewed as more extreme; these perceptions are influenced by education and are sharply divided along partisan lines.

Educational attainment appears to influence perceptions of ethical standards in political parties, as "a quarter of the public says 'high ethical standards' describes neither the Republican Party nor the Democratic Party" [4]. However, this view is more prevalent among those with higher education levels; specifically, "among those with at least a college degree, 31% say 'high ethical standards' does not describe the GOP or the Democratic Party" [7].

![College graduates are more likely to believe that neither political party has high ethical standards.](image3)

Conversely, "fewer of those with some college experience (26%) or a high school degree or less education (20%) think neither party has high ethical standards" [1].  This suggests that higher education may lead to more critical views of ethical standards in both political parties.  Views on party ethics are similar, according to the public, with views on party policy ideas [8]. The approval ratings of the president also differ across education levels, with postgraduate degrees disapproving the most  ![People with postgraduate degrees tend to disapprove more strongly.](image1).

Political affiliation also plays a significant role in these perceptions. Independents are more likely than partisans to believe that neither party has high ethical standards, with about 34% of independents holding this view, compared to only about 19% of Republicans and 18% of Democrats [10].

![The figure shows that the Republican Party and Democratic Party have very similar ethical standards.](image2)

Early midterm vote preferences also show educational differences, as those with postgraduate degrees favor the Democratic candidate over the Republican by roughly two-to-one (62% to 30%), and those with a four-year college degree favor the Democrat, 53% to 40% [2]. Preferences are more divided among voters who do not have a college degree [2]. Individuals tend to vote along party lines depending on their affiliation  ![Those who affiliate with the Democratic Party tend to vote for Democratic candidates.](image5).

In summary, perceptions of ethical standards and political party preferences vary significantly based on both education level and political affiliation, with higher education and independent status correlating with more critical views of both parties' ethical standards.

Public confidence in Trump's handling of economic policy is mixed, with $53\%$ expressing at least some confidence, while $46\%$ express little to no confidence [3].  ![53% of the public express at least some confidence in Trump’s ability to make good decisions about economic policy.](image3)

Partisan divisions are significant, with a large majority of Republicans expressing confidence in Trump, while a small minority of Democrats share this view [4]. Public confidence in Trump’s handling of economic policy has increased since January [10].  ![The graph illustrates public confidence in Trump across various policy areas.](image4)

Views on the ethical standards of Trump administration officials are also divided along partisan lines, with $75\%$ of Republicans giving the administration high marks and $86\%$ of Democrats rating its ethical standards negatively [5].  Even within the Republican party, there is a divide, with conservative Republicans viewing the ethical standards more positively than moderate and liberal Republicans [8]. Overall, just $41\%$ of Americans say the GOP has high ethical standards [2]. ![The image shows a breakdown of how different political affiliations view the ethical standards of Trump administration officials.](image1)

Views on Trump’s handling of economic policy and ethical standards are strongly divided along partisan lines, with Republicans generally more confident and Democrats more critical.

Public confidence in Trump's handling of economic policy and international crises has seen some shifts since January, but views remain divided. Public confidence in Trump’s handling of economic policy has ticked up since January [7]. Similarly, confidence in Trump to handle an international crisis has increased from 35% in January to 43% today [10].

However, public confidence in Trump on most key issues remains mixed [1]. For example, in May 2018, 53% of the public expressed at least some confidence in Trump’s ability to make good decisions about economic policy, while 46% expressed little or no confidence [6]. ![The graph shows public confidence in Trump's ability to handle international crisis and make good decisions about economic policy has increased since January 2018.](image1)

Partisan perspectives show a significant divide.  Eight-in-ten Republicans and Republican-leaners (80%) now say they agree with Trump on many or all issues, up 11 percentage points from last August [4].  Since January, Republicans have grown significantly more confident in Trump to handle an international crisis (84% now, 73% then) [5].

In summary, while overall public confidence in Trump's ability to handle economic policy and international crises has seen some improvement since the beginning of the year, it remains mixed, with significant partisan differences.

Public confidence in Trump's ability to handle economic policy and international crises has generally increased since January [7, 8]. Specifically, confidence in his ability to handle an international crisis has risen from 35% in January to 43% [10].
![Confidence in handling international crisis and economic policy has increased since January.](image2)
Similarly, public confidence in Trump's handling of economic policy has also ticked up since January [4].
![Public has somewhat or very confident in Trump's decision about economic policy.](image1)

Republican sentiment largely aligns with Trump, with agreement on many or all issues increasing from 69% in August to 80% currently [5, 9].
![Republicans and Republican-leaners support Trump on many or all issues, up 11 percentage points since August.](image4)
However, Democrats overwhelmingly disapprove of Trump's conduct, with 85% disliking his behavior [1].
![Democrats overwhelmingly dislike Trump's conduct.](image5)

While Republicans have grown more confident in Trump's ability to handle international crises (84% now, 73% then) [2], views on his economic policy decisions show 53% expressing at least some confidence [3]. The public’s confidence in Trump to handle international crisis and economy has increased since January [8]. Public confidence in Trump's abilities has seen an increase over time, with a stark contrast between Republican agreement and Democratic disapproval of his conduct.

Public confidence in Trump's ability to handle an international crisis and make good decisions about economic policy has shown different levels and changes over time [6].
![The graph illustrates the public's confidence in Trump's ability to handle an international crisis and make good decisions about economic policy over time.](image3)
Specifically, public confidence in Trump to handle an international crisis has increased from $35\%$ in January to $43\%$ today, though it remains slightly lower than the $48\%$ recorded last April [5]. Republicans have grown significantly more confident in Trump to handle an international crisis since January, with $84\%$ expressing confidence now compared to $73\%$ then [9]. In contrast, public confidence in Trump’s handling of economic policy has also increased since January, with $53\%$ now expressing confidence compared to $46\%$ then [3]. These diverging trends suggest that while confidence in both areas has generally improved, the specific dynamics and levels of confidence differ between handling international crises and managing economic policy.
Public confidence in Trump’s ability to handle an international crisis is at $43\%$, while confidence in his handling of economic policy is at $53\%$, and both have increased since January [3, 5].

Democrats continue to overwhelmingly dislike the way Trump conducts himself, with 85% expressing this sentiment [2, 5].
Republicans are more divided, with just 38% liking his conduct and 45% having mixed feelings [3, 5].
Conservative Republicans are more likely to approve of Trump's conduct than moderate or liberal Republicans (44% to 25%, respectively) [6].
![The opinions of Republicans, Democrats, and the total population on whether they like, have mixed feelings about, or don't like Trump's conduct.](image1)
Views on Trump's ethical standards differ significantly along ideological lines within the Republican party [9].
Conservative Republicans are much less likely to view the ethical standards of Trump administration officials negatively compared to moderate and liberal Republicans [10].
![This image shows that there is a divergence of views among Republicans and Republican leaners based on ideology.](image2)
There has been an increase in agreement with Trump on policy issues among Republicans and Republican leaners, with 80% now agreeing on many or all issues, up from 69% in August [7].
![This image compares views among Republican/Lean Republican and Democrat/Lean Democrat regarding agreement with Trump from May 2018 and August 2017.](image3)

Overall, Democrats remain critical of Trump's conduct and ethical standards, while Republicans show a more divided opinion influenced by ideology, although agreement with Trump's policies has increased over time.

The ethical standards of Trump administration officials are rated lower than those of previous administrations, which correlates with public approval of Trump's job performance [1, 8, 9].  Only 39% of Americans rated the ethical standards of Trump administration officials as excellent or good, while 58% rated them as not good or poor [1, 9].

The public's assessment of Trump's handling of his presidential duties has remained relatively consistent, aligning with his initial ratings upon assuming office [2].  However, this approval is divided, with 42% of the public strongly disapproving of Trump's performance [4].
![Trump administration ethical standards are rated lower compared to past administrations.](image1)
As illustrated in image1, the ethical standards of the Trump administration officials are rated lower compared to past administrations [8].

These low marks for ethical standards also reflect in the significant differences in views of Trump by race, age, and education [10].  Younger adults, those with higher education levels, and non-whites are more inclined to disapprove of Trump's job performance [10].  Therefore, the ethical standards of Trump's administration are rated lower compared to those of previous administrations, correlating with public approval of Trump's job performance.

People with different educational levels have different perceptions of ethical standards. Among those with at least a college degree, 31% say “high ethical standards” does not describe either the GOP or the Democratic Party [6].  ![Those with a college degree are more likely to say that high ethical standards does not describe either party.](image4)

There are significant differences in views of Trump by education [8]. Younger adults, those with higher levels of education are more likely to disapprove of the job Trump is doing [8].
  
Political affiliations also play a role. Just 15% of conservative Republicans express negative views of the ethical standards of Trump administration officials, while about a third (36%) of moderate and liberal Republicans say they are not good or poor [4]. Independents also have a more negative view; two-thirds (65%) say the administration’s ethical standards are “not good” or “poor” [2].  ![Independents are more likely to disapprove of the Trump administration.](image3)

Educational levels and political affiliations influence perceptions of ethical standards and approval ratings.

In 2016, voters found the presidential campaign to be more negative compared to past elections [7]. Post-election evaluations of candidates, parties, the press, and pollsters were more negative than in elections dating back to 1988 [9].

Reactions to Trump's election were mixed. Half of voters were happy about Trump's election, while about as many were unhappy [5, 6].  Reactions were similar to 2012 when Obama was reelected but less positive than after Obama's first election in 2008 [5].  This is confirmed by the following figure:
![The graph shows that 50% of voters were happy Trump won the election in 2016, which is similar to 2012 when Obama was reelected.](image3)

Emotional reactions to Trump's election included hopefulness (51%) and pride (36%) [2]. However, many voters also felt uneasy about the election of Trump [2]. In fact, voters expressed feeling uneasy at 53%, which was the most prevalent emotion [2]. The following figure confirms these statistics:
![The graph shows that the majority of voters (53%) felt uneasy about the election of Trump.](image2)

A significant majority of voters (73%) were surprised by Trump's victory, including 87% of Clinton voters [10].
![The graph shows that 73% of all voters were surprised that Trump won the election.](image4)

In summary, the 2016 election saw more negative evaluations and a greater sense of surprise among voters, with mixed emotions including hopefulness, pride, and uneasiness prevailing after Trump's victory.

Trump voters were overwhelmingly positive about Trump's election, while Clinton voters were largely negative [1].

Emotional reactions to Trump's election significantly diverged between Trump and Clinton voters, as illustrated in ![Trump and Clinton voters feel differently about Trump's election](image5). Among Trump voters, $96\%$ felt hopeful, and $74\%$ felt proud [1]. In stark contrast, substantial majorities of Clinton voters reported feeling uneasy $(90\%)$, sad $(77\%)$, and scared $(76\%)$ [1]. Very few Clinton voters felt hopeful $(7\%)$ or proud $(1\%)$ [1].

Expectations for Trump's first term are also vastly different between the two groups of voters, illustrated in ![Voters have different expectations for Trump's first term](image4). Nearly all Trump voters $(88\%)$ expressed confidence in the type of president he would be [9]. On the other hand, views of Trump's first term among Clinton voters are broadly negative [10]. Only $15\%$ of Clinton supporters thought Trump's first term would be successful, while $76\%$ thought it would be unsuccessful [10].

In summary, emotional reactions to Trump's election were highly positive among Trump voters and overwhelmingly negative among Clinton voters, mirroring their divergent expectations for Trump's first term in office.

Trump voters are overwhelmingly confident in his success and much more inclined to give him a chance compared to Clinton voters, who generally hold negative views and are less willing to support him. 

Here's a breakdown:

*   **Overall Expectations**: 56% of voters felt that Trump would have a successful first term, while 39% thought he would be unsuccessful [9].
    ![56% of all voters say it’s more likely that Trump will have a successful first term, while 39% say it’s more likely that he’ll have an unsuccessful first term.](image4)
*   **Trump Voters' Confidence**: A large majority of Trump voters (97%) anticipated a successful first term for him [6].
    ![An overwhelming 97% of Trump voters expect him to have a successful first term.](image5)
*   **Clinton Voters' Skepticism**: Only 15% of Clinton supporters believed Trump's first term would be successful, with 76% anticipating it would be unsuccessful [4].
    ![Overall, just 15% of Clinton supporters think Trump’s first term will be successful, while 76% think it will be unsuccessful.](image5)
*   **Willingness to Give Trump a Chance**: While 58% of Clinton voters were willing to give Trump a chance, a substantial 39% were not because of the kind of person he had shown himself to be [1, 10].
    ![58% of Clinton voters say they’re “willing to give Trump a chance and see how he governs as president.](image3)
*   **Confidence in Trump's Presidency**: 88% of Trump voters were confident about the kind of president he would be, whereas Clinton voters expressed little to no confidence in Trump to address major issues [8, 10].
    ![88% of Trump voters say they are confident about the kind of president he will be.](image1)

Trump and Clinton voters have significantly different priorities for Trump's presidency, reflecting their contrasting views on his leadership and vision for the country.

Firstly, health care is a major priority for Trump voters. Nearly three-in-ten (29%) Trump voters name health care as Trump’s first priority as president [1].  This contrasts with Clinton voters, only 12% of whom say the same [1].
![Trump voters prioritize health care more than Clinton voters](image1)
This is further supported by the fact that Trump voters were more likely to mention repealing the Affordable Care Act, while Clinton voters were more likely to mention maintaining it, or fixing it [6].

Secondly, Clinton voters prioritize unifying the country and addressing divisions.  About a quarter (23%) of Clinton voters suggest that Trump should prioritize healing divisions [8]. Specifically, 12% say that Trump should prioritize unifying the country, while 11% want to see him change his personal behavior and address divisions he created during his campaign [8].  This is in comparison to the 5% of Trump voters who think unifying the country should be a priority, and the 1% who believe he should change his personal behavior and address divisions he has created ![Clinton voters prioritize unifying the country and addressing Trump's behavior more than Trump voters](image1).

Thirdly, there is a disparity in how well each group understands Trump's goals.  87% of Trump voters say they have a good idea of where Trump wants to lead the country [5].  Conversely, 84% of Clinton supporters say Trump’s goals are not very clear [5].
![Trump voters are more likely to understand Trump's goals than Clinton voters](image2)
This divide suggests that Trump's message resonated more clearly with his own voters, while Clinton voters are less certain about his direction [5].

These differences highlight the polarized views on Trump's leadership, with his voters prioritizing policy changes like healthcare reform and feeling confident in his vision, while Clinton voters focus on reconciliation and express uncertainty about his goals.

Trump and Clinton voters diverge significantly in their confidence in Trump's handling of foreign policy and their expectations for race relations post-election.
![Clinton voters express very little confidence that Trump will do the right thing regarding foreign policy.](image1)
While 47% of Trump voters have a great deal of confidence that he will do the right thing on foreign policy, only 6% of Clinton voters share this level of confidence [7].
![Most voters believe race relations will get worse or stay the same after Trump's election.](image3)
Furthermore, there is a stark contrast in expectations for race relations, as an overwhelming majority of Clinton voters (84%) believed Trump's election would lead to worse race relations, whereas half of Trump voters expected race relations to get better [5, 1].

In summary, Clinton voters have significantly less confidence in Trump's foreign policy decisions and overwhelmingly anticipate worsening race relations compared to Trump voters.

After Trump's election, voters held different opinions on whether he would improve race relations [9]. Half of Trump voters thought race relations would improve, but most Clinton voters believed they would worsen [5]. `![The image shows voters' opinions on whether race relations will improve, stay the same, or worsen under Trump and Obama.](image1)` The graphic illustrates that 50% of Trump voters believed race relations would improve, compared to only 2% of Clinton voters [9]. Most Clinton voters, 84%, anticipated that race relations would worsen [5].

Regarding political cooperation, Trump's supporters were less optimistic about improvements compared to Obama voters in 2008 [4]. While 47% of Trump voters expected improvements, 55% of Obama voters felt the same way in 2008 [4]. Clinton voters were more likely than McCain voters in 2008 to believe relations would worsen [4]. `![The image compares voters' expectations for partisan relations to improve, stay the same or worsen under Trump in 2016 and Obama in 2008.](image5)` Specifically, 43% of Clinton voters anticipated worsening relations, compared to 31% of McCain's voters in 2008 [4].

In summary, Trump voters were optimistic about improved race relations and political cooperation under his presidency, while Clinton voters were largely pessimistic.

After Trump's election, voters were generally pessimistic about race relations, with nearly half believing they would worsen [1]. Specifically, $46\%$ of all voters anticipated worse race relations under Trump, while only $25\%$ expected improvement [1, 3]. Conversely, views on partisan relations were more mixed; $27\%$ of voters thought relations between parties would improve, while an equal percentage thought they would worsen [8].

![Views on race relations after Trump's election are divided along party lines.](image4)

In comparison, after Obama's first victory in 2008, there was more optimism about partisan relations, with $37\%$ expecting improvement and only $18\%$ expecting them to worsen [10]. Trump's supporters were somewhat less optimistic about partisan relations than Obama voters were eight years prior [9]. ![Voters in 2016 are split on whether partisan relations will get better, stay the same, or get worse.](image5)

Regarding the implications of having enthusiastic supporters, a majority of all voters, $73\%$, believed that having strong supporters means less gets done [image3].

![Most voters think having enthusiastic supporters means less gets done.](image3)

Overall, voters were more pessimistic about race relations than partisan relations following Trump's election, and most believed that strong presidential support could hinder progress.

After the 2016 election, Democrats showed a notable shift towards more liberal stances, whereas Republicans largely maintained their conservative preference. Democrats are more divided over whether their party’s future should be more liberal $(49\%)$ or more moderate $(47\%)$ [9]. The share of Democratic voters who would like to see a more liberal stance is up significantly from recent years [9]. Two years ago, in the week after the midterm election, just $38\%$ wanted to see the party move to the left [9].
![The graph depicts that 49% of the democratic voters prefer the party to be more liberal and 47% prefer it to be more moderate.](image3)
By a wide margin, Republican and Republican-leaning voters continue to want to see the GOP head in a more conservative, rather than moderate, direction [4]. Today, $60\%$ say they want to see the party move in a conservative direction, while $36\%$ say they’d like to see more moderation [4].
![The graph shows that 60% of the Republican voters want the party to be more conservative, while 36% want it to be more moderate.](image2)
Voters have mixed reactions to the results of congressional elections [10]. About half $(52\%)$ of voters say they are happy that the Republican Party maintained control of the U.S. Congress, while $45\%$ say they are unhappy [10].
![This image illustrates that 52% of all voters are happy with the Republican Party maintaining control of the U.S. Congress, while 45% are unhappy.](image5)
In summary, Democratic voters have become more inclined towards a liberal direction, while Republican voters have largely remained conservative; reactions to the 2016 election outcomes highlight a partisan divide.

In 2016, Democrats were much less supportive of working with the new president compared to Republican support for working with President Obama in 2008 [8]. In November 2016, 65% of Democratic and Democratic-leaning voters believed that Democratic leaders should stand up to Donald Trump, even if it meant less would get done in Washington [4]. Only 32% wanted party leaders to work with Trump, even if it meant disappointing Democrats [4].  In contrast, nearly eight-in-ten (78%) of Obama's voters in 2008 wanted Democratic leaders to work with Republicans, even at the risk of disappointing their supporters [9].

Comparing the sentiments of voters towards political leaders working with newly elected presidents, it's evident that more Democrats in 2016 preferred their leaders to stand up to Trump, while in 2008, most of Obama's voters wanted their leaders to cooperate with Republicans.

![In 2016, Democratic voters largely preferred their leaders to stand up to Trump, while Republican voters were more inclined to have their leaders work with him.](image1)

Republican and Republican-leaning voters showed a preference for Trump to work with Democratic leaders in Congress (53%), while 39% wanted him to stand up to them [5]. In 2008, nearly six-in-ten (59%) Republicans and Republican leaners said GOP leaders should work with Obama, while 36% wanted them to "stand up" to the new president [10].  Republican voters in 2008 were more inclined to have their leaders work with Obama compared to the percentage of Republican voters in 2016 who wanted Trump to work with Democratic leaders.

Therefore, in 2016, there was a greater emphasis on political leaders standing firm against the newly elected president compared to the sentiment in 2008, especially among Democratic voters.

Voter perceptions of the 2016 election were quite negative, impacting views of candidates, parties, and campaign conduct. Voters viewed the 2016 presidential campaign as extraordinarily negative, with $92\%$ saying there was more "mudslinging" compared to past elections [7].
![Voters believed there was more mudslinging in the 2016 election.](image1)
This perception of increased negativity was a significant rise from previous elections [9].
![Average grades for political actors in the 2016 election were low.](image4)
Voters gave low grades to Donald Trump, the Republican and Democratic parties, the press, and pollsters, reflecting widespread dissatisfaction [5]. The negativity of the campaign may have contributed to these low grades, as voters were critical of how these entities conducted themselves [8]. Even voters themselves received low grades [4].

The 2016 election campaign was perceived negatively by voters, which correlated with the low grades given to political entities involved.

The emotional reactions to Donald Trump's 2016 election victory varied significantly between Trump and Clinton voters, with feelings of surprise, negativity, and mudslinging permeating the overall perception of the election [7, 1].

For Trump voters, the most frequent emotion was "happy," followed by "surprised," "relieved" and "hopeful" ![Trump voters were most frequently happy about Trump's victory](image3). In contrast, Clinton voters most frequently expressed being "shocked," "disappointed," and "disgusted," with others noting surprise or disbelief [8]. ![Clinton voters were most frequently shocked by Trump's victory](image3). The emotional divide is further highlighted by the fact that 96% of Trump voters felt hopeful, and 74% felt proud, while substantial majorities of Clinton voters felt uneasy (90%), sad (77%), and scared (76%) [6].

The overall emotional landscape of the election was largely negative, with 92% of voters saying there was more "mudslinging" than in past elections [7]. ![The graph shows the percentage of voters who say there was more mudslinging than in past elections](image1). This perception of increased mudslinging may have contributed to the negative emotions experienced by Clinton voters and the surprise felt by many voters regardless of their candidate preference [7, 1]. Furthermore, both the Republican and Democratic parties received low grades from voters for their conduct during the campaign, with about three-in-ten giving them an F [3]. ![This image shows the grades given to political figures by voters.](image4). This indicates a widespread dissatisfaction with the campaign's tone and tenor, which likely exacerbated the negative emotional reactions to the election outcome.

The emotional reactions of Trump and Clinton voters differed sharply, reflecting the surprise result and the perceived negativity of the campaign.

Trump's victory evoked starkly different emotional reactions from his supporters compared to Clinton's supporters, reflecting the unexpected nature of the outcome and their contrasting expectations [8].

For Trump voters, "happy" was the most frequently mentioned feeling, while many also expressed "surprise" or "shock" at the election results [8].  This is further illustrated in the image, showing other common positive emotions among Trump voters, such as "hopeful" and "proud", in contrast to negative emotions [8].
![Trump voters commonly felt hopeful, proud, and relieved about Trump's victory.](image1)

A significant $60\%$ of Trump voters reported being surprised by Trump's victory [3]. This suggests that even among his own supporters, there was a considerable level of uncertainty or disbelief about his chances of winning [3]. The image also shows a comparison of the surprises of all voters, Trump voters and Clinton voters.
![Most voters were surprised by Trump's victory, including 60% of Trump voters and 87% of Clinton voters.](image2)

In contrast, Clinton voters primarily expressed negative emotions such as "shocked," "disappointed," and "disgusted" [7]. Image3 lists the common emotions of Trump voters and Clinton voters.
![Clinton voters commonly felt shocked, disappointed, and disgusted about Trump's victory.](image3)

The prevalence of surprise among both Trump and Clinton voters, along with the contrasting positive and negative emotions, highlights the unexpected nature of Trump's victory and the significant divergence in emotional responses between the two groups of supporters. The election outcome was a surprise for most voters [3].

Following Trump's victory, there are notable differences and shared sentiments among Trump and Clinton voters regarding the election outcome and future expectations.  A significant majority of voters, including both Trump and Clinton supporters, anticipate a female president in their lifetime [1].

However, reactions to Trump's victory varied sharply, as shown in this image `![This image illustrates that Trump voters felt mostly happy when summarizing their feelings about Trump’s victory while Clinton voters felt mostly shocked.](image4)`.

Trump voters were predominantly "happy," while Clinton voters often expressed "surprise" or "shock" [2]. Overall, 73% of all voters were surprised by Trump's victory, including 87% of Clinton voters and a 60% majority of Trump voters [5].
![The distribution of voter surprise regarding Trump's election win is displayed in this graph.](image1)

Despite the surprise, confidence in the accuracy of the vote count was similar between Trump (47%) and Clinton (44%) voters [6]. Most Trump voters (97%) reported happiness with his win, while 93% of Clinton voters expressed unhappiness [7]. Although unhappiness is common among voters of the losing candidate, it was less pronounced in 2008 when Obama won [7]. The sentiment towards Trump's victory was also more divided compared to Obama's election, as seen in this image `![This graph compares the percentage of voters happy with the election outcome across multiple presidential elections.](image5)`.

The sentiments of voters towards Trump's victory were strongly divided, with most voters overall being surprised, but a large majority still expect a female president in their lifetime.

Since the September 2001 terrorist attacks, Americans' ratings of the government’s efforts to reduce the threat of terrorism are now lower, with more people saying the government is doing not too well or not at all well [2]. Assessments of government efforts to combat terrorism are more negative across the political spectrum compared to early 2015 [3].

**Political Affiliation**

Republicans and Democrats have become more likely to say that the government’s anti-terrorism policies do not go far enough to protect the country since Snowden’s disclosures in 2013 [4].
![Republicans' concern that anti-terrorism policies don't go far enough has increased significantly since 2013.](image1)
**Age Group**

Older Americans are more likely than younger Americans to give the government low marks for reducing the threat of terrorism [9]. A majority of those 50 and older say the government is not doing well, while younger adults are more divided in their assessment [6].
![Older age groups express more concern that policies haven't gone far enough to protect the U.S.](image2)

In summary, public perception of government efforts against terrorism has declined, with Republicans and older Americans expressing increased concern that policies do not go far enough.

Older and less educated Americans tend to give the government lower ratings for their efforts in reducing the threat of terrorism [2, 6].

Evaluations of the government’s job reducing the threat of terrorism are more positive among those with a postgraduate degree than among other educational groups [9].
![Government performance is rated more positively by those with postgraduate degrees.](image3)
The image shows that 58% of individuals with postgraduate degrees rate the government's performance as very or fairly well, compared to 40% who rate it negatively [image3].

Furthermore, partisan affiliation also plays a significant role. Assessments of government efforts to combat terrorism have become more negative across the political spectrum compared to early 2015 [7].  Democrats are now the only partisan group in which a majority (64\%) say the government is doing at least fairly well, a decrease from 85\% in January [7]. Independents' positive ratings have dropped significantly, and Republicans' positive ratings have also decreased substantially [7].
![Republican, Democrat, and Independent opinions on government performance between 2001 and 2015.](image1)
The graph illustrates the change in approval ratings across political affiliations, highlighting the shift in Republican sentiment towards government efforts from the Bush to Obama administrations [image1]. For example,  $27\%$  of Republicans now say the government is doing very or fairly well reducing the terrorist threat, down from  $63\%$  at the beginning of the year [7].

Perceptions of government efforts to reduce the terrorist threat are influenced by age, education, and political ideology, with older, less educated individuals and Republicans expressing more negative views.

Older Americans are more critical of the government's performance in reducing the threat of terrorism compared to younger Americans [2]. According to the text,  $57\%$ of those 50 and older think the government is not doing well, while $46\%$ of younger adults (18-29 years old) share this negative view [4].

Evaluations of the government’s job reducing  the threat of terrorism are more positive among  and those with a postgraduate degree than  among other educational groups [5].
![Percentage of those who believe anti-terrorism policies have not gone far enough to protect the country is highest for those 65 and older.](image5)
As shown in the image, concern that anti-terrorism policies have not gone far enough increases with age [10].  A majority of those 65 and older express greater concern that policies have not gone far enough to protect the country [10].  Adults under 30 are split between concerns that U.S. policies place too many restrictions on civil  liberties and that they do not go far  enough to protect the country [10].

In 2015, older Americans are more critical of the government's performance in reducing terrorism and are more concerned that anti-terror policies haven't gone far enough, while younger adults are more divided on both issues.

Since July 2013, concern over government restrictions on civil liberties has decreased significantly [2].

The concern that anti-terrorism policies have not gone far enough to adequately protect the country is more pronounced among older individuals, with 71% of those 65 and older expressing this concern, compared to 52% of those aged 30-49 [8]. Adults under 30 are split, with 43% concerned about excessive restrictions on civil liberties and 44% worried that policies are insufficient [8]. ![Adults 65 and older are more concerned about security than civil liberties.](image4)

Both Republicans and Democrats have shifted towards believing that anti-terrorism policies do not go far enough [4]. This shift is more noticeable among Republicans [4]. Today, conservative Republicans (71%), moderate and liberal Republicans (74%), and conservative and moderate Democrats (67%) share the view that anti-terrorism policies have not gone far enough [7]. ![Republicans have shifted towards believing that anti-terrorism policies do not go far enough.](image3)

Americans are now more concerned that government anti-terror policies have not gone far enough to protect the country, with public concerns about restrictions on civil liberties at their lowest level in five years [1].

Americans' opinions on government anti-terrorism efforts reveal a growing concern for stronger protective policies across age groups and political affiliations, with older individuals and Republicans showing more pronounced concerns that policies do not go far enough.

Public perception of the U.S. military campaign against ISIS remains negative overall, but views on its potential success have improved [1].

**Views of the U.S. Campaign Against ISIS**

![Views of the U.S. campaign against ISIS in December 2015 indicate that more people think it is not going well.](image4)

About six-in-ten (58\%) say the U.S. effort against Islamic militants in Iraq and Syria is going either not too well (39\%) or not at all well (19\%); 35\% say the campaign is going either very (7\%) or fairly (28\%) well [4]. This negative assessment has been consistent over the past year [4]. However, there's a more positive outlook on whether the U.S. and its allies will succeed [7]. Two-thirds (66\%) now believe they will either definitely or probably succeed, up 11 points from July (from 55\%) [9]. The recent attacks in Paris and San Bernardino have not fundamentally altered public views on the campaign [8].

**Approval of U.S. Military Campaign Against ISIS**

![The graph indicates a consistent approval rate for the U.S. military campaign against ISIS throughout 2015.](image2)

Overall, a 64\%-majority continues to approve of the U.S. military campaign against Islamic militants in Iraq and Syria, while just 28\% say they disapprove [6]. Support for the U.S. military effort has been steady over the course of 2015 [6].

**Partisan Divides in Assessments**

![The bar graph illustrates that Republicans are more likely than Democrats to view ISIS as a major threat.](image1)

There are wide partisan divides in current assessments of the campaign against ISIS, but more modest ones in predictions of its ultimate success [2].  45\% of Democrats, compared with 33\% of independents and just 26\% of Republicans say the campaign is going at least fairly well [2]. Six-in-ten or more Republicans (65\%), Democrats (72\%) and independents (62\%) say it will ultimately be successful [2]. Three-quarters of Republicans (75\%) say their greater concern about military action in Iraq and Syria is that the U.S. will not go far enough in stopping the Islamic militants, while just 18\% say their greater concern is that the U.S. will become too involved [10].

**Concerns About U.S. Military Action**

![The bar graph shows the percentage of Americans who think the U.S. will not go far enough in stopping ISIS.](image3)

Slightly more now say their greater concern about U.S. military action in Iraq and Syria is that the U.S. will not go far enough in stopping the militants (50\%) than go too far getting involved [5].

Public perception of the U.S. military campaign against ISIS has largely remained negative, though optimism about its ultimate success has grown, with noticeable partisan divisions in how the campaign is currently assessed.

The perception of Islam's encouragement of violence varies significantly among different political affiliations, with Republicans being more likely to associate Islam with violence compared to Democrats; these perceptions also influence views on the government's handling of terrorism.

Assessments of government efforts to combat terrorism have become more negative across the political spectrum, with Democrats being the only partisan group in which a majority ($64\%$) say the government is doing at least fairly well [6]. Conservative Republicans are more inclined to believe that Muslims in the U.S. should be subjected to greater scrutiny compared to other religious groups [2]. .![The bar graph shows that the terrorist threat is a more significant concern for the Republican Party compared to the Democratic Party.](image5)

The perception of Islam encouraging violence varies among different political affiliations and has shifted over time, as have public opinions on which party is better at handling terrorism.

The partisan divide regarding the perception of Islam encouraging violence is significant, with Republicans more likely to view Islam as encouraging violence compared to Democrats [8].  In December 2015, 68% of Republicans believed Islam encourages violence more than other religions, a figure that has remained relatively stable since the fall of 2014, while only 30% of Democrats shared this view, a decrease from 42% in September 2014 [8]. Independents are split on this issue, with 45% believing Islam is more likely to encourage violence [9].
![The graph shows the shifting views on Islam encouraging violence among Republicans, Independents, and Democrats from 2002 to 2015.](image2)
The graph illustrates these trends over time, showing the divergence in views between Republicans and Democrats regarding whether Islam encourages violence [image2].

Ideological divides also contribute to differing perceptions, with 77% of conservative Republicans believing Islam is more likely to encourage violence, while 73% of liberal Democrats believe it is not [7].  The share of liberals saying Islam is more likely to encourage violence has decreased by 14 points since 2014 [2].  Similarly, the overall public perception of Islam encouraging violence has decreased slightly, from 50% in September 2014 to 46% [5].
![The bar graph shows public opinion on which party can better handle terrorist threats, with Republicans at 46% and Democrats at 34%.](image3)
Regarding handling terrorism, the Republican Party is generally perceived as being more capable than the Democratic Party, with 46% of the public believing the Republican Party can better handle terrorist threats at home, compared to 34% who favor the Democrats [6].  This perception of party competence in handling terrorism does not directly correlate with the shifting views on Islam encouraging violence; however, it suggests that public confidence in a party's ability to address terrorism may influence opinions on related issues [image3].

In summary, perceptions of Islam encouraging violence have diverged along political lines, particularly between Republicans and Democrats, while overall public perception has slightly decreased, and the Republican Party is generally seen as more capable of handling terrorism.

Independents hold views that often differ from those of Democrats and Republicans, particularly on issues of government size, regulation, and economic fairness.

The image shows a comparison of the views on government regulation of business across different political affiliations. ![The image illustrates the division of views on government regulation of business among Republicans, Democrats, Independents, and those who lean towards either party.](image1)
Most independents who do not lean toward a party share the view that the U.S. economic system unfairly favors powerful interests (70%) [3].  A  $63\%$  majority of those who identify as Republicans say the  U.S. economic system is fair to most Americans [6].  Large majorities of both Democrats $(85\%)$ and Democratic  leaners $(81\%)$ say the U.S. economic system unfairly favors  powerful interests [3].
The image illustrates the division of views on economic fairness among Republicans, Democrats, Independents, and those who lean towards either party. ![The image shows how republicans think the U.S. economic system is generally fair to most Americans.](image4)

In summary, independents' views on government regulation and economic fairness are more divided compared to the more uniform views held by Democrats and Republicans.

Over time, unfavorable views of both parties among independents have fluctuated, with differences seen among subgroups.
The share of independents who view both parties negatively has generally decreased in recent years [9]. At one point in 2015, more than a third of independents (36%) viewed both parties unfavorably [9].
![The chart shows the trend of independents with favorable or unfavorable views towards both parties.](image1)
The provided chart illustrates trends in independents' views toward both parties, highlighting those who are favorable to one party but unfavorable to the other, favorable to both parties, and unfavorable to both parties.
![The chart shows the percentage of the favorable and unfavorable opinions towards both parties among Republicans, Democrats, and Independents.](image3)
Among independents who do not lean to a party, a significant percentage holds unfavorable opinions of both parties [2, 8]; specifically, 37% have an unfavorable opinion of both parties [2]. However, this group also includes individuals with favorable opinions of both parties (22%) [2]. In contrast, independents who lean towards a party are more likely to have a favorable opinion of their own party and an unfavorable opinion of the opposing party [10].
Overall, intense dislike of the opposing party has increased among independents who lean toward either the Republican or Democratic parties [7, 6].
Independent subgroups differ with those who lean toward a party generally mirroring the views of those who identify with that party [4, 5, 10].

Over the past two decades, negative views of the opposing party have risen among Republicans, Democrats, and independents who lean toward a party [8]. The share of Democratic-leaning independents with a very unfavorable view of the Republican Party quadrupled from 8% in 1994 to 37% in 2018 [2].  Similarly, unfavorable views among Republican leaners toward the Democratic Party increased from 15% in 1994 to 39% in 2018 [2].  ![The graph illustrates how unfavorable opinions of the Republican and Democratic parties have changed from 1994 to 2018.](image4)
Currently, 87% of Republicans view the Democratic Party unfavorably, while 81% of Republican-leaning independents share this view [3].  Among Democrats, 88% view the GOP unfavorably, and 84% of Democratic leaners agree [3]. These figures are near all-time highs for both parties [3].
However, the percentage of independents with unfavorable views of both parties has declined in recent years [9]. While 36% of independents viewed both parties unfavorably in 2015, this number has decreased [9].  Independents who do not lean to either party are most likely to have an unfavorable opinion of both parties (37%) [6]. Another 22% have favorable opinions of both parties [6].  Just 11% of these independents view the Democratic Party favorably, and 9% have a favorable view of the GOP [6].  ![This image shows the percentages of people with various political affiliations who are favorable to both parties, favorable to one party and unfavorable to the other, and unfavorable to both.](image1)
In summary, while intense dislike of the opposing party has grown among partisans and leaners over the past two decades, independents who do not lean toward a party are more likely to hold unfavorable views of both parties, though this has decreased in recent years.

Republicans are more critical of China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak compared to Democrats [4]. Republicans are also more inclined to hold China accountable, even if it harms economic relations [4].

Republicans hold more negative views and are more critical of China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak compared to Democrats, and are more willing to prioritize holding China accountable, even if it harms U.S.-China relations.

Political affiliations significantly impact how Americans perceive the U.S.'s and China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic, with Republicans generally more positive about the U.S. and critical of China compared to Democrats.

In summary, political affiliation and education level significantly shape perspectives on how the pandemic will affect the future international influence of the U.S. and China.

After the coronavirus outbreak, expectations for the global influence of the U.S. and China varied significantly among different demographic and political groups. Clear partisan gaps emerged regarding the U.S.'s international influence, as Republicans were about twice as likely as Democrats to believe the U.S.'s influence would be strengthened, while Democrats were four times more likely to expect it to weaken [1].

Views on China's global influence also showed partisan divides, with roughly 60% of Republicans believing China's international clout would diminish, compared to just 40% of Democrats [4].  Age also played a role, as older Americans were more inclined to predict a decline in China's global influence [4].  ![Older Americans are more likely to say that China will have less influence.](image4)

Education levels also correlated with opinions on America's international role, as Americans with higher education were more likely to anticipate a decline in the country’s global influence [9].  ![Those with postgraduate degrees were most likely to say that the U.S. will have less influence.](image1)

Overall, while opinions varied, a significant portion of Americans believed that China's global stature would diminish after the pandemic [10].  ![Half of Americans believe China will have less influence.](image2)

Predictions about the global influence of the U.S. and China after the coronavirus outbreak were divided along political, age, and educational lines.

Most Americans believe that China has not done a good job dealing with the coronavirus outbreak [3]. According to the survey, nearly two-thirds of Americans hold this view [3].
![Americans say China has not done a good job dealing with the coronavirus outbreak.](image5)
Looking ahead, many believe the current crisis will have a long-term impact on China’s global stature:   $50\%$  say China will have less influence in world affairs after the pandemic [9]. As shown in image3, the influence of China will decrease after the pandemic according to 50% of Americans.
![Half of Americans believe China will have less influence after the pandemic.](image3)
There are significant partisan differences on this question, with Republicans expressing significantly more negative attitudes than Democrats [4]. For instance, six-in-ten Republicans believe China’s international clout will diminish as a result of the coronavirus outbreak, while just  $40\%$  of Democrats say the same [5].
![Republicans hold significantly more negative attitudes towards China.](image4)
In conclusion, most Americans perceive China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak negatively and anticipate a decrease in its global influence, with significant partisan divides in these perceptions.

Partisan views on the U.S.’s role in addressing global challenges have significantly diverged from 2013 to 2020 [5].
**International Engagement:**
Clear partisan gaps emerge regarding America's international influence, where Republicans are more inclined to believe the U.S.'s influence will strengthen, while Democrats anticipate a weakening [10].  The partisan gap in these views was far more modest in Pew Research Center telephone surveys dating back to 2013 [5].
**Helping Other Countries:**
Republicans are about twice as likely as Democrats to believe the U.S.’s international influence will be strengthened as a result of the crisis [10].
**Coronavirus Impact Assessment**
![Democrats are more likely than Republicans to think the U.S. will have less influence in world affairs after the coronavirus outbreak.](image2)
There are stark partisan and ideological differences in views about the coronavirus outbreak and its international implications [6]. Liberal Democrats are far more likely to have a bleak assessment of how the pandemic will affect America’s standing on the global stage [7].

In summary, partisan divides have widened between 2013 and 2020, with Republicans increasingly believing the U.S. does too much to address global challenges and anticipating strengthened international influence post-coronavirus, while Democrats hold contrasting views.

There are clear partisan divisions in how Americans view the U.S.'s ability to learn from other countries regarding the coronavirus and its role in global affairs [6]. Most Americans believe the U.S. can learn from other countries about slowing the spread of the coronavirus [3, 5]. However, this belief is more prevalent among Democrats than Republicans [8].

For example, while $60\%$ of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents think the U.S. can learn a great deal, only $28\%$ of Republicans and Republican leaners agree [8].  ![Democrats are more likely than Republicans to believe that the U.S. can learn a great deal from other countries about slowing the spread of the coronavirus.](image1)

There is also a partisan split on assessing the U.S.'s handling of the coronavirus outbreak, with liberal Democrats having a more negative view [6].  ![The proportion of liberal Democrats who think the U.S. has done a fair/poor job dealing with the outbreak is higher than the proportion of conservative Republicans.](image5) Additionally, liberal Democrats are more likely to believe that the U.S. will have less influence in world affairs due to the pandemic [6].

Partisan views differ on the U.S.'s ability to learn from other countries and its role in global affairs during the coronavirus pandemic, with Democrats generally being more open to learning from other countries and more critical of the U.S.'s handling of the pandemic and its future global influence.

Americans are divided on whether the U.S. should focus on its own problems or help other countries, with significant differences based on political affiliation and education levels [2].
![Views on US helping other countries differ based on political affiliation and ideology.]()

Republicans tend to believe the U.S. should focus on its own problems, while Democrats are more inclined to support helping other countries [4, 6].
![Views on US helping other countries differ based on education level.]()
Specifically, "About three-quarters of Republicans want the  U.S. to deal with its own problems and let other  countries manage as best they can" [6].  In contrast, more than half of Democrats believe the U.S. should assist other countries [4].  This divide is further accentuated by ideology within the Democratic party, where "64% of liberal Democrats say the U.S. should help other countries deal with their problems, compared with 44% of conservative and moderate Democrats" [4].  

Higher education levels correlate with greater support for the U.S. helping other countries [9].  "Six-in-ten postgraduates say  the U.S. should help other countries deal with their problems," while "clear majorities of those with some college experience and those with no  more than a high school diploma say the U.S. should deal with its own problems" [9].

In summary, views on whether the U.S. should address its own problems versus helping other countries differ significantly based on political affiliation and education level, with Republicans and those with lower education levels favoring a focus on domestic issues, while Democrats and those with higher education levels are more supportive of international assistance.

Evaluations of the U.S.’s role in solving world problems vary significantly depending on political affiliation [3]. Republicans generally believe the U.S. is doing too much, while Democrats tend to think it's doing too little [3].   Specifically, a majority of Republicans (62\%) think the U.S. does too much, compared to only 8\% who think it does too little [3].  Conversely, a plurality of Democrats (48\%) say the U.S. does too little [3].

![Democrats are more likely to believe that the U.S. should deal with their problems, while Republicans are more likely to believe that the U.S. should deal with other countries' problems.](image2)

Over time, these partisan views have become more pronounced.  In previous years, the partisan divide on these views was far less significant than it is today [6].  Currently, about three-quarters of Republicans want the U.S. to focus on its own problems [8].  Democrats are divided by ideology, with 64\% of liberal Democrats saying the U.S. should help other countries compared to 44\% of conservative and moderate Democrats [7].

![In 2020, the percentage of Republicans who said the U.S. does too much to help with world problems was higher than in previous years.](image3)

These diverging views reflect a broader trend where political affiliation increasingly shapes opinions on international engagement.
The perceptions of the U.S. role in solving world problems differ sharply by political affiliation, with Republicans favoring less involvement and Democrats advocating for more, and this divide has grown over time.

Republicans and Democrats have diverging views on global engagement, with a majority of Republicans believing the U.S. does too much to address global challenges [1]. Specifically, "About six-in-ten Republicans (62%) now think the U.S. does too much in helping address global challenges, while just 26% of Democrats share this view" [1].
![Republicans increasingly believe the U.S. is doing too much to solve world problems.](image4)
This contrasts sharply with Democrats, a plurality of whom believe the U.S. does too little to solve world problems [3]. As the graph illustrates, a majority of Republicans think the U.S. does too much, while a minority of Democrats agree.

Regarding domestic issues, opinions on the U.S.'s handling of the coronavirus outbreak are also heavily divided along party lines [2]. Evaluations of the U.S.'s performance in handling the coronavirus outbreak are significantly influenced by political ideology [2].
![The image shows that political affiliation greatly impacts how individuals view the US's response to the coronavirus outbreak.](image2)
While a large percentage of Democrats are critical of the U.S.'s response, similar percentages of Republicans praise the country's handling of the outbreak [2].
