Educational attainment also influences views on global engagement.
![The image shows that support for US involvement in international problem-solving increases with higher education levels.](image1)
"Those with higher levels of education are more supportive of helping other nations deal with their problems" [6]. The image illustrates that individuals with postgraduate degrees are more inclined to support the U.S. helping other countries compared to those with only a high school diploma [6].

In summary, political affiliation and educational attainment significantly shape opinions on U.S. global engagement and the handling of domestic issues, with Republicans and those with less education favoring a more inward-focused approach.

Americans have less confidence in Biden to deal with China than on other foreign policy issues [1, 7]. Only around half of Americans are confident in Biden's ability to deal effectively with China (53%) [2]. However, many Americans consider issues in the U.S.-China relationship to be very serious [10].

Americans express substantial concern regarding specific issues in the U.S.-China relationship, with about three-quarters or more saying that each issue is at least somewhat serious [10]. Issues such as cyber attacks from China, the loss of U.S. jobs to China, China’s growing military power, and China’s policies on human rights are considered very serious by half or more of Americans [10]. ![The chart displays that issues like cyberattacks, military power, trade deficits, job losses, and human rights concerns related to China are considered very or somewhat serious by a significant percentage of Americans.](image4)

While confidence in Biden's ability to handle China is at 53%, a higher percentage of Americans view specific issues related to China as very serious, for example, 65% of American view cyberattacks from China as very serious [2]. This disparity suggests that even though Americans may have reservations about Biden's handling of China, they still recognize the gravity of the issues involved. ![This image illustrates that confidence in Biden's ability to deal with China is the lowest among six tested foreign policy issues.](image1)

In summary, Americans' confidence in Biden's ability to handle China is relatively lower compared to their perception of the seriousness of issues like cyberattacks and military power related to China.

Confidence levels in Biden's ability to handle China vary significantly across demographic groups, and Americans hold substantial concerns regarding various aspects of the U.S.-China relationship.

Americans have less faith in Biden to deal with China  than on other foreign policy issues [9]. Americans express substantial concern when asked about eight specific issues in the U.S.- China relationship [5].

![Americans have the least confidence in Biden on dealing effectively with China compared to other issues.](image5)

Partisan affiliation plays a large role, with only 19% of Republicans and Republican leaners expressing confidence in Biden on China, compared to 83% of Democrats and Democratic leaners [3].  Conservative Republicans show even less confidence (10%) than moderate or liberal Republicans (30%) [3].

![Confidence in Biden's ability to deal with China varies significantly across different demographic groups.](image2)

Older Americans express more concern about China-related issues compared to younger adults [4]. Specifically, Americans ages 65 and older are at least 20 points more likely than those ages 18 to 29 to say that most issues asked about in the survey are very serious problems [4].

![Cyberattacks from China are considered the most serious problem by Americans.](image3)

The primary concerns include cyber attacks from China, the loss of U.S. jobs to China, China’s growing military power, and China’s policies on human rights [5]. About three-quarters or more say that each issue is at least somewhat serious [5]. Limiting the power and influence of China is a priority for both Republicans and Democrats, however, it is a higher priority for Republicans.

In summary, confidence in Biden regarding China varies widely across political, gender, racial, educational, and age demographics, while key concerns revolve around cyber security, job losses, military strength, and human rights.

Confidence in President Biden's ability to handle China is significantly divided along demographic and political lines [3, 4].
![Confidence in Biden's ability to deal with China is higher among women, Black adults and Hispanic adults.](image3)
Women are more confident than men (59% vs. 48%), and Black and Hispanic adults express more confidence than White adults (82% and 70% vs. 43%) [6]. Also, confidence is higher among those with a college degree compared to those with less schooling (60% vs. 50%) [6].  Partisan divisions are substantial, with 83% of Democrats having confidence in Biden, compared to only 19% of Republicans [4, 8].
![Republicans show less confidence in Biden’s ability to deal with China.](image1)
Conservative Republicans have even less confidence (10%) than moderate or liberal Republicans (30%) [4].

When it comes to specific concerns about the U.S.-China relationship, several issues stand out.
![Cyberattacks from China are considered very serious.](image4)
Cyber attacks from China, the loss of U.S. jobs to China, China's growing military power, and China's policies on human rights are considered very serious problems by half or more of Americans [5].  The share who see the loss of U.S. jobs to China as a very serious problem has increased since 2020 [7]. Nine-in-ten Americans believe that China does not respect the personal freedoms of its people [9].

In summary, confidence in Biden's ability to deal with China varies widely based on gender, race, education, and political affiliation, while major concerns regarding the U.S.-China relationship include cyber attacks, job losses, military power, and human rights issues.

Confidence in Biden's ability to handle China differs significantly across political affiliations and demographic groups. Only 19% of Republicans have confidence in Biden on China, compared to 83% of Democrats [3]. Conservative Republicans have even less confidence (10%) than moderate or liberal Republicans (30%) [3]. ![Republicans generally have less confidence in Biden to deal effectively with China.](image1)
Older Americans express more concern about China-related issues, with those aged 65 and older being at least 20 points more likely to see issues as very serious problems compared to those aged 18 to 29 [6].

Major concerns Americans have regarding China include cyber attacks, loss of U.S. jobs, China's growing military power, and human rights policies [10]. ![Cyber attacks from China are seen as the most serious problem.](image2) Cyber attacks from China evoke the most concern, with roughly two-thirds considering them a very serious problem [7]. The share who see the loss of U.S. jobs to China as a very serious problem has increased to 53% [8].
Americans' confidence in Biden's ability to deal with China varies greatly across political and demographic groups, and their primary concerns revolve around cyber attacks, job losses, military power, and human rights.

Americans hold critical views regarding China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic and its respect for personal freedoms. More than half of Americans believe China has done a bad job dealing with the COVID-19 outbreak [7]. ![Over half of Americans think China did a bad job handling COVID-19, similar to views on the U.S.'s response.](image2) Regarding personal freedoms, the vast majority of Americans, fully 90%, think the Chinese government does not respect the personal freedoms of its people [6]. ![90% of Americans believe China does not respect personal freedoms.](image1)

When it comes to priorities in the U.S.-China relationship, Americans are more inclined to prioritize human rights over economic relations.  Seventy percent of Americans say that the U.S. should promote human rights, even if it harms economic relations [See image1].
Specifically, 54% consider China's policies on human rights a very serious problem for the U.S. [5].
In conclusion, Americans view China negatively on both its handling of the COVID-19 pandemic and its respect for personal freedoms, and they prioritize human rights over economic benefits in the U.S.-China relationship.

Americans generally prioritize human rights over economic ties with China, but this view varies among different political affiliations [3]. The image displays that 70% of Americans believe that the U.S. should promote human rights in China, even if it harms economic relations ![70% of Americans prioritize promoting human rights in China, even if it harms economic relations](image4). This sentiment is particularly strong among conservative Republicans and liberal Democrats [5, 6]. Image3 shows the comparison among political affiliations on prioritizing human rights versus economic relations with China ![Conservative Republicans and liberal Democrats prioritize human rights over economic ties with China](image3). About seven-in-ten Democrats and Republicans agree that the U.S. should prioritize human rights, even if it harms economic relations [6]. According to Image3, approximately 72% of Republicans/Lean Republicans prioritize human rights, with conservatives at 77%; and approximately 69% of Democrats/Lean Democrats prioritize human rights, with liberals at 76% ![Conservative Republicans and liberal Democrats prioritize human rights over economic ties with China](image3). While there's broad agreement, conservative Republicans are more inclined to prioritize human rights compared to moderate or liberal Republicans. Similarly, liberal Democrats are more likely to prioritize human rights compared to conservative or moderate Democrats [6].

Different political affiliations in the U.S. show varied perceptions on the balance between promoting human rights and economic relations with China, with a general preference for human rights, especially among conservative Republicans and liberal Democrats.

Americans generally prioritize promoting human rights in China over strengthening economic relations, although there are differences based on political affiliation [7]. According to the text, $70\%$ of Americans believe that the U.S. should prioritize promoting human rights in China, even if it harms economic relations [7].

![The image shows that 70% of the total respondents believe that it is more important to promote human rights in China even if it harms economic relations with China.](image1)

According to the text, both Democrats and Republicans largely agree on prioritizing human rights over economic relations [10]. Image1 shows that approximately seven-in-ten Democrats and Republicans agree that the U.S. should promote human rights in China, even at the expense of economic ties [10].

![The image shows the percentage of people who want the U.S. to get tougher or build a strong relationship with China, broken down by political affiliation, race, age, education, and political leaning.](image5)

According to the text, Republicans are more inclined to favor getting tougher with China on trade issues [6]. The text also indicates a divide among Democrats, with most favoring stronger ties with China [6]. Conservative Republicans are more likely to want the U.S. to get tougher on China compared to moderate or liberal Republicans [6]. Image5 shows that $72\%$ of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents want the U.S. to get tougher with China [6]. This contrast highlights that while a majority across party lines support prioritizing human rights, views on trade toughness are more divided along political lines.

In summary, while a significant majority of Americans across both parties prioritize human rights in China over economic benefits, Republicans are more inclined to favor a tougher stance on trade with China, while Democrats are more likely to prefer building stronger economic ties.

There are significant partisan differences in how Americans view the impact of trade policies with China [2]. Republicans are more inclined to see increased tariffs as beneficial, with about half holding this view, especially among conservative Republicans [2]. Democrats, conversely, generally believe the tariffs were detrimental to the U.S [2].

Views on whether to get tougher with China also diverge along party lines.
![The graph displays the percentage of individuals favoring a tougher stance on China versus building a stronger relationship, broken down by political affiliation.](image3)
A substantial majority of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents favor a tougher stance on China [1].  Specifically, $72\%$ of Republicans and $81\%$ of conservative Republicans prefer the U.S. to get tougher [1]. In contrast, about six-in-ten Democrats and Democrat-leaning independents prefer building stronger ties [1].

These differences reflect a broader sentiment, where $64\%$ of Americans believe current economic relations between the U.S. and China are bad [6]. Republicans are more likely to view tariffs as good for the U.S., while Democrats see them as harmful, aligning with their preference for either getting tougher or building stronger relationships with China, respectively [2, 1].

Political affiliations strongly influence opinions on trade policies with China, with Republicans favoring a tougher stance and viewing tariffs more positively, while Democrats prefer stronger relationships and see tariffs as detrimental.

Republicans and Democrats diverge on the impacts of tariffs and international students, with Republicans viewing tariffs more favorably and Democrats more positively towards international students [1, 2].
![Republicans are more likely to view tariffs as good for the U.S. compared to Democrats.](image3)
Republicans are more inclined to view tariffs on foreign goods as beneficial for the U.S., particularly conservative Republicans [1, 10]. In contrast, Democrats generally believe that tariffs are detrimental to the U.S [10].  
![Democrats are more likely to view international students as an asset to U.S. colleges and universities compared to Republicans.](image1)
Democrats are also more likely to see international students as beneficial to U.S. colleges and universities, with $92\%$ holding this view compared to $67\%$ of Republicans [2].

In summary, Republicans are more supportive of tariffs, while Democrats have a more favorable view of international students in the U.S.

Older Americans are more inclined to support limitations on Chinese students studying in the U.S., and Republicans are more likely than Democrats to favor these limitations [3]. Specifically, approximately seven-in-ten Americans ages 50 and older favor limiting Chinese students, while those ages 30 to 49 are evenly split, and nearly two-thirds of Americans 18 to 29 oppose such limitations [3]. The image shows a breakdown of support for limiting Chinese students across different demographics. ![Support for limiting Chinese students varies across age groups and political affiliations.](image4)

Republicans are significantly more likely to advocate for a tougher stance on China regarding economic issues and view China as an enemy rather than a competitor or partner [1]. This aligns with the sentiment that "we rely TOO MUCH on goods from China," and there's a concern that China is trying to dominate the world [2]. Republicans are also more likely to support limiting the ability of Chinese students to study in the U.S [1].

Older Americans are more likely to express a lack of confidence in the Chinese president [10]. While 53% of those 65 and older say they have no confidence at all in Xi, only 35% of those 18 to 29 say the same [10]. The image shows that 57% of Republicans/Lean Republicans and 65% of Conservatives express no confidence in Xi at all, compared to 33% of Democrats/Lean Democrats [1]. ![The older and more conservative a person is, the more likely they are to have no confidence in Xi Jinping.](image1)

Opinions on limiting Chinese students in U.S. universities and confidence in Chinese leadership vary significantly across age and political affiliation, with older and more conservative Americans favoring limitations and expressing less confidence.

From 2018 to 2021, American perceptions of China have largely turned negative, influenced by concerns about human rights and economic issues. A majority of Americans have negative feelings toward China, up substantially since 2018 [8]. In fact, negative views of China up substantially since 2018 [5].

The percentage of Americans feeling "cold" toward China increased by 21 percentage points from 2018 to 2021 [8]. These views are particularly driven by Republicans, with a significant increase in negative feelings [3, 7]. ![The graph illustrates the percentage of Americans, broken down by political affiliation, who feel "cold" toward China and who prioritize limiting China's power and influence from 2018 to 2021.](image2)

Americans have many specific concerns when it comes to China, and the sense that certain issues in the bilateral relationship – including cyber attacks, job losses to China, and China’s growing technological power – are major problems has grown over the past year alone [6]. When Americans think of China, human rights and the economy are top of mind [2].  Concerns regarding human rights are frequently cited, including the treatment of Uyghurs in Xinjiang [1, 6, 10]. China’s policies on human rights are seen as a very substantial problem for the U.S. by half of American adults [1, 6]. ![According to the graph, 70% of Americans believe that the U.S. should try to promote human rights in China, even if it harms economic relations with China.](image1) Furthermore, nearly half of Americans think limiting the power and influence of China should be a top foreign policy priority for the country [4].

Overall, American perceptions of China have become more negative between 2018 and 2021, driven by concerns about human rights, economic issues, and China's growing influence.

Americans have several key concerns regarding China, which include human rights, economic issues, and security threats, and some of these concerns have intensified recently. Human rights and the economy are at the forefront of American concerns when thinking about China [2].
![Americans consider human rights and the economy as top-of-mind concerns regarding China.](image4)
Americans express significant worry about specific issues in the U.S.-China relationship, with about three-quarters or more describing each issue as at least somewhat serious [9]. Notably, issues such as cyber attacks from China, the loss of U.S. jobs to China, China’s growing military power, and China’s policies on human rights are seen as very serious by half or more of Americans [9].
![Several concerns about China have increased between 2020 and 2021.](image1)
These specific concerns, including cyber attacks, job losses, and China’s technological power, have grown over the past year [10]. For example, half of Americans now view China’s human rights policy as a very serious problem, marking a 7 percentage point increase since last year [10]. Overall, Americans' concerns about China have been rising across various issues [3].
Therefore, the key concerns include human rights, economic issues like job losses, and security threats such as cyber attacks and military growth, with several of these concerns intensifying recently.

Since 2008, most Latino subgroups have shown increased optimism regarding their finances [1].  Latinos are consistently more optimistic about their next year’s finances than the general public [3].  The share of Latinos who expect their family finances to improve “a lot” or “some” in the coming year is up 14 percentage points, from 67% in 2008 to 81% in 2015 [9]. By contrast, the share of all Americans who share this optimistic view rose 6 percentage points to 61% during that time [9].
![Hispanics have had a higher financial expectation than the general public from 2004 to 2015.](image5)
According to the latest survey, both Latino men (+18 points) and Latina women (+11) are more optimistic about their finances now than they were seven years ago [6].  Similarly, U.S.-born and immigrant Hispanics both saw a 14 percentage point increase in hopeful views, reaching 81% in each group [6].
![There has been an increase in the percentage of Hispanics across subgroups that expect their family's finances to improve between 2008 and 2015.](image1)
Economic optimism has grown faster among Latinos who completed some college (+20 percentage points) compared to those with a high school diploma (+9) or less education (+11) [2].  Older Latinos were significantly less upbeat about their short-term economic future compared to younger Hispanics [7].  The gains in economic optimism are similarly large among Latinos ages 30 to 49 and 50 to 64 (+16 points for each group) [5].

Financial optimism among Hispanic subgroups has generally increased from 2008 to 2015, outpacing the general population's increase, although optimism varies by education level and age.

Hispanics generally hold optimistic views about their children's financial futures, but these views can be influenced by their current financial situation and educational attainment [4, 7, 8].
![The graph shows the percentage of people who think their children will be better off based on their financial status.](image2)
Hispanics who view their current financial situation positively are more likely to expect their family's finances to improve, suggesting that current prosperity fuels optimism about the future [3].
![The bar chart displays the percentage of Hispanics who expect their children to be better off based on demographics.](image5)
Educational attainment also plays a role, as Latino high school graduates are more optimistic about their children's financial prospects compared to those with some college experience or more [5].

In summary, current financial well-being and educational attainment affect Hispanic's expectations for their children's financial future, with those in better financial situations and those with a high school education expressing greater optimism.

Between 2000 and 2015, the Latino community experienced fluctuating perceptions of financial well-being alongside notable shifts in unemployment trends.

Latinos are optimistic about their children's financial future, with the majority expecting them to be better off. [3]

Looking at the perceptions of financial well-being,  $81\%$  of Latinos expected their finances to improve in 2015, up from  $67\%$  in 2008 [7]. By contrast, the share of all Americans who share this optimistic view of their family’s pocketbook prospects rose 6 percentage points  to  $61\%$  during that time [7]. ![Hispanics showed greater optimism about their families' financial futures compared to the general public.](image4)

Regarding their children's future,  $72\%$  of Latino adults expected their children to be better off financially than themselves [3].  ![Most Latinos expect their children to be better off financially.](image2)

However, despite this growing confidence, federal government data revealed a mixed economic picture for the Hispanic community [6]. The Hispanic poverty rate of  $23.6\%$  in 2014 remained above pre-recession levels [1].  Furthermore, median household income for Hispanics has stagnated since the Great Recession [1].
![Median household income for Hispanics has stagnated.](image1)

The U.S. Latino unemployment rate declined but remained above its 2006 low [4]. The group’s unemployment rate has improved since the Great Recession, falling from a high of  $12.8\%$  in the first quarter of 2010 to  $6.4\%$  in the last quarter of 2015 [6]. Still, it remained above its low of  $5\%$  in the fourth quarter of 2006 and is higher than that for non-Hispanic workers [6]. ![The unemployment rate for Hispanics, while declining, remained higher than pre-recession levels and that of non-Hispanic workers.](image5)

In summary, while Latinos showed increasing optimism about their financial well-being and future prospects for their children, unemployment rates, poverty levels and household income trends presented a more complex and mixed economic reality between 2000 and 2015.

Hispanics and the general U.S. public show differences in unemployment rates, economic perceptions, income, and wealth. The Latino unemployment rate, while declining, "remains above its 2006 low" [2].  ![The graph shows the quarterly unemployment rate for Hispanic and Non-Hispanic populations from 2000 to 2015.](image5)
The graph illustrates that the Hispanic unemployment rate has generally been higher than that of non-Hispanics, although both groups saw a peak around the time of the recession. Despite these challenges, "Hispanics remain upbeat about national economic conditions" [9]. In fact, "35\% of Hispanics said economic conditions today are good or excellent, a higher share than among whites (25\%)" [9]. Furthermore, "one-third of Hispanics (34\%) say U.S. economic conditions will be better in the coming year, a share about twice as high as seen among other groups of Americans" [9]. This optimism, however, exists against a backdrop of economic realities reflected in income and wealth data.

Median household income for Hispanics has stagnated since the Great Recession; in 2014, it was approximately \$42,491 [3]. ![This graph illustrates trends in household income, poverty rates, and household net worth for Hispanic households as compared to all U.S. households.](image2)
This level has remained essentially unchanged, similar to the general U.S. public [3].  In 2014, the Hispanic poverty rate was 23.6\%, lower than its 2010 peak but still above pre-recession levels [3]. Regarding wealth, Hispanic households experienced the largest percentage decline in net worth through 2009 among major racial or ethnic groups, and unlike white households, their net worth continued to fall after the recession [3]. Despite these economic hardships, there's optimism regarding future financial prospects; "Fully 72\% say they expect their children will be better off financially than they themselves are now" [5]. ![This pie chart depicts the percentage of Latinos who anticipate their children will be financially better off than themselves.](image3)

In summary, while Hispanics show optimism about economic conditions and future financial mobility for their children, they face higher unemployment rates relative to their historical lows and experience stagnation in median household income and declines in net worth, contributing to income and wealth disparities compared to the general U.S. population.

The economic situation of Hispanic households compared to all U.S. households shows a mixed picture from 2000 to 2015.

The unemployment rate for Hispanics has improved since the Great Recession, but it still remains above its low in 2006 and is higher than that for non-Hispanic workers [1]. The graph illustrates the quarterly unemployment rate for Hispanics versus non-Hispanics, showing the disparity especially during and after the recession. ![The graph illustrates the quarterly unemployment rate for Hispanics versus non-Hispanics.](image5)

Median household income for Hispanics in 2014 was $42,491, which is essentially unchanged since the Great Recession, similar to the U.S. public [7].  The Hispanic poverty rate in 2014 was 23.6%, less than its peak in 2010 but still above pre-recession levels [7]. ![This figure shows that the Hispanic poverty rate in 2014 was 23.6%.](image2)

Hispanic households experienced the largest percentage decline in net worth through 2009 among major racial or ethnic groups, and unlike white households, their net worth continued to fall after the recession [7].  Despite these challenges, Latinos have become more optimistic about their personal finances and future since the Great Recession [2].

In summary, Hispanic households still face significant economic challenges compared to all U.S. households, particularly in terms of unemployment, poverty rates, and wealth, even though there have been some improvements and increased optimism since the Great Recession.

Between 2008 and 2015, Latino perceptions of their economic well-being generally increased [1]. About half (48%) of Latinos ages 18 to 29 reported being in excellent or good financial shape in 2015, which is a 27 percentage point increase from 2008 [6]. ![Latinos aged 18-29 showed a 27 percentage point increase in reported financial well-being from 2008 to 2015.](image3)

Looking at family income relative to the cost of living, about half (53%) of Latinos said their family income was not keeping up with the cost of living in 2015 [3].  However, views of their financial situation are more positive now than they were in 2004 [9]. ![Positive views of Hispanic economic situations were higher in 2015 than in 2004.](image2) Furthermore, most key Latino demographic subgroups saw gains in personal finance ratings since 2008 [7].  Ratings of personal finances improved among most Latino groups [8]. ![Most Latino demographic subgroups saw gains in personal finance ratings from 2008 to 2015.](image3)

Overall, Latino perceptions of their personal financial situations and family income relative to the cost of living generally improved from 2008 to 2015.

Internet usage and device ownership among seniors differ notably from the general adult population, with distinctive trends in their daily internet habits. Smartphone ownership is lower among older adults, especially those in their mid-70s and beyond [2].
![Smartphone and tablet ownership among all adults and those 65+](image3)
Compared to all adults, fewer seniors own smartphones or tablets [image3].

However, seniors who do use the internet tend to make it a regular part of their daily routine [8]. A significant majority of older adults who are online access the internet every day or almost every day [4].
![Percentage of internet users by age group who go online](image1)
Internet usage frequency varies across age groups, with 71% of seniors (65+) going online every day or almost every day [image1].

Device ownership also impacts internet usage frequency, with those owning a smartphone or having home broadband going online more often [8].
![Cell phone, internet, and broadband usage among all adults and those 65+](image5)
While internet and broadband usage is lower among seniors compared to all adults [image5], those who do use it tend to incorporate it into their daily lives.

In summary, while fewer seniors use the internet and own smartphones compared to all adults, those who are online tend to use it frequently as part of their daily routine.

Device ownership among older adults presents a distinct contrast with their internet usage habits. While smartphone ownership among older adults is at just 18% [5], tablet and e-book readers are equally popular with 18% owning them as well [7]. The proportion of older adults who own either a tablet or an e-book reader is larger than those owning a smartphone [7].
![Among the 65+ age group, 18% owns a smartphone while 27% owns a tablet or e-reader](image4)
However, internet usage among seniors is higher; six in ten seniors (59%) report using the internet [3]. This divide is further emphasized by the fact that among older adults who do use the internet, 71% go online every day or almost every day [10].
![Seventy-one percent of older adults use the internet every day or almost every day](image2)
While device ownership, particularly smartphones, is lower, a significant portion of seniors who are online engage with the internet regularly.

In summary, device ownership among older adults, especially smartphones, is lower compared to their overall internet usage, but those who do use the internet, do so frequently.

Device ownership varies notably between older adults and the general population [7]. Only 18% of seniors own a smartphone compared to 55% of all adults, whereas 27% of older adults own a tablet, an e-book reader, or both [1, 5].

The graph shows device ownership among older adults and all adults. ![The graph shows device ownership among older adults and all adults.](image3)

Internet usage among seniors is lower than the general adult population, with 59% of seniors using the internet compared to 86% of all U.S. adults [4].  However, internet adoption among seniors has increased over time; in May 2008, only 35% of older adults were internet users [4].  Also, broadband adoption among older adults has more than doubled over a five-year period: in May 2008 just 19% of seniors were broadband adopters [9].

The graph illustrates internet adoption over time for seniors versus all adults. ![The graph illustrates internet adoption over time for seniors versus all adults.](image4)

Device ownership and online activity differ between seniors and the general adult population, with seniors showing lower smartphone adoption but increasing internet and broadband adoption over time.

Seniors' device ownership and social networking habits reveal interesting trends [9]. While tablet or e-reader ownership stands at 27% among those aged 65+, smartphone ownership is at 18%, as illustrated in the graph `![Tablet or e-reader ownership is higher than smartphone ownership for seniors](image1)`.

Notably, only 27% of older adults use social networking sites (SNS) [7]. This is visually represented in `![Only 27% of seniors use social networking sites](image2)`, showing that a significant portion of seniors do not engage with online social networks.

This contrasts with the device ownership data, where a notable percentage of seniors own tablets or e-readers [10]. Interestingly, the proportion of older adults who own either a tablet or an e-book reader is actually larger than the proportion owning a smartphone [10].

Despite having devices that could facilitate social networking, a smaller percentage of seniors actively use social networking sites, indicating a potential gap between device ownership and online social engagement.

Internet and broadband adoption rates among seniors are affected by age, income, and education, and they generally lag behind the general adult population [5].

Affluent and well-educated seniors adopt the internet and broadband at substantially higher rates than those with lower income and education levels [1].
![The percentages of seniors that go online vary based on their age, education, and household income.](image5)

Internet use and broadband adoption drop off dramatically around age 75 [3]. This is further supported by data showing that among those 80 years of age or older, slightly more than one third (37%) use the internet, and just 21% have a broadband connection at home [10].
![Internet usage is lower among seniors who do not use social networking sites.](image2)

Younger, higher-income, and more highly educated seniors use the internet and broadband at rates approaching the general population [8].
![The percentages of seniors that use cell phones and smartphones vary based on their age, education, and household income.](image3)

While 59% of seniors report using the internet, this trails the general adult population, where 86% go online [2].
![This graph compares the internet usage of adults 18+ and adults 65+.](image4)

Internet and broadband adoption rates among older adults vary significantly based on age, education, and income, with rates generally lower than the general adult population but higher among younger, more affluent, and better-educated seniors.

Seniors' adoption rates for internet, broadband, cell phones, and smartphones are significantly influenced by their income and education levels. Seniors with higher education and income levels exhibit greater adoption rates across all these technologies [3, 9].

For internet and broadband adoption, there's a clear disparity based on income; among seniors with an annual household income of $75,000 or more, 90% go online and 82% have broadband at home, compared to just 39% and 25% respectively for those earning less than $30,000 annually [9]. ![Seniors with higher income and education levels have higher rates of going online and having broadband at home.](image3)

Education also plays a crucial role, as 87% of seniors with a college degree use the internet, and 76% have broadband, while only 40% of seniors who have not attended college use the internet and 27% have broadband [7, 9].

Cell phone ownership is widespread among seniors, with 77% owning a cell phone [4]. However, smartphone adoption tells a different story.  Smartphone adoption rate is only at 18% among seniors [10]. ![Smartphone and tablet adoption rates are lower for seniors compared to all adults.](image1) Even within the senior demographic, smartphone adoption varies significantly based on income and education, as shown in image5; seniors with higher income and education are more likely to own smartphones.

Affluent and well-educated seniors adopt the internet at higher rates [1].  ![College graduates are more likely to own e-book readers and tablets.](image1)
Seniors with higher education levels are more likely to own e-book readers and tablets [7].   Smartphone ownership is also correlated with income; among older adults with higher incomes, a greater percentage own smartphones compared to the average [6].  ![Smartphone adoption is correlated to income and education.](image4)
However, smartphone ownership decreases substantially for seniors in their mid-70s and becomes nearly non-existent among those in their 80s and beyond [8].

The digital divide among seniors is influenced by income and education, with lower adoption rates for those with lower income and education levels.

Seniors with different educational backgrounds show significant disparities in internet usage and smartphone ownership. Seniors who are college graduates have much higher rates of internet use [7]. ![College graduates have the highest rate of going online and broadband adoption at home](image2)

Those who have not attended college tend to be much more removed from online life [4].
![College graduates are more likely to own e-readers or tablet computers compared to seniors with only a high school education](image3)

Smartphone ownership is also correlated with educational attainment [7].
![The rate of smartphone adoption increases with household income](image5)

Internet usage and smartphone ownership among seniors vary significantly depending on their level of education.

Seniors with higher education and income levels show greater adoption rates of internet and broadband, as well as cell phones and smartphones. 

For seniors with a college degree, 87% go online, and 76% have broadband [1].  In contrast, among those who have not attended college, only 40% go online, and 27% have broadband at home [1].  ![College graduates show higher rates of going online and broadband adoption, followed by lower rates for those with some college and high school graduates.](image3)

The same trend applies to income levels, with 90% of seniors earning $75,000 or more going online and 82% having broadband, compared to 39% and 25% respectively for those earning less than $30,000 [3].

Cell phone ownership is high across all demographics, but smartphone adoption is still relatively low, especially among the oldest seniors [7, 8].  ![Cell phone ownership among seniors in different age groups from 65-69 to 80 and above, showing declining ownership with age.](image2)

While 77% of all seniors own cell phones, only 18% are smartphone adopters [7, 9].  Even among affluent seniors (household income of $75,000 or more), smartphone ownership is high relative to other seniors, but trails the general population [10]. This divide highlights that while basic cell phone use is widespread, advanced mobile technology adoption lags among seniors, particularly those with lower incomes and less education.

In summary, seniors with higher education and income levels are more likely to adopt both internet and broadband services, as well as cell phones and smartphones, compared to those with lower education and income.

Seniors with higher educational attainment and higher household incomes are more likely to adopt broadband at home. Seniors with a college degree show significantly higher online engagement, with "Fully $87\%$ of seniors with a college degree go online, and $76\%$ are broadband adopters" [10].
![College graduates are more likely to have broadband at home.](image2)
This contrasts sharply with those who have not attended college, where only "$40\%$ go online and just $27\%$ have broadband at home" [10]. Additionally, income plays a crucial role, as "$90\%$ go online and $82\%$ have broadband at home" among seniors with an annual household income of $75,000 or more, compared to "$39\%$ go online and $25\%$ have broadband at home" for those earning less than $30,000 annually [10].
![Seniors with higher household incomes are more likely to have broadband at home.](image2)
In summary, broadband adoption at home is notably higher among seniors with higher educational attainment and household income.

Among seniors, tablet and e-reader adoption is strongly linked to education levels [4]. Seniors who have graduated from college are around three times as likely to own both an e-book reader and a tablet as are seniors who have not attended college [4]. ![Tablet and e-book reader ownership by seniors is correlated with educational attainment.](image3)

This educational divide also influences general internet usage among seniors, as shown in the trends of technology adoption across different age groups over time. ![The graph illustrates the trends of technology adoption across different age groups over time.](image2)

The adoption rate of social networking sites is also influenced by the age of seniors, with younger seniors (65-69) showing higher adoption rates compared to those 80 and older [8]. Some 54% of internet users ages 65-69 use social networking sites, compared with just 27% of internet users ages 80 and older [8].
The adoption of tablets and e-book readers among seniors is significantly influenced by their level of education, mirroring broader trends in technology adoption across different age groups.

Educational attainment significantly shapes how workers view technology's impact on their careers [6]. Those with higher education levels are more likely to see technology as a positive force that enhances their work and career prospects, while those with less education are less likely to hold such positive views [6]. For example, a college degree drastically change the opinion regarding the influence of technology in making work more interesting and providing chances for career advancement ![{College graduates are more likely to view technology as enhancing their work and career prospects}](image1).

Workers with high school diplomas or less are less likely to view technology as making their jobs more interesting or increasing their opportunities for career advancement compared to those with more education [7]. Only 38% of workers with a high school diploma or less find that technology has made their jobs more interesting, and only 32% believe it has increased their career advancement opportunities [7]. In comparison, college graduates are substantially more likely to report that technology has made their work more interesting (64% vs. 38%) and increased their opportunities for career advancement (53% vs. 32%) [10].

![Most people expect driverless cars within the next half-century](image2)

Regarding driverless car technology, there's a widespread expectation of its advancement and adoption in the coming decades [3]. The vast majority of Americans (94%) are aware of the development of driverless vehicles [2]. Roughly two-thirds of the public anticipates that most vehicles on the road will be driverless within the next half-century, with 9% predicting this will occur within the next 10 years [2].

Educational attainment influences perceptions of workforce technologies, with higher education correlating to more positive views, and driverless car technology is widely anticipated to advance and be adopted in the coming decades.

Workers with varying levels of educational attainment express pronounced differences in their views of workplace technology [8]. For each of the six specific technologies measured in the survey, workers with at least a four-year college degree have markedly more positive views compared with those with high school diplomas or less [4]. These differences are most pronounced in the case of office productivity tools such as word processing or spreadsheet software. There is a 45-percentage point difference in the share of workers with college degrees (90%) and with high school diplomas or less (45%) who feel these technologies have had a positive impact on them professionally [4].

![Workers with college degrees generally view workplace technologies more positively.](image3)

Workers generally express more positive than negative views when asked a more general set of questions about the impact of all the various technologies they might have used throughout the course of their careers [9]. Roughly half of workers (53%) feel that technology in general has made their work more interesting, but 12% say it has made their work less interesting – and around one-third (34%) say it hasn’t had a major impact either way in this regard [9].  Many Americans anticipate that various automation technologies will make significant inroads in terms of their development and adoption in the coming decades [1]. Driverless vehicles are perhaps the most prominent example of this trend [1]. Fully 94% of Americans have some awareness of the effort to develop driverless vehicles, and roughly two-thirds of the public anticipates that most vehicles on the road will be driverless within the next half-century – with 9% predicting that this will occur in the next 10 years [1].

![Most Americans expect driverless cars to become common within the next 50 years.](image5)

Workers with higher education levels generally view workplace technologies more positively, while a significant majority of Americans anticipate the widespread adoption of driverless cars within the next half-century.

Americans have a high awareness of the development of driverless vehicles, and most anticipate their widespread use in the next half-century [6]. Fully $94\%$ of Americans are aware of the efforts to develop driverless vehicles, with roughly two-thirds expecting most vehicles to be driverless within 50 years [6]. Although some positive outcomes are expected from automation, attitudes often reflect worry and concern about the societal implications [5].

However, current experiences with workforce technologies elicit mixed views from workers [1, 2].  Many workers view technologies positively, while substantial shares find them damaging or neutral to career prospects [1].

![Workers express mixed opinions on the impact of technologies in their careers.](image1)

Workers express diverse views on the impact of technologies on their jobs and careers [4]. Technologies such as word processing, spreadsheet software, smartphones and email have positively impacted many careers [4]. Roughly half of workers feel technology has made their work more interesting [7]. ![Technology has made workers job more interesting.](image5)

Overall, while there's widespread anticipation and some apprehension about future technologies like driverless vehicles, current workforce technologies are met with mixed reviews, with benefits often accruing to those with higher education [1, 8].

In summary, Americans are widely aware and expectant of automation technologies like driverless vehicles with mixed emotions, while their current experiences with technologies in the workforce vary, depending on the specific technology and the worker's educational attainment.

Workers' perceptions of workplace technologies are significantly influenced by their level of education [7]. Those with higher education generally express more positive views [1].
![College graduates are more likely to say technology has made their work more interesting and increased opportunities for career advancement.](image3)
College graduates are more inclined to view technology as having a positive impact on their careers. For instance, a higher percentage of college graduates believe that technology has made their work more interesting (64% vs. 38%) and increased their opportunities for career advancement (53% vs. 32%) compared to those with high school diplomas or less [2].  This is further highlighted by the fact that workers with higher levels of education are more likely to say that technology has increased opportunities and made their jobs more interesting [3].
![The data shows that 53% of workers feel that technology in general has made their work more interesting.](image2)
Workers generally express more positive than negative views about technology's impact on their careers. Approximately 53% feel that technology has made their work more interesting, while 12% say it has made it less interesting. Similarly, 46% feel that technology has increased their opportunities for career advancement [5]. However, these views differ significantly based on education level.
![A plurality of workers (46%) feel that technology has increased their opportunities for career advancement.](image1)
Those with only a high school diploma or less are more likely to have a downbeat perspective on the impact of technology on their careers compared to college graduates [6].

In summary, workers with higher education levels perceive workplace technologies more positively, especially in terms of job interest and career advancement, compared to those with lower education levels.

Workers with varying levels of educational attainment have different views on workplace technology [3]. College graduates are more likely to find that technology has made their work more interesting and has increased opportunities for career advancement compared to those with high school diplomas or less [1].

For instance, 64% of college graduates find technology has made their work more interesting, compared to only 38% of workers with high school diplomas or less [1]. A similar trend is observed in career advancement opportunities, with 53% of college graduates reporting increased opportunities versus 32% of those with a high school diploma or less [1]. ![College graduates are more likely to report that technology has made their work more interesting and increased career opportunities compared to high school graduates.](image5)

In general, those who have not attended college are much less likely to view today's workforce technologies in a positive light [6]. The difference in perception is quite significant across various technologies; for example, 90% of college graduates feel word processing and spreadsheet software have had a positive impact, compared to only 45% of those with a high school diploma or less [9]. ![College graduates are substantially more likely to perceive word processing or spreadsheet software as having a positive impact compared to those with a high school diploma or less.](image3)

Educational attainment strongly influences how workers perceive the impact of technology on their work, with higher education levels associated with more positive views regarding job interest and career advancement.

Workers with higher education levels generally view technology's impact on their careers more positively [6]. Workers with higher levels of education are more likely to report that technology has increased their opportunities and made their jobs more interesting [8].
![Workers with college degrees are more likely to say that technology has increased their opportunities for advancement and made their work more interesting.](image3)
For example, college graduates are substantially more likely to say that technology has made their work more interesting (64\% vs. 38\%) and increased their opportunities for career advancement (53\% vs. 32\%) compared to workers with high school diplomas or less [9]. In contrast, a significant percentage of non-college educated workers feel that technology has not impacted their careers in any meaningful way [7]. For instance, 44\% of workers with high school degrees or less say their professional lives have not been impacted by word processing or spreadsheet software [7].
![College graduates are much more likely to have positive views on office productivity tools such as word processing and spreadsheet software.](image1)
The difference in perception is stark, with a 45-percentage point gap between college graduates (90\%) and those with high school diplomas or less (45\%) who feel these technologies have positively impacted them professionally [10].

Educational levels significantly influence workers' perceptions of technology's effects on job opportunities and work interest, with higher education correlating with more positive views.

Americans familiar with the idea of machines doing human jobs are more likely to express enthusiasm, yet they also maintain substantial concerns [6]. Image3 shows that 47% of those who have heard a lot about automation are very or somewhat enthusiastic. ![Those familiar with the concept of automation are more enthusiastic about it.](image3)

Even with increased enthusiasm, worry remains prevalent [3]. The image also indicates that 76% of those familiar with the concept still express worry, a figure comparable to those with less awareness [9].

Most Americans foresee negative outcomes, such as increased inequality [5, 10]. ![Americans expect negative outcomes like increased inequality.](image4) As shown in Image4, 76% of Americans expect greater economic inequality. However, a very large portion of the public, 85%, favors robots and computers doing jobs that are dangerous or unhealthy for humans [2]. ![Most Americans favor limiting robots to dangerous or unhealthy jobs.](image2)

In conclusion, while greater awareness of automation correlates with increased enthusiasm, it does not diminish concerns about potential negative outcomes, especially economic inequality, and the majority supports limiting robots to dangerous or unhealthy jobs.

Democrats are more supportive of guaranteed income and national service programs than Republicans in the event of widespread job losses due to automation [5]. Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents are substantially more likely than Republicans and Republican-leaning independents to favor both a universal income (by a 77% to 38% margin) and a national service program (by a 66% to 46% margin) in the event that machines threaten to displace substantial numbers of human workers [9]. But the vast majority of Americans – regardless of party affiliation – support limiting machines to performing dangerous and dirty jobs [9].

![Democrats and Republicans have different levels of support on policies related to workforce automation.](image3)

When it comes to limiting robots and computers to "dangerous and dirty" jobs, the public shows strong support [10]. Fully 85% of Americans favor this type of policy, with nearly half (47%) saying they favor it strongly [6]. Opposition to government job- and income-supporting programs is stronger than opposition to the idea that robots should mostly be limited to doing dangerous or unhealthy jobs [7]. For instance, **18%** of Americans are strongly opposed to a guaranteed minimum income [7].

![Most people favor that machines should be limited to doing dangerous or unhealthy jobs.](image5)

Democrats are more inclined to support guaranteed income and national service programs compared to Republicans, while there is broad, bipartisan support for limiting machines to dangerous jobs.

Political affiliation significantly impacts views on government obligations to displaced workers, while education levels affect opinions on automation limits. Democrats are more supportive of government aid for workers displaced by automation, whereas Republicans believe individuals should be responsible for their own financial well-being [3].
![Democrats are more inclined to believe that the government should provide assistance to displaced workers compared to Republicans.](image4)
This divide is evident in the support for policies like universal basic income, with $77\%$ of Democrats favoring it compared to $38\%$ of Republicans [1].
![There is a significant difference in support between Democrats and Republicans for a universal basic income.](image2)
Conversely, views on limiting how many human jobs businesses can replace with machines are more aligned across parties [7]. However, attitudes towards government job- and income-supporting programs face stronger opposition than limiting robots to dangerous jobs [4].  Educational attainment also plays a role, as those with lower education levels are more likely to support limits on job automation by businesses [10].
![Individuals with lower educational attainment are more likely to favor limits on the number of human jobs that can be automated by businesses.](image4)
Therefore, partisan affiliation and educational attainment create distinct viewpoints on the role of government and the regulation of automation in the workforce.

Americans' views on policies related to workforce automation and job displacement are significantly influenced by their political affiliations [1]. Democrats are more inclined to support a universal basic income and a national service program in the event of widespread job losses due to automation [2]. ![Democrats are more likely to support guaranteed income and national service programs.](image4)

Democrats are also more likely to believe that the government should take care of workers displaced by automation, even if it means higher taxes, while Republicans tend to think individuals should be responsible for their financial well-being [4].
![Democrats are more likely to believe that government should take care of displaced workers, even if it means raising taxes.](image3)

Despite these differences, there is some bipartisan agreement; for example, similar percentages of Democrats and Republicans agree that there should be limits on how many human jobs businesses can replace with machines [6, 10].

Political affiliations significantly shape American views on policies addressing workforce automation and job displacement, particularly concerning government intervention and support for displaced workers.

Attitudes toward workforce automation and technology's impact differ across age groups and education levels. Workers with higher education generally have more positive views on workplace technologies [3]. ![College graduates are more likely to find that technology has made their work more interesting and increased opportunities for career advancement.](image4) College graduates are more likely to report that technology has made their work more interesting and increased career opportunities, with 64% finding their work more interesting and 53% noting increased career advancement opportunities [8]. In contrast, only 38% of workers with high school diplomas or less find their jobs more interesting due to technology, and just 32% see increased career advancement opportunities [8]. ![The youngest adults are among the most likely to have been personally impacted by workforce automation.](image3) Younger adults, particularly those aged 18-24, are more likely to have experienced job loss due to automation [2]. Overall, educational attainment significantly shapes perceptions of technology's impact on work and career prospects.

The impact of technology on jobs and careers is viewed with mixed feelings, as many see the benefits accruing more to those with higher education [1]. These differences highlight how education plays a crucial role in shaping perceptions and experiences with automation in the workforce.

Workers express diverse opinions on the impact of today's technologies on their jobs and careers, with substantial shares viewing them as damaging or neutral to their career prospects [4, 8]. However, the benefits of these tools are most likely to accrue to workers with high levels of formal educational attainment [4].

College graduates are significantly more likely to report that technology has made their work more interesting (64% vs. 38%) and increased their opportunities for career advancement (53% vs. 32%) compared to workers with high school diplomas or less [1]. ![College graduates find technology makes their work more interesting and increases their opportunities for advancement.](image4)

Workers lacking a college education are much less likely to express positive attitudes towards the current generation of workforce technologies [2, 6]. These impacts vary considerably across different technologies. For example, while many workers report a positive impact from technologies like word processing software and smartphones, fewer report a positive impact from technologies that help customers serve themselves or from industrial robots [10].

Overall, workers' views on the impact of technology are mixed, with those having higher educational attainment generally viewing technology more positively [3, 5, 6]. The impact of workforce automation and technology varies significantly across different demographics and education levels, with those having higher education generally perceiving technology more positively.

Workers' perceptions of how interesting their jobs are and whether they have opportunities for advancement are influenced both by their education levels and by the specific types of technologies they use.

Workers generally express more positive views than negative ones regarding the impact of technology, but there are still some who feel technology has decreased their opportunities [2, 10]. Roughly half of workers (53%) feel that technology in general has made their work more interesting, but 12% say it has made their work less interesting [2].
![Roughly half the workers feel that technology has made their work more interesting.](image1)

Those who have not attended college are much less likely to view today’s workforce technologies in a positive light [3]. Just 38% of workers with high school diplomas or less indicate that technology in general has made their jobs more interesting, and a similarly modest share (32%) feels that technology has increased their opportunities for career advancement [7]. The image shows that workers with higher education levels are more likely to say that technology has increased opportunities and made their jobs more interesting [6].
![Workers with higher education levels generally agree that technology has increased their opportunities and made their jobs more interesting.](image2)

Specific technologies like word processing and spreadsheet software (70%), smartphones (67%), and email or social media (60%) have positively impacted workers' careers [9]. Workers with college degrees are substantially more likely than those who have not attended college to say that each of these individual technologies has had a positive impact on their jobs or careers [5].
![A majority of workers claim word processing, spreadsheet software, smartphones, and email or social media have had a positive impact on their careers.](image4)

Education levels and specific technologies impact a worker's perception of their job's interest and advancement opportunities.

Younger adults are more inclined to encounter content that amuses them [1]. Conversely, older adults experience amusement less frequently [5]. However, amusement is the emotion most frequently experienced overall by social media users [7].

The frequency of feeling amused varies across age groups, with younger adults reporting it more often than older adults, as shown in the data. ![Younger adults frequently feel amused by social media content, while older adults' amusement levels are lower.](image2)

Additionally, users commonly encounter posts that are dramatic and exaggerated, as well as arguments without full information, both sparking different emotional responses [2]. Social media is a mixed bag of positive and negative interactions, with amusement being a prominent emotion alongside anger [6, 3]. The most common reaction to congressional Facebook posts is now the "anger" emoticon [4]. Overall, amusement is the most frequently experienced emotion on social media [7].  ![Amusement is the emotion that users most frequently experience.](image3)

Social media users frequently experience amusement, but also encounter anger-inducing content, with younger adults feeling more amused than older adults.

Younger adults are more prone to feeling lonely on social media compared to older adults, with $15\%$ of users aged 18-29 reporting frequent feelings of loneliness, in contrast to only $4\%$ of those 50 and older [1].  Older adults are not frequently amused by content they see on social media [1]. In fact, similar shares of social media users ages 65 and older say they frequently see content on these  platforms that makes them feel amused   $\left(30\%\right)$   and angry   $({\it24\%})$ [1].

![A bar graph illustrates the frequency of emotions experienced by different age groups on social media.](image1)

Younger adults are twice as likely to say they frequently see content on social media that makes them feel amused   $\left(54\%\right)$   as they are content that makes them feel angry   $\left(27\%\right)$ [7]. But users ages  65 and older encounter these two types of content with more comparable frequency [7].

![A bar graph illustrating the frequency of different types of content seen on social media.](image4)

Social media users frequently encounter overly dramatic or exaggerated posts, with $58\%$ reporting seeing such content frequently [5].  Additionally, $59\%$ frequently see people making accusations or starting arguments without having all the facts [5].

Different age groups on social media experience a range of emotions, with younger adults more likely to feel lonely and amused, while older adults encounter amusement and anger with similar frequency, and social media frequently exposes users to dramatic and argumentative content.

Younger adults are more likely than older adults to say they frequently encounter content on social media that makes them feel lonely [7]. Some $15\%$ of social media users ages 18 to 29 say this, compared with $7\%$ of those ages 30 to 49 and just $4\%$ of those 50 and older [7].
![Young adults are more likely to feel lonely from social media content compared to older adults.](image2)
Men are around twice as likely as women to say they more often see people being deceptive on social media ($24\%$ vs. $13\%$) [10]. But majorities of both men $(58\%)$ and women $(67\%)$ see an equal mix of deceptiveness and attempts to correct misinformation [10].
![Men are more likely than women to perceive deceptiveness on social media.](image4)
The survey also included a series of questions about how often social media users encounter certain types of behaviors and content [4]. These findings indicate that users see two types of content especially frequently: posts that are overly dramatic or exaggerated ($58\%$ of users say they see this type of content frequently) and people making accusations or starting arguments without waiting until they have all the facts ($59\%$ see this frequently) [4].
![Many social media users frequently encounter overly dramatic posts and accusations.](image5)
Different age groups and genders vary in their emotional responses and perceptions of behaviors on social media, with younger adults feeling more loneliness, men perceiving more deceptiveness, and both genders commonly encountering dramatic and argumentative content.

Social media users' experience varies in relation to the emotions they feel and the behaviors they observe, with these differences often linked to age and gender [8, 9, 10].

Around half (54%) of social media users say they typically see an equal mix of people being kind or supportive and people being mean or bullying [8]. However, gender differences exist, as a slightly larger share of men (29%) than women (19%) say they more often see people being mean or bullying content on social media platforms than see kind behavior [10]. Conversely, women are slightly more likely than men to say that they more often see people being kind or supportive [10].
The largest shares of both men (52%) and women (56%) say that they typically see an equal mix of supportive and bullying behavior on social media [10].

Users are exposed to posts that evoke a range of emotions; a significant number of users frequently feel amused (44%), while others feel angry (25%), connected (21%), inspired (16%), depressed (13%), and lonely (7%) [5].
![Social media users frequently feel amused while using social media.](image2)
Ages also contributed the emotions one frequently feels while using social media [7].
![Younger users frequently feel amused while using social media.](image4)

In terms of the types of content encountered, posts that are overly dramatic or exaggerated (58%) and people making accusations or starting arguments without having all the facts (59%) are frequently seen by users [9]. A majority of social media users also say they at least sometimes encounter posts that appear to be about one thing but turn out to be about something else, as well as posts that teach them [6].
![Overly dramatic posts are frequently encountered by social media users.](image5)

Different age groups and genders experience emotions and behaviors on social media uniquely, with certain types of posts being commonly encountered.

Men are more likely than women to perceive bullying and deception on social media, while women are more inclined to see kindness and support [9, 10].

Men are around twice as likely as women to say they more often seeing people being deceptive on social media (24% vs. 13%) [5]. Women are slightly more likely than men to say that they more often see people being kind or supportive [10]. Despite these differences, majorities of both men and women report seeing an equal mix of supportive and bullying behaviors [10].  ![Men are more inclined to observe bullying and deception on social media, whereas women tend to notice kindness and support.](image1)
Social media users frequently encounter dramatic or exaggerated posts, with 58% of users reporting they see this type of content frequently [3]. Additionally, 59% frequently see people making accusations or starting arguments without having all the facts [3]. ![Most users frequently come across posts that are overly dramatic or exaggerated.](image4)
Men and women have different perceptions regarding bullying and deception on social media, and a large percentage of users see dramatic and exaggerated content frequently.

Men are more prone to seeing deceptive content, while women tend to observe more supportive interactions, though most see a mix of both [4, 10].
![Men are more likely to see bullying on social media, while women are more likely to see kindness.](image2)
Men are around twice as likely as women to say they more often seeing people being deceptive on social media (24% vs. 13%) [10]. Women, on the other hand, are slightly more likely than men to say that they more often see people being kind or supportive [4]. Men are somewhat more likely than women to see people being bullying on social media [8]. However, majorities of both men (58%) and women (67%) see an equal mix of deceptiveness and attempts to correct misinformation [10]. Social media platforms can use these differences to tailor content and advertisements [2].
Overall, men and women experience social media content differently, with men noticing more deception and bullying, while women perceive more kindness, suggesting that platforms could refine their algorithms to cater to these gender-specific perceptions.

User comfort with social media data usage varies significantly across age groups and depends on the purpose [8]. For example, comfort levels differ depending on whether the data is used to recommend events or deliver political messages [1].

Social media users across different age groups generally find it acceptable for platforms to use their data to recommend events in their area, but they are more cautious about their data being used for political messaging [9]. ![Acceptability of data use for recommending events is consistent across age groups.](image1)

However, views diverge when it comes to other uses of personal data.  About two-thirds of social media users younger than 50 find it acceptable for social media platforms to use their personal data to recommend connecting with people they might want to know, but fewer than half of users ages 65 and older share this view [6]. Older users are generally less accepting of social media sites using their data for reasons other than recommending local events [10]. The acceptability of data use for recommending friends decreases with age [10].

Across age groups, users are most comfortable with social media sites using their data to recommend events in their area, but less comfortable with the use of their data for political messaging and recommending new connections [9]. Overall comfort levels depend heavily on the specific context and purpose for which the data are being used [8].

The public's perceptions of fairness and effectiveness in automated systems vary considerably depending on the application, revealing nuanced attitudes toward algorithmic decision-making [6]. For instance, while similar percentages of people believe personal finance scores and criminal risk scores are effective, there's a significant gap in perceived fairness, with 50% viewing criminal risk scores as fair compared to only 32% for personal finance scores [1]. This suggests that the context in which these algorithms are deployed greatly influences public acceptance.

The image highlights the difference between the perceived effectiveness and fairness of different automated systems. ![Effectiveness and fairness ratings show varied public perceptions across different automated systems.](image3)

This divergence is further underscored by the finding that only 32% of Americans believe personal finance scores are fair to consumers, while a substantial 68% find the algorithm unacceptable [7, 9].  ![A majority of people find the use of automated personal finance scores unacceptable.](image2) This lack of trust may stem from concerns about privacy violations and the potential for these systems to misrepresent individuals [6].

In general, Americans are largely skeptical about the fairness of algorithmic programs, as none are viewed as fair by a clear majority [7, 10]. ![The graph illustrates public sentiment, showing that many people believe computer programs will always reflect human bias.](image1)

These differences highlight that public trust in automated systems is not solely based on their perceived effectiveness but is significantly shaped by concerns about fairness, transparency, and potential biases.

The public generally views the ethical standards of top Trump administration officials lower than those of previous administrations [1, 4]. A majority of the public, 58%, trusts what Trump says less than previous presidents, while only 26% trust him more [9].
![Views of Trump administration officials are lower than those of officials in the previous five administrations.](image1)
This image illustrates ethical standards of top administration officials from Trump to Reagan.

However, there's a significant partisan divide: Most Republicans (58%) trust Trump more than previous presidents, whereas only 15% trust him less [6]. Democrats overwhelmingly (94%) trust Trump less than previous presidents [2].
![Democrats overwhelmingly trust Trump less than previous presidents.](image4)

Views on the ethical standards of Trump administration officials are highly divided along party lines, with 76% of Republicans rating them as excellent or good, compared to only 10% of Democrats [10]. This divide has persisted and even widened since 2017 [5].
![Partisan divide on how Trump's policies affect the country.](image3)
The perception of Trump's ethical standards and trustworthiness is significantly lower compared to previous presidents among the general public and especially Democrats, but Republicans tend to trust him more.

The public generally views Trump as less trustworthy compared to previous presidents [9]. A majority of the public, specifically $58\%$, expresses less trust in Trump's statements than they did in those of past presidents [10]. Conversely, only $26\%$ trust Trump more than previous presidents, and $14\%$ have about the same level of trust [10].

Partisan divisions significantly influence these perceptions.  Among Republicans, $58\%$ trust Trump more than previous presidents, while $25\%$ trust him about the same, and $15\%$ trust him less [8]. ![Republicans trust Trump's statements more than previous presidents.](image3) Almost all Democrats, $94\%$, express less trust in Trump compared to previous presidents [5]. This distrust has increased since April 2017, when $51\%$ felt this way [7].

A majority, $64\%$, believes Trump has a responsibility to release his tax returns [3].  ![Most people think Trump should release his tax returns](image1) This view is held by nearly all Democrats, $91\%$, and even a notable portion of Republicans, $32\%$ [3].

In summary, public trust in Trump is generally lower compared to previous presidents, with significant partisan divides; a majority believes he should release his tax returns.

Perceptions of Trump's presidency are deeply divided along partisan lines, especially concerning ethical standards, economic impact, and long-term success, setting him apart from his predecessors. Views of the ethical standards of top Trump administration officials remain at record lows compared with previous administrations dating back to the 1980s [1].

Republicans and Republican-leaning independents largely believe Trump will be a successful president, while Democrats hold contrasting views. About two-thirds of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents (65\%) say Trump will be a successful president in the long run [3].
![Republicans are more likely to believe Trump would be successful compared to Democrats.](image5)

Regarding the economy, there's a notable partisan split. Nearly eight-in-ten Republicans and Republican leaners (79\%) say that his economic policies had improved conditions in the country (up from 63\% in October 2017). Almost half (46\%) of Democrats now say his economic policies have made conditions worse [9].
![Republicans generally think Trumps economic policies are getting better.](image4)

Compared to previous presidents, fewer people think it is "too early to tell" whether Trump will be successful, indicating more established views, whether positive or negative [5].  Views of Trump administration officials are lower than those of officials in the previous five administrations, often measured at times of specific ethical controversies [7].
![Trump has a lower ethical standing than previous administration officials.](image1)
