In summary, perceptions of Trump's presidency are highly polarized, with Republicans generally optimistic and Democrats critical, and the public holds firm views on his potential success compared to his predecessors.

Republicans generally view Trump as more successful than Democrats do, a trend consistent across presidencies [3]. Specifically, about two-thirds of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents (65%) say Trump will be a successful president in the long run [1]. In contrast, an even larger share of Democrats and Democratic leaners (80%) think that Trump will be an unsuccessful president [5]. ![Views of Trump's long-term success among Republicans and Democrats are polarized.](image1)

The public was less sure about the success of previous presidents at comparable points in their administrations [4].  For example, at the start of Barack Obama’s third year in office, nearly half of the public (47%) said it was too early to tell whether he would be successful [4].  Perceptions of Trump's potential success have become more polarized, with Republicans becoming more positive and Democrats more negative since 2017 [8]. ![The image illustrates polarization in views on Trump's economic policies.](image2)

Over time, the percentage of people who think it is too early to tell has decreased, suggesting that opinions have solidified more quickly under Trump than they did for his predecessors [4].  However, Trump's negative ratings are higher compared to Obama and George W. Bush at similar points in their presidencies [6]. ![Views of Trump's success compared to Clinton, Bush, and Obama over time.](image3)

In summary, perceptions of Trump's presidency are more polarized and solidified than those of his predecessors, with Republicans largely optimistic and Democrats pessimistic about his long-term success.

Republicans and Democrats diverge significantly in their perceptions of Trump's potential success and their confidence in the Mueller investigation. Republicans are more optimistic about Trump's success, while Democrats express greater confidence in the fairness of the Mueller investigation.

Republicans are more inclined to believe Trump will be successful in the long run, with about two-thirds $(65\%)$ holding this view [6]. In contrast, a large majority of Democrats $(80\%)$ think Trump will be an unsuccessful president [3]. Democrats are far more likely to lack confidence in Trump's handling of matters related to the investigation, with $92\%$ expressing a lack of confidence [9]. Three-quarters of Republicans are confident in Trump to handle the inquiry appropriately [9].
![Republicans are more likely to find Trump successful, while Democrats are more likely to find Trump unsuccessful.](image3)

Regarding the Mueller investigation, Democrats show higher confidence in its fairness compared to Republicans. About seven-in-ten Democrats $(72\%)$ are at least somewhat confident in the fairness of Mueller’s investigation, while a larger share of Republicans $(58\%)$ are not too or not at all confident in Mueller [7]. ![Republicans are more likely to find Mueller's investigation unfair than Democrats.](image2)

Overall, confidence in the Mueller investigation has remained relatively stable, with $55\%$ of the public expressing confidence in its fairness [5, 8]. ![The public confidence in Mueller's investigation has remained at 55% over the course of a year.](image5)

In summary, Republicans are more optimistic about Trump's success and less confident in the Mueller investigation, while Democrats hold the opposite views.

There's a notable partisan divide in the perceptions of job availability, with Republicans generally holding more positive views compared to Democrats [2, 6, 7].

Currently, $71\%$ of Republicans say there are plenty of jobs available, compared with $53\%$ of Democrats [2]. ![Republicans are more likely to rate their financial situation as excellent or good.](image2)

This partisan gap has been observed consistently, with Republicans being more likely than Democrats to rate their personal financial situation as excellent or good [7]. As shown in the graph, Republicans generally have a more positive view of the job market [1, 5].  ![Since 2001, positive view on job availability rose sharply.](image1)

Over time, positive views on local job availability have risen, tracking with more positive views of the economy [10]. ![Republicans are more likely to report plenty of jobs available compared to Democrats.](image5)

Views on job availability vary significantly between Republicans and Democrats, with Republicans generally more optimistic; this partisan gap has persisted over time, even as overall perceptions of job availability have improved [2, 7].

Perceptions of job availability significantly differ between Republicans and Democrats, and these views have shifted notably over the years [2, 10]. Currently, a large majority of Republicans (71%) believe there are plenty of jobs available, compared to a smaller majority of Democrats (53%) [2, 10]. `![Republicans are more optimistic about job availability than Democrats.](image2)`This partisan gap is a consistent trend [10].

Over time, the perceptions have evolved, especially with political changes.  The public’s perceptions of the availability of jobs have undergone a similar transformation [7]. For the first time in Pew Research Center surveys dating to 2001, a clear majority of Americans (60%) say there are plenty of jobs in their communities [7].  ![The job availability perceptions among Republicans and Democrats from 2001 to 2019.](image1) As shown in the image, during periods with a Republican president (Bush and Trump), Republicans generally have a more positive view of job availability, while Democrats' views become more positive during Democratic presidencies (Obama) [1, 9, 8].  ![Republicans' view of economic conditions since Trump's election.](image4)

Overall, perceptions of job availability are divided along partisan lines, with Republicans generally holding more optimistic views compared to Democrats, and these perceptions are influenced by the prevailing political administration.

Public opinions on Wall Street's impact on the economy differ significantly along partisan lines [1]. Republicans are more inclined to believe that Wall Street helps the U.S. economy, with $55\%$ holding this view, compared to $31\%$ who think it hurts the economy [1]. In contrast, Democrats are more divided on the issue; $46\%$ feel Wall Street hurts the economy, while $41\%$ believe it helps [7].
![Republicans are more likely to say Wall Street helps the U.S. economy, while Democrats are more divided.](image3)
This divergence in opinion is also reflected in the overall satisfaction with the state of the nation. As of a recent survey, only $8\%$ of Democrats expressed satisfaction, whereas $90\%$ expressed dissatisfaction [2].  Republicans are more evenly split, with $47\%$ satisfied and $47\%$ dissatisfied [9].
![Democrats' satisfaction levels with the state of the nation have dropped significantly.](image2)
The overall public dissatisfaction is at $70\%$ [3].
![The graph illustrates public dissatisfaction with the way things are going in the country.](image1)
In summary, Republicans tend to view Wall Street more favorably and show higher, though recently declining, satisfaction with the nation, while Democrats are more critical of Wall Street and express greater dissatisfaction with the country's direction.

From 1990 to 2019, public satisfaction has fluctuated, with dissatisfaction reaching higher points [10]. Currently, a large majority of Americans are dissatisfied, as "seven-in-ten Americans now say they are dissatisfied with the way things are going in this country" [1].

Here is the trend of satisfaction levels from 1990 to 2019 shown in the image.

![Satisfaction levels from 1990 to 2019, showing the trend of public opinion regarding the state of the country.](image2)

Partisan lines significantly divide views on Wall Street's impact; "More Republicans say that on balance, Wall Street helps the economy more than it hurts it $(55\%$ vs. $31\%)$" [7]. Democrats are more split, with similar percentages believing Wall Street hurts $(46\%)$ or helps $(41\%)$ the economy [3].

Views on Wall Street's impact are divided along party lines.

![Views on Wall Street's impact on the economy are split along party lines.](image4)

The changes in satisfaction and political affiliation from 1990 to 2019 have reinforced partisan divisions regarding Wall Street's impact on the economy, with Republicans generally viewing Wall Street more positively than Democrats.

Republicans and Democrats have significantly different levels of confidence in Trump's ability to make good appointments to the federal courts, and this divergence is mirrored in other key areas.

Republicans generally express high confidence in Trump across various issues, but his ability to work effectively with Congress receives comparatively lower ratings [7, 8]. For instance, while most Republicans are confident in Trump on most issues, only 31% are very confident in his ability to work with Congress [8]. On the other hand, the public's confidence in Trump to handle key issues is mixed, with economic conditions receiving relatively higher confidence compared to working with Congress [10].

Confidence in Trump's abilities varies considerably depending on the specific issue. ![The chart shows the confidence level of the public on Trump's ability to handle various issues.](image1) As shown in the image, Trump's highest confidence ratings are for negotiating trade agreements, while his lowest ratings are for working effectively with Congress.

There are substantial partisan divisions in confidence levels. ![Republicans and Democrats have diverging confidence in Trump's ability to handle various issues.](image3) For example, 89% of Republicans are confident in Trump's ability to negotiate favorable trade agreements, compared to only 19% of Democrats [1].

Public confidence in Trump's ability to make good appointments to the federal courts is significantly divided along party lines, with Republicans expressing much higher confidence compared to Democrats, a pattern consistent across various other key issues.

Confidence in Trump's ability to separate his business interests varies significantly across political affiliations.  Among Republicans, a majority express confidence, while Democrats are largely skeptical [2, 10].  Specifically,  $55\%$ of Republicans are very confident, and $23\%$ are somewhat confident [10].  In stark contrast, $69\%$ of Democrats are not at all confident that Trump keeps his business interests and his presidential decisions separate, with an additional $20\%$ saying they are not too confident [2]. Liberal Democrats are even more skeptical, with $83\%$ expressing a lack of confidence [2].  This divide is visually represented in the distribution of confidence levels among different political groups. ![Democrats have less confidence that Trump keeps his business interests separate.](image3)

Furthermore, public opinion is divided on whether Trump has a responsibility to release his tax returns [3, 8]. Overall, $64\%$ of the public believes he should release his tax returns, while $32\%$ do not [8]. However, Republican views diverge significantly, with only $32\%$ thinking he has this responsibility, and $64\%$ believing he does not [3].
![Percentage of people who believe Trump should release his tax returns by party affiliation.](image4)

In summary, confidence levels in Trump's ability to separate business and presidential decisions, along with the perception of his responsibility to release tax returns, are deeply divided along political lines, with Republicans generally more supportive and Democrats more skeptical.

Partisan divides significantly influence perceptions of the COVID-19 response and trust in institutions, with Republicans and Democrats holding divergent views on various aspects of the pandemic [1, 6]. Democrats overwhelmingly believe the U.S. response was less effective compared to other wealthy countries, with 87% expressing this view ![Democrats believe that the U.S. response to COVID-19 has been less effective compared to other wealthy countries.](image1).

Republicans are far less critical, with only 34% considering the U.S. response less effective [1]. Only 22% of Republicans believe that the U.S. response has been more effective than that of other wealthy nations [1, 7]. This divergence extends to the assessment of public health officials; only 53% of Republicans rate the CDC's response positively, a significant drop from 84% in late March, while Democrats' positive ratings remain relatively stable at around 72% [4, 10].  ![Approval of public health officials' COVID-19 response has decreased among Republicans from March to August.](image5)

Partisan divides also affect how people interpret the rise in confirmed cases, with Democrats more likely to attribute it to rising infections rather than increased testing [3]. Geographic differences are less significant than partisan differences in these views [3]. Republicans living in less hard-hit areas are slightly less likely to attribute the increase in cases to more infections compared to those in harder-hit areas [8]. These partisan divides overshadow geographic differences, emphasizing the strong influence of political affiliation on perceptions of the pandemic [6].  Views of hospitals' response to COVID-19 are more consistent across party lines, but wider differences exist regarding opinions of other officials and Trump [5].

Partisan divides significantly shape perceptions of the COVID-19 response effectiveness and trust in institutions, with Democrats and Republicans exhibiting markedly different viewpoints on the U.S. response, public health officials, and the causes behind rising cases.

Partisan divisions significantly influenced how the public viewed the responses of public health officials and Donald Trump to the COVID-19 outbreak [1].

Democrats' views on public health officials remained largely stable, while Republicans' positive ratings declined sharply [2].

Specifically, the share of Republicans rating public health officials positively fell by 31 points, from 84% to 53% [2]. Conversely, Democrats' views remained consistent, at 74% in March and 72% currently [2].  ![Democrats have a more favorable view of public health officials than Republicans.](image3)

There is a clear partisan divide in the assessment of public health officials' response, with Democrats generally approving and Republicans showing significantly less approval [5]. In contrast, hospitals received positive ratings across party lines [4].

Views of Donald Trump's response to the outbreak also reveal a significant partisan divide [7].  ![Republicans are much more likely to approve of the job Trump is doing than Democrats.](image5)
The share of Democrats rating Trump's response as "poor" increased sharply, from 56% in March to 82% [9].  Republicans' approval of Trump's handling of the crisis also decreased since March [7].

In summary, partisan affiliation heavily shaped the perception of the COVID-19 responses by public health officials and Donald Trump, with Democrats maintaining more positive views of public health officials and increasingly negative views of Trump, while Republicans' approval declined for both.

In August, $63\%$ say public health officials are doing an excellent or good job in responding to the coronavirus outbreak, down from $79\%$ in March [1]. Most of this decline comes from Republicans [4].
![Views of public health officials have fallen from March to August.](image4)
In August, only about half of Republicans $(53\%)$ give CDC officials and other public health officials positive ratings for their response to the outbreak, 31 points lower than in late March $(84\%)$ [5]. Democrats' views are largely unchanged over that time period $(74\%$ in March, $72\%$ today) [5].
![Democrats approval of public health officials has remained largely constant, while republicans approval has decreased by more than 30%.](image3)
Trump's positive ratings for dealing with the coronavirus have fallen since March [6].
![Trump's rating has declined since March.](image4)
$37\%$ say he is doing an excellent or good job in responding to the coronavirus outbreak, while $63\%$ say he is doing only a fair or poor job [6]. The share of Democrats who rate Trump's response as "poor" has risen steeply since March, from $56\%$ to $82\%$ [8]. Republicans and Republican leaners have largely continued to approve of Trump’s performance [2]. As of now, $77\%$ of Republicans approve of Trump’s performance, and only $5\%$ of Democrats approve [2].
![Republicans overwhelmingly approve of Trump's performance, while Democrats overwhelmingly disapprove.](image5)
Approval ratings for public health officials and Donald Trump have decreased since March, with Republicans showing a greater decline in approval for public health officials, and Democrats increasingly disapproving of Trump's handling of the coronavirus.

Americans hold different views on the COVID-19 response by state governments compared to that of Donald Trump. While both have received negative assessments, the specifics and intensity of criticism vary.

Many U.S. adults (69%) are more concerned that state governments lifted restrictions too quickly, as opposed to 30% who feel they were too slow [2]. ![69% of U.S. adults are more concerned about states lifting restrictions too quickly.](image5)

Evaluations of state government officials' response have declined since March [10]. However, local hospitals and medical centers maintain overwhelmingly positive views [10]. This suggests a distinction in public perception between governmental actions and healthcare providers.

Assessments of Donald Trump's handling of the outbreak are broadly negative [3]. Nearly half of Americans (48%) rate Trump's response as "poor," which is up 16 points since March [4]. ![48% of Americans currently rate Trump’s response to the outbreak as “poor.”](image1)

In summary, while state governments face concern over the pace of lifting restrictions, Trump's response receives widespread negative ratings, highlighting a more critical view of his overall handling of the crisis.

Americans generally hold more positive views of local hospitals and medical centers than elected officials and public health officials, but public health officials are viewed more positively than elected officials. About six-in-ten Americans (62\%) say the U.S. response to the coronavirus outbreak has been less effective when compared with other wealthy countries [4]. Evaluations of state and local government officials have declined since March, while local hospitals and medical centers maintain overwhelmingly positive views [5].

![Americans give Donald Trump a poor rating for his handling of the coronavirus.](image4)

Views on the performance of public health officials have decreased from 79\% in March to 63\% [2]. This decline is primarily among Republicans, with only about half giving positive ratings, a 31-point decrease from late March [3]. In comparison, 72\% of Democrats rate public health officials positively, which is consistent with March [3].

![Most Americans think not enough people are practicing social distancing and mask-wearing which contributes to the continued outbreak.](image1)

A large majority (75\%) believe a major reason for the continued outbreak is that too few people are following social distancing and mask-wearing guidelines [8]. Democrats are more likely than Republicans to view the federal government's response as inadequate (82\% vs. 21\%) and to see the lifting of COVID-19 restrictions too quickly as a major factor (82\% vs. 31\%) [9].

Overall, Americans perceive public health officials more positively than elected officials, but negative views have increased, particularly among Republicans, and the lack of adherence to guidelines is viewed as a major contributing factor to the continued outbreak.

Political affiliation significantly shapes perceptions of government responsibility during the COVID-19 pandemic, as well as the reasons cited for the outbreak's continuation [4]. Republicans and Democrats hold contrasting views on whether the federal government or state and local governments should be primarily responsible for policies to limit the spread of COVID-19 [4]. `![Democrats are more inclined to believe that the federal government should bear most of the responsibility, while Republicans think state and local governments should.](image4)` Overall, the public is almost evenly divided, with 51% saying states should be primarily responsible and 48% believing the federal government should be [9]. However, 68% of Republicans favor state and local control, while 64% of Democrats prefer federal oversight [9].

Major reasons for the continued outbreak also vary along partisan lines.  Democrats are more likely than Republicans to say most of these factors are major reasons the outbreak has continued [5].
![Democrats are more concerned about the federal government's inadequate response and premature lifting of COVID-19 restrictions compared to Republicans.](image5) The most significant partisan differences lie in perceptions of the federal government's response and the speed of lifting COVID-19 restrictions [5]. Specifically, 82% of Democrats view the federal government's response as inadequate, compared to only 21% of Republicans [5]. Similarly, 82% of Democrats believe restrictions were lifted too quickly, versus 31% of Republicans [5].

Insufficient social distancing and mask-wearing is identified as a major reason for the continued outbreak by most Americans [1]. `![A majority of those surveyed believe that insufficient social distancing and mask-wearing is a major reason why the coronavirus outbreak has continued.](image1)` About nine-in-ten Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents say insufficient adherence to social-distancing and mask-wearing guidelines is a major reason for the continued coronavirus outbreak [3]. This reason also tops the list among Republicans and GOP leaners of the six asked about in the survey, though a narrower majority (57%) considers this a major reason for the continued spread of the virus [3].

Political affiliations strongly influence perceptions of government responsibility and the perceived reasons for the ongoing COVID-19 outbreak, with Democrats more critical of the federal response and Republicans emphasizing state and local control.

Democrats and Republicans diverge significantly on the reasons for the continued COVID-19 outbreak, especially concerning the federal government's response and adherence to social distancing guidelines [5]. Democrats are far more critical of the federal government's response, while both groups acknowledge the impact of insufficient social distancing.

Most Americans cite insufficient social distancing as a major reason COVID-19 outbreak has continued [3]. Three-quarters of Americans agree that "not enough people following social distancing and mask-wearing guidelines" is a major factor [6]. ![Seventy-five percent of all respondents believe not enough people social distancing and mask-wearing is a major reason for the continuation of the coronavirus outbreak.](image4)

There's a significant partisan divide regarding the adequacy of the federal government's response [5]. A large majority of Democrats, 82%, view the federal response as a major reason for the continued outbreak, compared to only 21% of Republicans [5]. This is further highlighted by the fact that nearly half (45%) of Republicans believe the federal response is not a reason for the continuation [9]. ![Democrats are significantly more likely than Republicans to say that the federal government's response is a major reason for the continuation of the outbreak.](image5)

Both Democrats and Republicans largely agree that insufficient adherence to social distancing and mask-wearing is a major reason for the continued coronavirus outbreak [7]. This reason tops the list for both groups, although a narrower majority of Republicans (57%) consider this a major reason compared to Democrats (about nine-in-ten) [7].

Political affiliations significantly influence perceptions of the reasons for the continuation of the COVID-19 outbreak, with Democrats emphasizing the federal government's inadequate response and Republicans focusing on individual adherence to social distancing guidelines.

Democrats are significantly more critical of the federal government's response to COVID-19 compared to Republicans [1, 3]. According to Democrats, major reasons for the outbreak's continuation include an inadequate federal response and the premature lifting of COVID-19 restrictions [3, 4].  Republicans are less likely to view these factors as major reasons; for example, only 21% of Republicans consider the federal response inadequate, while 82% of Democrats do [3].

![Democrats are more likely than Republicans to view inadequate federal government response as a major reason for the continuation of COVID-19 outbreak](image1)

Overall, a majority of Americans (53%) believe an inadequate federal government response is a major reason for the outbreak's continuation [5]. Insufficient social distancing and mask-wearing are also widely recognized as significant factors across party lines [7, 8]. The public also cites a lack of timely testing and unclear instructions for preventing the spread as major reasons for the continued outbreak [5].

![Most Americans view inadequate social distancing and mask-wearing as a major reason for the continuation of the COVID-19 outbreak](image5)

In summary, Democrats and Republicans differ significantly on whether the federal government's response and the easing of restrictions contributed to the continuation of the COVID-19 outbreak, while the general public identifies inadequate federal response, insufficient testing, unclear guidelines, and lack of social distancing as major contributing factors.

Partisan beliefs significantly diverge on the reasons for the continuation of the COVID-19 outbreak. Republicans are more inclined to attribute the continuation of the outbreak to factors such as the impossibility of controlling the spread [3]. Democrats are more critical of the federal government's response, as "82% of Democrats view this as a major reason the outbreak has continued, compared with 21% of Republicans" [7].

The views on easing restrictions also differ substantially, where "82% of Democrats point to some places being too quick to ease restrictions as a major reason for the outbreak continuing, while just 31% of Republicans say this" [5].

Views on whether an inadequate federal response is a major reason for the outbreak also diverge sharply as shown in the below image.
![Democrats are far more likely than Republicans to consider the federal response as a major reason for the continuation of the outbreak.](image3)

There is also a notable split regarding the role of testing in the increase of confirmed cases. A "62% majority of Republicans say that 'the increase in confirmed coronavirus cases is primarily a result of more people being tested than in previous months'" [6]. This contrasts with the general American view, where "most Americans attribute the rise in confirmed coronavirus cases more to rising infections than to a rise in testing" [8]. The image below highlights the partisan split.
![There is a significant partisan divide on whether increased testing or infections are the primary reason for the increase in confirmed coronavirus cases.](image4)

Partisan beliefs differ significantly, with Democrats emphasizing the role of the federal response and premature easing of restrictions, while Republicans focus on factors like testing and the perceived limitations of controlling the virus.

Democrats and Republicans diverge significantly on the reasons for rising coronavirus cases [7]. Democrats overwhelmingly attribute the rise in cases primarily to more infections, while a majority of Republicans believe it's due to increased testing [7].

There is a wide partisan divide as most Americans attribute the rise in confirmed coronavirus cases more to rising infections than to a rise in testing [10].
![Most Americans attribute the rise in confirmed coronavirus cases more to rising infections than to a rise in testing, with a wide partisan divide in these views.](image1)

Regarding the lifting of restrictions, Democrats are more concerned that state restrictions on public activity have been lifted too quickly [1]. In contrast, Republicans are more divided, with slightly more concerned that restrictions haven't been lifted quickly enough [8].
![Democrats are more concerned that state restrictions on public activity have been lifted too quickly while Republicans are more concerned that restrictions have not been lifted quickly enough.](image2)

The partisan gap is widest on two other reasons, and restrictions have been lifted too quickly in some places [9]. And while 82% of Democrats point to some places being too quick to ease restrictions as a major reason for the outbreak continuing, while just 31% of Republicans say this [9].
![Democrats are more concerned that the restrictions have been lifted too quickly while Republicans are not.](image5)

Political affiliations significantly shape perspectives on the reasons for rising COVID-19 cases and the appropriateness of lifting restrictions, with Democrats attributing the rise to infections and expressing concern over rapid restriction lifts, while Republicans lean towards increased testing as the cause and are more inclined to believe restrictions are not being lifted quickly enough.

Democrats are more likely to attribute the increase in coronavirus cases to new infections, while Republicans attribute it to increased testing [9]. This difference in perception is connected to their views on state restrictions, where Democrats are more concerned about the restrictions being lifted too quickly [2], and Republicans are more divided, with a considerable percentage feeling they have not been lifted quickly enough [1].

Views on lifting restrictions are strongly tied to political affiliation, as evidenced by differing concerns among Democrats and Republicans. Overwhelming shares of Democrats are concerned that state restrictions on public activity have been lifted too quickly [2]. Conversely, Republicans are divided, with a notable portion wanting restrictions lifted more rapidly [1]. This divergence extends to perceptions of the outbreak's continuation, where Democrats are more likely to blame the rapid easing of restrictions [3].
![Democrats overwhelmingly attribute the rise in coronavirus cases primarily to more infections, while Republicans attribute it to increased testing.](image5)
The reasons for the continued outbreak are also viewed differently, as shown in image3; Democrats are more likely to consider the rapid lifting of COVID-19 restrictions as a major reason, while Republicans are less likely to agree ![Democrats are more likely than Republicans to view lifting COVID-19 restrictions too quickly as a major reason for the outbreak's continuation.](image3).
This divide highlights the partisan gap in how the pandemic is perceived and managed, influencing opinions on the appropriate pace of lifting restrictions.
![Most Americans are more concerned that state governments have been lifting restrictions too quickly.](image4)
Overall, most Americans are more concerned that state governments have been lifting restrictions too quickly [8].

The perceived cause of increased COVID-19 cases is related to opinions on lifting restrictions, with Democrats attributing the rise to infections and favoring slower restriction lifting, while Republicans lean towards increased testing as the cause and express more varied opinions on the pace of restriction removal.

Views on requiring government-issued photo identification vary across different racial groups and political affiliations [1].
![Government-issued photo identification support among Democrats](image2)
While a narrow majority of White Democrats (54%) favor requiring voters to show government-issued photo identification to vote, larger shares of Black (65%), Hispanic (72%) and Asian Democrats (71%) say the same [2].
![Government-issued photo identification support among Republicans](image3)
Republicans overwhelmingly support this policy (93%) [3]. Black adults also show among the lowest levels of support for restrictive policies such as requiring voters to show government-issued photo identification [8].
![Support for showing photo ID to vote across racial groups](image5)
Overall, racial and ethnic groups have different preferences regarding the requirement of government-issued photo identification for voting, with Republicans showing more consistent support compared to Democrats [1].

Racial and ethnic differences significantly influence support for various voting policies [3].
For example, while a narrow majority of White Democrats (54%) favor requiring voters to show government-issued photo identification to vote, larger shares of Black (65%), Hispanic (72%) and Asian Democrats (71%) say the same [2].
![Democrats Favoring Photo ID](image5)
Black adults are among the least supportive of restrictive policies like removing people from registration lists if they haven’t recently voted or requiring government-issued photo identification [4].
Black adults are more likely to favor 'no excuse' early, absentee voting [1].
![Support for Early or Absentee Voting](image3)
Additionally, White Democrats are more supportive of allowing early or absentee voting compared to Democrats of other races and ethnicities, while the opposite holds true for White Republicans compared to Hispanic Republicans [10].
Racial and ethnic backgrounds correlate with differing levels of support for various voting policies, with Black adults generally favoring more expansive policies and White Democrats showing greater support for early voting compared to other racial groups within the Democratic Party.

Racial and political affiliations significantly influence perspectives on voting policies, particularly regarding photo identification requirements and voting accessibility.

White Democrats show less support for requiring government-issued photo identification compared to Black, Hispanic, and Asian Democrats [6]. The image shows the majority of Black (65%), Hispanic (72%) and Asian Democrats (71%) support photo identification requirements, while White Democrats support is at 54%.

Republicans are much more likely than Democrats to strongly favor photo identification requirements for voting [9]. The image shows that 81% of Republicans strongly favor photo identification requirements compared to 30% of Democrats.

![Republicans more strongly favor photo identification requirements compared to democrats.](image2)

There are substantial racial and ethnic differences in support for voting policies [8]. Black adults are more likely to favor allowing people convicted of felonies to vote after serving their sentences [7]. Image3 indicates the percentage of each race that supports allowing people convicted of felonies to vote after serving their sentences.

![Black adults are more in favor of allowing convicted felons to vote after serving their time.](image3)

White Democrats are more supportive of allowing all voters to vote early or absentee than are Democrats of other races and ethnicities [2].

Views on government-issued photo identification requirements and voting accessibility policies are significantly shaped by racial and political affiliations.

The attitudes toward independent redistricting and early absentee voting vary significantly across political and demographic groups.
For the redistricting proposal, nearly half of U.S. adults approve the proposal by House Democrats that would require states to put together redistricting commissions composed of equal numbers of Democrats and Republicans to draw their congressional maps [8]. ![Democrats are more likely to approve of independent redistricting commissions.](image2) Just $13\%$ disapprove of this proposal, while $38\%$ say they are unsure about it [8]. While $59\%$ of Democrats approve of the redistricting proposal, only $38\%$ of Republicans approve the redistricting proposal [8].

Regarding early or absentee voting, partisanship is a key factor in attitudes, with only $38\%$ of Republicans favoring allowing all voters to vote early or absentee [3]. However, Republicans who voted absentee in 2020 are more supportive of no-excuse absentee or early voting [1]. ![Most demographics support options for early absentee voting.](image1) White Democrats show more support for early/absentee voting than Democrats of other races, while the opposite is true for White Republicans compared to Hispanic Republicans [2]. Conservative Republicans are more likely to say voters should provide documented reasons for absentee or early voting $\left(70\%\right)$ than to say it should not be necessary $\left(30\%\right)$ [9].  As shown in image1, $63\%$ of total adults say any voter should have the option to vote early or absentee [6].

In summary, Democrats and most demographic groups generally favor both independent redistricting commissions and no-excuse early/absentee voting, while Republicans are more divided, with conservatives and those who voted in person on election day being less supportive.

According to the data, there are notable differences in how different political affiliations view voting methods and redistricting proposals.
Specifically, Republicans and Republican leaners are more likely to disapprove of non-legislative commissions for redistricting compared to Democrats [8]. However, they are also more likely to be unsure about it, as indicated by the higher percentage of Republicans who say they are not sure either way (42% vs. 32%) [8]. This is further illustrated in ![Republicans/lean Republicans, Democrats/lean Democrats, and the total population view on a proposal that would require all states to  put together committees with equal numbers of  Democrats and Republicans who would be responsible  for determining the state’s congressional maps](image5), which shows that 38% of Republicans/lean Republicans approve of a proposal for committees with equal numbers of Democrats and Republicans determining congressional maps, compared to 59% of Democrats/lean Democrats.

Regarding voting methods, Republicans who voted early or absentee in November are more likely to favor no-excuse absentee or early voting [2]. ![Support for ‘no excuse’ absentee or early voting is more prevalent among Republicans who voted absentee in the 2020 election](image3) clearly demonstrates this, showing that 52% of Republicans/lean Republicans who voted absentee favor no-excuse absentee voting, while only 22% of those who voted in person on Election Day hold the same view. Furthermore, conservative Republicans are more likely to say that voters should be required to provide documented reasons for voting absentee or early compared to moderate and liberal Republicans [9]. ![Support for "any voter should have the option to vote early or absentee" is divided between those who believe a documented reason should be provided](image4) indicating that 70% of conservative Republicans believe a voter should only be allowed to vote early or absentee if they have a documented reason, compared to 49% of moderate/liberal Republicans.

In summary, Republicans are more divided on redistricting and voting methods compared to Democrats, with conservative Republicans favoring stricter voting requirements and less support for non-legislative redistricting commissions.

In recent years, there's been a notable divergence in the views of Republicans and Democrats concerning certain voting policies. Democrats have largely maintained their stance, whereas Republicans' opinions have shifted, particularly on the issue of early or absentee voting [1].
![Democrats favor automatically registering all eligible citizens to vote](image5)
Democrats consistently support automatically registering all eligible citizens to vote, with about 82% in favor [1, 5]. Conversely, support among Republicans for automatically registering all eligible citizens has decreased from 49% in 2018 to 38% in 2021 [7].
![Support among Republicans for no-excuse early voting has declined](image2)
Regarding "no excuse" early or absentee voting, Republicans have become significantly less supportive, as the share of Republicans who say any voter should be allowed to vote early or absentee without a documented reason has fallen 19 percentage points, from 57% to 38% [5]. Democrats, on the other hand, remain highly supportive of no-excuse early voting, with about 84% in favor, and their views have remained virtually unchanged in recent years [5].

In summary, Democrats' views on 'no excuse' early or absentee voting and automatically registering all eligible citizens to vote have remained stable, while Republicans have shown a decline in support for these policies since 2018.

In 2021, Democrats were more likely to favor making Election Day a national holiday compared to 2018, while Republican views remained relatively stable [1].
![Support for making Election Day a national holiday increased among Democrats from October 2018 to April 2021.](image2)
The image illustrates that Democratic support for making Election Day a national holiday rose from 71% in October 2018 to 78% in April 2021, while Republican support saw a slight decrease from 65% to 59%.

There has been little change in views on requiring photo ID to vote since 2018, with Republicans continuing to overwhelmingly support this policy [6].
![Republican support for photo ID requirements remained high from October 2018 to April 2021.](image2)
The image indicates that Republican support for requiring photo ID at the polls was at 91% in October 2018 and rose to 93% in April 2021.

Overall, Democratic support for making Election Day a holiday increased, while Republican support for photo ID requirements remained high between 2018 and 2021.

In recent years, Latino voters have predominantly leaned towards the Democratic Party, but their future party affiliation remains uncertain, and certain issues have grown in importance [2, 3]. Latino registered voters identify more with the Democratic Party than the Republican Party, with 64% leaning Democratic compared to 33% leaning Republican in 2022; this has remained relatively stable over the past few years ![Party identification among Latino registered voters](image2).

The economy remains the top issue for Latino voters, with 80% considering it very important [10]. Other significant issues include healthcare (71%), violent crime and education (70% each), and gun policy (66%) [10]. Abortion has significantly increased in importance, with 57% of Hispanic voters considering it very important in August 2022, up from 42% in March, following the Supreme Court's decision to end the federal guarantee of a right to legal abortion [8]. ![The importance of abortion among Latino voters has increased from March to August 2022](image3).

Preferences vary based on demographic factors, such as the importance of Hispanic identity; most Hispanics who consider their Hispanic identity extremely or very important (60%) would vote for the Democratic candidate [7]. In the 2022 congressional elections, 53% of Latino registered voters said they would vote for the Democratic candidate, while 28% would vote for the Republican candidate [9]. ![Vote choice among Latino registered voters](image4). However, some Latino voters are open to supporting another presidential candidate who shares their views, rather than having their own candidate run for president ![Latino registered voters' presidential candidate preference](image1).

In summary, while Latino voters predominantly lean Democratic, their party affiliation is not entirely fixed, with the economy and healthcare consistently ranking high in importance, and abortion rising significantly as a key issue, especially after the Supreme Court's decision.

Hispanic Democrats and Republicans diverge significantly on the future political role of Donald Trump and the perception of racial discrimination. Most Hispanic Democrats do not want to see Trump remain a national political figure, while most Republicans do [7].
![Hispanic registered voters opposed to Trump remaining a national political figure](image4)
A notable  $94\%$ of Latino Democrats and Democratic leaners do not want to see Trump remain a national political figure [7]. In contrast, $63\%$ of Hispanic Republicans and GOP leaners wish to see Trump remain a national political figure [7].  Regarding racial discrimination, opinions diverge along party lines as well [1].
![Views on racial discrimination among Latinos differ among party lines](image5)
$73\%$ of Latino Democrats and Democratic leaners consider the lack of recognition of racial discrimination as a significant issue, while $62\%$ of Republicans and Republican leaners believe that people seeing racial discrimination where it does not exist is a more significant problem [1].

In summary, Hispanic Democrats largely oppose Trump's continued political presence and recognize racial discrimination as a significant issue, while a majority of Hispanic Republicans support Trump's role and are more concerned about perceived false accusations of racial discrimination.

Hispanic registered voters are divided on whether Donald Trump should remain a national political figure, and this division correlates with their views on racial discrimination and gun rights [3]. A significant majority of Hispanic registered voters, $73\%$, do not want Trump to remain a national political figure [6, 8]. However, this sentiment is heavily influenced by party affiliation, with $94\%$ of Latino Democratic voters holding this view [8].

Conversely, $63\%$ of Hispanic Republicans would like to see Trump remain a national political figure [6].  Of these, $41\%$ believe he should run for president in 2024 [6].  ![Hispanic Republicans are more likely to support Trump remaining a national political figure.](image4)

The views on racial discrimination also play a role, as more Democrats than Republicans within the Latino community believe that people not seeing racial discrimination is a big problem [9].  This aligns with the broader discussion about race and equality following George Floyd’s killing [10].  ![Latino democrats are more likely to see racial discrimination as a problem.](image5)

When it comes to gun policy, about seven-in-ten Hispanics (73%) prioritize controlling gun ownership [7].  However, Hispanic Democrats are about twice as likely as Hispanic Republicans to prioritize controlling gun ownership (85% vs. 45%) [7]. ![Most Hispanics prioritize controlling gun ownership.](image3)

In summary, Hispanic registered voters' views on Trump's political future are strongly linked to their political party affiliation and are further influenced by their perspectives on racial discrimination and gun control.

Hispanic Republicans and Democrats diverge significantly on Trump's political future and racial discrimination perceptions. According to the survey, a clear majority of Hispanic registered voters $(73\%)$ say they would not like to see Trump remain a national political figure [6]. However, this view is heavily influenced by party affiliation.  Nearly all Latino Democrats and Democratic leaners $(94\%)$ do not want Trump to remain a national political figure, while $63\%$ of Hispanic Republicans and GOP leaners would like to see him remain a national political figure [6].
![Hispanic voters are largely against Trump remaining a national political figure, but Republican leaners are more open to it.](image5)
This image shows that 73% of Hispanic registered voters do not want Trump to remain a national political figure, with a stark contrast between Democratic leaners (94%) and Republican leaners (35%).

Regarding racial discrimination, there is also a notable divide. The survey indicates that among Latinos, more Democrats than Republicans say people not seeing racial discrimination is a big problem [5].  Nearly three-quarters of Latino Democrats and Democratic leaners $(73\%)$ say people not seeing racial discrimination where it really does exist is a bigger problem [10]. Conversely, about six-in-ten Republicans and Republican leaners $(62\%)$ say it is a bigger problem that people see racial discrimination where it really does not exist [10].
![There is a perception gap on racial discrimination, with most Latinos feeling people do not see racial discrimination where it exists.](image2)
The graphic illustrates that 61% of all Latinos feel that people do not see racial discrimination where it exists, while 35% think people see it where it does not.

In summary, Hispanic Democrats overwhelmingly oppose Trump's continued political presence and perceive a significant issue with people overlooking racial discrimination, while a majority of Hispanic Republicans support Trump remaining a political figure and believe that people often misinterpret situations as racial discrimination when it is not.

Hispanic perceptions of socialism and capitalism differ significantly based on political affiliation [1, 8]. While Hispanic Democrats are split, Hispanic Republicans tend to view capitalism more favorably [1].

For socialism, the division is evident with age, where younger Hispanics (18-29) are more open to socialism compared to older Hispanics (50+) who view it negatively [5, 6]. ![Hispanics' views of socialism and capitalism vary by age groups, with younger adults having a more positive impression of socialism compared to older adults.](image5)

Specifically, among Hispanic Democrats and Democratic leaners, views on socialism are divided, with 48% having a negative view and 50% a positive view [8]. In contrast, a larger share of Hispanic Republicans and Republican leaners (68%) have a positive view of capitalism, compared to Hispanic Democrats and Democratic leaners (50%) [1]. This is visually supported in the provided chart, which shows a higher percentage of Hispanic Republicans having a positive view of capitalism. ![Hispanic Republicans are more likely to have a positive view of capitalism compared to Hispanic Democrats.](image3)

Hispanic perceptions of socialism and capitalism are significantly influenced by both political affiliation and age.

Hispanic Democrats and Democratic leaners are split on how they view socialism, with 48% having negative views versus 50% having positive views [4]. By contrast, Hispanic Republicans and Republican leaners have a largely positive view of capitalism (68%), which is a greater share than among Hispanic Democrats and Democratic leaners (50%) [6].
![Hispanic Democrats/lean Democratic views on socialism is 50% positive and 48% negative.]()
Also, a larger share of Hispanics have a negative than positive impression of socialism (53% vs. 41%), but they have a more positive than negative view of capitalism (54% vs. 41%) [5].
![All Hispanics views on socialism is 41% positive and on capitalism is 54% positive.](image1)
Hispanics' views on socialism and capitalism vary significantly based on their political affiliations [3].

Among Latinos, there are varying views on whether political parties work hard to earn their votes.
![The chart displays the percentage of Latinos who say Democrats work hard to earn Latino votes across different demographic groups.](image5)
Looking at which party is working hard to earn the Latino votes, substantial shares of immigrants, Spanish speakers, Catholics, and evangelicals agree that Democrats work hard to earn Latinos' votes [2, 9].  For example, 44% of Latino immigrants believe Democrats work hard to earn their votes.  And a substantial share of Latino Republican and Republican-leaning conservatives say that Republicans work hard to earn Latinos’ votes [7]. However, relatively few Latinos believe Republicans try hard to earn their vote [3].
![The chart shows the percentage of Latinos who say Republicans work hard to earn Latino votes across various demographic groups.](image1)
Smaller shares of Latinos feel that Republicans work hard to earn their votes, including about a quarter of immigrants, Spanish-dominant Latinos, evangelicals, those ages 50 to 64, and those ages 65 or older [6]. Overall, these differing perceptions highlight the complex political landscape within the Latino community, with views varying significantly across different demographic and political affiliations.

Hispanic Republicans are more inclined to believe that the Democratic Party works hard to earn Latino votes, while only about a third of Hispanic Democrats feel the same about the Republican Party [1]. Specifically, $56\%$ of Hispanic Republicans and Republican leaners think the statement "the Democratic Party works hard to earn Latinos' votes" describes their views at least somewhat well [1]. Conversely, only $35\%$ of Hispanic Democrats and Democratic leaners believe that "the Republican Party works hard to earn Latinos' votes" describes their views at least somewhat well [1]. ![Republicans are more likely to think the Democratic Party works hard to earn Latino votes than Democrats are to think the same of the Republican Party.](image5)

Despite these differing perceptions, the partisan alignment among Latino registered voters has remained relatively stable, with a nearly two-to-one preference for the Democratic Party over the Republican Party (${\it64\%}$ vs. $33\%$) [2]. This trend has shown little change over the past few years [2]. ![Latino voters' party affiliation has remained relatively stable over the past few years, with a higher percentage leaning towards the Democratic Party.](image2)

Furthermore, a significant portion of Hispanics do not perceive a substantial difference between the Democratic and Republican parties [5].  About half of Hispanics see a great deal of difference between the parties [5]. A considerable number of Hispanic partisans hold at least a somewhat favorable view of the opposing party [6].  For example, a third of Latino Republicans and GOP leaners ($36\%$) think "the Democratic Party really cares about Latinos" describes their views at least somewhat well, while $21\%$ of Latino Democrats and Democratic leaners think "the Republican Party really cares about Latinos" describes their views at least somewhat well [8]. This indicates a level of openness and potential fluidity in party affiliation among Latino voters [4].

The perceptions of the Democratic and Republican parties' efforts to engage with Latino voters differ among different political affiliations, but the overall party affiliation trends have remained relatively stable in recent years.

Hispanics' perceptions of party differences and support for political parties vary over time and by political affiliation. Fewer than half of Hispanics perceive a great deal of difference between the Democratic and Republican parties [1].  The survey showed that $45\%$ see a great deal of difference between the parties [6]. `![The image shows the percentage of Hispanics who perceive differences between the Democratic and Republican parties.](image5)`

Latino registered voters tend to identify more with the Democratic Party than the Republican Party, with a nearly two-to-one margin [8]. Latino party identification has shown little shift over the past few years [8].  ![This image shows party affiliation among Latino voters from 2019 to 2022.](image2) The Democratic Party is viewed more positively by Hispanics, with majorities believing the Democratic Party represents their interests well across various demographic groups [5].  ![This image shows that the Democratic Party is more likely to be seen as caring about and working for Latinos' votes compared to the Republican Party.](image4)

Views on whether each party "really cares about Latinos" vary significantly between Democrats and Republicans.   The image demonstrates that 78% of Hispanic Democrats/Lean Democrats believe the Democratic Party "really cares about Latinos," while only 21% think the Republican Party does [image1].

Therefore, while a large number of Hispanics view the Democratic Party more favorably, a large number do not see a significant difference between the two parties, and party affiliation has remained relatively stable in recent years.

About half of Hispanics do not see a great deal of difference between the Democratic and Republican parties [1].  In fact, $36\%$ say there is a fair amount of difference and $16\%$ saying there is hardly any difference at all between the parties [1]. Meanwhile, $45\%$ see a great deal of difference between the parties [1]. ![About half of Hispanics see at least a fair amount of difference between the Democratic and Republican parties.](image1)

Even so, Latino registered voters’ future party affiliation remains uncertain [10].  A 2021 Pew Research Center study  of  Americans’ political views found substantial shares of Latino voters fell into groups with soft ties to the political parties [10]. For example, roughly one-in-ten Latino voters who identified as either a Democrat [10]. ![Latino party affiliation has remained relatively stable in recent years.](image2)

The views of Latino voters regarding the differences between the Democratic and Republican parties are mixed, and their future party affiliation remains uncertain due to soft ties to political parties [1, 10].

Most Americans consider STEM jobs as attracting top talent and having better compensation compared to other industries [3, 1]. However, when it comes to balancing work and family, only a few think STEM jobs provide more flexibility [5].

While flexibility is important to both men and women, they diverge on other job characteristics [9]. ![Men in STEM jobs value opportunities for promotion and high pay more than women in STEM jobs.](image1) A higher percentage of men prioritize high pay and promotion opportunities, whereas women are more inclined towards jobs focused on helping others [9].  As shown in the image, 59% of men in STEM value having a high-paying job, compared to 48% of women, and 57% of men value opportunities for promotion, compared to 46% of women in STEM [9].

Men in STEM jobs are more likely to prioritize higher pay and promotion opportunities, while women in STEM jobs are more inclined to value jobs focused on helping others.

Men and women in STEM share some similar job preferences, such as the need for flexibility [1]. However, there are notable differences. Women in STEM place a higher value on jobs that help others, with 59% considering it important compared to 31% of men [1, 7].
![Women in STEM value having a job focused on helping others more than men.](image4)
While men prioritize higher pay and opportunities for promotion, women are more inclined to seek jobs that allow them to make a meaningful contribution to society [7]. This divergence in priorities can influence career choices and job satisfaction.

One of the major reasons for underrepresentation is discrimination; About half of women in STEM jobs (48%) say gender discrimination in recruitment, hiring and promotions is a major reason there are not more women in STEM jobs, compared with 29% of men in STEM jobs [10].
![Reasons for women's underrepresentation in STEM.](image3)
These differences in values and the perception of discrimination contribute to the challenges women face in STEM. Women in STEM jobs are much more likely than men in such jobs to say they have experienced discrimination at work because of their gender [3]. Many Americans attribute the limited diversity of the STEM workforce to a lack of encouragement for girls to pursue STEM from an early age [5].

In summary, while both men and women in STEM value job flexibility, women prioritize roles that are helpful and contribute meaningfully to society, and the experience of gender discrimination makes it harder for them to succeed at work.

The underrepresentation of women, blacks, and Hispanics in STEM jobs is attributed to a combination of factors, including discrimination, lack of encouragement, and limited access to quality education [1, 6, 10]. However, the perceived importance of these factors varies among different groups.

One major reason for underrepresentation is discrimination in recruitment, hiring, and promotions.
![Discrimination in recruitment, hiring, and promotion is a major reason for underrepresentation of women, blacks, and Hispanics in STEM jobs.](image1)
According to the survey, $39\%$ of U.S. adults believe that women face discrimination in recruitment, hiring, and promotions, which is a major reason for the lack of gender diversity in STEM [2].
In contrast, a higher percentage of Americans consider limited access to quality education a significant barrier for blacks and Hispanics [9].
$42\%$ of Americans say limited access to quality education to prepare them for these fields is a major reason blacks and Hispanics are underrepresented in the STEM workforce [9].
Additionally, $72\%$ of blacks in STEM jobs believe that discrimination is a major reason for the underrepresentation of blacks and Hispanics, compared to only $27\%$ of whites and $28\%$ of Asians [5, 8].

Lack of encouragement to pursue STEM from an early age is another factor [6]. A significant percentage of Americans believe that a lack of encouragement for girls and blacks and Hispanics to pursue STEM from an early age contributes to their underrepresentation [6].
In summary, while discrimination is a significant concern for women in STEM, limited access to quality education and a general lack of encouragement are seen as major barriers for blacks and Hispanics.

STEM workers tend to have higher levels of education than non-STEM workers, with 65% holding at least a bachelor’s degree compared to 32% of non-STEM workers [7]. Furthermore, about three-in-ten STEM workers have a postgraduate degree [6].

![STEM employed individuals have higher education levels, with 29% holding a postgraduate degree, compared to non-STEM employed, with 12%.](image2)

Most STEM workers are employed in the private, for-profit sector (66%), similar to the share of all employed adults [8]. However, there are differences across specific STEM fields; for example, engineers and architects (82%) and computer workers (77%) are among the most likely to work for private employers [8]. In contrast, fewer healthcare practitioners and technicians work in the private, for-profit sector (58%), with almost a quarter (23%) working for not-for-profit employers [8]. Workers in social science occupations and postsecondary education jobs, by contrast, are more likely to work in government and non-profit organizations [10].

![STEM jobs are predominantly in the private sector, but this varies across specific STEM fields like engineering and healthcare.](image4)

STEM-employed individuals generally have higher education levels and are primarily employed in the private sector, while non-STEM-employed individuals have lower education levels and are distributed differently across employment sectors.

STEM workers generally have higher levels of education compared to non-STEM workers [6]. STEM jobs have relatively high earnings compared with many non-STEM jobs [5].
![STEM employed have a higher percentage with a bachelor's degree, postgraduate degree, and some college compared to non-STEM employed.](image2)
Overall, STEM workers are about twice as likely as those in non-STEM occupations to have earned at least a bachelor’s degree (65% vs. 32%) [6]. Roughly three-in-ten STEM workers (29%) have earned a master’s, doctorate, or professional degree, far exceeding the share of non-STEM workers with advanced degrees (12%) [6]. Some 36% of STEM workers have a bachelor’s degree (but no postgraduate degree) compared with 21% of non-STEM workers [6].
![Most of the all employed, STEM jobs and Non-STEM jobs work for a private, for-profit sector.](image3)
Most STEM workers work for a private, for-profit employer [4]. The share – 66% – is substantively identical to the share of all employed adults [4]. The representation of women, blacks and Hispanics holds pocketbook implications for workers [5]. Although women have made gains in representation in the STEM workforce over the past roughly 25 years, particularly in life and physical science jobs, they remain strongly underrepresented in some STEM job clusters, notably computer jobs and engineering [10].
![The number of female computer and engineering jobs have changed from 1990 to 2016.](image1)
While women's representation in computer jobs has decreased from 32% in 1990 to 25% in 2016, it has increased in engineering from 12% in 1990 to 14% in 2016 [10].

STEM workers typically have higher educational attainment than non-STEM workers and primarily work in the private sector, although representation in specific STEM fields like computer jobs and engineering have varied over time.

Black STEM employees are significantly more likely to report experiences of discrimination at work compared to other racial and ethnic groups [3, 5]. A higher share of blacks in STEM jobs report experiencing racial/ethnic discrimination (62%) than Asians (44%), Hispanics (42%), and whites (13%) [5, 7, 10].
![Black STEM workers are more likely to experience discrimination.](image5)
In comparison, gender-based discrimination also affects a significant portion of women in STEM, with half (50%) reporting they have experienced some form of discrimination due to their gender [6]. This rate is notably higher than that of men in STEM (19%) [6]. The most common forms of gender discrimination experienced by women in STEM jobs include earning less than a man doing the same job (29%), being treated as if they were not competent (29%), and experiencing repeated small slights in their workplace (20%) [6].  In computer jobs, 74% of women have experienced gender-related discrimination at work compared to 16% of men in computer jobs. ![Women in computer jobs experience much more gender-related discrimination.](image3)
The experiences of discrimination vary significantly across racial and ethnic groups, with Black STEM employees reporting the highest rates, while women in STEM also face substantial gender-based discrimination, exceeding the experiences of men in the field.

Women in STEM jobs, especially those in male-dominated workplaces, face significant challenges related to gender discrimination and inequities [2, 6].
![Women in STEM jobs in mostly male workplaces reported the highest percentage of gender discrimination experiences.](image1)
Women in STEM are more likely than men to report workplace discrimination due to their gender, with half of women in STEM jobs experiencing at least eight forms of discrimination [9].
In majority-male workplaces, about half of women in STEM feel their gender hinders their success [4].
![Women in STEM in more male workplaces feel the need to prove themselves.](image4)
Women in STEM jobs working in majority-male workplaces are significantly more likely to report gender-related discrimination and to believe their gender has made it harder to succeed [8].
Women in STEM feel they are treated differently, often in subtle ways [3]. The feeling of needing to prove themselves to be respected by coworkers is especially prevalent in male-dominated settings [3].
These women are also more likely to think they need to prove themselves at least some of the time at work in order to be respected by their coworkers [3].

Women in STEM jobs in male-dominated environments experience more workplace discrimination and gender inequities compared to those in more gender-balanced settings.

Several factors influence how Hispanics in the U.S. self-identify across generations, including language, cultural connections, and personal identity [2, 10, 8, 5]. Racial and ethnic identity is based on self-reports [5].

One key factor is the passage of time and generational distance from immigrant roots [1]. By the third generation, only $77\%$ self-identify as Hispanic, and this drops to about half by the fourth generation [1]. This decline is linked to mixed backgrounds or distant Hispanic ancestry, as indicated by $27\%$ of adults with Hispanic ancestry who do not identify as Hispanic [10].
![27% of adults with Hispanic ancestry do not identify as Hispanic due to mixed backgrounds.](image2)

Language plays a role, but it is not always a defining factor. A majority of Latino adults, including $58\%$ of immigrants and $84\%$ of second-generation Latinos, believe that speaking Spanish is not required to be considered Latino [6]. The percentage increases to $92\%$ among third or higher generation Latinos [6].
![Self-identified Hispanics indicates most believe speaking Spanish is not required.](image5)

Cultural connections also play a significant role. Sixteen percent of adults with Hispanic ancestry do not identify as Hispanic because of their upbringing or limited contact with Hispanic relatives [10]. Furthermore, $15\%$ do not identify as Hispanic due to a lack of Spanish language skills or cultural ties [10]. This is also influenced by how "American" they consider themselves. The percentage of Hispanics who consider themselves a typical American increases across generations [7]. Only about $36\%$ of immigrant Hispanics consider themselves a typical American, while $63\%$ of second-generation and $73\%$ of third or higher generation Hispanics feel the same [7]. This reflects their birth country and lifetime experiences [7].

In summary, self-identification as Hispanic in the U.S. is influenced by generational distance from immigrant roots, mixed backgrounds, limited cultural connections, and personal identity, with language and cultural connections becoming less critical across generations.

The frequency of attending Hispanic cultural celebrations and engaging in parental pride discussions decreases across generations for both self-identified Hispanics and non-Hispanics with Hispanic ancestry [10].

Among immigrant self-identified Hispanics, $59\%$ report their parents often took them to Hispanic cultural celebrations [9]. Second-generation Hispanics show a slight decrease, with $49\%$ reporting frequent attendance [6]. This drops further to $35\%$ for third or higher generation Hispanics [6].

Parental pride discussions also decline across generations, with $57\%$ of immigrant and $50\%$ of second-generation self-identified Hispanics reporting frequent discussions [7]. By the third generation, only $33\%$ say their parents often talked about pride in their roots [7].

For non-Hispanics with Hispanic ancestry, only $9\%$ report their parents often took them to Latino cultural celebrations [1]. This suggests a significant distancing from their immigrant roots compared to self-identified Hispanics [3].  Cultural celebrations and parental pride discussions diminish across generations, with non-Hispanics reporting significantly lower engagement compared to self-identified Hispanics.

Language dominance shifts across generations as English becomes more prevalent [5]. In summary, language dominance shifts toward English, parental encouragement of Spanish diminishes, and participation in cultural celebrations decreases across generations of self-identified Hispanics.

In-store Wi-Fi serves multiple purposes, including analytics, promotions, and integration with CRM systems [2, 4, 9]. Wi-Fi usage provides insights into bandwidth at the application level [10]. Data collected via Wi-Fi can be integrated into POS, CRM, and loyalty systems [5, 7].

![Overall, 54% of Wi-Fi use is for both company and customer access.](image2)

Wi-Fi is used for both company and customer access, with variations across different sectors; for instance, hospitality leads with 85% usage for both, while food, drug, and convenience stores show a higher use, with 78%, just for company purposes. The use of Wi-Fi varies across sectors, each adapting Wi-Fi to their specific operational needs.

In-store Wi-Fi can be leveraged for customer engagement and promotions [1]. Stores are looking at how Wi-Fi can feed information into their point of sale (POS), customer relationship management (CRM), and loyalty systems [3]. Here's how different sectors approach Wi-Fi usage:

**Wi-Fi Usage by Sector:**
![Percentage of companies using Wi-Fi for both company and customer access versus those using it for only company use.](image5)
Overall, 54% of companies use Wi-Fi for both company and customer access, while 42% use it just for company use; in the Food, Drug, Conv, Mass sector, only 22% use Wi-Fi for both, with 78% using it only for company use; General Merchandise & Specialty stores show 51% using it for both, and Hospitality leads with 85% using it for both, indicating varied strategies for Wi-Fi deployment based on industry needs.

**Key Analytics for Assessing Wi-Fi Usage:**
Stores use various analytics to evaluate Wi-Fi usage, including traffic counting, guest Wi-Fi session duration, customer devices, hotspots in the store, loyalty and repeat visits, time in store, social media conversions, times of use, sales conversion by Wi-Fi, and demographics [2].
![Analytics usage of in-store Wi-Fi.](image3)
Traffic counting is the most used at 56%, followed by guest WiFi session duration and customer device usage at 49%, while demographics are the least used analytic at 17% [3].

In-store Wi-Fi is used for customer engagement and promotions, with stores using key analytics to assess Wi-Fi usage.
