From 2014 to 2018, India experienced substantial growth in its e-commerce sales, driven by factors such as increased smartphone penetration and infrastructure development [3, 5]. E-commerce sales jumped from \$11 billion in 2014 to \$43 billion in 2018, which includes both product e-commerce and travel-related sales ![The graph shows the growth of e-commerce sales in India from 2014 to 2018, with a significant increase in both product e-commerce and travel-related sales.](image1).

The increasing penetration of digital payments also influenced shopping behaviors [6]. As shown in the image, cash on delivery (COD) decreased from 60% in 2013 to 50% in 2016, while the use of EMIs and third-party wallets increased ![The bar graph compares the percentage of different payment methods used in e-commerce transactions in 2013 and 2016, showing a decrease in COD and increases in credit/debit cards, net banking, EMI, and third-party wallets.](image4).
Additionally, digital advertising spend has increased significantly, with digital platforms emerging as the fastest-growing sector, reflecting a 29.9% CAGR ![Digital ad spend in India from 2012 to 2016 demonstrates that digital media is the fastest growing sector.](image5).
Overall, growth in digital media and e-commerce has increased digital advertising and online sales between 2014 and 2018.

Several factors contributed to the growth of eCommerce sales from 2014 to 2018, and there is a correlation with the age distribution of online buyers. Key drivers include infrastructure development, increased smartphone penetration, improved payment systems, and the availability of best prices online, which all enhance convenience and value for customers [8, 9].  The growth in eCommerce sales from 2014 to 2018, with an increase from $11 billion to $43 billion indicates a substantial expansion in the market ![eCommerce sales increased from 2014 to 2018.](image4)

Furthermore, the increasing digital payments penetration, including the use of debit cards and third-party wallets, supports this growth [3].  By 2016, half of Indians were expected to have debit cards [3]. The largest segment of online buyers is between 26-35 years old (55%), followed by the 18-35 years old segment (35%) ![The largest segment of online buyers are between 26 and 35 years old (55%), followed by the 18-35 years old segment (35%).](image5).

The growth in eCommerce sales from 2014 to 2018 is driven by infrastructure development, increased smartphone penetration, improved payment systems, and is correlated with a large segment of young online buyers.

The evolution of e-commerce is significantly influenced by multiple factors, leading to specific stages of market development [7]. Infrastructure development, smartphone penetration, and digital payments are key drivers [4]. ![Mobile commerce shows that more than 50% of transactions come from the top 3 e-commerce companies.](image2)
The shift from customer acquisition to retention also marks an important evolutionary step [3].  Tata Group, inspired by Alibaba, entered the e-commerce space, indicating market evolution [6].

The gross merchandise value (GMV) influenced by women increased from $122 million in 2012 to a projected $4.2 billion in 2016, showing market growth [8].  This also indicates an increasing influence and participation of women in the e-commerce market. ![Women-influenced GMV experienced significant growth from 2012 to 2016.](image1)
Great entrepreneurial opportunities exist in enhancing the ecosystem to improve retention and logistics efficiency [1]. Additionally, digital payment methods, such as EMI payments and third-party wallets, are becoming more popular, mirroring trends seen in China [10].

The shift towards profitability consolidation, with top horizontal players and niche players focusing on unique selections and customer experience, represents an evolution in market strategy [3]. ![The 26-35 age group accounts for 55% of users.](image3) The 26-35 age group, representing 55% of users, plays a dominant role in shaping e-commerce trends [8].

E-commerce growth and evolution are significantly shaped by infrastructure development, payment solutions, strategic focus shifts, and the dominant purchasing power of the 26-35 age group.

The evolution of payment methods and changing consumer demographics significantly shape e-commerce opportunities in India. With increasing digital payments penetration, cash on delivery (COD) shipments are reducing [6].  ![The chart illustrates the shift in payment methods between 2013 and 2016, showing a decrease in COD and an increase in digital payment methods.](image4)
The rise of digital payment methods such as EMI payments and third-party wallets provide strong value propositions, with the latter expected to quickly gain popularity [6]. By 2016, half of Indians were projected to have debit cards [6].  The landscape is also influenced by changing consumer demographics; for instance, women influenced GMV increased from 15% of the market in 2012 to a projected 35% in 2016 []. ![The graph shows the increase in women-influenced GMV from 2012 to 2016.](image1)

The growth and evolution of payment methods, along with the shift in consumer demographics, are creating new opportunities and shaping the e-commerce landscape in India.

In 2016, half of Indians had debit cards [6]. There was also increasing digital payments penetration and thus the share of COD shipments was reduced [6].
![COD payments decreased from 2013 to 2016 while EMI and 3rd party wallets increased.](image4)
From 2013 to 2016, there was a shift in online retail payment methods in India, with a decrease in COD and increases in EMI and third-party wallet usage, impacting gross margin contributions by product categories.

From 2013 to 2016, there was a shift in online retail payment methods in India, influencing e-commerce platforms [10].

The payments landscape is an important factor for e-commerce [4].
![The graph illustrates the shift in online retail payment methods in India from 2013 to 2016P.](image1)

With increasing digital payments penetration, the share of COD shipments is reducing [10]. Consumers can research online using smartphones, check product reviews and make comparison before buying online or in store ![Consumers can research online using smartphones, check product reviews and make comparison before buying online or in store](image3). As the use of digital payments increases, cash on delivery decreases, and the popularity of EMI payments and third-party wallets rises [10].

These changes in payment methods influence e-commerce platforms regarding payment integration and consumer behavior.

The distribution of transaction volumes across different categories in online retail doesn't directly align with the gross margin contributions, suggesting strategic implications for supply and demand [7].

Based on transaction volume, fashion, footwear & accessories lead with 35% of transactions, while mobile, tablets, and accessories account for only 9% ![Fashion, footwear & accessories make up the largest portion of transaction volume.](image3).
However, when looking at the Gross Margin contributions, mobile, tablets & accessories contribute 35%, while fashion, footwear & accessories contribute only 28% ![Mobile, Tablets & Accessories are the largest category by gross margin.](image1).

This discrepancy indicates that while fashion items drive transaction volumes, electronics generate higher margins. This may be due to factors such as higher average selling prices, lower return rates, or more efficient supply chains in the electronics category.

![The two sided business model depicts supply, logistics and demand.](image4)
To capitalize on these trends, e-commerce businesses need to strengthen their ecosystem by "increasing retention, increasing logistics efficiency, analytics etc" [1]. Focusing on customer retention, improving logistics, and leveraging data analytics is essential to optimize the supply and demand balance. Ultimately, the focus should shift from discounting to improving customer experience and focus from customer acquisition to retention [2].

Consumers now "EXPECT ALL TO ALL EXPERIENCE" [5]. Consumers research products online using smartphones, they also look at product reviews in social media and compare shopping across different sites before buying online or going to a store ![Consumers are researching online, checking reviews in social media and comparison shopping before buying online.](image5).

The category-wise transaction volumes and gross margin contributions in online retail suggest that focusing on high-margin categories such as electronics, while improving logistics and customer retention strategies, is crucial for optimizing the e-commerce supply and demand model.

E-commerce platforms operate on a "two sided business model" [10]. This model involves both supply and demand aspects, which are crucial for understanding how consumer expectations are met in online retail.
![The image highlights the two-sided business model in e-commerce, involving supply and demand facilitated by an e-commerce platform.](image1)
Consumers generally expect an "ALL TO ALL EXPERIENCE" [4]. This implies that they seek a seamless, integrated experience across all touchpoints, from product discovery to purchase and post-sales service. Consumers also do research using smartphones to compare products before buying online or in store. ![This illustrates the consumer journey from online research to purchase, highlighting comparison shopping across sites.](image2)

Critical success factors for e-commerce platforms include "Widest Selection", "Great Shopping Experience", and "Pricing (Its not about discounts alone)" [image1]. Platforms need to offer a wide variety of products to meet diverse consumer needs.
![The graphic shows multiple channels through which consumers can access e-commerce, emphasizing flexibility and convenience.](image3)
The A-team of e-commerce consists of Seller management, Marketing, Product, Customer servicing, Technology, Logistics, Finance and Strategy teams to provide error free service, great experience, and new customers [image5]. Customer acquisition and retention are also very important [3]. This ultimately affects profitability of business [3].

The critical success factors of an e-commerce platform such as offering a great shopping experience and widest selection are essential for meeting consumer expectations of a seamless and integrated experience in online retail.

The Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) operates under the Department of Space (DOS), which in turn reports to the Space Commission and ultimately the Prime Minister, as illustrated in the organizational chart ![The chart illustrates the organizational structure of Indian space program, highlighting the relationships between various departments and organizations.](image3). The Space Commission formulates policies and oversees the implementation of the Indian space program [7]. DOS implements these programs through various entities, including ISRO, Physical Research Laboratory (PRL), National Atmospheric Research Laboratory (NARL), North Eastern-Space Applications Centre (NE-SAC) and Semi-Conductor Laboratory (SCL) [7].

The budgetary allocation for ISRO's various programs can be seen for the years 2015-2016 and 2016-2017 in the bar graph ![The bar graph compares the budgetary allocations for space technology, applications, INSAT operational, space sciences, and other programs between 2015-2016 and 2016-2017.](image1). The graph specifies the allocation for Space Technology, Space Applications, INSAT Operational, Space Sciences, Direction & Administration and Other Programmes and Grand Total.

ISRO's organizational structure includes various centers and units that focus on specific aspects of space research and applications, with budgetary allocations varying across these programs.

The Indian Space Programme involves various centers, each with specific roles and significances, supported by budget allocations reflecting their importance.

The North Eastern-Space Applications Centre (NE-SAC) provides developmental support to the North Eastern Region using space science and technology [6]. ![NE-SAC provides developmental support to the North Eastern Region.](image4)

The Semi-Conductor Laboratory (SCL) focuses on creating a strong microelectronics base in the country and enhancing capabilities in the VLSI domain [10]. ![SCL focuses on microelectronics and VLSI domain.](image5)

The National Atmospheric Research Laboratory (NARL) is a center for atmospheric research, emphasizing technology development, observations, and data modeling [9]. ![NARL is dedicated to atmospheric research and technology.](image3)

Antrix Corporation Limited serves as the marketing arm of ISRO, promoting and commercializing space products and services [2].  They also facilitate the development of space-related industrial capabilities in India [2]. As the commercial and marketing arm of ISRO, Antrix provides end-to-end solutions for many space products and services to international customers [4].

The Indian Institute of Space Science and Technology (IIST) offers high-quality education in space science and technology to meet the demands of the Indian Space Programme [5, 7].

The budget allocation for various space programs, including Space Technology, Space Applications, and Space Sciences, reflects their significance in the overall Indian Space Programme. ![The image depicts the budget allocation for various space programs.](image1)

These centers, along with their budget allocations, play crucial roles in advancing India's space capabilities and applications.

The National Atmospheric Research Laboratory (NARL) and the Semi-Conductor Laboratory (SCL) serve distinct but critical functions within India's space program. NARL focuses on atmospheric research, while SCL is dedicated to developing microelectronics.

NARL's primary function is atmospheric research with the goal of predicting the behavior of Earth's atmosphere through observation and modeling [4]. NARL emphasizes technology development, data handling, and assimilation to achieve this goal [4]. NARL conducts research under seven groups, namely: Radar Application and Development Group, Ionospheric and Space Research Group, Atmospheric Structure and Dynamics Group, Cloud and Convective Systems Group, Aerosols, Radiation and Trace Gases Group, Weather and Climate Research Group and Computers and Data Management Group [10]. ![NARL is located in Tirupati, it is the National Atmospheric Research Laboratory.](image1)

SCL's main function is to establish a strong microelectronics base in India and improve capabilities in VLSI [8].
The activities at SCL include design, development, fabrication, assembly, testing, and reliability assurance of CMOS and MEMS devices [8].
![This image shows Wafer Fabrication Lab in SCL where the Wafer Fabrication Lab has been upgraded, and CMOS Wafer Fabrication Line is prepared for production activities.](image4)
SCL also focuses on Hi-Rel Board Fabrication and Component Screening for ISRO units [3].

Therefore, NARL focuses on atmospheric research and prediction, while SCL is dedicated to microelectronics development and production.

Many people do not use technology outside of their homes, in contrast to the technologies that people have working in their households.

In households, 86% use mobile phones, 49% use television, 45% use the radio, 10% use a computer, and 5% use the internet. The image shows the usage of different technologies within the household. ![Technology usage inside the household includes mobile phones, television, radio, computers, and internet](image2)

Outside of the household, the technology usage varies significantly. A large percentage, 68%, do not use any of these technologies outside their homes. For those who do, mobile phones are used by 20%, television by 11%, computers by 4%, and the internet by 4%. ![A significant portion of people do not use any listed technologies outside of their homes](image1)

Radio listening habits also differ across demographics, with 76% of people overall listening to the radio and 40% listening on their mobile phones. The radio is more used by 77% in rural areas while mobile phone is more used in urban areas with 70%. And, males use the radio more with 75% compared to females using 77%. ![Radio listening habits vary across rural, urban, male, and female demographics](image3)

46% never listen to the radio. Of those who do, 27% listen every day, 19% listen a few times a week, and 7% listen a few times a month. Radio listening differs based on location, where 27.4% in rural areas listen to the radio everyday compared to the 26.1% of urban areas. And, 34.3% of males listen to the radio everyday while only 20% of females listen everyday. ![Radio listening frequency and demographics, including location, and gender](image4)

Technology usage inside the household is higher than outside the household, and radio listening habits vary across demographics.

Indonesian mobile internet users engage in a variety of online activities, with social media being the most popular at 24%, followed by entertainment at 20% and general information at 16% ![Mobile users prefer social media](image3).

E-commerce activities also take place on mobile phones, with e-commerce users preferring to shop online through social media (26%), IM groups like BBM Group (27%), and forums/classifieds like Kaskus and OLX (27%) [8]. E-commerce traffic is significant, with almost 30% of e-commerce traffic in Asia Pacific coming from smartphones and tablets [3]. Indonesian e-commerce websites also record a substantial portion of their sales from mobile devices, with lojai.com recording almost 20% of their sales from mobile in May 2014 [3].  Apparel is the top product category for both offline (79.2%) and online (67.1%) shopping ![Apparel is the most popular product category for both offline and online shopping](image1).

Mobile internet usage in Indonesia significantly influences shopping behaviors, with users actively engaging in e-commerce through various mobile platforms.

Mobile internet usage in Indonesia is characterized by specific demographics and content preferences, which in turn shape business opportunities.

Mobile devices account for 36% of the average Indonesian user's five hours of daily media consumption [7]. The largest portion of mobile internet users are between 25-35 years old, while student consists of 16% [3].

Mobile users primarily engage in social media, followed by entertainment and general information seeking, as shown in ![Mobile users spend the most time on social media.](image2). This preference for social media is also evident in the fact that 92% of internet users in Indonesia own a Facebook account, with almost 90% of them accessing it through mobile [5].

Games and apps are the most downloaded mobile content, with 70% of users downloading Games/Apps [2]. This indicates a significant opportunity for mobile game and application developers.

Mobile devices significantly influence customer decisions, accounting for 55% of influence [7]. In terms of e-commerce, a substantial portion of traffic in Asia Pacific originates from smartphones and tablets [9].

The primary revenue sources from mobile internet include advertisements, revenue sharing/commission, traffic/user exchange, games, music, and downloads, which provides an overview on how revenue is generated from mobile internet usage ![Mobile internet revenue comes from advertisement, games, and music](image4).

The demographics of mobile internet users correlate with content preferences and business opportunities in Indonesia, particularly in mobile advertising, e-commerce, and mobile content development.

Telkomsel consistently leads in subscriber count, followed by XL and Indosat. Telkomsel also boasts the highest number of data users.

In late 2014, Telkomsel had 132.7 million subscribers and 60.5 million data users, while XL had 68.5 million subscribers and 37.5 million data users, and Indosat had 59.7 million subscribers and 29 million data users ![Telkomsel leads in subscribers and data users in late 2014](image1).

By 2015, Telkomsel's subscriber base had grown to 139.3 million with 63.5 million data users. In comparison, XL had 58.3 million subscribers with 32 million data users, and Indosat had 54.2 million subscribers with 29 million data users ![Telkomsel maintained its lead in subscriber base and data users in 2015](image3).

Telkomsel has the largest share of subscribers at 42%, XL+Axis at 18%, and Indosat at 16.7% [7]. ![Telkomsel has the largest share of subscribers](image4)

Telkomsel consistently has more subscribers and data users than XL and Indosat.

From 2013 to 2014, the telecom sector saw significant changes. People started using data-based services like IM and VoIP more, leading to a decline in SMS and voice call usage [1]. This shift impacted the Average Revenue Per User (ARPU) [9].
![Mobile Data ARPU will pickup later as users data consumption increases.](image1)
From the text, we can infer that a "continued trend of declining ARPU until 2015 where data users will start to enroll for bigger data plans due to increased usage of the mobile Internet and compensate the declining voice and SMs ARPU" [7]. While the provided quotes do not give explicit subscriber numbers, this suggests a potential increase in data subscribers which may have contributed to the trends in ARPU from 2013-2014 [7].

The shift to data usage influenced ARPU trends in the telecom sector.

Between 2013 and 2014, the ARPUs of voice and SMS showed a decreasing trend [2], but data ARPU are expected to increase in the long term [2].  The decreasing trend is because people are using data-based messaging and Voice over Internet Protocol (VoIP) [4].  Less usage on SMs and voice also lead to reduced ARP U [5].

Initially reduced ARP U was due to a massive price war,initiated by the government [9]. `![Line graph indicates ARPUs for voice and SMS would continue to decrease while mobile data ARPU showed an increase between 2013 and 2017.](image2)`

The decline of ARPUs in general may have stopped because tariffs have hit rock-bottom [10].

![The bar graph displays subscriber, smartphone, Blackberry, Android, and data users in millions for Telkomsel, XL, and Indosat.](image3)
Based on the graph it can be observed that Telkomsel and XL both had a significant number of smartphone users in 2014. The number of Android users are more than Blackberry users in both Telkomsel and XL [1].

The changes in the number of smartphone users and ARPU trends for Telkomsel and XL between 2013 and 2014 were influenced by the increasing adoption of smartphones and data-based services, leading to a decline in voice and SMS usage and a shift towards data consumption.

Streaming has rapidly become the dominant format in the music industry [1, 4]. The distribution of streaming versus album sales differs considerably among genres, as illustrated in ![Streams account for 70% of total music consumption, with album sales at 51%.](image5). For total music, streams account for 70% of consumption, compared to album sales at 51%.

Analyzing specific genres, Rock music shows a very high streaming percentage ![Rock music is driven by streams with 82%.](image1). Conversely, ![Album sales make up 37% of the total activity in Rock music.](image4), album sales in Rock represent a larger share compared to other genres. Pop music is mainly current [3], meaning it relies more on the latest hits, while rock maintains popularity through its extensive catalog [3]. Hip-hop has a significant streaming presence, as well [7].

These differences indicate varying consumption trends: genres like Rock still see value in album purchases, possibly due to dedicated fan bases who prefer owning physical or digital copies, while Pop and Hip-hop heavily rely on streaming, reflecting a preference for on-demand access to the newest tracks [3, 7].

In summary, streaming dominates overall music consumption, but album sales remain relevant in specific genres like Rock, revealing diverse preferences in how people choose to consume music across different genres.

The contribution of streams to total music activity varies significantly across different genres and total music consumption, with some genres being more heavily influenced by streaming than others. Streaming has become the leading format in the music industry [5].
 
For total music consumption, streams contribute to 70% of the total activity, which is higher than album sales at 51% and song sales at 49% ![Streams make up 70% of total music consumption, more than album or song sales.](image4)

Rock music streams account for 82% of the total activity, whereas rock album sales only stand at 63% [7]. ![Rock music streams account for 82% of the total activity.](image2)
In comparison, the streams in country music only accounts for 70% of total music activity. ![Streams in country music account for 70% of total music activity.](image2)
R&B/Hip-Hop and Pop streams account for 61% and 58% of the total activity, respectively. ![R&B/Hip-Hop and Pop streams account for 61% and 58% of the total activity, respectively.](image2)

The contribution of streams to total music activity varies across different genres and total music consumption.

Rock is driven by catalog at all formats, while Pop is mainly driven by current music [1]. Consumption patterns vary across genres, impacting success paths, as "DIFFERENT TYPES OF CONSUMPTION MEANS DIFFERENT PATHS TO SUCCESS" [7].

The hypothesis suggests that label words act as anchors in the ICL information flow [1]. In shallower layers, information flows from demonstration examples to label words, while in deeper layers, information is extracted from label words for the final prediction, as illustrated in Figure 2 [1].
![The hypothesis suggests that label words act as anchors, gathering information in shallow layers and providing information for prediction in deep layers.](image4)
Figure 3 shows the significance of information flow, where  $S_{w p}$ represents information flow from text to label words and  $S_{p q}$ represents information flow from label words to target positions [5, 8, 10, 9].  In shallow layers,  $S_{w p}$ is high, while  $S_{p q}$ is low, but in deeper layers,  $S_{p q}$ dominates [8].
![The graph shows the relationship between information flow and model layers, with Swp and Spq representing different flow significances.](image2)
This indicates that the information flow from text to label words ($S_{w p}$) is not always greater than the information flow from label words to the target position ($S_{p q}$), especially in deeper layers [8].

To gauge the degree of confusion between categories, the metric  $\mathsf{C o n f u s i o n}_{i j}$  is utilized [6].  Confusion $_{ij}$  is calculated using the AUC-ROC metric [7].  Confusion $_{ij}$ never exceeds 1; values closer to 1 indicates less confusion and vice versa [10]. Figure 6 shows the predicted and real confusion matrix on TREC [8].

Based on the predicted and real confusion matrix on TREC, the most confusing category pair is Description-Entity in the figure [1].

![Predicted and real confusion matrix on TREC showing similarity in confusing category pairs.](image1)

The predicted confusion matrix,  Confusion i  $j^{\mathrm{pred}}$, is influenced by the value of M [2]. The Confusion $_{ij}$ metric allows for a more accurate representation of the model’s degree of confusion for different categories, mitigating the impact of randomness [5].

Based on the figure, the category most confusing for Abbreviation is Location.

The logic programming module in L OGIC -LM is implemented using the Pyke expert system [5]. Pyke makes inferences based on the logic programming language and uses forward- and backward-chaining algorithms to infer new facts and substantiate the goal [5]. Figure 1 illustrates the L OGIC -LM framework, which includes a problem formulator, a symbolic reasoner, and a result interpreter, where the symbolic reasoner utilizes symbolic solvers such as Pyke for logic programming.
![Pyke is used as a symbolic reasoner for logic programming in the LOGIC-LM framework.](image4)
Therefore, the Pyke expert system is used to implement the logic programming module.

The algorithm with more lines is the Collapsed Tree Algorithm. Both algorithms are described through pseudocode, with the Tree Traversal algorithm described in Algorithm 1 and the Collapsed Tree algorithm in Algorithm 2 [8]. The tree traversal method traverses the tree layer-by-layer, pruning and selecting the most relevant nodes at each level [7].
![Algorithm 1 shows pseudocode for Tree Traversal algorithm.](image2)
The pseudocode for Tree Traversal retrieval is shown above.

In contrast, the Collapsed Tree method evaluates nodes collectively across all layers to find the most relevant ones [7]. The pseudocode for Collapsed Tree retrieval is shown below.
![Algorithm 2 shows pseudocode for Collapsed Tree algorithm.](image5)
A visual representation of both retrieval methods can be seen below.
![Both Tree Traversal and Collapsed Tree Retrieval are shown.](image3)
By comparing the two algorithms, the Collapsed Tree Algorithm has more lines.

Active learning tends to select data that is biased to specific classes, and active querying strategies can barely outperform random sampling at the beginning because some classes are simply not selected for training [8]. Datasets in practice are often highly unbalanced, particularly in medical images, which can escalate the biased sampling [8].

According to Figure 2, active querying strategies such as VAAL tend to be biased towards certain classes, for example, in OrganAMNIST, VAAL prefers selecting data in the femur-right and platelet class, but largely ignores data in the lung, liver and monocyte classes [6].
![VAAL tends to be biased towards certain classes.](image1)
Label diversity is an important underlying criterion in designing active querying criteria [2]. As shown in Figure 6 and Table 7, diversity is a significant add-on to most querying strategies [4, 9].

Therefore, VAAL generally yields the worst label diversity on all the datasets.

The system generates a natural language response by combining the state tracker outputs and retrieved KB entities [6]. The dialogue action, user goal tracking results, and query results are used to generate the final natural language system response via a natural language generator (NLG) [4]. ![System generates a response to the user's request through a natural language generator.](image2)
A template-based NLG is used, where delexicalized tokens are replaced by values from either the estimated user goal values or KB entities, depending on the emitted system action [6]. Therefore, the system response is produced based on the dialogue state, user's goal, and query results.

RAPTOR improves the accuracy and F1 scores of various models across different datasets. Here's a breakdown:

1.  **QASPER Dataset Performance**:
    *   RAPTOR consistently outperforms BM25 and DPR across different Language Models on the QASPER dataset [5, 7].
    *   When using GPT-3, GPT-4, and UnifiedQA, RAPTOR's F-1 Match scores are $53.1\%$, $55.7\%$, and $36.6\%$, respectively, surpassing DPR by margins of 1.8, 2.7, and 4.5 points, and BM25 by 6.5, 5.5, and 10.2 points [5].
    *   RAPTOR paired with GPT-4 sets a new benchmark on QASPER, with a $55.7\%$ F-1 score, surpassing CoLT5 XL's score of $53.9\%$ [1].
    *   ![RAPTOR+GPT-4 achieves a higher F-1 match score on the QASPER dataset compared to LongT5 XL and CoLT5 XL.](image5)

2.  **QuALITY Dataset Performance**:
    *   RAPTOR achieves an accuracy of $62.4\%$ on the QuALITY dataset, which is a $2\%$ and $5.1\%$ improvement over DPR and BM25, respectively [10].
    *   ![RAPTOR improves the accuracy of different models on the QuALITY dataset.](image4)
    *   RAPTOR outperforms the baselines of BM25 and DPR by at least $2.0\%$ in accuracy [2].

3.  **Narrative QA Dataset Performance**:
    *   RAPTOR excels across multiple metrics on the Narrative QA dataset [4].
    *   For ROUGE-L, it surpasses BM25 and DPR by 7.3 and 2.7 points, respectively [4].
    *   In metrics like BLEU-1, BLEU-4, and METEOR, RAPTOR outperforms BM25 and DPR by margins ranging from 1.7 to 5.8 and 0.7 to 2.1 points, respectively [4].
    *  RAPTOR, when paired with UnifiedQA 3B, sets a new state-of-the-art in the METEOR metric [9].

RAPTOR enhances model performance by achieving higher accuracy and F1 scores across multiple datasets and language models compared to baseline methods like BM25 and DPR.

The SnapNTell dataset distinguishes itself from other VQA datasets through several key features, including a wide range of categorized entities, knowledge-intensive question-answer pairs, and the incorporation of representative images for each entity [6, 4]. SnapNTell includes a diverse range of fine-grained entities, with entity names specifically mentioned in the answer sets [4].

SnapNTell includes a wide range of fine-grained entities, accompanied by corresponding representative images [4]. SnapNTell contains 22 major categories and 7,568 unique entities [6]. ![SnapNTell dataset encompasses 22 categories and 7568 entities.](image1)

Compared to datasets like ViQuAE and Encyclopedic VQA, SnapNTell includes a greater variety of categories, more distinct entities, and a higher number of QA pairs [5].  Additionally, the SnapNTell dataset includes 10 images for each entity, whereas the exact number of images per entity in ViQuAE and Encyclopedic VQA is unspecified [5]. SnapNTell's questions are also highly anonymous [5]. ![SnapNTell has knowledge, entities and categorization.](image3)

The SnapNTell dataset surpasses others in the variety of categories, the number of distinct entities, the overall number of QA pairs, and boasts a higher count of images and a longer average length for answers [5].
The SnapNTell dataset is unique compared to existing VQA datasets because it includes fine-grained categorized entities, images, and knowledge-intensive responses [8].

The DSC loss method demonstrates superior performance across various datasets [10]. The results on Chinese datasets show that DSC loss outperforms the best baseline results by a large margin, achieving SOTA performance on CTB5, CTB6, and UD1.4, surpassing BERT-tagger significantly in F1 score [3].
![DSC outperforms BERT-tagger by a large margin on Chinese datasets](image5)
On English datasets, specifically for NER tasks, DSC outperforms BERT-MRC on CoNLL2003, OntoNotes5.0, MSRA, and OntoNotes4.0, achieving new SOTA performances [7].
![DSC outperforms BERT-MRC on English OntoNotes 5.0 dataset with a F1 score of 92.07](image1)
In MRC tasks, the DSC loss obtains significant performance boosts on both EM and F1 with either BERT or XLNet [5]. However, DSC is not accuracy-oriented and should not be used for accuracy-oriented tasks [6]. Across multiple datasets DSC consistently performs the best [10].

The DSC loss method generally achieves the highest F1 score across multiple datasets.

The performance of BERT-MRC model variations can be evaluated based on the English CoNLL 2003 and English OntoNotes 5.0 datasets.

On the English CoNLL 2003 dataset, the BERT-MRC model achieves an F1 score of 93.04 [8]. The BERT-MRC+DSC model outperforms the original BERT-MRC model with an F1 score of 93.33, showing an improvement of +0.29.  ![BERT-MRC+DSC shows the best F1 score compared with other model variations on English CoNLL 2003 dataset.](image4)

On the English OntoNotes 5.0 dataset, the BERT-MRC model has an F1 score of 91.11. ![BERT-MRC+DSC achieves the highest F1 score on the English OntoNotes 5.0 dataset compared to other model variations.](image1)  The BERT-MRC+DSC model outperforms the original BERT-MRC model with an F1 score of 92.07, indicating a performance increase of +0.96 [8].

In summary, the BERT-MRC+DSC model consistently outperforms the original BERT-MRC model on both the English CoNLL 2003 and English OntoNotes 5.0 datasets.

Our approach shows significant improvements in instruction execution performance when compared to other recent methods, particularly on the LANI navigation task [2]. Decomposing goal prediction and action generation leads to better results [2]. However, performance on the CHAI instructions is weaker, reflecting the task's complexity [2].

On the LANI task, "Our Approach" outperforms CHAPLOT 18, with a 5% increase in task completion accuracy [3].  C HAPLOT 18 and M ISRA 17 both struggle to learn on CHAI , while "Our Approach" demonstrates some improvement in stop distance [3]. However, all models, including ours, still perform poorly on manipulation accuracy (MA) in the CHAI environment [3].
![Table 4 shows the performance of different methods on the held-out test dataset, including LANI and CHAI, with metrics such as stop distance (SD), task completion (TC), and manipulation accuracy (MA).](image1)
In the LANI environment, human ratings correlate well with the automated stop distance metric, suggesting that our automated evaluation approach is appropriate for assessing performance [7].
![Histogram displays human evaluation ratings for LANI, comparing human followers and "Our Approach".](image5)
"Our Approach" demonstrates higher accuracy on the held-out test dataset for both LANI and CHAI environments. The approach achieves SD 8.43 and TC 36.9 on LANI, and SD 3.34 and MA 39.97 on CHAI.  This indicates that decomposing goal prediction and action generation is effective [6].

Overall, "Our Approach" achieves superior performance on the LANI dataset, but still faces challenges with the more complex CHAI dataset, particularly in manipulation accuracy.

The "CCNN+WLSTM+CRF" model, which combines character CNN with word LSTM and CRF, achieves the highest NER F1-value [6].

The LSTUR approach demonstrates superior performance in news recommendation due to its ability to capture both long-term preferences and short-term interests, which is crucial for understanding the complex user interests [3].The sequence-based encoders like GRU, LSTM outperform Average and Attention-based encoders as they capture sequential new reading patterns for learning short-term user representations [4].
Additionally, the integration of both long-term and short-term user representations improves performance [7]. According to Figure 5, GRU has better performance than LSTM [4]. ![GRU performs better than LSTM.](image5)
The neural network-based methods (CNN, DKN, LSTUR) outperform manual feature engineering methods (LibFM, DeepFM) because neural networks can capture global and local semantic contexts in news [10]. In the LSTUR approach, the news encoder, using a combination of a CNN and an attention network, is more effective than using CNN, LSTM, or LSTM with attention alone [8]. As shown in Figure 1, LSTUR-con and LSTUR-ini outperform other methods across various metrics including AUC, MRR, nDCG@5 and nDCG@10. ![LSTUR-con and LSTUR-ini outperform other methods across various metrics including AUC, MRR, nDCG@5 and nDCG@10.](image1)

The LSTUR approach, particularly when combining long- and short-term user representations through concatenation (LSTUR-con) or initialization (LSTUR-ini), achieves the best performance for news recommendation based on AUC and nDCG@10 metrics.

The BERT (Large) model achieves the highest test median score [4]. According to the Table 1, the test median score of BERT (Large) is 0.712, which is the highest among all models. The ProgramFC model demonstrates superior performance compared to FLAN-T5, particularly with smaller model sizes and increasing task complexity, and it also shows better retrieval recall compared to one-step retrieval.

Decomposition is more effective than one-step prediction [1]. On average, there is a 6.0% improvement in the gold evidence setting and a 4.5% improvement in the open-book setting [1]. As smaller models have less capacity for complex reasoning, the performance of the end-to-end FLAN-T5 model decreases significantly with decreasing model size; however, this trend is less notable for ProgramFC [8].

Iterative retrieval guided by the reasoning program yields better results [6]. The high-level reasoning plan offered by reasoning programs substantially alleviates the demands on the subsequent sub-task solvers [8]. Figure 5 compares the retrieval performance of the one-step BM25 retriever used in the baselines to the iterative step-by-step BM25 retriever in PROGRAM FC [4].

ProgramFC can achieve comparable performance to the 137x larger FLAN-T5 model with end-to-end reasoning for 4-hop claims, using FLAN-T5-small (80M parameters) as sub-task solvers [8]. ProgramFC outperforms one-step retrieval on all datasets, with the largest improvement of 37.1% on HOVER 4-hop ![ProgramFC outperforms one-step retrieval, especially on HOVER 4-hop, due to iterative retrieval guided by the reasoning program.](image2)

The ProgramFC model excels over FLAN-T5, particularly with smaller models and complex tasks, while also achieving superior retrieval recall compared to one-step retrieval methods.

PROGRAM FC's performance varies across different fact-checking tasks when compared to other models, and it exhibits specific error trends in its predictions. P ROGRAM FC effectively balances model capability, learning efficiency, and interpretability [4]. Figure 5 illustrates that P ROGRAM FC outperforms one-step retrieval on all datasets, showing a significant improvement of 37.1% on HOVER 4-hop, as iterative retrieval guided by the reasoning program yields better results. ![ProgramFC outperforms one-step retrieval on all datasets, especially HOVER 4-hop.](image4)

The results presented in Table 3 show that most models achieve a Macro-F1 score only slightly above random guessing on the HOVER dataset, demonstrating the difficulty of relying solely on parametric knowledge for fact-checking complex claims [10]. Chain-of-thought prompting scores an average of 2.7 points higher than direct prompting, highlighting the importance of step-by-step reasoning for complex fact-checking, and it outperforms P ROGRAM FC on HOVER 2-hop and FEVEROUS, but performs worse on HOVER 3-hop and 4-hop [10].  The model's effectiveness is particularly notable when the model size is small, as program-guided reasoning alleviates the demands on sub-task solvers, allowing FLAN-T5-small (80M parameters) to achieve comparable performance to the 137x larger FLAN-T5-XXL (11B) model for 4-hop claims [1].

However, as the complexity of claims increases, the proportion of semantic errors in the programs also increases, especially structural errors, which highlights the difficulty in generating appropriate step-by-step reasoning strategies for claims requiring long-chain reasoning [8]. ![Semantic errors increase with claim complexity, especially structural errors.](image1) No syntax errors were found, which indicates that Codex effectively generates executable programs through few-shot in-context learning [7]. An example structural error is depicted in Figure 6, where the model fails to parse the second sentence of the claim into correct program instructions [8].

P ROGRAM FC shows strong performance in complex reasoning tasks, particularly with smaller models, but faces challenges with semantic and structural errors as the complexity of the claims increases.

The performance of ProgramFC increases with the required reasoning depth, as shown in the HOVER dataset [10].  ProgramFC outperforms baselines by 10.38%, 11.37%, and 14.77% on two-hop, three-hop, and four-hop claims, respectively [10]. As shown in the image, the performance of ProgramFC is better compared to One-step Retrieval in HOVER (2-hop), HOVER (3-hop) and HOVER (4-hop) datasets ![ProgramFC outperforms One-step Retrieval across 2-hop, 3-hop, and 4-hop scenarios in the HOVER dataset](image4).

However, an increasing number of semantic errors affect the programs as the complexity of the claims increases [5]. For instance, structural errors become prevalent, reflecting challenges in generating step-by-step reasoning strategies for claims requiring long-chain reasoning [5].  Incorrect program execution, due to failures in question answering or fact-checking modules, is a major source of errors [2].  As shown in the image, the proportion of semantic errors increases with the number of hops, particularly in the structure of the program ![Semantic errors increase with the number of hops, with structural errors being significant in 4-hop scenarios](image3).

In summary, ProgramFC's performance generally improves with increasing reasoning depth in datasets like HOVER, but this is accompanied by a rise in semantic and structural errors, particularly in more complex, multi-hop scenarios.

The 'hard-to-contrast' strategy shows superior performance compared to other querying strategies, particularly in addressing the cold start problem in active learning.

The 'hard-to-contrast' querying strategy yields the highest performance amongst existing active querying strategies [3].  Hard-to-contrast data (red lines) outperform other initial queries in every cycle of active learning on Organ aM NIST [6]. 
![Hard-to-contrast data consistently outperforms other initial queries in active learning, as shown in the graph.](image1)

Figure 4 presents the quantitative comparison of four map-based querying strategies, wherein easy- or hard-to-learn are selected by the maps based on ground truths, easy- or hard-to-contrast are selected by the maps based on pseudo- labels [3]. The Pearson correlation coefﬁcient between $\mathrm{AUC_{20}}$  (starting) and $\mathrm{AUC_{50}}$ (ending) shows strong positive correlation [9].
![Hard-to-contrast data outperforms other strategies on OrganAMNIST, BloodMNIST, and PathMNIST, improving model performance.](image2)

Selecting hard-to-contrast data contribute to the optimal models [3]. Hard-to-contrast querying strategy significantly outperforms random selection by $1.8\%$ on PathMNIST, $2.6\%$ on OrganAMNIST, and $5.2\%$ on BloodMNIST, by querying 0.1% of entire dataset [3]. Similarly on CIFAR-10-LT, hard-to-contrast outperforms random selection by $21.2\%$ and $24.1\%$ by querying 20% and 30% of entire dataset respectively [3].

The 'hard-to-contrast' strategy outperforms other querying methods and improves initial query selection by focusing on label diversity and informative data points, which leads to better model performance, especially in the early stages of active learning.

The performance of LLMs can be significantly influenced by prompt construction [1]. Instruction formats and demonstration selections are two aspects of prompt construction that influence the performance of ChatGPT and Codex.

Diverse instruction strategies yield comparable results [1]. ![Instruction format has a minor impact on F1 score](image3)

The selection strategy of demonstration matters [1]. Sentence embedding and EPR surpass random sampling by a large margin [10]. ![Demonstration selection significantly impacts F1 score](image3)

LLMs, such as LLaMA and Vicuna, have more limited capacities in leveraging demos compared to OpenAI models, with their performance stagnating or even collapsing with only a few demos [3].  Current LLMs are not good few-shot information extractors in general [5].

In summary, instruction format has a minor impact, demonstration selection significantly impacts performance, and open-source LLMs are limited in leveraging demos, impacting ChatGPT and Codex performance on the FewNERD dataset.

The most common reasoning steps in S C I T AB include simple lookup and comparison, while challenges often arise from incorrect calculations, approximations, and insufficient evidence.

To understand the nature of reasoning in S C I T AB , a set of table-based reasoning categories from INFOTABS were adapted, defining 14 atomic reasoning types [6]. Among these, closed-domain knowledge (background information from the table caption or title) and open-domain knowledge (commonsense knowledge not in the table) are specifically designed for S C I T AB [6].

The dataset exhibits a multifaceted complex range of reasoning types and a high proportion of claims requiring different types of domain knowledge [6]. ![The table shows different atomic reasoning types, including closed and open-domain knowledge.](image1)

S C I T AB exhibits diversity in refuted claims; common error types include incorrect calculation results (41.7%) and incorrect approximation words (33.33%) [4]. For unverified claims, the most common features are insufficient evidence in the table and the lack of background knowledge [9]. ![This image shows the refuted and NEI reasons in the SciTAB dataset.](image5)

S C I T AB contains more challenging claims that require up to 11 reasoning steps for verification [10]. ![This image shows the distribution of reasoning steps needed to verify claims in the SciTAB dataset.](image4)

The SciTab dataset involves a variety of reasoning functions, each contributing to the complexity of verifying claims using tabular data [5, 6].

The primary reasoning functions and their proportions include simple lookups (20.6%) and comparisons (19.5%), as well as the use of closed-domain knowledge (12.1%) ![Function names and their Descriptions](image4). These functions reflect the different types of reasoning needed to validate scientific claims based on tabular data [5].

The distribution of reasoning steps in SciTab shows that most claims require multiple steps, with a significant percentage requiring between 3 and 6 steps ![Reasoning steps required for claim verification.](image5). This indicates that verifying claims often requires a sequence of reasoning operations, reflecting the dataset's complexity [5].

The need for multiple reasoning steps highlights the complexity of the SciTab dataset [5].  Models often struggle to perform well because of these challenges, achieving only marginally superior  $F_{1}$  scores than random guessing [6]. The challenging nature of SciTab is further demonstrated by the difference between machine performance and human annotators, where even the best open-source LLMs show a large gap compared to human capabilities [1].  ![Performance of different LLMs compared to human performance on SciTab](image1).

The SciTab dataset involves diverse reasoning functions and multiple reasoning steps, making it a challenging benchmark for scientific fact-checking [5, 6].

The SciTab dataset exhibits diverse reasoning patterns and error types that reflect the complexities of real-world scientific fact-checking [6, 7]. The types of errors and their estimated proportions for incorrectly-predicted samples in Program of Thoughts (PoT) are presented in Table 5 [1].

Errors are divided into four categories: Grounding errors, Ambiguity errors, Calculation errors, and Program errors [3]. ![Table 5 shows the error types and their estimated proportions for incorrectly-predicted samples in PoT.](image5) Grounding errors, where the program incorrectly associates data with the respective cells in the table, make up 50% of errors [3]. Ambiguity errors, where the claim contains ambiguous expressions that the program fails to represent, account for 22% of errors [3]. Calculation errors, where incorrect floating point arithmetic calculation in Python lead to inaccurate results, account for 20% of errors [3]. Program errors, which encompass mistakes such as incorrect or missing arguments/variables, and erroneous operations, make up 8% of errors [3].

The two most common features for unverifiable claims are insufficient evidence in the table and the lack of background knowledge [6]. The lack of closed-domain knowledge is another reason for NEI, where additional information in the paper is necessary to verify the claim [6].  The majority of models are impacted by these errors [8]. The distribution of reasoning steps and common error types are intricately linked in the SciTab dataset, where diverse reasoning patterns are present, encompassing tasks such as simple lookups, comparisons, and extracting closed-domain knowledge ![This image represents various reasoning tasks and their proportions in the dataset, highlighting the importance of simple lookups and comparisons.](image1). The main reasoning types in the SciTab dataset include grounding, ambiguity, calculation, and program errors, which contribute to the diverse challenges present in real-world scientific fact-checking.

The SciTab dataset exhibits diversity in refuted claims, with incorrect calculations and approximation words being major error types, while LLMs generally struggle with fact-checking on this dataset [3, 9].

The reasons for refuted claims in the SciTab dataset include incorrect calculation results (41.7%), incorrect approximation words (33.33%), and cases where the claim is partially right (10.0%) [9]. `SciTab exhibits diversity in refuted claims`().

In general, open-source LLMs do not achieve promising results on SCITAB, with a large gap from human performance [3]. The best result is 63.62 for the 2-class setting by Vicuna-7B and 38.05 for the 3-class setting by FLAN-T5-XL, which are only moderately better (+13.62 and +4.72) than random guessing [3]. ![FLAN-T5-XL achieves the best result in the 3-class setting](image4).

The relatively poor performance of LLMs reveals the challenging nature of SCITAB [3].

The primary reasons for refuted claims include incorrect calculation results and wrong approximation words, while NEI claims often suffer from insufficient evidence and lack of domain knowledge [3, 8]. Models struggle with NEI claims, leading to diminished confidence and poorer results in 3-class classification [6, 10].

The SCITAB dataset exhibits greater diversity in refuted claims, with common error types being "incorrect calculation results" (41.7%) and "incorrect approximation words" (33.33%) [8].  ![Refuted reasons include incorrect calculations and approximations, while NEI reasons include insufficient evidence and a lack of knowledge](image4)

For NEI claims, the most common features are insufficient evidence in the table (33.3%) and the lack of open-domain knowledge (25.0%) [3]. The lack of closed-domain knowledge is another reason for NEI, where additional information in the paper is necessary to verify the claim [3].

InstructGPT tends to classify supported and refuted claims as ‘NEI’, displaying a pattern of “less confident” [6]. In contrast, GPT-4 incorrectly categorizes NEI claims as either supported or refuted, exhibiting overconfidence [6]. This discrepancy highlights the challenge models face in determining whether a claim is verifiable [6]. The results in the 3-class setting are notably poorer than those in the 2-class setting, revealing the difficulties that most models face when confronted with the NEI class [10]. One plausible explanation could be the inherent difficulty in distinguishing between ‘refuted’ and ‘NEI’ claims [10].

The reasons for refuted and NEI claims significantly challenge the performance of models, particularly in zero-shot 3-class classification due to the difficulty in distinguishing between refuted and NEI claims and the models' confidence levels.

InstructGPT and GPT-4 exhibit distinct performance levels and error patterns in zero-shot 3-class classification on the S CI T AB dataset [10]. GPT-4 achieves a macro-$F_{1}$ score of 64.80, outperforming InstructGPT, as indicated by the overall results [1]. The performance comparison between InstructGPT and GPT-4 is shown in the table, which highlights the label distribution percentages for both models.

InstructGPT tends to classify supported and refuted claims as 'NEI', showing a "less confident" pattern, while GPT-4 incorrectly categorizes NEI claims as either supported or refuted, displaying overconfidence [10]. The confusion matrices reveal that both models struggle with accurately predicting the NEI class [10].

Furthermore, error analysis reveals specific challenges in the S CI T AB dataset that affect performance. The major error types include grounding errors, ambiguity errors, calculation errors and program errors.
![The major error types include grounding errors, ambiguity errors, calculation errors and program errors.](image4)
Specifically, InstructGPT and GPT-4 encounter difficulties in grounding data, handling ambiguous claims, and compositional reasoning, which are unique to the S CI T AB dataset [4, 9].

GPT-4 outperforms InstructGPT in zero-shot 3-class classification, but both models struggle with the NEI class due to challenges like grounding and ambiguous claims.

InstructGPT and GPT-4 show different patterns in predicting the NEI class, with InstructGPT being "less confident" and GPT-4 exhibiting "over confidence" [6]. This difference reflects a key challenge in the SCITAB dataset: distinguishing whether a claim is verifiable [6].
![InstructGPT and GPT-4 confusion matrices show label distribution percentages in the zero-shot 3-class setting.](image2)
In the zero-shot setting, InstructGPT tends to classify supported and refuted claims as NEI, indicating a lack of confidence, whereas GPT-4 often misclassifies NEI claims as either supported or refuted, highlighting overconfidence [6]. The table presents the error types and their estimated proportions for incorrectly-predicted samples in PoT [1]. This discrepancy in performance highlights the difficulty models face when dealing with the NEI class, where distinguishing between 'refuted' and 'NEI' claims poses a challenge, even for trained human annotators [4]. The performance difference suggests that InstructGPT is more conservative, opting for NEI when uncertain, while GPT-4 is more assertive, potentially leading to more incorrect classifications of NEI claims.
![Table shows the error types and their estimated proportions for incorrectly-predicted samples in PoT.](image3)
InstructGPT tends to be less confident, frequently classifying supported and refuted claims as ‘NEI’, whereas GPT-4 exhibits overconfidence, incorrectly categorizing NEI claims as either supported or refuted.

InstructGPT and GPT-4 encounter difficulties in accurately predicting the NEI (Not Enough Info) class [5]. `S CI T AB` presents unique challenges related to grounding and ambiguous claims, which contributes to the difficulty in zero-shot learning [4].

InstructGPT tends to classify supported and refuted claims as NEI, displaying a "less confident" pattern [5]. ![InstructGPT's confusion matrix in the zero-shot 3-class setting shows a tendency to classify claims as NEI.](image5)

GPT-4, in contrast, exhibits overconfidence, incorrectly categorizing NEI claims as either supported or refuted [5]. ![GPT-4's confusion matrix in the zero-shot 3-class setting shows a tendency to misclassify NEI claims as supported or refuted.](image5)

The main challenge for both InstructGPT and GPT-4 is determining whether a claim is verifiable, but InstructGPT tends to be less confident and classifies claims as NEI more often, whereas GPT-4 tends to be overconfident and incorrectly classifies NEI claims as supported or refuted [5].

The performance of GPT2-XL and GPT-J models can be evaluated across different datasets using metrics like accuracy and speed-up ratio, while confusion matrices offer insights into classification accuracies by visualizing category confusions.

The GPT2-XL model was chosen for its suitable size and ICL performance, and it was evaluated on datasets such as SST-2, TREC, AGNews, and EmoContext [6].  `Anchor Re-weighting (1-shot per class)` method shows significant performance improvements on all datasets.

The speed-up ratio, which indicates efficiency improvements, varies from $1.1\times$ to $2.9\times$, influenced by demonstration length, with GPT-J showing a more pronounced acceleration effect than GPT2-XL [2, 5]. ![GPT-J has the best performance among all three compression methods.](image3)

Confusion matrices reveal category confusions, showing that ICL errors occur in categories with similar label anchors [9]. Predicted confusion scores are compared with actual confusion scores via heatmaps to analyze model confusion [1].

The distances between key vector components correspond to category confusion, revealing the origin of ICL errors [4]. ![Heatmaps for GPT2-XL show the normalized distances between key vector components.](image4)

In summary, the performance metrics of GPT2-XL and GPT-J vary across datasets, and confusion matrices help understand classification accuracies by visualizing category confusions.

Llama 2-Chat models generally perform better than existing open-source models in terms of safety and appear to be on par with some closed-source models based on human evaluations [2]. Figure 17 illustrates the overall violation percentage and safety ratings of various LLMs, indicating that Llama 2-Chat has a comparable or lower overall violation percentage across different model sizes [3].

To improve the safety of Llama 2-Chat models, several measures were implemented, including safety-specific data annotation and tuning, red-teaming, and iterative evaluations [2]. The development process of Llama 2-Chat involved human feedback to ensure safety and helpfulness, as depicted in image1, which shows the steps of pretraining, human feedback and fine-tuning to optimize dialogue use cases for Llama 2-Chat. ![The diagram illustrates the pretraining, human feedback, and fine-tuning processes used to develop Llama 2-Chat.](image1)

The safety performance of Llama 2-Chat is particularly notable in multi-turn conversations, where it outperforms baselines [7]. However, it's important to interpret safety results carefully due to the limitations of the prompt set, subjectivity of review guidelines, content standards, and individual rater subjectivity [3]. Figure 4 shows the violation percentages of different LLMs, where a lower percentage indicates better safety [3]. ![The bar graph compares violation percentages across various LLMs.](image4)

Llama 2-Chat models are fine-tuned to optimize for dialogue use cases and have demonstrated competitiveness with existing open-source chat models, achieving competency equivalent to some proprietary models [4, 10].

Llama 2-Chat models achieve competitive safety performance through a combination of data annotation, tuning, red-teaming, and iterative evaluations.

The removal of knowledge elements significantly impacts citation precision and recall but has a minimal impact on correctness [2]. As more knowledge is removed, precision and recall drop drastically, demonstrating that the coverage issue poses a considerable challenge to generating answers with high-quality citations [2].

The trend of precision and F1-Score increases with the number of absent knowledge in KG. The recall remains stable at approximately 15, irrespective of the quantity of absent knowledge, suggesting that LLMs possess a limited capability to recognize absent knowledge [5]. This is further visualized in the experiment results shown in image3, illustrating the effect of removing knowledge on precision, recall, and F1-Score.
![The image visualizes the impact of removing knowledge on precision, recall, and F1-Score, showing a clear upward trend for precision and F1-Score, while recall remains stable.](image3)

This demonstrates the increasing effectiveness of the "Conscious Incompetence" setting as the coverage of the attribution source worsens [3]. "Conscious Incompetence" enables generated outputs to locate absent knowledge more accurately as more knowledge is absent in KG [5].

The impact of poor retrieval quality on recall is more significant than on precision [10]. This indicates that the model can filter out incorrect knowledge to a certain extent, resulting in a less noticeable impact on precision compared to recall [10]. The reduction in recall was nearly linear as retrieval accuracy decreased [10]. This is evident in the retrieval analysis depicted in image5, which illustrates how precision, recall, F1-Score, and correctness change with retrieval accuracy.
![The image depicts the relationship between retrieval accuracy and various metrics, including precision, recall, F1-Score, and correctness, showing downward trends as retrieval accuracy decreases.](image5)

The removal of knowledge elements leads to a significant drop in citation precision and recall, highlighting coverage challenges, while the "Conscious Incompetence" setting helps models identify and handle absent knowledge to some extent.

The performance of models on the MAVEN-ERE and Causal-TimeBank datasets is influenced by the use of logical constraints and the number of demonstration samples.  Adding logical constraints into LLM instructions can provide stable improvements, especially with more demonstrations [7]. ![Adding logical constraints with smaller number of demonstrations surpasses prompts with larger number of demonstrations.](image4)

Specifically, models incorporating logical constraints with fewer demonstrations can outperform models using only a larger number of demonstrations [7]. For example, the performance of using 5 demonstrations on MAVEN-ERE with logical constraints (25.7%) surpasses that of 10 demonstrations without logical constraints (24.5%) [7]. This highlights the importance of providing LLMs with both "What" (demonstrations) and "How" (logical constraints) [7].

Furthermore, the effectiveness of logical constraints is evident in pre-trained models.  Once trained on LLM-LR, the performance of LlaMA2-13B and Vicuna-13B improves greatly compared with baselines without logical constraints [9].  As shown in the table, models like Turbo, Davinci, GPT-4, Vicuna, and Llama2 generally achieve better Micro-F1 scores and lower logical inconsistency (LI) when using CoT with logical constraints, compared to vanilla ICL or vanilla ICL with CoT [6]. ![Models generally achieve better Micro-F1 scores and lower logical inconsistency when using CoT with logical constraints.](image1)

The use of logical constraints and demonstration samples significantly enhances the performance of various models on the MAVEN-ERE and Causal-TimeBank datasets by improving both accuracy and logical consistency.

The impact of logical constraints and post-processing on reducing logical inconsistency (LI) varies across different Large Language Models (LLMs) and datasets. According to [8], retrieval-based approaches to obtain logical constraints and incorporate them into LLM instruction greatly reduced the logical inconsistency of LLMs’ answers. However, post-processing, while guaranteeing the absence of logical conflicts, may severely affect the quality of the whole generation [8].
 

 Examining the results in Image 1, it can be observed that post-processing consistently reduces the LI to 0% across all models (Turbo, Davinci, GPT-4, Vicuna, and Llama2) for both MAVEN-ERE and Causal-TimeBank datasets. ![Post-processing reduces logical inconsistency to 0% across all models and datasets](image1)
 

 However, this often comes at the cost of Micro-F1 score, as the semantics of the post-processing answer may deviate significantly from the ground truth due to the random selection [8]. For instance, GPT-4 achieves 37.3% Micro-F1 on MAVEN-ERE with all logical constraints, but this drops to 17.0% with post-processing; similarly, on Causal-TimeBank, it goes from 26.0% to 19.0%.
 

 In contrast, incorporating logical constraints without post-processing generally leads to a smaller reduction in LI but maintains a higher Micro-F1 score. This suggests that while logical constraints help guide the LLM towards more consistent reasoning, they do not eliminate inconsistencies entirely and that adding logical constraints into LLM instructions can provide stable improvements, especially with more demonstrations [2].
 

 Overall, post-processing is effective in eliminating logical inconsistencies but can negatively impact the quality of the generated content, while logical constraints offer a balance between reducing inconsistencies and preserving generation quality.

The contemporary evaluation practices of RAG models emphasize three primary quality scores and four essential abilities [3]. To evaluate the generation quality, the assessment focuses on the generator’s capacity to synthesize coherent and relevant answers from the retrieved context [2].

Several benchmark tests and tools are proposed to evaluate RAG models [6]. These instruments furnish quantitative metrics that gauge model performance and enhance understanding of the model’s capabilities across various evaluation aspects [6]. Prominent benchmarks such as RGB, RECALL and CRUD focus on appraising the essential abilities of RAG models [6]. State-of-the-art automated tools like RAGAS, ARES, and TruLens employ LLMs to adjudicate the quality scores [6]. These tools and benchmarks form a robust framework for the systematic evaluation of RAG models [6].
![Evaluation frameworks like RGB, RAGAS, ARES, TruLens, and CRUD assess both retrieval and generation quality, using metrics like accuracy, cosine similarity, and BLEU.](image2)

The specific metrics for each evaluation aspect are derived from related work and represent traditional measures [5]. It is essential to recognize that these metrics do not yet represent a mature or standardized approach for quantifying RAG evaluation aspects [5].

The evaluation frameworks that focus on both retrieval and generation quality include RGB, RAGAS, ARES, TruLens, and CRUD, which use various metrics such as accuracy, cosine similarity, and BLEU across different evaluation aspects.

RAG evaluation involves assessing both retrieval and generation quality using specific metrics and frameworks [10].
![Evaluation of RAG focuses on both retrieval and generation quality.](image1)

Traditional measures are used, but they are still evolving, and custom metrics are being developed [4]. RAGAS, ARES, and TruLens use LLMs to evaluate the quality scores [10]. Evaluation aspects include answer relevance, context relevance and answer faithfulness [10].  
![Different evaluation aspects of RAG.](image5)
These frameworks use a range of metrics to evaluate different aspects of RAG models.

The key evaluation aspects for RAG models include retrieval and generation quality, which are assessed using various metrics across different evaluation frameworks [10].

The RGB and CRUD evaluation frameworks differ in their evaluation targets and aspects within the context of RAG models. RGB focuses on retrieval and generation quality, assessing noise robustness, negative rejection, information integration, and counterfactual robustness, whereas CRUD targets retrieval and generation quality by creative generation, knowledge-intensive QA, error correction, and summarization [9].

RGB evaluates retrieval quality and generation quality based on noise robustness, negative rejection, information integration, and counterfactual robustness, using metrics like Accuracy and EM scores, as shown in Table IV ![RGB evaluates Retrieval Quality and Generation Quality using metrics like Accuracy and EM scores](image4).

CRUD evaluates retrieval and generation quality based on creative generation, knowledge-intensive QA, error correction, and summarization, using metrics such as BLEU and ROUGE-L, as shown in Table IV ![CRUD evaluates Retrieval and Generation Quality using BLEU and ROUGE-L metrics](image4).

In summary, RGB emphasizes robustness and factual correctness, while CRUD focuses on creative and knowledge-intensive aspects of generation.

The evaluation frameworks RGB, RAGAS and CRUD differ in their evaluation targets, aspects, and quantitative metrics. RGB evaluates Retrieval Quality and Generation Quality, considering aspects like Noise Robustness, Negative Rejection, Information Integration, and Counterfactual Robustness, and uses quantitative metrics such as Accuracy and EM. RAGAS also targets Retrieval Quality and Generation Quality but focuses on Context Relevance, Faithfulness, and Answer Relevance, using Cosine Similarity as a metric. CRUD assesses Retrieval Quality and Generation Quality by evaluating Creative Generation, Knowledge-intensive QA, Error Correction, and Summarization, and employs metrics like BLEU, ROUGE-L, BertScore, and RAGQuestEval.

The evaluation frameworks focus on different aspects of retrieval and generation quality and employ distinct quantitative metrics to assess these aspects. The assessment of generation quality centers on the generator’s capacity to synthesize coherent and relevant answers from the retrieved context [8].
![RGB, RAGAS and CRUD are evaluation frameworks that target Retrieval Quality and Generation Quality.](image4)
RGB focuses on retrieval and generation quality, considering noise robustness, negative rejection, information integration, and counterfactual robustness, using accuracy and EM as metrics [See image4]. RAGAS also targets retrieval and generation quality but focuses on context relevance, faithfulness, and answer relevance, using cosine similarity as a metric [See image4]. CRUD assesses retrieval and generation quality by evaluating creative generation, knowledge-intensive QA, error correction, and summarization, and employs metrics like BLEU, ROUGE-L, BertScore, and RAGQuestEval [See image4].
Therefore, each framework employs a unique combination of targets, aspects, and metrics to evaluate RAG models.

Advanced RAG enhances retrieval quality by employing pre-retrieval and post-retrieval strategies [1]. It refines indexing techniques and incorporates optimization methods to streamline the retrieval process [1].
![Advanced RAG improves upon Naive RAG via Index/pre-retrieval/post-retrieval optimization.](image5)
The modular RAG architecture offers enhanced adaptability and versatility, going beyond the former two RAG paradigms [8].
![Modular RAG offers enhanced adaptability and versatility over the other two RAG paradigms.](image3)
The development of Advanced RAG and Modular RAG is a response to the specific shortcomings in Naive RAG [3]. Advanced RAG improves upon Naive RAG by refining indexing techniques and incorporating optimization methods, while Modular RAG enhances adaptability and versatility, addressing the limitations of both Naive and Advanced RAG.

The Naive, Advanced, and Modular RAG frameworks represent a progression in the approach to document retrieval and query processing, each building upon the foundations of its predecessors to overcome limitations and enhance adaptability [4, 10]. Naive RAG follows a traditional "Retrieve-Read" framework [3]. Advanced RAG enhances retrieval quality through pre-retrieval and post-retrieval strategies, refining indexing techniques and incorporating metadata [1]. Modular RAG offers adaptability by allowing module substitution or reconfiguration to address specific challenges, going beyond the fixed structures of Naive and Advanced RAG [5].

The evolution from Naive to Advanced and Modular RAG involves increasing complexity and flexibility in how modules are arranged and how they interact, ultimately supporting both sequential processing and integrated end-to-end training [10]. For example, innovations like the Rewrite-Retrieve-Read model leverage the LLM’s capabilities to refine retrieval queries, improving task performance [9]. The advancements in Modular RAG, as illustrated in image1, include the addition of specialized components to enhance retrieval and processing capabilities, such as search, memory, routing, predict, and task adapter modules [7]. ![Modular RAG framework introduces additional specialized components to enhance retrieval and processing capabilities.](image1)

Modular RAG's architecture allows for dynamic adjustments in module arrangement and interaction, such as the Demonstrate-Search-Predict (DSP) framework and the iterative Retrieve-Read-Retrieve-Read flow, enhancing module synergy and integrating more easily with other technologies [6]. As shown in image3, the complexity of the RAG system increases from Naive RAG to Modular RAG [3]. ![The complexity of the RAG system increases from Naive RAG to Modular RAG.](image3)

In summary, Naive RAG uses a simple retrieve-and-read approach, Advanced RAG enhances retrieval quality with optimization strategies, and Modular RAG offers adaptability through flexible module arrangements and interactions.

RAPTOR's querying mechanisms include tree traversal and collapsed tree methods, each offering unique ways to retrieve relevant information from the multi-layered RAPTOR tree [9]. The collapsed tree approach, which searches through all nodes simultaneously, is believed to be better because it retrieves information at the correct level of granularity for a given question [10]. In contrast, tree traversal maintains a constant ratio of thematic information to granular details, regardless of the question [10].

![The diagram contrasts Tree Traversal Retrieval with Collapsed Tree Retrieval, illustrating the flow from query to answer using different tree structures.](image2)

Figure 3 shows that the collapsed tree approach consistently performs better than tree traversal [10].

![The line graph compares the performance of the collapsed tree and tree traversal methods on the QASPER dataset, showing F1 scores against context length.](image3)

Table 3 indicates that RAPTOR consistently outperforms BM25 and DPR across different Language Models on the QASPER dataset [2]. RAPTOR's F-1 Match scores are  $53.1\%$  ,  $55.7\%$  , and  $36.6\%$   when using GPT-3, GPT-4, and UnifiedQA, respectively [2]. These scores surpass DPR by margins of 1.8, 2.7, and 4.5 points and outdo BM25 by 6.5, 5.5, and 10.2 points across the respective LLMs [2]. Additionally, RAPTOR outperforms the baselines of BM25 and DPR by at least  $2.0\%$   in accuracy when using GPT-3 and UnifiedQA 3B [4]. RAPTOR also outperforms BM25 and DPR across all tested language models, with F-1 scores that are at least $1.8\%$ points higher than DPR and at least $5.3\%$ points higher than BM25 [6].

In summary, the collapsed tree retrieval method outperforms tree traversal and RAPTOR with DPR on the QASPER dataset and other evaluation metrics due to its flexibility and ability to retrieve information at the appropriate level of granularity.

RAPTOR employs two querying mechanisms: tree traversal and collapsed tree [6]. The collapsed tree approach, which searches through all nodes simultaneously, is believed to be better due to offering greater flexibility, allowing it to retrieve information at the correct level of granularity for a given question [5]. In comparison, tree traversal maintains a constant ratio of thematic information to granular details, regardless of the question [5].

The "collapsed tree" method generally outperforms the "tree traversal" method across varying context lengths, as it can retrieve information at the correct level of granularity for a given question, offering greater flexibility compared to tree traversal ![Collapsed tree retrieval is better due to its flexibility and ability to retrieve information at the correct level.](image3)
