Specifically, RAPTOR’s higher-level summary nodes allow it to outperform methods that can only extract the top-k most similar raw chunks of text, which may not contain the correct response in isolation [4]. On QASPER, RAPTOR with GPT-4 sets a new benchmark with a 55.7% F-1 score, surpassing CoLT5 XL's score of 53.9% [8]. This shows the effectiveness of RAPTOR in synthesizing information within NLP papers [4].  ![RAPTOR, combined with GPT-4, achieves a superior F-1 score compared to other models on the QASPER dataset.](image3)

RAPTOR's tree-based retrieval system augments the parametric knowledge of large language models with contextual information at various levels of abstraction, leading to more effective retrieval [9]. RAPTOR excels across multiple metrics and datasets due to its ability to synthesize information at various levels and its hierarchical tree structure [1, 9].

RAPTOR consistently outperforms other models across various datasets and language models, often setting new state-of-the-art results. For instance, on the QASPER dataset, RAPTOR's F-1 Match scores surpass DPR by margins of 1.8, 2.7, and 4.5 points, and outdoes BM25 by 6.5, 5.5, and 10.2 points when using GPT-3, GPT-4, and UnifiedQA, respectively [2].
![RAPTOR outperforms BM25 and DPR with GPT-3, GPT-4 and UnifiedQA models](image2)
As shown in Table 3, RAPTOR achieves F-1 scores of 53.1%, 55.7%, and 36.6% with GPT-3, GPT-4, and UnifiedQA, respectively [2]. Furthermore, RAPTOR paired with GPT-4 sets a new benchmark on QASPER, achieving a 55.7% F-1 score, surpassing the CoLT5 XL’s score of 53.9% [10].
![RAPTOR with GPT-4 sets a new F-1 score benchmark on QASPER, outperforming CoLT5 XL](image4)
In the QuALITY dataset, RAPTOR paired with GPT-4 sets a new state-of-the-art with an accuracy of 82.6%, surpassing the previous best result of 62.3% [3].
![RAPTOR with GPT-4 achieves state-of-the-art accuracy on the QuALITY dataset](image5)
RAPTOR achieves an accuracy of 62.4% on the QuALITY dataset, improving over DPR and BM25 by 2% and 5.1%, respectively [7].

In summary, RAPTOR consistently demonstrates superior performance compared to BM25, DPR, and other state-of-the-art models across multiple datasets and language models.

RAPTOR exhibits robust performance across multiple datasets and evaluation metrics when combined with different language models.

On the QASPER dataset, RAPTOR consistently outperforms BM25 and DPR across GPT-3, GPT-4, and UnifiedQA, with F-1 scores surpassing DPR by 1.8 to 4.5 points and BM25 by 5.5 to 10.2 points [4]. ![RAPTOR outperforms BM25 and DPR across GPT-3, GPT-4 and UnifiedQA on the QASPER dataset.](image2)

Inter-annotator agreement varies when evaluating task fulfillment and relevance across different models compared to Chameleon.  Figure 9b shows Chameleon's win rates over baseline models [8]. ![Chameleon's win rates against baseline models show varying degrees of preference by annotators.](image1)

Conversely, Figure 9b also indicates that when comparing Chameleon to the original responses from Gemini without augmented images, Chameleon's responses are considered better in 53.5% of cases [8]. Table 4 shows the numbers of cases where annotators agree [9]. For each model pair, there is a bit higher than 10% of the cases where there is no agreement among the three annotators [9]. On about 28% to 35% of the pairs, all annotators have unanimous judgments, and in about 55% to 60% of the pairs, one annotator differs from other two [9].
![The table provides a comparison of agreement levels among annotators when evaluating Chameleon against other models, indicating varying degrees of consensus.](image2)

In conclusion, Chameleon performs similarly to other baselines in many cases, making the relative evaluation challenging, indicated by the varying agreement rates among annotators [9].

In relative evaluations, there is unanimous agreement among all annotators in about 28% to 35% of the pairs, while in 55% to 60% of pairs, only one annotator differs from the other two [1]. In about 10% of the cases, there is no agreement among the three annotators, which is considered a tie [1].

![The table shows agreement levels among annotators for Chameleon compared to Gemini+ and GPT-4V.](image2)

For absolute evaluations, annotators rarely disagree on simple, objective properties of the responses, like objectionable content [2]. The levels of agreement on each question in the absolute evaluation are shown in Figure 10 [3].

![This bar graph illustrates the agreement levels among annotators for various aspects of model evaluation, including containing images, image quality, image relevance, language quality, objectionable content, relevance, task fulfillment and accuracy.](image4)

Chameleon and its comparison models show varying levels of inter-annotator agreement, with high agreement on objective properties and more disagreement on subjective aspects.

The safety of Chameleon's responses is evaluated across different model sizes and datasets. The agreement level among annotators when comparing Chameleon to other models is also considered.

Evaluations of  Chameleon  show high safety ratings, with the 7B model having 0.39% unsafe responses and the 30B model having only 0.095% unsafe responses [9].  ![Crowdsourced and Red Team datasets were used to assess the safety of Chameleon models, with results showing high percentages of safe responses.](image3)

The relative evaluation, indicates annotators often agree, but there's still a notable percentage of disagreements [2]. Specifically, around 10% of cases show no agreement among three annotators, roughly 28% to 35% show unanimous agreement, and about 55% to 60% have one differing annotator [2].

Based on crowd sourced prompts, a majority of Chameleon’s responses are considered safe [9].
The agreement level among annotators varies, but a significant portion of evaluations have unanimous or majority agreement [2].

The Chameleon models' safety performance and their benchmark evaluation in commonsense reasoning and math tasks can be compared using the provided data.

Regarding safety, the 7B and 34B parameter Chameleon models show high safety rates on the crowdsourced dataset, as indicated by:

In contrast, the 34B model's safety performance decreases to 93.9% on the Red Team dataset, with 1.6% unsafe and 4.5% unsure, indicating a higher risk profile in adversarial settings.

The RAR method demonstrates effectiveness across both fine-grained visual recognition and zero-shot object recognition, with specific performance improvements noted in each area.

In fine-grained visual recognition, RAR (LLaVA1.5) shows a notable increase in classification accuracy, boosting the top-1 accuracy from 57.0% to 63.2% on the 4-shot setting, and from 63.0% to 69.8% on the 8-shot setting [1]. This improvement highlights RAR's ability to use context and detail for better alignment with ground truth [1].
![RAR improves classification accuracy.](image1)

RAR also enhances performance in zero-shot object recognition.  For example, when combined with InternLM-XC2, the approach yielded an 8.4% improvement [7]. The experimental results on V3Det reveal that RAR achieves a commendable improvement, surpassing the CLIP baseline by 1.5 percentage points in overall average precision [10]. This is significant, given the dataset's complexity, which includes 13,204 distinct classes [10].

RAR's retrieving and ranking mechanisms allow MLLMs to effectively navigate extensive and fine-grained category landscapes [10]. On the LVIS dataset, applying RAR yields notable improvements across all metrics [7]. The integration of RAR to MLLMs demonstrates a heightened ability to discriminate among the rare classes [3]. Our RAR achieves a robust enhancement in the model’s ability to discern and accurately classify objects that are infrequently encountered [3].

In summary, the RAR (LLaVA1.5) model demonstrates significant performance improvements in both fine-grained visual recognition and zero-shot object recognition by leveraging its retrieving and ranking mechanisms to enhance the ability of MLLMs to classify images accurately.

The RAR models generally outperform baseline models in zero-shot object recognition, particularly on datasets with large vocabularies, by leveraging retrieving and ranking mechanisms [8, 9]. On the LVIS dataset, RAR achieves a 6.4% improvement, and on the V3Det dataset, it gains 1.5% [5]. These improvements highlight the effectiveness of the RAR approach in enhancing the performance of MLLMs for object detection tasks with extensive category lists [9].

RAR with LLaVA1.5, Qwen-VL and InternLM-XC2 models show improvements in average precision (AP) compared to CLIP w/ box across different object scales;  RAR with InternLM-XC2 performs best overall.

RAR demonstrates a substantial advantage, particularly with rare categories, surpassing the CLIP model by as much as 19.6 percentage points [7]. This significant leap in performance suggests that RAR's retrieving and reranking mechanism effectively pools relevant information from the external memory, providing the MLLMs with a richer context for rare class identification [7].

![RAR achieves higher AP scores compared to CLIP in rare category recognition.](image2)

In scenarios with an extremely large number of fine-grained categories, experiments on V3Det reveal that RAR has achieved a commendable improvement in performance, surpassing the CLIP baseline by 1.5 percentage points in overall average precision with InternLM-XC2 [9]. The method significantly enhances few-shot learning abilities, yielding an average improvement of 6.2% over 11 image classification datasets under the 4-shot setting [5].

![The chart shows the classification and RAR performance across fine-grained and common datasets.](image3)

The RAR approach enhances zero-shot object recognition performance by effectively retrieving and ranking relevant information, especially for rare categories and large vocabulary datasets [7, 9].

In object detection datasets, the process involves additional pre-processing steps and leveraging CLIP's image-text interaction capabilities [8]. Cropping and blurring are applied to focus the MLLMs on relevant objects, with image-to-text retrieval used to obtain category information [8].
![The image illustrates the pre-processing and embedding & retrieval steps for object detection datasets.](image4)
For object detection datasets, the methodology starts with cropping image regions based on proposal bounding box coordinates, and the cropped region is subsequently resized to a fixed proportion [8]. Additionally, a blurring technique is applied to non-target areas to direct the MLLMs' focus toward the objects of interest [8]. The image embedding $e$ is then navigated through the constructed memory index and ranked by similarity to identify the top-k related images [10].
![The image illustrates the architecture for retrieving and ranking augmented method for MLLMs.](image3)
This method uses CLIP’s inherent image-text interaction capabilities to conduct image-to-text retrieval to get the top-k category information with the highest similarity [6].The MLLMs then rank these retrieved candidate results as the final prediction results [9].

The multimodal retriever system processes and ranks objects for recognition in detection datasets by cropping, blurring, and using image-to-text retrieval to focus on relevant objects.

On TimeQA, Step-Back + RAG is able to fix $39.9\%$ of baseline's wrong predictions while causing $5.6\%$ errors, and it fixes $21.6\%$ of errors coming from RAG, with Step-Back causing only $6.3\%$ errors to RAG [4]. ![Step-Back + RAG fixes 39.9% of baseline's wrong predictions on TimeQA while introducing few errors.](image2)

On StrategyQA, Step-Back + RAG improves $15.4\%$ of the baseline model's wrong predictions but introduces $6.1\%$ errors, and it corrects $12.7\%$ of RAG's errors, with Step-Back causing only $4.4\%$ errors to RAG [10].
Additionally, Figure 7 shows the error analysis of Step-Back + RAG on StrategyQA against the baseline model and the raw retrieval augmentation variant of PaLM-2L [10].

These differences are significant because the TimeQA test set contains 5226 examples [7], focusing on temporal reasoning, while the StrategyQA dev set includes 229 examples and requires multi-hop reasoning [7]. The error analysis reveals that Step-Back + RAG is more effective at correcting baseline predictions in TimeQA ($39.9\%$) compared to StrategyQA ($15.4\%$) [4, 10]. The error rate introduced by Step-Back is relatively low in both datasets [4, 10].

The error analysis for Step-Back + RAG shows a higher error correction rate on TimeQA compared to StrategyQA, reflecting the differences in the nature and scale of the datasets.

The 'Step-Back' prompting method demonstrates notable performance improvements and error reduction compared to baseline models and other prompting techniques. On the TimeQA benchmark, the Step-Back + RAG method significantly boosts accuracy to 68.7% compared to baseline models [4]. Regular RAG improves the accuracy to 57.4% [4]. CoT and TDB prompting techniques do not show significant improvements for SituatedQA [3].

Error analysis reveals that Step-Back prompting fixes a substantial portion of errors made by baseline models. Step-Back prompting is able to fix 39.9% of the predictions where the baseline prediction is wrong [5]. ![Step-Back fixes a substantial portion of errors made by baseline models, with reasoning errors being the most dominant source of errors.](image2) Ablation studies indicate that the performance of Step-Back prompting is robust to the number of exemplars used in demonstration [9].

Moreover, Step-Back prompting shows strong performance on knowledge-intensive tasks.  On MMLU Physics, PaLM-2L + Step-Back achieves 73.2%, while on MMLU Chemistry, it reaches 81.8% [5]. ![PaLM-2L with Step-Back prompting shows performance improvements in MMLU Physics and Chemistry.](image5) The effectiveness of Step-Back prompting is also evident on SituatedQA, where it achieves a moderate quality gain [3].

Step-Back prompting provides a helpful abstraction before addressing the original question [5]. The accuracy on TimeQA achieves a remarkable 68.7% [4]. Overall, the 'Step-Back' prompting method enhances accuracy and corrects errors effectively across various benchmarks, demonstrating its value in improving model performance.

The performance of various methods, including Step-Back Prompting and RAG, significantly impacts the accuracy in different Knowledge QA tasks compared to baseline models like GPT-4, while Step-Back Prompting encounters reasoning and retrieval errors.

Step-Back Prompting enhances performance across various tasks:
*   **Multi-Hop Reasoning:** Step-Back Prompting significantly outperforms GPT-4 on MuSiQue and StrategyQA tasks [1]. Specifically, Step-Back Prompting achieves $42.8\%$ on MuSiQue and $86.4\%$ on StrategyQA, surpassing GPT-4 [1]. The use of abstraction in Step-Back Prompting leads to the best performance across all methods [1].
*   **Knowledge QA:**  Step-Back + RAG improves accuracy on TimeQA to $68.7\%$, demonstrating the effectiveness of using high-level concepts for reliable retrieval augmentation [9].

Here is the table demonstrating the results of Step-Back Prompting on Multi-Hop Reasoning:
![Step-Back Prompting significantly outperforms GPT-4 on MuSiQue and StrategyQA tasks.](image5)

*   **MMLU Physics and Chemistry:** Step-Back prompting outperforms PaLM-2L, CoT, and TDB methods [3]. Step-Back Prompting achieves $73.2\%$ on MMLU Physics and $81.8\%$ on MMLU Chemistry [3].

Here is the table demonstrating the results of Step-Back Prompting on Knowledge QA tasks:
![Step-Back prompting outperforms PaLM-2L, CoT, and TDB methods on MMLU Physics and Chemistry.](image1)

Common error types associated with Step-Back Prompting:
*   **Reasoning Errors:**  More than half of the errors are due to reasoning errors [10].  $55\%$ of errors are due to failure in reasoning [4].
*   **RAG Failures:** A significant portion of errors are due to the failure in retrieving the right information, despite the abstraction provided by Step-Back [10].   $45\%$ of errors are due to failure in retrieving the right information [10].
*   **StepBack rarely fails**: StepBack rarely fails [10].

Here is a analysis of errors Step-Back makes:
![The major error sources for Step-Back are Reasoning and RAG.](image3)

In summary, Step-Back Prompting generally improves performance in QA tasks, but its effectiveness is limited by reasoning errors and retrieval failures, while it significantly outperforms other methods and models like GPT-4 by leveraging abstraction and relevant information retrieval.

The S TEP -B ACK prompting technique, especially when combined with Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG), significantly improves the performance of PaLM-2L across several challenging Question Answering (QA) tasks [5].

On TimeQA, PaLM-2L with Step-Back + RAG achieves an accuracy of 68.7%, a notable improvement compared to the baseline models [4]. ![PaLM-2L achieves 68.7% accuracy on TimeQA by using Step-Back and RAG.](image2)

In the MuSiQue benchmark, PaLM-2L's baseline performance is low at 35.5%, but S TEP -B ACK prompting, combined with RAG, boosts the performance to 42.8% [7]. ![PaLM-2L achieves 42.8% accuracy on MuSiQue by using Step-Back and RAG.](image5)

For StrategyQA, which has a stronger baseline, S TEP -B ACK prompting with RAG still improves PaLM-2L's performance, achieving an accuracy of 86.4% [7]. ![PaLM-2L achieves 86.4% accuracy on StrategyQA by using Step-Back and RAG.](image5)

In summary, PaLM-2L with Step-Back and RAG consistently outperforms baseline models and other prompting techniques across TimeQA, MuSiQue, and StrategyQA, demonstrating the effectiveness of abstraction in improving performance on complex reasoning tasks.

The inclusion of entity detection (ED) and retrieval augmentation (RA) significantly enhances the performance of the SnapNTell model by improving accuracy and reducing hallucination rates.

The impact of entity detection (ED) on the model's performance can be seen from the following:
*   The approach incorporating entity detection markedly surpasses the variant lacking this feature [2]. This highlights the significant contribution and necessity of the entity detection step in the model’s overall effectiveness [2].
*   `w/ ED` method performs better in terms of ROUGE, BLEU, METEOR and BELURT than `w/o ED`. ![The table shows the approach incorporating entity detection markedly surpasses the variant lacking this feature.](image1)

The benefits of retrieval augmentation (RA) are:
*   Retrieval augmentation can significantly enhance performance across various entity types [1].
*   The performance improvement for torso-to-tail entities far exceeds that of head entities, effectively addressing the challenge of hallucinations in long-tailed entities through retrieval augmentation [1].
*   The accuracy improvements and reduced hallucination rates for Head, Torso, and Tail entities when using retrieval augmentation (RA) relative to not using it (w/o RA). ![Retrieval augmentation resulted in accuracy improvements and reduced hallucination rates for Head, Torso, and Tail entities.](image2)

In summary, both entity detection and retrieval augmentation contribute to the SnapNTell model's improved accuracy and reduced hallucination rates, particularly for long-tail entities.

The SnapNTell model demonstrates superior performance compared to existing baseline models due to its retrieval-augmented multimodal LLM architecture [5].

The SnapNTell model architecture utilizes retrieval augmentation to gather relevant information about the entity in the image, enhancing the quality of responses [5]. The architecture takes an image-question pair as input, merging text embeddings with image-projected embeddings before entering the LLM, which results in a knowledgeable answer as the output `![The SnapNTell model architecture processes image-question pairs, uses retrieval augmentation, and outputs a knowledgeable answer.](image3)`.

The performance disparities among baseline models are not significant on traditional VQA datasets, but the SnapNTell dataset shows larger differences and lower performance, highlighting its effectiveness in evaluating models' abilities to recognize entities and produce entity-centered responses [8].  As shown in the table, SnapNTell outperforms other models in ROUGE, BLEU, METEOR, and BLEURT metrics `![SnapNTell achieves higher scores compared to other models in various evaluation metrics.](image2)`.

The inclusion of entity detection (ED) significantly boosts the model's effectiveness, as demonstrated by the performance increase when ED is incorporated [10]. The results in the table demonstrate that the approach incorporating entity detection markedly surpasses the variant lacking this feature `![The table highlights the improvement in performance metrics when entity detection (ED) is included in the model.](image1)`. Furthermore, the retrieval augmentation (RA) particularly enhances the performance for torso-to-tail entities, addressing the challenge of hallucinations in long-tailed entities `![Retrieval augmentation improves accuracy and reduces hallucinations, especially for torso and tail entities.](image4)`.

In pairwise comparisons against ground-truth data, the SnapNTell model displays a significantly smaller difference compared to baselines, showcasing its robustness [7].  In the pairwise comparison our model outperforms the baselines by displaying a significantly smaller difference when measured against manually annotated ground-truth samples, highlighting its robustness `![The chart illustrates that the SnapNTell model has fewer losses compared to other models, indicating superior performance against ground truth data.](image5)`.

The SnapNTell model outperforms existing baselines due to its retrieval-augmented multimodal LLM architecture and the inclusion of entity detection, which allows for more accurate and coherent answers, especially for long-tail entity queries.

The inclusion of entity detection (ED) significantly enhances the performance of the SnapNTell model across various evaluation metrics. The table shows performance comparison with and without ED component. ![The approach incorporating entity detection markedly surpasses the variant lacking this feature.](image1) As indicated in Table 5, the approach incorporating entity detection markedly surpasses the variant lacking this feature [4]. This highlights the significant contribution and necessity of the entity detection step in the model’s overall effectiveness [4].

The use of entity detection in the SnapNTell model leads to better performance across different evaluation metrics.

SnapNTell's performance has been evaluated using both NLP metrics and human evaluations, showing it surpasses baseline models but still has room for improvement compared to human annotations [2, 9]. The quality of answers is assessed using NLP metrics such as BLEU, METEOR, ROUGE, and BLEURT, along with accuracy and hallucination rate metrics [9].

The SnapNTell dataset shows significantly larger differences and lower performance compared to existing VQA datasets, indicating its effectiveness in evaluating models' abilities to recognize entities and produce entity-centered responses [10].  ![SnapNTell demonstrates marked performance disparities compared to other VQA datasets.](image2)

Compared to baseline models, retrieval-augmented multimodal LLM used in SnapNTell surpasses their performance across all assessed metrics, emphasizing the efficiency of retrieval augmentation in producing entity-centric information [7].  ![SnapNTell outperforms existing models across multiple NLP evaluation metrics.](image4)

Human evaluation results suggest significant potential for further improvement [2]. Although the approach often neared human-level performance, it did not consistently outperform human annotations, showing opportunities for future advancements [2]. The human evaluation process involved a panel of five judges who assessed key aspects according to specific instructions [8]. ![SnapNTell exhibits competitive performance in a human evaluation.](image1)

SnapNTell outperforms existing approaches, providing more accurate and coherent answers and addresses the challenge VLLMs face with long-tail entity queries, which often lead to inaccurate or hallucinated responses [5]. The performance improvement for torso-to-tail entities far exceeds that of head entities, effectively addressing the challenge of hallucinations in long-tailed entities through retrieval augmentation [3].  ![Retrieval augmentation significantly enhances performance, especially for torso-to-tail entities.](image3)

SnapNTell demonstrates superior performance compared to baseline models and near-human level performance; it has room for improvement when compared to human annotations.

SPECTER demonstrates superior performance in document classification and citation prediction compared to other models, and it exhibits clearer topic separation in visualized embeddings compared to SciBERT.

For document classification, SPECTER outperforms other baselines, achieving an F1 score of 86.4 on the MeSH dataset and 82.0 on the MAG dataset, which represents an absolute increase of approximately 2.3 and 1.5 points, respectively [5]. In user activity prediction, SPECTER achieves a MAP score of 83.8 on the co-view task and 84.5 on the co-read task, surpassing the best baseline by 2.7 and 4.0 points, respectively [5]. SPECTER also outperforms Citeomatic on the direct citation task and substantially outperforms it on co-citations (+2.0 nDCG) [5].
![SPECTER generally outperforms other models in different tasks]()

SPECTER's embeddings are better at encoding topical information, as the clusters appear more compact; the homogeneity and completeness values for SPECTER are 0.41 and 0.72, respectively, compared to SciBERT's 0.19 and 0.63, showing improvement in separating topics using the projected embeddings [6].
![SPECTER separates topics better than SciBERT in visualized embeddings.](image2)

In recommendation tasks, SPECTER also outperforms all other models, achieving an nDCG of 53.9 [8].

SPECTER demonstrates superior performance across various tasks compared to other baseline models, and the inclusion of additional metadata fields like venue and author can have varying effects on its performance [1].

SPECTER achieves an average performance of 80.0 across all metrics and tasks, representing a 3.1-point absolute improvement over the next-best baseline, and it obtains an 86.4 F1 score on the MeSH dataset, a +2.3 absolute increase over the best baseline [1, 6]. 

For user activity prediction, SPECTER achieves a MAP score of 83.8 on the co-view task and 84.5 on the co-read task, improving over the best baseline by 2.7 and 4.0 points, respectively [6]. In the recommendation task, SPECTER outperforms all other models with an nDCG of 53.9 [7].

![SPECTER shows more compact clusters, indicating better encoding of topical information compared to SciBERT.](image1)

Adding authors as an input hurts performance, possibly because author names are sparse in the corpus or because tokenization using Wordpieces is suboptimal for author names [3]. Adding venues slightly decreases performance, except on document classification, where it makes sense for venues to have high correlation with paper topics [3].

![SPECTER achieves the best performance with an average of 80.0 across classification, user activity prediction, citation prediction, and recommendation tasks.](image4)

SPECTER generally outperforms SciBERT models, even when the latter is fine-tuned on end tasks or their multitask combination [2]. Overall, SPECTER outperforms other models across various tasks, and the inclusion of metadata fields like venue and author may have varied effects on its performance [6, 3].

SPECTER outperforms SciBERT in various tasks and demonstrates better topic encoding in its embeddings [2, 4].

SPECTER achieves substantial improvements over a wide variety of baselines, demonstrating its effectiveness [4]. As shown in Figure 2, SPECTER embeddings are better at encoding topical information compared to SciBERT, with more compact clusters; homogeneity and completeness values for SPECTER are 0.41 and 0.72, respectively, compared to SciBERT's 0.19 and 0.63 [2].

![SPECTER (left) and SciBERT (right) embeddings visualized using t-SNE, showing SPECTER's improved topic separation.](image2)

SPECTER demonstrates superior performance compared to SciBERT in separating topics within the projected embeddings, as indicated by the clustering quality measures [2].

In Table 3, SPECTER outperforms SciBERT, even when SciBERT is fine-tuned on end tasks, highlighting the versatility of SPECTER embeddings [3].

![SPECTER compared to SciBERT fine-tuned on various training signals, showing SPECTER's superior performance.](image5)

SPECTER's fixed representations generally outperform fine-tuned SciBERT on task-specific signals [5].

In summary, SPECTER generally outperforms SciBERT and provides better topic encoding, as demonstrated by its superior performance in various tasks and improved topic separation in its embedding visualizations.

SPECTER generally outperforms SciBERT when the latter is fine-tuned on task-specific signals in document classification, user activity prediction, citation prediction and recommendation tasks, demonstrating the effectiveness and versatility of SPECTER embeddings [3]. Fine-tuning SciBERT on task-specific data, such as co-views, co-reads, and co-citations, is generally inferior to using fixed representations from SPECTER [7].

As illustrated in Table 3, SPECTER outperforms a SciBERT model fine-tuned on the end tasks as well as their multitask combination, further demonstrating the effectiveness and versatility of SPECTER embeddings [3].
The table shows that SPECTER achieves an average score of 80.0 across tasks, while SciBERT fine-tuned on different signals has lower scores, for example SciBERT fine-tune on co-view only reached 76.0 [3].

SPECTER demonstrates superior performance compared to SciBERT when fine-tuned on task-specific signals.

The performance of different classifiers on the code-mixed dataset varies across sentiment classes [8]. Logistic regression, random forest classifiers, and decision trees performed comparatively better across all sentiment classes [8]. However, all the classification algorithms perform poorly on the code-mixed dataset [8].

To evaluate the classifiers, precision, recall, and F-score metrics are used [4]. Micro-average is preferred for imbalanced datasets, while macro-average treats all classes equally [4]. A weighted average considers the number of examples available for each class [4].

The micro-average is calculated by aggregating the contributions of all classes to compute the average metric. In a multi-class classification setup, micro-average is preferable if there are class imbalances [4].
![Micro-average is preferable for imbalanced datasets.](image1)

Referring to the results presented in image1, image2, and image5, it is difficult to pinpoint one classifier that consistently shows better results across all metrics for negative sentiment detection. Overall, the classifiers show variable performance in negative sentiment detection, with Random Forest and Logistic Regression showing relatively better results, but the overall performance is still poor [8].

The DS-DST and DS-Picklist models show significant improvements in joint accuracy and slot accuracy compared to the DS-Span model, especially for categorical slots. DS-Picklist assumes a full ontology is available and treats all domain-slot pairs as categorical slots [1].

DS-DST and DS-Picklist outperform BERT-DST in joint accuracy, indicating the effectiveness of their model design based on BERT ![DS-DST achieves 51.21% joint accuracy while DS-Picklist gets 53.30%.](image1)

DS-DST and DS-Picklist dramatically reduce errors for slots like attraction-type, hotel-internet and hotel-parking [4]. These slots benefit from being treated as categorical slots because their values usually have different expressions and cannot be extracted from the dialog context [3]. ![DS-DST and DS-PickList improve accuracy for specific slot types in MultiWOZ 2.1 test set.](image5)

DS-Picklist improves DST performance further when the model has access to the full ontology [6]. DS-DST and DS-Picklist perform much better than DS-Span, particularly for slots where values cannot be easily extracted from the dialog context [3]. The joint use of non-categorical and categorical approaches is helpful in multi-domain DST [6].

DS-Picklist generally performs better than DS-DST due to its access to a full ontology, enabling it to predict values directly from candidate-value lists [4].

The DS-DST and DS-Picklist models exhibit varying performance across different slots on the MultiWOZ 2.1 dataset. Overall, DS-Picklist tends to outperform DS-DST, but the extent of outperformance depends on the specific slot [5].
![DS-Picklist genelrally has a higher overall joint accuracy performance.](image3)
DS-Picklist generally achieves higher accuracy compared to DS-DST, as shown in the table with joint accuracy on the test sets of MultiWOZ 2.1.

DS-Picklist has a higher average accuracy, outperforming DS-DST [7].
![DS-Picklist has a higher average accuracy compared to DS-DST.](image1)

DS-DST shows significant improvement over DS-Span for some slots, including hotel-type, attraction-type, attraction-name, hotel-internet and hotel-parking [2].
There are specific slots where DS-Picklist significantly reduces errors compared to DS-DST, such as time-related slots like taxi-leave at and train-arrive by [3].
While DS-Picklist is generally higher than DS-DST, it may be non-trivial to have access to the full ontology in real scenarios [5].

In summary, while DS-Picklist generally performs better overall due to its access to a full ontology, there are specific scenarios and slots where DS-DST is more practical and still provides significant improvements over baseline models; DS-Picklist demonstrates a higher overall performance on the MultiWOZ 2.1 dataset and performs significantly better than DS-DST in specific slots.

The DS-Picklist model generally shows performance improvements over DS-Span and DS-DST, especially when the full ontology is accessible [1]. DS-Picklist is higher than DS-DST, in real scenarios, it may be nontrivial to have access to the full ontology [1].

The joint accuracy of DS-Picklist is higher than DS-DST [1]. As shown in this image, DS-DST and DS-Picklist models use BERT to encode candidate value lists, domain-slot pairs, and recent dialogue context.  ![DS-DST and DS-Picklist utilize BERT for encoding various elements.](image1)

DS-Picklist can further reduce the error rates, since the predicted values can be found in the candidate-values lists [6].

For specific slots like hotel-type, attraction-type, hotel-internet and hotel-parking, DS-Picklist performs significantly better than DS-Span [4]. The slot-level accuracy on the test set of MultiWOZ 2.1 shows performance improvement/degradation compared with DS-Span. ![DS-DST and DS-Picklist slot-level accuracy compared to DS-Span.](image5)

The DS-Picklist model generally achieves higher accuracy compared to DS-DST and DS-Span, particularly in scenarios where accessing a full ontology is feasible and for slots that benefit from direct prediction from candidate-value lists.

The LANI dataset focuses on navigation between landmarks, while the CHAI dataset combines navigation with simple manipulation, which requires achieving multiple intermediate goals [9]. The evaluation metrics differ as well; LANI is evaluated using stop distance (SD) and task completion (TC), whereas CHAI is evaluated using stop distance (SD) and manipulation accuracy (MA) [6].

The performance of various methods on LANI and CHAI also differ significantly, as evidenced by the development and test results [3]. For example, on LANI, the approach outperforms CHAPLOT18, improving task completion (TC) accuracy, whereas on CHAI, all models perform poorly, especially on manipulation (MA) [5].

![Our approach achieves a task completion accuracy of 35.72% on LANI, outperforming other methods like STOP, RANDOM WALK, and MOST FREQUENT, as well as MISRA17 and CHAPLOT18](image4)

This table illustrates that our approach achieves a task completion accuracy of 35.72% on LANI, outperforming other methods like STOP, RANDOM WALK, and MOST FREQUENT, as well as MISRA17 and CHAPLOT18. In contrast, on CHAI, while our approach shows some improvement in stop distance, the manipulation accuracy is relatively low, indicating the complexity of the task [5].  The differing complexities and evaluation metrics highlight the distinct challenges presented by each dataset [9, 6].

The key differences between LANI and CHAI lie in the complexity of instructions, the tasks required (navigation vs. navigation + manipulation), and the evaluation metrics used (TC for LANI, MA for CHAI), resulting in varied performance across different methods.

The LANI and CHAI systems have different task completion metrics; the former uses stop distance (SD) and task completion (TC), and the latter uses stop distance (SD) and manipulation accuracy (MA) [9].
![Table 4 shows the performance on the held-out test dataset for LANI and CHAI.](image1)
Our approach outperforms CHAPLOT18, improving the task completion accuracy on LANI [7]. However, all models perform poorly on manipulation (MA) on CHAI [7]. The  state space of LANI is significantly larger than existing navigation environments [10].
![The table shows mean goal prediction error for LANI instructions.](image2)
The LANI dataset uses spatial relations, conjunctions, temporal coordination and constraints [3]. The CHAI dataset focuses on temporal coordination and co-reference categories [3].

In summary, LANI and CHAI differ in their evaluation metrics and task performance, with LANI achieving better navigation performance and CHAI struggling with manipulation, reflecting the distinct challenges and linguistic features of each task.

The proposed approach demonstrates superior performance in task completion (TC) for LANI compared to other methods, while manipulation accuracy (MA) remains a challenge for all models in CHAI.

On the LANI dataset, the proposed approach outperforms CHAPLOT18, with a 5% improvement in task completion (TC) accuracy, surpassing MISRA17 as well [7]. ![The proposed approach outperforms CHAPLOT18 in task completion (TC) accuracy for the LANI dataset.](image2)

Conversely, on the CHAI dataset, all models, including the proposed approach, struggle, particularly in manipulation accuracy (MA) [7]. Even when provided with oracle goals, the model fails to learn a reasonable manipulation behavior for CHAI [1]. ![Even with oracle goals, the model struggles with manipulation in CHAI, indicating the domain's complexity.](image1)

The data suggests that while the proposed approach effectively handles navigation tasks in LANI, the complexity of manipulation in CHAI poses a significant challenge that requires further research and development.

The 'Our Approach' method demonstrates notable performance improvements in navigation, particularly on the LANI dataset [3]. The table provides a comparison of the stop distance (SD) and task completion (TC) metrics for LANI, as well as SD and manipulation accuracy (MA) for CHAI across different methods. ![The table compares different methods including “Our Approach” based on Stop Distance (SD) and Task Completion (TC) for LANI and Stop Distance (SD) and Manipulation Accuracy (MA) for CHAI.](image4)

On LANI, 'Our Approach' outperforms CHAPLOT18, improving task completion (TC) accuracy by 5% [3]. The approach also outperforms MISRA17 on LANI [3]. For CHAI, while CHAPLOT18 and MISRA17 struggle, 'Our Approach' shows an improvement in stop distance (SD) [3].
However, all models, including 'Our Approach', perform poorly on CHAI, especially in manipulation (MA) [3]. The model's performance, especially on the CHAI manipulation task, is complex, as planning complexity impacts manipulation behavior [10].
'Our Approach' with access to oracle goals significantly improves navigation performance on both tasks, with potential reasons likely due to eliminating ambiguity that automated metrics fail to capture [10]. On the held-out test dataset, "Our Approach" achieves a distance of 8.67 and an accuracy of 35.83 on LANI, and a distance of 2.12 with an accuracy of 40.3 on CHAI [5].
In summary, 'Our Approach' achieves competitive navigation performance, particularly on LANI, but faces challenges with manipulation on CHAI, with its performance potentially influenced by task complexity and automated metric limitations.

The GLUE benchmark results indicate performance variations between BERT and CNN models, highlighting their respective strengths [9]. BERT models generally show superior performance on tasks involving sentence-pairs, while CNN models also perform well [9].

The CNN base model achieved an average score of 77.7, while the CNN Large model scored 78.6. In contrast, the $BERT_{BASE}$ model attained a score of 79.6, and the $BERT_{LARGE}$ model reached 81.9 [9]. In conclusion, BERT models generally outperform CNN models on the GLUE benchmark, particularly in tasks that require understanding relationships between sentences, while CNN models also show competitive performance.

Furthermore, the GLUE benchmark experiments reveal significant improvements over the state of the art for each task, with a notable 9.1 point gain on RTE compared to previous models [2]. The average GLUE score is 81.3 when trained with 18B tokens ![The average GLUE score increases with more training data tokens.](image3). This indicates that CNN models, when combined with techniques like fine-tuning and stacking, achieve superior results across diverse NLP tasks.

The CNN base model performs as well as STILTs in aggregate, however, on some tasks involving sentence-pairs, STILTs performs much better (MRPC, RTE); there is a similar trend for BERT [3].
![BERT_LARGE outperforms CNN Large on various NLP tasks.](image5)
The CNN Large model achieves an average GLUE score of 78.6, while BERT_LARGE attains a higher average of 81.9, showcasing BERT's superior performance across diverse tasks.

Figure 3 illustrates that more training data can significantly increase accuracy [2].
![More training data leads to a higher average GLUE score.](image1)
As the training data increases, the average GLUE score also increases, indicating a positive correlation between training data size and model performance.

Increasing the training data size improves the average GLUE score, and BERT_LARGE generally outperforms the CNN Large model across different NLP tasks.

The amount of training data significantly impacts the GLUE score, as observed through experiments with varying data sizes [10].

The figure illustrates the relationship between the amount of training data and the average GLUE score, showing a general increase in performance with more data. ![Average GLUE score increases as the amount of training data increases](image5)

The use of more training data generally leads to improved performance on GLUE tasks [4]. For pretraining on Common Crawl, CoLA and RTE benefit most from additional training data [4]. The results suggest that more training data is likely to further increase performance [10].

Pretraining data size and the structure of training examples both significantly impact performance [4, 8, 10]. The use of larger training corpora improves pretraining [10]. ![Average GLUE score increases with the growth of train data tokens](image4) shows that a larger amount of training data generally leads to higher accuracy. More data for pretraining improves performance, keeping everything else equal [4].  Also pretraining on corpora that retains paragraph structure performs better than individual sentences [4]. For example, models trained on Common Crawl, which contains multi-sentence examples, outperform those trained on News Crawl, which consists of individual sentences, especially on sentence pair tasks [5].  
Furthermore, the training regime also plays a crucial role [8]. The cloze-driven training regime is more effective than predicting left and right tokens separately [8]. ![Cloze loss performs significantly better than the bilm loss](image5) shows the cloze loss performs significantly better than the bilm loss [1]. Fine-tuning the model gives the biggest performance gain [3]. The performance on NLP tasks is significantly affected by the amount and structure of pretraining data, along with the choice of training regime and fine-tuning.

The effect of aligning word embeddings on BLEU scores varies across different language pairs. While the alignment of word embeddings can increase BLEU scores for multilingual systems, it does not guarantee improvements and sometimes has insignificant effects in bilingual systems.

The alignment of word embeddings helps to increase the BLEU scores for all three tasks, as a single encoder is used for both of the source languages [7].  ![Aligning word embeddings helps increase BLEU scores for all three tasks](image2)

Aligning word embeddings was not beneficial for training, with gains or losses essentially being insignificant across all languages [8].  ![The alignment of word embeddings might not be necessary](image3)

For ES, FR, and IT, the BLEU scores generally follow the hypothesis that more similar languages see larger accuracy gains [5]. This can be attributed to systems with larger headroom to improve tending to see larger increases [5].  ![BLEU score increases are larger for RU and HE compared to FR and IT](image5)

The alignment of word embeddings may not be necessary [8]. The behavior of pre-training is affected by language families and other linguistic features of source and target languages [3].

Pre-trained word embeddings in Neural Machine Translation (NMT) can improve translation accuracy, especially in low-resource scenarios, and the effectiveness is influenced by training set size and language similarity [4].

Pre-training improves translation accuracy across the vocabulary, particularly for low-frequency words [1]. This is further supported by qualitative analysis, showing that pre-training helps the model capture rarer vocabulary and generate more grammatically well-formed sentences [7]. For example, the model can successfully translate a person’s name and multi-word phrases, demonstrating the usefulness of pre-trained embeddings in providing better representations of less frequent concepts when used with low-resource languages [7].
![The pre-aligned model can translate person name and multi-word phrases while the bi-std model failed to translate meaningfully.](image2)

The gains from pre-training are related to the similarity between the translation pairs [3].  The gains in each translation pair are roughly in order of their similarity, with GL/PT showing the largest gains, and BE/RU showing a small decrease [3]. The increase in BLEU scores for all three tasks when aligning word embeddings is intuitive, as a single encoder is used for both source languages, and pre-training and alignment ensures that the word embeddings of the two source languages are put into similar vector spaces [3].
![BLEU score is higher when word embeddings of two languages are put into similar vector spaces through pre-training and alignment.](image3)

The effectiveness of pre-trained embeddings has a "sweet spot," where there is very little training data but not so little that the system cannot be trained at all [4]. As shown in the graphic, pre-training is more effective for more similar translation pairs and training set size influences translation accuracy [5]. In addition, the BLEU scores of ES, FR, and IT generally follow the hypothesis that more similar languages benefit more from pre-training [8]. Languages like RU and HE, which are very different, see larger accuracy gains compared to their more similar counterparts FR and IT, potentially because systems with more room for improvement tend to show larger increases [8].
![The BLEU scores of ES, FR, and IT generally follow the hypothesis.](image1)

Pre-training improves translation accuracy, especially for low-frequency words and similar language pairs, but its effectiveness depends on an adequate but not excessive amount of training data.

The alignment of word embeddings and its impact on translation performance varies across different language pairs, and the F-measure scores for target words show improvements, especially for low-frequency words when pre-training is used.

Alignment of embeddings may not be necessary in bilingual scenarios but can be helpful in multilingual scenarios [5].  aligning word embeddings helps increase BLEU scores in multilingual translation, ensuring similar vector spaces for source languages and facilitating the learning process, as shown in the multilingual translation results into English ![Effect of pre-training on multilingual translation into English. bi is a bilingual system trained on only the eval source language and all others are multi-lingual systems trained on two similar source languages.](image3).  In the translation from GL to EN, pre-training helps the model capture rarer vocabulary and generates more grammatically well-formed sentences ![Pre-training helps the model to capture rarer vocabulary.](image1).

However, a priori alignment of embeddings may not be necessary in the context of NMT, as NMT systems can learn a reasonable projection of word embeddings during training [2].  shows the effect of alignment on translation performance for various language pairs, where some pairs benefit from alignment while others do not ![The table shows the effect of alignment on translation performance for various language pairs.](image4). Qualitative analysis reveals that pre-training improves translation accuracy across the vocabulary, particularly for low-frequency words ![Pre-training improves the accuracy of translation for the entire vocabulary, but particularly for words that are of low frequency in the training corpus.](image2).

Pre-trained embeddings improve translation accuracy, especially for low-frequency words, and aligning embeddings can be beneficial in multilingual scenarios.

The ablation studies reveal the impact of removing specific components on model performance in both unmasked and masked settings. Removing the R-GCN component significantly reduces accuracy, while removing specific relation types like DOC-BASED, MATCH, and COREF also affects performance differently.

Replacing ELMo with GloVe results in a competitive system, but removing R-GCN from the GloVe setup causes a significant 8.0 point drop in accuracy, showing the impact of the R-GCN component ![Removing R-GCN from the GloVe setup decreases accuracy by 8.0 points.](image1).

Removing relation types results in marginal improvements compared to ELMo alone, suggesting the need for more informative graph construction [9]. Ablating graph edges, particularly DOC-BASED connections, significantly impacts performance because it removes important information about mentions appearing closely in the same document [1, 10].

Removing MATCH or COREF connections has a less significant impact, with coreference links playing a marginal role because MATCH captures easier coreference cases [1]. However, modelling all these different relations together gives the Entity-GCN a clear advantage [1]. The model benefits more from DOC-BASED connections than MATCH or COREF connections [1].

Induced edges, where edges are predicted instead of predetermined, perform worse than models without R-GCN, indicating difficulty in learning dependencies on their own [5]. ![Induced edges perform worse than models without R-GCN, making it hard to learn dependencies.](image1)

In summary, the ablation experiments demonstrate that the R-GCN component and DOC-BASED connections are crucial for model performance, while other components like MATCH and COREF have more marginal roles.

The impact of coreference information on the performance of Entity-GCN models differs between unmasked and masked settings. In the unmasked setting, the model's performance degrades with coreference, while in the masked setting, coreference resolution is not applied but benefits from consistent entity identifiers [2, 6].

In the unmasked setting, mentions to an entity may differ, making it harder for the coreference system to retrieve them, which makes the task harder for all models [2, 10]. Surprisingly, with coreference, a performance degradation on the test set is observed, likely because the test documents are harder for the coreference system [6]. ![The table illustrates the performance of Entity-GCN models with and without coreference in both unmasked and masked settings.](image4)

In the masked setting, coreferred mentions are labeled with the same identifier, even if their original surface forms did not match, as the masked version refers to an entity via the same unique surface form [2]. Since Entity-GCN gains little advantage using the coreference system, the test results are reported both with and without using it [6]. Despite not applying coreference resolution in the masked setting, performance tends to be stronger because the consistent entity identifiers facilitate coreference link recovery [2].

In the unmasked setting, the inclusion of coreference information degrades performance, but in the masked setting, coreference resolution is not applied but benefits from consistent entity identifiers.

The 'full (ensemble)' model significantly outperforms the 'GloVe with R-GCN' model in both unmasked and masked conditions, and relation-based accuracy varies depending on the type of question, with place-related questions being more challenging for the Entity-GCN model.

In the unmasked condition, the 'full (ensemble)' model achieves 68.5, while 'GloVe with R-GCN' scores 59.2 [5].  In the masked condition, the 'full (ensemble)' model attains 71.6, whereas 'GloVe with R-GCN' only reaches 11.1 [5].
![The table presents the performance metrics of different models, including "full (ensemble)" and "GloVe with R-GCN," under both unmasked and masked conditions.](image5)

The model's ability to effectively utilize graph structure is examined by comparing scenarios with and without relation types.  When all nodes are fully connected without distinguishing edge types, only marginal improvements are observed compared to using ELMo alone [4].
![The table displays accuracy results for different question types, highlighting that questions about places (birth and death) are more challenging for the Entity-GCN model.](image2)

Specifically, questions concerning places like birth and death are more challenging for the Entity-GCN model [9]. This model encounters difficulties due to mismatches between W IKIPEDIA and W IKIDATA annotations and differing degrees of granularity in answers [9]. Therefore, questions regarding places are considered harder for Entity-GCN [9].

The DyGIE system demonstrates strong performance in both entity and relation extraction across various datasets, with coreference and relation propagation layers playing a significant role in its effectiveness.

DYGIE achieves substantial improvements on both entity recognition and relation extraction across the four datasets and three domains [9]. DyGIE attains 25.8% relative improvement over SOTA on ACE04 and 13.7% relative improvement on ACE05 for the relation extraction task [9]. On ACE04 and ACE05, DYGIE achieves 7.1% and 7.0% relative improvements over the state of the art on NER, respectively [9].

![DYGIE's entity extraction results on overlapping datasets show improvements over the state of the art.](image1)

DYGIE improves 11.6% on the state of the art for ACE04-O and 11.3% for ACE05-O [2]. DYGIE also advances the state of the art on GENIA, albeit by a more modest 1.5% [2].

![This image presents the ablations on the ACE05 development set with different graph propagation setups.](image2)

The table shows the effects of ablating coreference and relation propagation layers on entity and relation extraction; removing coreference propagation impacts entity extraction, while removing relation propagation impacts relation extraction [5].

![The figure shows the effect of the number of iterations for coreference propagation in the entity extraction task.](image3)

Coreference propagation is mainly helpful for entities, and relation propagation significantly benefits both entity and relation extraction [1]. The figure shows that the coreference layer obtains the best performance on the second iteration (N=2) [7].

![DYGIE outperforms other models in entity and relation extraction for multiple datasets.](image5)

DYGIE outperforms current state-of-the-art methods in different datasets for entity and relation extraction [6].

In summary, the DyGIE system excels in both entity and relation extraction tasks across multiple datasets, with coreference propagation primarily aiding entity extraction and relation propagation significantly boosting both entity and relation extraction performance.

The D Y GIE system demonstrates state-of-the-art performance on entity recognition and relation extraction tasks across various datasets [2].

D Y GIE shows substantial improvements on both entity recognition and relation extraction [4].  The system achieves state-of-the-art results on ACE04 and ACE05 datasets [4]. For relation extraction, D Y GIE attains significant improvement over the state of the art on ACE04 and ACE05 [4].

 DYGIE advances the state of the art by 5.9% and 1.9% for relation extraction and NER, respectively, on SciERC [8]. The improvement of D Y GIE over the previous SciERC model highlights the ability of coreference and relation propagation to construct rich contextualized representations [8].

The impact of coreference propagation and relation propagation varies across tasks and datasets.  Coreference propagation primarily benefits entity extraction, while relation propagation significantly benefits both entity and relation extraction [6].

Coreference propagation has a greater impact on entity extraction, and relation propagation has a greater impact on relation extraction [3]. The figure illustrates the effect of the number of iterations for coreference propagation in the entity extraction task, showing that the best performance is achieved on the second iteration ![Coreference layer performs best at the second iteration.](image1).

In summary, D Y GIE achieves state-of-the-art performance, with coreference and relation propagation playing significant roles in enhancing entity and relation extraction tasks.

The DyGIE model's performance on entity and relation extraction varies across different datasets, and the CorefProp and RelProp components play distinct roles in these variations.

The DyGIE model was evaluated on ACE2004, ACE2005 and GENIA datasets for overlapping entity extraction [4]. The model improves $11.6\%$ on the state of the art for ACE04-O and $11.3\%$ for ACE05-O and also advances the state of the art on GENIA, albeit by a more modest $1.5\%$ [2]. The results suggest that D Y GIE can be utilized fruitfully for information extraction across different domains with overlapped entities, such as bio-medicine [2].
![DyGIE achieves state-of-the-art entity F1 scores on ACE04-O, ACE05-O, and GENIA datasets.](image3)

The impact of coreference propagation (CorefProp) and relation propagation (RelProp) on entity and relation extraction varies by dataset. On ACE05, coreference propagation is mainly helpful for entities but appears to hurt relation extraction [9].  CorefProp has a much smaller effect on entity F1 compared to ACE05 [7]. Relation propagation significantly benefits both entity and relation extraction in both ACE05 and SciERC domains [9].  There are a large portion of sentences with multiple relation instances across different entities in both ACE05 and SciERC, which is the scenario in which relation propagation is expected to help [9].  Figure 4 shows that relation propagation achieves significant improvement in sentences with more entities [3].

For example, in SciERC, the pronouns are uniformly assigned with a "Generic" label, explaining why CorefProp does not have much effect on entity extraction performance [6].  The table shows the results of the overlapping entity extraction experiments on different datasets [2].

The DyGIE model's performance varies across datasets, with CorefProp and RelProp having different impacts depending on the dataset characteristics and task.

DYGIE improves overlapping entity extraction on ACE04-O and ACE05-O, with more modest gains on GENIA [4].
