The number of iterations for coreference and relation propagation affects the F1 scores for entity and relation extraction, with optimal performance typically achieved at two iterations, while the number of entities in a sentence impacts the relation F1 score, generally showing a decline in performance as the number of entities increases beyond a certain point.

The optimal number of iterations for coreference propagation in entity extraction is two, as shown in Figure 3a. ![CorefProp obtains the best performance on the second iteration.](image5) In relation extraction, the model achieves the best performance with relation propagation at the second iteration as well [4]. This suggests that  CorefProp  and  RelProp  are most effective when the number of iterations are set to 2.

Figure 3b demonstrates that relation propagation benefits both entity and relation extraction in ACE05 and SciERC domains [5]. In both ACE05 and SciERC, a large portion of sentences contain multiple relation instances across different entities, which is where relation propagation is expected to help [5]. ![The Relation F1 score tends to decrease as the number of entities in a sentence increases.](image4) DyGIE's Relation F1 score tends to decrease with the number of entities in a sentence and DyGIE without relation propagation yields a similar result.

Coreference propagation has the most effect on entity extraction, while relation propagation has the most effect on relation extraction [4].  Figure 3a shows the effect of the number of iterations for coreference propagation in the entity extraction task [2].  Figure 3b shows the effect of the number of iterations for relation propagation in the relation extraction task [8]. Our model achieves the best performance on the second iteration for both coreference and relation propagation [2, 8].

![Coreference layer obtains the best performance on the second iteration.](image5)

Figure 4 shows that relation propagation achieves significant improvement in sentences with more entities, where one might expect that using broader context [5].

![Relation propagation achieves significant improvement in sentences with more entities](image3)

CorefProp has a much smaller effect on entity F1 compared to ACE05 [9]. The optimal number of iterations for both coreference and relation propagation is two, and relation propagation is more effective in sentences with a higher number of entities.

The Simple Word-Embedding-based Models (SWEMs) and Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) exhibit varying performance characteristics across different datasets and subspace dimensions. SWEM demonstrates higher accuracy than CNN for a large range of low subspace dimensions, which indicates that SWEM is more parameter-efficient in achieving a decent solution ![SWEM shows higher accuracy than CNN for a large range of low subspace dimension.](image1). Specifically, on AG News dataset, SWEM exhibits a lower intrinsic dimension  $d_{\mathrm{int}}$ than CNN if a performance threshold of $80\%$ testing accuracy is set [3]. However, when the subspace dimension $d$ is large, CNN can leverage more trainable parameters to achieve higher accuracy [3].

On topic prediction tasks, SWEM models exhibit stronger performances compared to LSTM and CNN architectures by leveraging both average and max-pooling features from word embeddings [7].  ![SWEM-max achieves a test accuracy of 83.8% on the SNLI dataset.](image2) In sentence classification tasks, SWEM yields inferior accuracies on sentiment analysis datasets, but comparable performance on subjectivity and question classification tasks, with much fewer parameters and faster training [10]. For the Chinese dataset represented by Pinyin, SWEM-hier achieves an accuracy comparable to CNN and LSTM, which suggests that hierarchical pooling is more suitable for Chinese text classification [8].

In summary, SWEM tends to be more parameter-efficient and performs well with low subspace dimensions and on topic prediction tasks, while CNN can achieve higher accuracy with larger subspace dimensions, particularly on tasks requiring more complex feature extraction.

The performance of aspect-level sentiment classification models can be improved by transferring knowledge from document-level data [6].  Ablation tests reveal the impact of transferring different layers from the document-level model to the aspect-level model, demonstrating that transfer is helpful in all settings, with the LSTM and embedding layers being more useful than the output layer [7].
 
 The table shows the ablation tests on PRET with different layers transferred from the document-level model to the aspect-level model.
 
Furthermore, the percentage of document-level training examples significantly impacts the model's accuracy and macro-F1 scores [5].  For datasets D3 and D4, sharp increases in macro-F1 scores are observed when increasing the percentage of document-level examples from 0 to 0.4 [5].

 This figure illustrates the changes in accuracies and macro-F1 scores on four datasets when varying the percentage of document-level training examples.
 
In general, transferring layers and increasing the percentage of document-level training examples improves the model performance, particularly on datasets with unbalanced label distributions [7, 5].

TRADE demonstrates state-of-the-art performance on the MultiWOZ dataset, achieving a joint goal accuracy of 48.62% across five domains [3]. The dataset information of MultiWOZ includes 30 (domain, slot) pairs from five selected domains, and the number of dialogues for train, validation, and test sets is specified in Table 1 ![MultiWOZ dataset statistics are shown](image1).

The evaluation metrics used are joint goal accuracy and slot accuracy [5].  TRADE also exhibits strong transferring ability by simulating zero-shot dialogue state tracking for unseen domains [3]. It achieves 60.58% joint goal accuracy in one of the zero-shot domains [3]. Table 2 displays the multi-domain DST evaluation on MultiWOZ and its single restaurant domain, highlighting that TRADE has the highest joint accuracy [8].

TRADE's performance varies across different domains and excels in zero-shot settings, particularly in the taxi domain, as illustrated in the MultiWOZ dataset.

The TRADE model demonstrates superior performance compared to other models on the MultiWOZ dataset, particularly in joint goal accuracy, and it benefits from fine-tuning in domain adaptation scenarios [7].

On the MultiWOZ dataset, TRADE achieves the highest performance with $48.62\%$ on joint goal accuracy and $96.92\%$ on slot accuracy [10]. This is shown in the following table:
![TRADE achieves the highest joint and slot accuracy on MultiWOZ compared to other models.](image1)

When expanding from four domains to a new domain, TRADE achieves better performance than training from scratch on the new domain [7].  For example, it achieves $59.83\%$ joint accuracy after fine-tuning using only $1\%$ of Train domain data, outperforming training the Train domain from scratch, which achieves $44.24\%$ using the same amount of new-domain data [7].

When fine-tuning TRADE with GEM, the performance on the original four domains is better maintained, as the joint accuracy only drops from $58.98\%$ to $53.54\%$ for the hotel domain, while naive fine-tuning causes a more significant drop [9].  The table presents the results of domain expansion experiments, highlighting the performance of various fine-tuning strategies:
![GEM outperforms Naive and EWC fine-tuning in terms of catastrophic forgetting on the four domains.](image3)

In summary, the TRADE model achieves higher accuracy on the MultiWOZ dataset and benefits from fine-tuning strategies like GEM in domain adaptation scenarios.

GEM outperforms naive and EWC fine-tuning in overcoming catastrophic forgetting [6]. For example, GEM obtains $34.73\%$ joint accuracy on the attraction domain, but naive fine-tuning on that domain can only achieve $29.39\%$ [1].

Fine-tuning TRADE with GEM maintains higher performance on the original four domains [5].
![GEM outperforms naive and EWC fine-tuning in terms of catastrophic forgetting on the four domains.](image3)
In the hotel domain, for instance, performance on the four domains after fine-tuning with GEM only drops from $58.98\%$ to $53.54\%$ ($-5.44\%$) on joint accuracy, whereas naive fine-tuning deteriorates the tracking ability, dropping joint goal accuracy to $36.08\%$ ($-22.9\%$) [5].

![This figure shows the zero-shot analysis of the Hotel and Restaurant domains, highlighting knowledge transfer for slots like 'people', 'area', 'price range', and 'day'.](image2)
Knowledge about slots like people, area, price range, and day are successfully transferred from other domains, while unseen slots unique to a domain are harder to track [7]. Slots that are not empty are also considered to better understand the behavior of knowledge transferring [7].

GEM generally outperforms naive and EWC fine-tuning strategies in domain expansion, while slot similarities can affect how well knowledge is transferred to new domains.

The performance of machine translation (MT) systems varies across different languages and systems, with gender bias being a significant factor [1, 5, 9]. Systems often perform better on pro-stereotypical assignments compared to anti-stereotypical ones [1].

The performance of commercial MT systems on the WinoMT corpus varies across languages, with accuracy ($Acc$) indicating the percentage of instances where the translation had the correct gender, $\Delta_{G}$ denoting the difference in $F_{1}$ score between masculine and feminine scores, and $\Delta_{S}$ indicating the difference in $F_{1}$ score between pro-stereotypical and anti-stereotypical gender role assignments. Numbers in bold indicate the best accuracy for the language across MT systems, and underlined numbers indicate the best accuracy for the MT system across languages.

For example, Figure 2 shows Google Translate's absolute accuracies on stereotypical and non-stereotypical gender roles across tested languages, demonstrating a performance decrease in translating anti-stereotypical roles [1].  ![Graph of Google Translate showing absolute accuracies on stereotypical and non-stereotypical gender roles across languages.](image3)

The overall system accuracy is calculated by the percentage of instances in which the translation preserved the gender of the entity from the original English sentence [8]. However, most tested systems perform poorly on this metric across eight tested languages, often not doing much better than a random guess [8].

The translation accuracy and gender bias differ significantly across various machine translation systems and languages.

The impact of stereotype-based adjustments on gender bias in machine translation is complex and varies across languages. According to [8], adding adjectives like "handsome" or "pretty" can "correct" profession bias by influencing the translation towards a specific gender inflection.

For example, consider the translation from English to Spanish, where adding the adjective "pretty" before "doctor" changes the translation from the male "el doctor" to the female "la doctora", mitigating the original bias as shown in the below example ![Adding a stereotypically female adjective to "baker" in the source sentence corrects the gender bias in the Spanish translation.](image3).

Table 4 provides performance data for Google Translate on Spanish, Russian, and Ukrainian, showing improved gender prediction accuracy when stereotypical gender adjectives are added [6].  This is show in the image below. ![Accuracy increases in Spanish, Russian, and Ukrainian when stereotypical gender adjectives are added to the WinoMT corpus.](image2)

These adjustments, however, are acknowledged as impractical for general debiasing, as they rely on oracle coreference resolution and indicate a relation between coreference resolution and machine translation, further highlighting gender bias [8].  It is important to note that while these adjustments can improve accuracy in some languages, they are not a universally applicable solution for debiasing machine translation systems.

Different training and evaluation strategies have a notable impact on F1 scores, particularly in multi-hop question answering tasks. Training on adversarial distractors can improve accuracy when evaluated on adversarial distractors [9].

![Training on adversarial distractors improves accuracy.](image4)

The table shows the F1 scores for models trained and tested on original and adversarial distractors, with and without entity type filtering; the model trained on original distractors achieves 67.08 F1 when evaluated on the original distractors, but drops to 46.84 F1 when evaluated on adversarial distractors [10]. However, the model trained on adversarial distractors recovers much of its accuracy, increasing to 60.10 F1 when tested on adversarial distractors [9]. Moreover, filtering by entity type further impacts performance, where the original model's accuracy degrades significantly, but the adversarially trained model can recover most of its original accuracy [6]. The type of question (multi-hop vs. single-hop) also plays a role, as many comparison questions are multi-hop or context-dependent multi-hop, leading to near-chance accuracy for single-paragraph BERT [7, 8]. 

![Multi-hop, context-dependent, and single-hop questions have varying F1 scores.](image3)

Different training and evaluation strategies greatly influence F1 scores, especially in multi-hop question answering.

The adversarial data setup significantly impacts the performance of BERT models on the ARCT dataset by eliminating spurious statistical cues, leading to a more robust evaluation of machine argument comprehension [6, 8].

Initially, BERT achieved a peak performance of $77\%$ on the ARCT dataset, closely approaching the average untrained human baseline, but this was due to the exploitation of spurious statistical cues [8]. This initial performance is shown in ![BERT's original performance on the ARCT dataset reached 77.0%.](image5)

To address this, an adversarial dataset was constructed by negating the claim and inverting the label for each data point, which mirrors the distributions of cues around both labels [2]. This is visualized through ![Original and adversarial data examples.](image3)

When models were trained and validated on the original data and then evaluated on the adversarial set, the results were worse than random, because of overfitting to the cues in the original training set [6]. However, when BERT models were trained from scratch on the adversarial training and validation sets, their peak performance dropped to $53\%$, with the mean and median around $50\%$ [6]. Table 4 shows the performance of BERT Large on the adversarial test set with adversarial training and validation sets, indicating the elimination of cues, as shown in ![BERT's peak performance reduced to 53% on the adversarial test set.](image4)

This drastic reduction in performance indicates that the adversarial dataset effectively eliminated the spurious cues, providing a more accurate assessment of argument comprehension [6].  It suggests that BERT, in its original configuration, learned very little about argument comprehension, relying instead on these statistical cues [7]. The creation and adoption of the adversarial dataset are recommended to spur more productive research in the field [10].

In conclusion, the adversarial data setup reveals that BERT's initial high performance on ARCT was due to exploiting statistical cues rather than actual argument comprehension, highlighting the importance of robust evaluation methods.

The COMET model's performance with different decoding methods is benchmarked against human validation, and the amount of training data significantly influences the quality and novelty of the generated knowledge.

The image shows that using greedy decoding for knowledge tuples results in a performance close to human evaluation, with only a 10% relative gap compared to human evaluation on the ATOMIC test set. This indicates that the knowledge produced by the model approaches human performance. ![Greedy decoding achieves an average of 77.53%, approaching human performance.](image1)

Even when trained with only 10% of the available training data, COMET can still generate coherent, adequate, and novel knowledge. ![Training with 10% of the data shows reasonable PPL, BLEU-2, N/T o and N/U o scores.](image3) Using only 1% of the training data diminishes the quality, while training without pre-trained weights performs similarly to training with 10% of the seed tuples, showing the impact of pre-trained language representations [8].

The performance of COMET is highly influenced by the amount of training data and the decoding method used, with greedy decoding achieving results close to human validation and reasonable performance even with limited training data.

The COMET model demonstrates superior performance in generating accurate and novel knowledge compared to other models on the ConceptNet dataset [4, 7]. The COMET model achieves a high accuracy rate with  $91.7\%$  of generated tuples for ConceptNet relations being correct, approaching human performance [3, 7]. In addition to high quality, the tuples generated by COMET are also novel;  $59.25\%$  of the tuples are not present in the training set [1]. `COMET (- pretrain)` model generates "mango IsA spice" which could be a reasonable inference given the information about "mango" in the seed set of knowledge [2].

The table presented in ![The table shows a comparison of different models based on metrics such as PPL, Score, N/T sro, N/T o, and Human evaluation scores.](image1) displays the results of various models, including COMET, LSTM, and CKBG, evaluated on different metrics. It indicates that COMET achieves a low perplexity (PPL) score of 4.32 and a high classifier score of 95.25%, signifying strong model confidence and high-quality tuple generation [10]. The novelty metrics, N/T sro and N/T o, further highlight the model's ability to generate new knowledge by identifying edges between existing nodes and even creating new nodes [7]. COMET outperforms LSTM and CKBG models across these metrics, suggesting the effectiveness of COMET in generating novel and accurate common-sense knowledge.

The COMET model's ability to generate high-quality and novel common-sense knowledge suggests it is an effective approach for automatic knowledge base construction and commonsense reasoning, offering a promising alternative to extractive methods [3, 7].

The sensitivity and word error rate (WER) vary between closed and open vocabulary models depending on the backoff strategy used [4]. "Open vocabulary (i.e. char-only, word+char, word-piece) down- stream classiﬁers consider every unique combi- nation of characters differently, whereas word- only classiﬁers internally treat all out of vocab- ulary (OOV) words alike" [4].

For open vocabulary models, the pass-through variant tends to be more sensitive because it passes words as is, treating each combination uniquely, as seen in the table ![Pass-through backoff has higher error rates compared to background and neutral backoff in open vocab models.](image2). However, the background model achieves a lower error rate of $6.9\%$, leading to better word recognition compared to the vanilla ScRNN model with pass-through [9].

In contrast, for word-only models, pass-through is less sensitive since all out-of-vocabulary character combinations are rendered identical [8]. The neutral backoff variant has the lowest sensitivity because it returns a fixed neutral word whenever the ScRNN predicts an UNK, reducing the number of unique outputs, but it can hurt performance in no attack settings [1, 4].

Ideally, low sensitivity and word error rate are preferred, but in practice, a low error rate often increases sensitivity; however, sensitivity is the more dominant factor [10]. The neutral backoff has the lowest sensitivity, resulting in higher robustness on most attack types [7]. Figure 2 visualizes this trade-off between WER and sensitivity and depicts the robustness when using different backoff variants ![The sensitivity and WER trade-off with pass-through, background, and neutral backoff strategies.](image4).

In summary, sensitivity and word error rate differ based on the vocabulary model (closed vs open) and backoff strategy, where open vocabulary models with pass-through have high sensitivity, while neutral backoff generally provides lower sensitivity but can impact performance in certain scenarios.

The BiDAF model generally outperforms FastQA across various datasets and test conditions, particularly when information is distributed across multiple documents [3]. In the masked setup, both neural RC models are able to largely retain or even improve their strong performance when answers are masked and they are able to leverage the textual context of the candidate expressions [8].

In the "gold chain" setup, where models are presented with only relevant documents,  $B i D A F$  shows significant improvement, achieving up to 81.2%/85.7% on WIKI H OP in the masked setting [5].  ![BiDAF and FastQA models improve greatly in the gold chain setup.](image4)

However,  FastQA shows a slight increase of 2.2%/3.2% for WIKI H OP and a decrease of 2.7%/4.1% on M ED H OP, indicating that FastQA has problems integrating cross-document information [9].  Also,  $B i D A F$ is overall strongest across both datasets [3].

Overall,  $B i D A F$ generally performs better than FastQA, especially in scenarios requiring integration of information across multiple documents, but both models show sensitivity to the inclusion of irrelevant documents [3].

The performance of BiDAF and FastQA models varies across WIKIHOP and MEDHOP datasets depending on the test conditions [9].

When presented with only the relevant documents, BiDAF can achieve up to 81.2%/85.7% on WIKIHOP in the masked setting, while models can pick up on the masking template and achieve almost perfect scores [1]. This is shown in ![BiDAF mask has the best score on gold chain at WIKIHOP and MEDHOP](image3).

However, the models' answer selection process is not robust to the introduction of unrelated documents [1]. The table shows the test accuracy comparison when only using documents leading to the correct answer [7].

When discarding documents that do not contain candidate mentions, BiDAF experiences a significant performance drop, indicating its ability to leverage cross-document information [3]. The performance of BiDAF and FastQA models differs, with BiDAF generally performing stronger across both datasets, possibly due to its iterative latent interactions [4]. This is highlighted in ![BiDAF and FastQA performance comparison on WikiHop and MedHop datasets](image2).

Overall, BiDAF and FastQA show varying performance across WIKIHOP and MEDHOP datasets, influenced by the relevance of documents and the presence of masking.

The RetNRef models, particularly RetNRef++, show improvements in word statistics compared to Seq2Seq models, making them closer to human utterances [8]. Seq2Seq models tend to produce shorter sentences with more common words than humans, while RetNRef models increase the use of rare words [8].
 

 ![RetNRef++ model has word statistics closer to human utterances compared to Seq2Seq.](image3)
 

 In terms of engagingness, all RetNRef variants outperform Seq2Seq, with SetNRef++ slightly outperforming the retriever it conditions on [9]. However, Seq2Seq is stronger at using the persona [9]. As shown in A/B tests, RetrieveNReﬁne obtains statistically signiﬁcant wins over the retriever Memory Network model and the generator Seq2Seq model, with a win rate of approximately 54% [6].
 

 ![RetNRef++ has better Engagingness compared to other models.](image2)
 

 The RetNRef++ model demonstrates the ability to use the retriever while also generating novel content when needed, unlike a standard retriever [1]. RetNRef++ has a word overlap of greater than 80% with the retriever output around 53% of the time, whereas Seq2Seq and RetNRef rarely overlap with the retriever [1].
 

 ![RetNRef++ has a high word overlap with the retriever output.](image4)
 

 The RetNRef++ model has similar statistics to human utterances and provides more engaging conversations according to human judgments [7]. Longer sentences with nuanced entity information often come from attending to the retriever, while the generator can produce shorter replies independent of the retriever that fit the context well [4].
 

 The RetNRef models enhance conversational ability by using more human-like word statistics, achieving higher engagingness scores, and effectively choosing between retrieving and generating responses.

The WMT19 Metrics Task was designed for segment-level evaluation [2]. One key aspect of the evaluation is to ensure that error metrics are converted to the same orientation as human judgements [1]. This means higher scores should indicate higher translation quality [1, 10].

`YiSi` metrics demonstrate high correlations across multiple language pairs in system-level evaluation [7, 9].

For example, in system-level evaluation, `YiSi-1_srl` achieves a correlation of up to .947 for Chinese-English and .936 for English-German [7].  ![YiSi metrics generally achieve the highest correlations.](image5)

`YiSi-1` shows notable performance in segment-level evaluation as well [4]. Absolute Pearson correlation of out-of-English system-level metrics with DA human assessment in newstest2019 are shown [5]. Absolute Kendall’s Tau formulation of segment-level metric scores with DA scores are also shown [3, 8].  Across various language pairs, different metrics may be highlighted in bold, indicating they were not significantly outperformed by any other metric [3, 5, 8]. Metrics are evaluated at both segment-level and system-level [2].

`YiSi` metrics generally achieve the highest correlations with human assessment across the most language pairs in the newstest2019 dataset.

For language pairs not involving English, the YiSi metrics achieved the highest correlations and were not significantly outperformed by other metrics [2].  The absolute Pearson correlation of system-level metrics for language pairs not involving English with DA human assessment in newstest2019 are shown in Table 5 [1]. Absolute Pearson correlation of out-of-English system-level metrics with DA human assessment in newstest2019 is displayed in Table 4 [6].  ![Table 8 shows segment-level metric results for language pairs not involving English, presenting absolute Kendall’s Tau correlations with DA scores.](image2)

For language pairs involving English, metrics also achieved high correlations [8]. Table 6 shows segment-level metric results for to-English language pairs in newstest2019, presenting absolute Kendall’s Tau correlations with DA scores [7].  ![Table 4 shows system-level metric results for to-English language pairs.](image3)
Many metrics demonstrated strong correlations with human assessments, with YiSi metrics being particularly prominent in pairs not involving English.

In system-level evaluation, the YiSi metrics often achieve top correlations across various language pairs [2]. It is observed that metrics such as YiSi and ESIM, which perform well in judging systems, utilize semantic features [3].
Looking at the absolute Pearson correlation of out-of-English system-level metrics with DA human assessment, certain metrics stand out.

Across different language pairs, YiSi metrics often achieve the highest correlations. ![YiSi metrics achieve the highest correlations in several language pairs.](image2)

In newstest2019, several metrics consistently perform well across different language pairs as shown in Table 4 and Table 8 [7, 10].

The significance test results in Figure 1 and Figure 2 allow for pairwise comparisons of metrics to determine which ones significantly outperform BLEU [6]. Pairwise comparisons of metrics may be also of interest. ![Pairwise comparisons of metrics are shown in Figure 1.](image3)

Metrics based on word or sentence-level embeddings like YiSi and ESIM show high performance [5]. Semantic understanding may contribute to a metric’s performance gains [3]. Some metrics are not significantly outperformed by any other for specific language pairs, indicating strong performance as highlighted in bold in tables [7, 10]. The penalization of ties makes the evaluation asymmetric and dependent on whether the metric predicted the tie correctly [1, 9]. Error metrics are converted to the same orientation as human judgments, ensuring that higher scores indicate higher translation quality [1, 8].

Across different language pairs, YiSi metrics often achieve the highest correlations in several language pairs. ![Absolute Pearson correlation of out-of-English system-level metrics with DA human assessment in newstest2019 is shown.](image5)

YiSi metrics consistently perform well, often outperforming others, and metrics based on semantic features tend to achieve higher performance in translation evaluation.

For the en-fi language pair, several metrics achieve high correlations with human assessments, as shown in the table ![Metrics correlation for en-fi and en-kk language pairs](image4). Metrics like BEER, CHRF+, EED, and YiSi-0 exhibit strong performance, with correlation values exceeding 0.99 [4, 5].

In the en-kk language pair, metrics such as BEER and EED also demonstrate robust correlations, with values around 0.97 or higher ![Metrics correlation for en-fi and en-kk language pairs](image4).  Other metrics like WMDO and YiSi-0 also show high correlations, nearing 0.99 [4, 5].

Therefore, several metrics like BEER, CHRF+, EED, YiSi-0, and WMDO show strong positive correlations with human assessments for both the en-fi and en-kk language pairs.

Novo Nordisk considers foreign exchange risk as the most significant financial risk, which can substantially affect the financial statements [1]. To mitigate the short-term adverse effects of exchange rate fluctuations, the company actively manages foreign exchange risk to maintain predictability in financial outcomes [3]. They use financial instruments, such as forward exchange contracts and currency options, to hedge forecast transactions, assets, and liabilities, typically hedging the majority of their currency exposure [7, 9]. The overall financial risks have been summarized in the image below.

![Novo Nordisk identifies foreign exchange risk as high, while credit, interest rate, and liquidity risks are considered low.](image1)

The image below demonstrates the impact of exchange rate adjustments and cash flow hedges on Novo Nordisk's reserves.

![The table outlines the reserve changes due to exchange rate adjustments, cash flow hedges, and other items, reflecting a total reserve of (911) DKK million at the end of 2020.](image2)

Furthermore, Novo Nordisk hedges existing assets and liabilities in key currencies, along with future expected cash flows, up to 24 months forward, applying hedge accounting to align the impact of the hedged item and hedging instrument in the income statement [8]. The impact of immediate 5% increase/decrease in currencies versus EUR and DKK on Novo Nordisk’s operating profit is shown below:

![The table displays the impact of immediate 5% increase/decrease in currencies versus EUR and DKK on Novo Nordisk’s operating profit, showing a total impact of (1,594) DKK million with an increase and 1,594 DKK million with a decrease in 2020.](image3)

In 2020, exchange rate adjustments and cash flow hedges led to a reserve of (2,528) DKK million and 1,802 DKK million respectively, impacting the total reserve [image2].

In 2020, changes in exchange rates and financial risks led to significant adjustments in reserves and comprehensive income, with active hedging strategies employed to mitigate potential adverse impacts on Novo Nordisk's financial results.

McDonald's experienced revenue declines across its company-operated and franchised segments in 2020, particularly in the International Operated Markets, which affected its overall earnings per share [6, 5].

In 2020, total Company-operated sales and franchised revenues decreased by 10% [6]. This decline was primarily due to sales decreases within the International Operated Markets segment, which were impacted by COVID-19-related restaurant closures and operational limitations [6, 5]. However, the U.S. showed positive sales performance, although this was offset by increased spending on marketing and franchisee incentives [6]. Image 5 shows the franchised revenues from U.S. decreased 2% while International Operated Markets decreased 14%.

![The table shows revenues for company-operated sales and franchised revenues across different markets from 2018 to 2020.](image5)

The decline in revenues contributed to a decrease in GAAP earnings per share-diluted from $7.88 in 2019 to $6.31 in 2020, a decrease of 20% [Image3]. The strategic gains related to the sale of McDonald's Japan stock also affected the earnings per share [2]. McDonald's Non-GAAP earnings per share-diluted decreased from $7.84 in 2019 to $6.05 in 2020, a decrease of 23% [Image3].

![The table shows the reconciliation of diluted earnings per share, highlighting GAAP and Non-GAAP earnings and strategic gains.](image3)

The declines in company-operated and franchised revenues, especially in international markets, led to a decrease in both GAAP and Non-GAAP earnings per share for McDonald's from 2019 to 2020.

Chevron Corporation experienced a significant turnaround in net income and return on stockholders' equity from 2020 to 2021, as highlighted in the financial results [1, 2].

In 2021, Chevron reported net income of $15,625 million, a substantial increase compared to a net loss of $(5,543) million in 2020 ![Net income attributable to Chevron Corporation shifted from a loss to a profit between 2020 and 2021](image4). This shift was driven by improved performance across various sectors, as U.S. upstream reported earnings of $7.3 billion in 2021 compared to a loss of $1.6 billion in 2020 [5]. Similarly, international upstream reported earnings of $8.5 billion in 2021, a significant increase from a loss of $825 million in 2020 [6]. The U.S. downstream sector also contributed positively, with earnings of $2.4 billion in 2021, a notable improvement from a loss of $571 million in 2020 [8].

The return on stockholders' equity also saw a marked improvement, increasing to 11.5% in 2021 from -4.0% in 2020 ![Return on stockholders' equity improved substantially between 2020 and 2021](image3).

Overall, Chevron Corporation's net income shifted from a loss of $(5,543) million in 2020 to a profit of $15,625 million in 2021, and the return on stockholders' equity increased from -4.0% to 11.5%.

Cash flows from financing activities significantly increased, while cash flows from investing activities also saw a notable increase between 2020 and 2021.

Cash inflows from financing activities saw a substantial change, increasing by €12,087 million to reach €11,839 million [5].  ![Cash flows from financing activities increased significantly in 2021.](image4)

This surge was strongly influenced by financing activities related to the acquisition of Varian [5]. Additionally,  Siemens Group provided inflows from borrowings of €10.0 billion and an additional €850 million in financing in fiscal year 2021 to support the Varian acquisition [8]. These inflows were partially offset by cash outflows from the repayment of matured loans totaling €730 million and €300 million [8].

Conversely, cash outflows from investing activities also increased, rising by €12,228 million to €14,140 million [6].  ![Cash flows from investing activities saw a substantial outflow increase in 2021.](image4)

This increase was primarily due to the payout for the acquisition of Varian [6]. Further cash outflows of €117 million were attributed to additions to intangible assets, property, plant, and equipment, primarily for capacity expansions [6]. Siemens ­ Healthineers’ investments were aimed mainly at enhancing competitiveness and innovation capability [2].

In summary, Siemens Healthineers experienced a significant increase in both cash inflows from financing activities and cash outflows from investing activities in 2021, primarily driven by the financing and execution of the Varian acquisition.

To determine the total long-term capital and finance lease obligations for December 31, 2017, several components and calculations are involved. The amount of long-term capital lease obligations as of December 31, 2016 and 2017 were $5,080 million and $8,438 million, respectively; The amount of long-term finance lease obligations as of December 31, 2016 and 2017 were $2,439 million and $4,745 million, respectively [1].
 
The calculation of total long-term capital lease obligations involves subtracting imputed interest and the current portion of capital lease obligations from the gross capital lease obligations ![The calculation of total long-term capital lease obligations involves subtracting imputed interest and the current portion of capital lease obligations from the gross capital lease obligations.](image3). As of December 31, 2017, gross capital lease obligations were \$14,811 million, imputed interest was \$534 million, and the current portion of capital lease obligations was \$5,839 million, resulting in total long-term capital lease obligations of \$8,438 million ![The long-term capital lease obligations as of December 31, 2017 totaled $8,438 million.](image3).

Similarly, the calculation of total long-term finance lease obligations involves subtracting imputed interest and the current portion of finance lease obligations from the gross finance lease obligations ![The calculation of total long-term finance lease obligations involves subtracting imputed interest and the current portion of finance lease obligations from the gross finance lease obligations.](image4). As of December 31, 2017, gross finance lease obligations were \$6,265 million, imputed interest was \$1,238 million, and the current portion of finance lease obligations was \$282 million, resulting in total long-term finance lease obligations of \$4,745 million ![The total long-term finance lease obligations as of December 31, 2017 totaled $4,745 million.](image4).

The total long-term capital and finance lease obligations for December 31, 2017, are determined by calculating gross lease obligations, subtracting imputed interest and the current portion of lease obligations.

In 2020, IBM experienced varying financial performances across its systems and geographical regions. The total revenue saw a decrease of 4.6 percent as reported [3].

**Systems Performance**:

*   **Overall Systems Revenue**: Experienced a decrease of 8.2 percent year to year [7].
*   **Systems Hardware**: Declined by 7.4 percent, primarily driven by declines in Power Systems and Storage Systems, although partially offset by growth in IBM Z [7].
*   **IBM Z**: Despite the challenging environment, IBM Z revenue increased by 1.9 percent [2]. This growth underscores the platform's value, especially with its cloud-native development capabilities [2]. The systems gross profit margin increased by 2.8 points to 55.9 percent in 2020 compared to the prior year, driven primarily by margin improvements in IBM Z and Power Systems, and a mix to IBM Z hardware [5].

![IBM Z revenue increased by 1.9 percent in 2020, contributing to overall systems hardware revenue.](image1)

*   **Power Systems and Storage Systems**: Faced revenue declines, with Storage Systems decreasing by 6.1 percent, mainly due to high-end storage declines influenced by the IBM Z cycle [10].
*   **Operating Systems Software**: Revenue decreased by 11.2 percent compared to the prior year [7].
*   **Transaction Processing Platforms**: Revenue decreased by 16.8 percent. Purchase deferrals due to the COVID-19 pandemic impacted transactional software performance, though subscription and support revenue grew [6].

![The external systems hardware gross profit margin increased by 4.4 points in 2020, driven by improvements in IBM Z and Power Systems.](image2)

**Global Financing**:

*   **Pre-tax Income**: Decreased by 27.8 percent year to year, primarily due to lower revenue, partially offset by a decrease in expenses [8].

**Regional Performance**:

*   **Total Revenue**: Decreased by 4.6 percent year to year [3].
*   **Americas**: Experienced a revenue decrease of 6.0 percent [4].
*   **Europe/Middle East/Africa**: Revenue decreased by 3.3 percent [4].
*   **Asia Pacific**: Revenue decreased by 3.5 percent [4].

![The total revenue for IBM in 2020 was $73,620 million, a decrease of 4.6 percent year to year.](image4)

In 2020, IBM experienced a mixed financial performance with declines in total and systems revenue, offset by growth in IBM Z and improvements in gross profit margins, influenced by regional and strategic factors.

In 2020, the total derivative financial instruments were valued at DKK 63,390 million, while in 2019, they were valued at DKK 50,455 million. This represents a significant increase in derivative financial instruments from 2019 to 2020. The positive and negative fair values also changed; in 2020, positive fair value stood at DKK 2,332 million and negative fair value at DKK 1,365 million, whereas in 2019, they were DKK 188 million and DKK 734 million, respectively. ![The table shows the amounts and values of derivative financial instruments for 2020 and 2019, categorized by contract type and fair value.](image1)

Changes in working capital, including exchange rate adjustments, also impacted the cash flow statement.  The change in working capital was (DKK 2,624) million in 2020 and (DKK 3,564) million in 2019; Exchange rate adjustments were (DKK 1,729) million in 2020 and DKK 176 million in 2019.  The cash flow change in working capital was (DKK 4,353) million in 2020 and (DKK 3,388) million in 2019. ![The table summarizes changes in working capital and exchange rate adjustments affecting cash flow for 2020 and 2019.](image5)

Net gains and losses arising from changes in the fair value of financial assets are recognized in the income statement as financial income or expenses [7]. The financial contracts are expected to impact the income statement within the next 12 months, with deferred gains and losses on cash flow hedges then being transferred to financial income or financial expenses [9]. These derivative instruments affect the income statement and cash flow statement, with fair value changes recognized as financial income or expenses and gains/losses from cash flow hedges impacting financial results [7, 9].

In summary, derivative financial instruments increased significantly from 2019 to 2020, and changes in working capital along with exchange rate adjustments influenced the cash flow, both of which impact the income statement through recognized gains, losses, and financial income or expenses.

In fiscal year 2021, changes in financial assumptions resulted in a loss of €26 million, whereas in 2020, these changes led to a gain of €72 million. ![Changes in financial assumptions led to a loss of €26 million in 2021, compared to a gain of €72 million in 2020.](image5)

Siemens Healthineers considers the decline in pension plans' funded status due to adverse development of plan assets or defined benefit obligation as a significant risk [5]. This risk is significantly affected by changes in actuarial assumptions, primarily the discount rate, and movements in financial markets [3, 5]. The company implements an investment strategy aligned with the defined benefit obligation and manages risks using a defined risk measure (Value at Risk, VaR) [5]. They also use derivatives to reduce risks [5]. The discount rates are determined by reference to yields on high-quality corporate bonds [7]. ![Discount rates for Euro, U.S. dollar, British pound and Swiss franc.](image3)

Changes in financial assumptions led to a significant swing from a gain of €72 million in 2020 to a loss of €26 million in 2021 in the actuarial gains and losses of Siemens Healthineers' defined benefit plans.

Toyota's financial strategy, characterized by stability, growth, and efficiency, plays a crucial role in addressing climate change risks and opportunities [7, 8]. The company is dedicated to enhancing its corporate value and ensuring sustainable growth to benefit its shareholders [10].

Toyota uses scenarios to examine future images of society based on the current policy scenario, scenarios below 2°C, and scenarios below 1.5°C [5]. These scenarios help the company conduct risk and opportunity analysis and inform their strategies. The company discloses information concerning risks and opportunities related to climate change and their analyses [9]. Toyota strives to identify risks and opportunities arising from environmental issues, taking action while validating strategies like the Toyota Environmental Challenge 2050 [1].
![Toyota considers climate change risks and opportunities.](image4)
The company recognizes that climate change requires measures in various areas, including new technologies and responses to tighter government regulations [1]. As climate change progresses, higher temperatures, rising sea levels, and more severe natural disasters are expected [1].

To address these challenges, Toyota is reinforcing its profit structure through cost reduction and the Toyota Production System, securing funds to invest in advanced technologies [6]. Retained earnings are utilized for investments in next-generation growth, such as environmental technologies for a carbon-neutral society [10]. Toyota engages in constructive dialogue with shareholders to improve corporate value and achieve sustainable growth [3].
![Toyota aims to build a robust financial foundation to support sustainable growth.](image5)
Toyota aims to maintain and improve upon its consolidated payout ratio of 30% and also considers its shareholders benefit as an important element of its management policy [10]. Toyota aims to build a robust financial foundation to support sustainable growth by maintaining adequate stability while pursuing growth and efficiency over the medium and long terms [7].

Toyota’s financial strategy supports its response to climate scenarios by investing in environmental technologies and ensuring stable returns for shareholders.

In 2021, premiums earned increased by $2.6 billion (7.4%) compared to 2020 [4]. Similarly, premiums written in 2021 increased by $3.5 billion (9.9%) compared to 2020, but this figure includes a reduction of approximately $2.9 billion due to the GEICO Giveback program [4].
![Premiums earned and written are shown for 2019, 2020, and 2021.](image3)
The GEICO Giveback program significantly impacted these figures; premiums written and earned in 2020 decreased by $1.1 billion (3.0%) and $479 million (1.3%), respectively, compared to 2019, largely due to the program reducing premiums written by $2.9 billion and premiums earned by $2.5 billion in 2020 [10].

Conversely, interest and other investment income saw a decline of $470 million (44.4%) in 2021 compared to 2020, which itself declined by $1.0 billion (49.0%) compared to 2019 [6]. This decline was mainly due to lower income from short-term investments and fixed maturity securities, influenced by lower short-term interest rates [6].
![Net investment income components for 2019, 2020, and 2021 are listed.](image2)
While dividend income increased by $365 million (8.1%) in 2020 compared to 2019, this wasn't enough to offset the significant drop in interest income [9].

While premiums earned generally increased from 2019 to 2021, net investment income decreased over the same period, primarily due to declining interest rates and lower income from short-term investments.

In 2020, IBM experienced a notable turnaround in its net change in cash, cash equivalents, and restricted cash compared to 2019.

The net cash provided by operating activities significantly increased by $3,426 million in 2020 [4]. This improvement was driven primarily by an increase in cash provided by receivables of $4,795 million due to sales of receivables, including financing receivables of $3,076 million [6, 10].
![Net cash from operating activities increased by $3.4 billion due to increase in cash provided by receivables](image2)

Additionally, net cash used in investing activities decreased by $23,908 million [5]. This decrease was mainly due to a $32,294 million reduction in net cash used for acquisitions, as the Red Hat acquisition occurred in the prior year [1, 9]. This was partially offset by a $6,245 million decrease in cash provided by net non-operating finance receivables, primarily from winding down OEM IT commercial financing operations [1, 9].

However, financing activities presented a net use of cash of $9,721 million in 2020, contrasting with a net source of cash of $9,042 million in 2019 [8].  Total equity decreased by $258 million, mainly due to dividends paid of $5,797 million [2].

Overall, IBM's net change in cash, cash equivalents, and restricted cash improved significantly in 2020 compared to 2019 due to increased cash from operating activities and decreased cash used in investing activities, despite a net use of cash in financing activities.

In 2020, total Company-operated sales and franchised revenues decreased by 10% [9]. This decrease was primarily due to sales declines in the International Operated Markets segment because of COVID-19, even though the U.S. had positive sales performance [9].
![Total Company-operated sales and Franchised revenues decreased by 10% from 2019 to 2020.](image5)
The revenue declines were more significant in the International Operated Markets segment, and the number of drive-thru locations impacted the ability of each market to drive sales and revenue growth [1]. These declines were driven by the U.K., France, Germany, Italy, and Spain [1]. Additionally, the Company supported marketing through incentives to franchisees, including the free Thank You Meals served to first responders and healthcare workers, which also offset the positive sales performance in the U.S [9].

Total restaurant margins also decreased by 13% in 2020 [8].
![Total restaurant margins decreased by 13% from 2019 to 2020.](image2)
This was a result of sales declines in the International Operated Markets segment due to COVID-19, partially offset by positive sales performance in the U.S [8]. Furthermore, Company-operated margins in the U.S. and International Operated Markets segments were impacted by incremental COVID-19 expenses, which included employee-related costs, personal protective equipment, and signage and other restaurant costs [10].

In summary, the total revenues and restaurant margins decreased from 2019 to 2020, primarily due to COVID-19-related sales declines in international markets and increased expenses, despite positive sales performance in the U.S.

BHP's governance framework actively addresses climate change risks through several mechanisms, including board oversight and consideration in financial statements, while also emphasizing director training through briefings, development sessions, and site visits.

Climate change is a key issue on the Board agenda, influencing strategy, portfolio reviews, investment decisions, and risk management [3]. The Risk and Audit Committee (RAC) assists the Board in overseeing climate-related risk management, while the Board maintains overall accountability for BHP’s risk profile [3].
![The Risk and Audit Committee confirms the fairness and balance of BHP’s 2021 Annual Report, covering climate change risks.](image3)

The Committee considered how the Group’s greenhouse gas emissions reduction commitments and climate change scenarios are reflected in key judgements and estimates used in the preparation of the Group’s FY2021 finance statements [7]. The Committee concluded that climate change has been appropriately considered by management in key judgements and estimates and concurred with the disclosures proposed by management [1].

![BHP provides briefings and development sessions for directors to understand the activities, environment, key issues, and direction of the assets, along with HSEC and public policy considerations.](image5)

BHP ensures directors are well-informed through briefings, development sessions, and site visits, including climate change sessions [5].
The governance framework supports the integration of climate change considerations into BHP's strategic and operational processes.

From the beginning to the end of 2021, total WFAM assets under management decreased by $603.0 to $0 due to the sale of WFAM [image1].

In addition, the amortized cost, net of the allowance for credit losses, of AFS debt securities decreased from December 31, 2020 [3]. The total net unrealized gains on AFS and HTM debt securities also decreased from December 31, 2020, driven by higher interest rates [8]. ![Comparison of available-for-sale and held-to-maturity securities between December 31, 2021, and December 31, 2020.](image4)

Wells Fargo's financial strategy was influenced by changes in total assets and the sale of Wells Fargo Asset Management (WFAM) between 2020 and 2021.

The total assets of Wells Fargo decreased slightly from 2020 to 2021, as shown in the "Selected Balance Sheet Data (period-end)". ![Wells Fargo's total assets decreased by 1% from 2020 to 2021.](image3)

In February 2021, Wells Fargo announced an agreement to sell Wells Fargo Asset Management (WFAM), and the sale closed on November 1, 2021 [6]. The sale of WFAM resulted in a significant outflow of assets under management [10]. The WFAM assets under management decreased from $603.0 billion in 2020 to $0 in 2021 due to the sale. ![WFAM assets under management decreased from $603.0 billion to $0 due to the sale.](image5) WFAM offered Wells Fargo proprietary mutual funds and managed institutional separate accounts, generating fees as a percentage of the market value of the AUM [10].
Management believes that AUM is a useful metric because it allows management, investors,  and others to assess how changes in asset amounts may impact  the generation of certain asset-based fees [4].

These changes, including the sale of WFAM and the fluctuations in total assets, prompted Wells Fargo to reposition its overall portfolio for capital management purposes by transferring $\S56.0$ billion of AFS debt securities to HTM debt securities in 2021 [9]. The bank had to rebalance its AFS debt securities portfolio to meet the Company’s interest rate risk management objectives [8].

The changes in total assets and the sale of WFAM led Wells Fargo to adjust its capital and risk management strategies, including repositioning its investment portfolio and rebalancing its debt securities portfolios.

To calculate the sales to working capital ratio, we need to divide the revenue by the working capital.
First, we need to find the revenue for 2015.

Based on the Consolidated Statements of Operations, the Revenues in 2015 is $6,779,511 [2].
![The revenue for the year ended December 31, 2015 is $6,779,511.](image2)

Next, we need to calculate the working capital for 2015, which is current assets minus current liabilities.
From the Consolidated Balance Sheets, the current assets in 2015 are $5,431,840 and the current liabilities are $3,529,624 [5].
![The current assets and current liabilities in 2015 is $5,431,840 and $3,529,624.](image5)

Therefore, working capital = $5,431,840 - $3,529,624 = $1,902,216.
Finally, we can calculate the sales to working capital ratio:
Sales to Working Capital Ratio = Revenue / Working Capital = $6,779,511 / $1,902,216 = 3.5639.

The sales to working capital ratio of Netflix in FY 2015 is 3.56.

From December 31, 2020, to December 31, 2021, total loans outstanding increased, primarily driven by commercial loans [1].
```
Commercial loans increased from December 31, 2020, predominantly due to an increase in the  commercial and industrial loan portfolio, driven by higher loan  demand resulting in increased originations and loan draws,  partially offset by paydowns and PPP loan forgiveness.
```
Consumer loans decreased due to paydowns and the transfer of mortgage loans to loans held for sale [1].
```
Consumer  loans decreased from December 31, 2020, predominantly driven  by a decrease in the residential mortgage – first lien portfolio due  to loan paydowns reflecting the low interest rate environment  and the transfer of  $\S17.8$   billion of first lien mortgage loans to  loans held for sale (LHFS) substantially all of which related to the  sales of loans purchased from GNMA loan securitization pools in  prior periods, partially offset by originations of   $\S72.6$   billion.
```
Total loans increased from $887,637 million to $895,394 million from Dec 31, 2020 to Dec 31, 2021, while commercial loans increased and consumer loans decreased. ![Total loans increased from 2020 to 2021, with a shift from consumer to commercial loans.](image5)

 ![Total deposits grew, especially in noninterest-bearing demand deposits, while time deposits decreased from 2020 to 2021.](image1)

```
actions taken to manage under the asset cap resulting in  declines in time deposits, such as brokered certificates of deposit (CDs), and interest-bearing deposits in non-U.S.  offices.
```
These changes suggest a strategy focused on growing the commercial loan portfolio while managing assets to comply with regulatory requirements.

The loan and deposit figures indicate a strategic shift towards commercial lending and active management of deposit types, likely influenced by regulatory constraints and market conditions.

From FY2020 to FY2021, BHP experienced significant changes impacting its Underlying EBITDA. Revenue of US\$60.8 billion increased by US\$17.9 billion, or 42 per cent, from FY2020, which was primarily attributable to higher average realised prices for iron ore, copper, nickel, oil, natural gas and thermal coal [2]. However, total expenses excluding net finance costs of US\$34.5 billion also increased by US\$5.7 billion, or 20 per cent, from FY2020 [8].

The change in sales prices had a substantial positive impact, increasing Underlying EBITDA by US\$16,965 million, while operating cash costs slightly decreased Underlying EBITDA by US\$34 million. ![The table shows the impact of various factors on Underlying EBITDA from FY2020 to FY2021, including changes in sales prices and operating cash costs.](image1)

In summary, the increase in Underlying EBITDA from FY2020 to FY2021 was positively impacted by higher average realised prices for various commodities, while operating cash costs had a minor negative impact.

In 2020, impairment charges of $6,117,000 ($5,434,000 after tax) were included within the consolidated statement of profit or loss and other comprehensive income [6]. This includes charges from exiting the Spanish market and a write-down of assets within the store network [6]. In 2019, no impairment charges were recognized [6].

The statutory net profit after tax decreased by 69.7% to $11.2 million [10].  Excluding the impact of AASB 16 and impairment charges, earnings before interest and tax would have been $30.6 million [10]. Profit attributable to ordinary shareholders for 2020 was $11,221,000, while in 2019 it was $37,043,000. ![Profit attributable to ordinary shareholders decreased between 2019 and 2020.](image1)

The increase in impairment charges significantly reduced the profit attributable to ordinary shareholders from $37,043,000 in 2019 to $11,221,000 in 2020.

To determine the Gross Profit to Total Assets ratio for Best Buy for the fiscal year ending January 28, 2023, we need to extract the Gross Profit and Total Assets values from the provided images.

Based on the consolidated statements of earnings, the Gross Profit for the fiscal year ending January 28, 2023, is $9,912 million. ![Gross profit for the fiscal year ending January 28, 2023, is $9,912 million.](image5)

From the consolidated balance sheets, the Total Assets as of January 28, 2023, is $15,803 million. ![Total Assets as of January 28, 2023, is $15,803 million.](image2)

The Gross Profit to Total Assets ratio is calculated as follows:
Ratio = Gross Profit / Total Assets = 9912 / 15803 = 0.627

Therefore, the Gross Profit to Total Assets ratio for Best Buy for the fiscal year ending January 28, 2023, is approximately 0.627.

In 2020, PepsiCo's net cash provided by financing activities was $3.8 billion, mainly from long-term debt issuances, but this was partially offset by returning operating cash flow to shareholders through dividends and share repurchases, as well as payments of long-term debt borrowings and redemptions [5]. In contrast, 2019 saw net cash used for financing activities totaling $8.5 billion, primarily due to returning cash flow to shareholders and debt payments, offset by proceeds from long-term debt issuances [10].

![Net cash from financing activities was positive in 2020 but negative in 2019.](image4)

The free cash flow in 2020 was $6,428 million, a 15% increase compared to $5,587 million in 2019; this free cash flow is utilized for acquisitions, debt repayments, dividends, and share repurchases [9]. The company has total contractual commitments of $66,321 million, which include long-term debt obligations, operating leases, a one-time mandatory transition tax, other long-term liabilities, interest on debt obligations, purchasing commitments, marketing commitments and other long-term contractual commitments [5].

![PepsiCo has total contractual commitments of $66,321 million.](image5)

PepsiCo's financing activities in 2020 led to positive cash flow, contributing to free cash flow used for strategic investments and shareholder returns, while maintaining significant contractual obligations.

In 2020, TLAC ratios were calculated using the regulatory capital rule that allows a five-year transition period related to the adoption of CECL [1]. The standardized approach was used to calculate TLAC and long-term debt ratios [4].
![TLAC amounts and regulatory minimums for 2019 and 2020.](image5)
The image shows that the TLAC amount increased from $367,449 in 2019 to $405,153 in 2020, and the long-term debt increased from $171,349 in 2019 to $196,997 in 2020.

![Risk-weighted assets under standardized and advanced approaches for 2019 and 2020.](image2)
The risk-weighted assets (in billions) under the Standardized approach decreased from $1,493 in 2019 to $1,480 in 2020, and under the Advanced approaches, they decreased from $1,447 in 2019 to $1,371 in 2020. The Corporation is required to maintain TLAC ratios in excess of minimum requirements plus applicable buffers to avoid restrictions on capital distributions and discretionary bonus payments [10]. The regulatory minimums for risk-based capital at both December 31, 2020 and 2019 are the minimum ratios under Basel 3 including a capital conservation buffer of 2.5 percent [8].

In summary, risk-weighted assets decreased under both standardized and advanced approaches, while TLAC and long-term debt increased, and the corporation maintains TLAC ratios above the regulatory minimums.

UnitedHealthcare experienced varied changes in the number of individuals served across its different segments between 2019 and 2020.

The number of people served through commercial risk-based and fee-based plans decreased, as shown in the following image.
![Commercial risk-based and fee-based plans saw a decrease in individuals served.](image3)

Specifically, risk-based commercial plans decreased by 665,000 (8%), and fee-based commercial plans decreased by 875,000 (5%) [3]. "Fee-based and risk-based commercial business decreased primarily due to increased unemployment and related attrition" [10].

However, the number of individuals served through Medicare Advantage and Medicaid increased, as shown in the following image.
![Medicare Advantage and Medicaid saw an increase in individuals served.](image3)
Specifically, Medicare Advantage increased by 440,000 (8%) and Medicaid increased by 720,000 (12%) [3].  "Medicare Advantage increased due to growth in people served through individual Medicare Advantage plans" [10]. The increase in Medicaid was due to states easing redetermination requirements and growth in Dual Special Needs Plans [10].

In contrast, the number of people served by UnitedHealthcare Global decreased by 295,000 (5%) [3]. "The decrease in people served by United Healthcare Global is a result of increased unemployment and underwriting discipline" [10].

In summary, UnitedHealthcare saw a decrease in commercial and global segments due to unemployment and underwriting discipline, but increases in Medicare and Medicaid due to plan growth and policy changes.

From 2021 to 2022, there were changes in both the discount rate and the expected return on plan assets for pension and other retiree benefits, which can impact the net amount recognized.

For pension benefits, the discount rate increased from 1.5% in 2021 to 1.7% in 2022, while the expected return on plan assets decreased from 6.5% to 5.5% ![Pension Benefits discount rate increased to 1.7% and Expected return on plan assets decrease to 5.5% in 2022 compared to prior year.](image4).

For other retiree benefits, the discount rate increased from 3.2% in 2021 to 5.0% in 2022, while the expected return on plan assets remained constant at 8.4% ![Other Retiree Benefits discount rate increased to 5.0% and Expected return on plan assets remained constant at 8.4% in 2022 compared to prior year.](image4).

These changes impact the net periodic benefit cost/(credit). As shown in image2, the expected return on plan assets decreased from $(783) to $(684) for pension benefits, and from $(508) to $(564) for other retiree benefits ![The expected return on plan assets for pension and other retiree benefits in 2022.](image2). Additionally, the actuarial gain for pension plans in 2022 was primarily related to increases in discount rates [4]. The effect of discount rates also applies to other retiree benefits [10].

The net amount recognized for pension benefits decreased from $\$(5,428)$ in 2021 to $\$(2,435)$ in 2022; at the same time, the net amount recognized for other retiree benefits increased from $2,238 in 2021 to $3,819 in 2022 ![Net amount recognized for pension benefits and other retiree benefits in 2022 and 2021.](image5).

In summary, the discount rates increased for both pension and other retiree benefits, while the expected return on plan assets decreased for pension benefits and remained the same for other retiree benefits, impacting the net periodic benefit cost/(credit) and the overall net amount recognized.

In 2020, HSBC's net operating income and adjusted revenue from Global Markets experienced notable changes compared to 2019. The bank also implemented changes to improve the reflection of revenue and expense [1].
![The net operating income in 2020 vs 2019 increased by $434 million.](image4)
According to the management view of adjusted revenue, net operating income increased by $434 million from 2019 to 2020.

![Adjusted revenue from global markets increased from 5,728 million to 7,290 million.](image4)
Adjusted revenue from Global Markets increased by $1,562 million, or 27%, driven by higher volatility levels and increased client activity, particularly in Foreign Exchange and Credit [9]. FICC performance was improved with wider spreads [9].
![Management view of adjusted revenue.](image1)
The allocation of revenue and expenses relating to Markets Treasury, the funding costs of HSBC Holdings debt, and the impacts of hyperinflation in Argentina to the global businesses, which was implemented to improve how the bank reflects revenue and expenses related to the global businesses, also had an impact on the adjusted revenue [1, 7].

In 2020, HSBC saw an increase in both net operating income and adjusted revenue from Global Markets, primarily due to higher market volatility and increased client activity, along with changes in revenue allocation.

ExxonMobil's share of equity decreased by $34.5 billion, from $191.7 billion in 2019 to $157.2 billion in 2020 [1]. This change is evident in the financial statements.

The reduction in equity for losses was $22.4 billion, and the reduction for distributions to ExxonMobil shareholders, all in the form of dividends, was $14.9 billion [1]. These factors significantly contributed to the overall decrease in equity.

However, some factors increased equity. Foreign exchange translation effects from the weaker U.S. dollar increased equity by $1.8 billion, and a $1.0 billion change in the funded status of the postretirement benefits reserves also increased equity [1].

In summary, ExxonMobil's total equity decreased significantly from 2019 to 2020, primarily due to losses and dividend distributions, partially offset by foreign exchange effects and changes in postretirement benefits reserves.

NBCUniversal's financial performance from 2019 to 2021 was affected by various factors, including revenue trends and customer relationships. The Media segment saw revenue increase by 20.3% to $22.8 billion, although Adjusted EBITDA decreased by 18.0%, impacted by the Tokyo Olympics broadcast in 2021 [1]. Excluding the Olympics, Media segment revenue increased by 11.0% due to growth in distribution, advertising, and other revenues, influenced by COVID-19 effects in the prior year [1]. The number of subscribers and audience ratings at the networks are expected to continue to decline as a result of the competitive environment and shifting video consumption patterns [9].

The Studios segment experienced a 16.2% revenue increase to $9.4 billion, driven by content licensing, theatrical revenue, and home entertainment growth as production operations returned to full capacity [1]. The Theme Parks segment revenue significantly increased by 141.2% to $5.1 billion, with Adjusted EBITDA rising from $(0.5) billion to $1.3 billion, reflecting improved operations compared to the prior year's closures and restrictions, and the opening of the Beijing theme park in September 2021 [1].

Sky's performance, as shown in the image, indicates a fluctuating number of total customer relationships from 2019 to 2021. ![Sky's total customer relationships showed a fluctuating trend from 2019 to 2021.](image1) In 2021, there was a net loss of 198,000 customer relationships [image1].

Despite the drop in customer relationships, Sky saw an increase in average monthly direct-to-consumer revenue per customer relationship. ![Average monthly direct-to-consumer revenue increased from 2020 to 2021.](image2)The average monthly direct-to-consumer revenue per customer relationship increased by 8.7% from 2020 to 2021 [image2]. This increase reflected impacts from the postponement of sporting events in the prior year due to COVID-19, higher sales of wireless handsets, and rate increases in the United Kingdom, offset by declines in average rates in Italy [8].

Peacock, generated revenue of $778 million in 2021, compared to $118 million in 2020, with operating costs and expenses of $2.5 billion and $781 million in 2021 and 2020, respectively [1].

Overall, NBCUniversal's financial performance was shaped by increased revenue in several segments, offset by costs associated with strategic initiatives and external factors such as COVID-19 and changes in sports programming rights. The fluctuating customer relationships and increasing average revenue per customer at Sky further influenced the financial outcomes.

BHP's Nomination and Governance Committee plays a crucial role in ensuring effective board succession planning and director development through several key processes. The Nomination and Governance Committee oversees and monitors renewal and succession planning, Board and Director performance evaluation, Director training and development, and advises and makes recommendations on the Group’s governance practices [5].
![The image outlines BHP's structured and rigorous approach to Board succession planning.](image2)
BHP adopts a structured and rigorous approach to Board succession planning, including considering Board diversity, size, tenure, and the skills and experience needed to govern and manage risk effectively [Step 1, image2]. The process is continuous and ensures the Board remains fit for purpose, considering the changing environment and BHP's circumstances [Step 2, image2]. The committee oversees the preparation of role descriptions for new appointments and partners with search firms to identify suitable candidates [Step 3 & 4, image2].
![This image illustrates the responsibilities of the Nomination and Governance Committee including succession planning processes, evaluation and training and corporate governance practices.](image3)
Moreover, Non-executive Directors participate in continuous improvement activities, including training and development programs overseen by the Nomination and Governance Committee covering business, environmental, social, and governance matters [7]. These programs are designed to maximize effectiveness and incorporate results from Director performance evaluations [7]. The Committee ensures Directors have a deeper understanding of BHP’s activities through briefings and development sessions on topics like strategy, climate change, and innovation, as well as site visits [image1].

BHP's Nomination and Governance Committee ensures effective board succession planning and director development through rigorous processes, continuous monitoring, and tailored training programs.

In 2021, Chevron's U.S. upstream segment reported earnings of $7.3 billion, which is a significant increase compared to the loss of $1.6 billion in 2020 [3]. The U.S. downstream segment also saw a significant increase, reporting earnings of $2.4 billion in 2021, compared to a loss of $571 million in 2020 [5]. The financial results for 2002-2003 show a gross profit of Rs. 8873.49 lac [5]. However, the export potential for tobacco is significantly higher. India currently holds only 0.7% share of the USD 30 billion annual Global Import Export Tobacco Trade, and there's a potential to increase export earnings seven times with just 5% share of the global tobacco trade ![India has a significant export potential for tobacco](image3).

Despite the higher gross profit, the net profit of the company was lower at Rs. 37.91 crore as against Rs. 47.80 crore in the previous year due to taxation and exceptional expense on account of Assam dues becoming doubtful of recovery [7].
Discriminatory taxation could shift consumption from cigarettes to cheaper non-cigarette products ![Discriminatory taxation affects the consumption of cigarettes](image1).

Given the export potential, the company could focus on increasing tobacco exports to improve its financial performance and reduce its reliance on the domestic market, which is subject to discriminatory taxation. The sales turnover was also higher at Rs. 1077 crore as against Rs. 945 crore in the previous year, registering an increase of $14\%$ [3]. The financial results for 2002-2003, compared to the export potential for tobacco, suggest that the company should consider increasing tobacco exports to improve its financial performance.

Global Business Services (GBS) and Global Technology Services (GTS) experienced different financial outcomes from 2019 to 2020.
GBS saw a revenue decrease of 3.8 percent as reported [3]. However, the GBS gross profit margin increased by 2.0 points to 29.7 percent [1].
![GBS gross profit margin increased 2.0 points to 29.7 percent.](image4)
Despite the gross margin expansion, pre-tax income decreased by 16.8 percent, and the pre-tax margin declined by 1.2 points to 8.3 percent [1]. Cloud revenue within GBS grew by 11 percent [2].

GTS revenue decreased by 5.7 percent [10]. This decline was attributed to lower client business volumes due to the macroeconomic environment, though cloud revenue did grow [10]. The revenue for Infrastructure & Cloud Services decreased by 5.1 percent, and Technology Support Services revenue decreased by 7.3 percent [6, 7].
![Global Technology Services external revenue decreased by 5.7%.](image3)
Total backlog for GTS also decreased from $112.4 billion in 2019 to $110.8 billion in 2020 [2].
![Total backlog decreased from $112.4 billion in 2019 to $110.8 billion in 2020.](image2)

In summary, GBS experienced revenue declines but improved gross profit margins, while GTS saw revenue declines across its main services and a decrease in total backlog.

These declines were attributed to lower interest rates on cash and U.S. Treasury Bills holdings [10].
