This shift represents a significant decline of 31 percentage points among Republicans [1, 2, 8]. Currently, 72% of Democrats view public health officials favorably [6].

Overall positive views of public health officials have decreased from 79% in March to 63% [9]. This decline in positive assessments is primarily seen among Republicans [4]. Republicans' approval of public health officials has decreased significantly while Democrats' views have remained largely consistent.

Hispanics have shown more optimism about their financial future compared to the general public [2]. This optimism has increased more rapidly among Hispanics since the Great Recession [8].

In 2015, $81\%$ of Hispanics expected their family's financial situation to improve, compared to $61\%$ of the general public [1]. ![Hispanics show a greater increase in positive financial expectations compared to the general population from 2008 to 2015.](image1)

Looking back to before the recession, Latino views of their financial situation are more positive now than they were in 2004, when roughly a third (31%) rated their financial condition as excellent or good [5]. By contrast, the public’s view of its finances is lower now than in 2004, when about half (51%) had a positive view [5]. Half of Americans believe China will have less influence in world affairs after the pandemic [3]. Latino Democrats and Republicans differ significantly in their views on whether the Democratic and Republican parties work hard to earn Latino votes, with Democrats generally viewing the Democratic Party more favorably and Republicans viewing the Republican Party more favorably [6].

According to the survey, the Democratic Party is generally viewed more favorably among Latino adults.  About half of Latino Democrats $(51\%)$ say the Democratic Party works hard to earn Latinos’ votes, saying the statement describes their views well [4]. By contrast, nearly half of Republicans $(46\%)$ hold the opposing view that the statement does not describe their views well [4]. ![Democrats are more likely to agree that the Democratic Party works hard to earn Latinos’ votes.](image1)

Views on the Republican Party's efforts also diverge, with a substantial share of Latino partisans expressing differing opinions, and Hispanics generally having more positive attitudes toward the Democratic Party than the Republican Party [3, 6].

In summary, Latino Democrats are more likely to believe the Democratic Party works hard for their votes, while Latino Republicans are more skeptical of the Democratic Party's efforts and more supportive of the Republican Party's efforts.

Women's representation in STEM jobs varies by their level of education [2]. Women with advanced degrees in STEM are more likely to report gender discrimination and believe their gender hinders their success [3]. Additionally, they are more skeptical about fair treatment in promotion opportunities [3].

![Women's representation in STEM jobs decreases as education level increases.](image3)

The representation of women in STEM jobs tends to decrease with higher levels of education, as seen in the graph, where the percentage of women employed in STEM jobs with a high school education or less is 55%, while it drops to 41% for those with a professional or doctoral degree [9]. In general, women's representation in STEM jobs is lower among those with advanced degrees [9].

Women's representation in STEM occupations varies significantly by occupational subgroup [8]. Engineering occupations have the lowest share of women at $14\%$ [8]. Computer occupations follow, with women comprising a quarter of workers $(25\%)$ in these fields [8]. Women are underrepresented among physical scientists $(39\%)$, but their representation among life scientists $(47\%)$ and math workers $(46\%)$ roughly equals women’s overall share in the workforce $(47\%)$ [8].
![The chart illustrates women's representation across various STEM job clusters.](image3)
Women's representation varies widely across different STEM job clusters, with health-related jobs having the highest representation and engineering having the lowest.

Blacks in STEM jobs are much more likely to experience discrimination and perceive unfair treatment compared to their white counterparts. 62% of blacks in STEM say they have experienced discrimination at work because of their race or ethnicity, which is significantly higher than the 13% of whites who report the same [4]. ![62% of blacks in STEM say they have experienced discrimination at work because of their race.](image4)

Black STEM workers are less convinced than white STEM workers that black employees where they work are treated fairly when it comes to hiring and promotions [3]. Specifically, $43\%$ of blacks in STEM believe that blacks are usually treated fairly during recruitment, while $37\%$ believe this is the case during promotion and advancement opportunities [3]. By contrast, most white STEM workers believe that blacks are usually treated fairly in these processes, with $78\%$ reporting this about hiring and $75\%$ about advancement [3].

These disparities in experiences and perceptions highlight a significant divide in the STEM workplace, where blacks are more likely to encounter discrimination and perceive unfair treatment in hiring and promotion processes compared to whites. This is further supported by the fact that blacks working in STEM jobs tend to report experiences of workplace discrimination due to race more than blacks in non-STEM jobs ($62\%$ vs. $50\%$) [10].

Pre-training word embeddings can have varying impacts on BLEU scores depending on the language pairs and resource availability. In higher-resource languages, pre-training leads to consistent gains of approximately 3 BLEU points [1]. For extremely low-resource languages, the effect of pre-training can be small or very large, with gains up to 11 BLEU points in some cases [1].

For instance, the gains in BLEU score are highest when the baseline system is not too poor, typically with a baseline BLEU score in the range of 3-4 [4]. This indicates that a moderately effective system is necessary for pre-training to be effective [4].
![BLEU score improvements on different datasets](image3)
As shown in the image, pre-training leads to a larger gain when systems have more room to improve, as seen with RU and HE [9].

Pre-training helps the model capture rarer vocabulary and generates more grammatically well-formed sentences [2]. For example, pre-training helps to translate a person’s name and multi-word phrases, providing better representations of less frequent concepts in low-resource languages [2].

The impact of pre-training on BLEU scores varies depending on the language pairs, resource availability, and initial system performance, often improving translation accuracy, especially for low-frequency words.

The inclusion of the source in the COMET models appears to affect the performance of language pairs differently depending on whether English is the source or target language.

For language pairs where English is the source, the COMET models generally outperform other metrics [1, 6].
![COMET models outperform other metrics when English is the source language.](image1)

Specifically, "across the board our three models trained with the C OMET  framework outperform, often by signiﬁcant margins, all other metrics" [6]. The DA RR Ranker model specifically "outperforms the two Estimators in seven out of eight language pairs" [6].

However, for language pairs where English is the target, the impact of including the source language is more pronounced, as indicated by a higher  $\Delta\tau$ [8].
![Delta tau values indicate the change in performance with the inclusion of source text.](image2)
This is shown in Table 3, where the difference  $(\Delta\tau)$  between using reference-only and reference+source models is higher for language pairs with English as the target [8]. This suggests the source language contributes more when predicting the quality of translations into English compared to translations from English.

To further investigate the contribution of the source language, two versions of the  DA RR Ranker model were trained: one using only the reference and another using both reference and source [9].  The models were then tested on WMT 2018 corpus for language pairs and the reversed directions. As shown in Table 3 and [8], the value  and contribution of the source language input in the models’ ability to learn accurate predictions varies by language pair.

The inclusion of reference translations in the COMET-RANK metric differentially affects language pairs involving English, with a more pronounced impact when English is the target language.

The annotator agreement levels vary when comparing Chameleon with other baseline models, suggesting the relative evaluation can be challenging due to Chameleon's similar performance.

These levels of agreement suggest that Chameleon often performs similarly to other baselines, making it difficult to distinguish its performance, which complicates the relative evaluation process.

The evaluation of continuous importance scores assigned to tokens by models involves converting soft scores into discrete rationales [6]. Metrics for continuous or soft token scoring models consider token rankings, rewarding models for assigning higher scores to marked tokens [1]. AUPRC, or Area Under the Precision-Recall Curve, is constructed by sweeping a threshold over token scores and is used to assess the quality of token scores with respect to human annotations [1, 3].

The highest and lowest AUPRC values for the BoolQ dataset can be identified in ![AUPRC values for different model combinations on the BoolQ dataset.](image5). The highest AUPRC value is 0.525, corresponding to the GloVe + LSTM - Attention model combination, while the lowest AUPRC value is 0.072, corresponding to the GloVe + LSTM - Gradient model combination.

The difference between the highest and lowest AUPRC values for the BoolQ dataset is 0.453, with the GloVe + LSTM - Attention model having the highest value and the GloVe + LSTM - Gradient model having the lowest.

As the number of demonstrations increases from 1 to 5, there is an evident improvement in performance; however, subsequent improvements are limited when the number of demonstrations continues to increase [10]. Adding logical constraints into LLM instructions can provide stable improvements, especially with more demonstrations [10]. The performance of incorporating logical constraints with a smaller number of demonstrations can even surpass that of prompts with only a larger number of demonstrations [10].

Overall, the data indicates that increasing the number of demonstrations improves Micro-F1 performance up to a point, and incorporating logical constraints can further enhance performance, even with fewer demonstrations.

The main error types in Step-Back Prompting on TimeQA are Reasoning and RAG, with Reasoning errors being more prevalent [7].

Errors in Step-Back prompting can stem from several sources. Sometimes, the step-back question itself is unhelpful [2]. Other times, RAG fails to retrieve relevant information even when the step-back question is good [2].
![The chart shows the breakdown of errors made by Step-Back Prompting on TimeQA, highlighting Reasoning and RAG as the primary error sources.](image3)
As shown in Figure 5, Reasoning and RAG errors are the dominant sources of errors, while StepBack rarely fails [6, 7]. More specifically, reasoning errors constitute more than half of the errors, while a significant portion is due to RAG failing to retrieve the correct information [6].

In conclusion, the primary errors in Step-Back Prompting on TimeQA are due to reasoning failures and the inability to retrieve relevant information via RAG.

The survey categorizes correction methodologies into training-time, generation-time, and post-hoc approaches [3, 10]. Training-time correction involves rectifying model behavior during the training phase, typically using human feedback or self-training [4, 7]. Generation-time correction uses automated feedback to guide the LLM to correct errors during generation [6]. Post-hoc correction refines the model output after it has been generated, without updating the model parameters [8]. As illustrated in the survey, different strategies are employed for each correction type, such as human feedback, reward models, and automated feedback for training-time correction ![Training-time correction uses different forms of feedback during training](image4). Generation-time correction uses generate-then-rank and feedback-guided decoding ![Two typical strategies of generation-time correction](image3).

Among these, **post-hoc correction** appears to have a significant number of representative papers, with various methods listed such as Self-Refine, Reflexion, and others that utilize different feedback sources and refinement strategies. ![Post-hoc correction methods use diverse feedback sources and refinement strategies](image1).

Post-hoc correction is the most representative strategy with a variety of feedback sources and refinement strategies.

The multitask model differs from the single-task model because it uses a shared encoder but separate attentions and decoders [2]. Figure 1 in the paper illustrates different model architectures; specifically, Figure 1a shows the single-task model, and Figure 1b depicts the multitask model.  ![Figure 1 illustrates different model architectures.](image4)

The standard encoder-decoder multitask model jointly models two output sequences using a shared encoder but separate attentions and decoders [2].  In contrast, the single-task model has one attention module and decoder after the encoder. The multitask model's architecture allows it to handle two tasks simultaneously, leveraging shared information at the encoder level while maintaining task-specific attention and decoding processes. The single-task model, on the other hand, is designed for a singular task [2]. The multitask model uses separate attention modules for each task, while the single-task model has only one.

The RAR pipeline leverages a multimodal retriever to augment MLLMs for enhanced visual recognition [9]. The key components include a multimodal retriever, an index system, and the MLLMs themselves [1, 2].

The multimodal retriever encodes and stores embeddings, optimizing retrieval speed through index construction techniques, which addresses the challenge of managing large volumes of image/text embeddings [8]. ![The multimodal retriever stores multimodal embeddings and focuses on retrieval speed through index construction techniques.](image3)

To enhance retrieval speed, an index system using the HNSW algorithm reduces dimensionality, which transforms vectors into a reduced space [7].

The MLLMs rank the retrieved category labels alongside the image embedding, combining internal knowledge with retrieved information for a contextually aware classification prediction [4]. The prompt merges the input image with retrieved category information, guiding MLLMs to rank candidate object categories based on similarity [5]. ![This is an example of the ranking prompt used in the RAR pipeline, including the input image, retrieved images with their categories, and how the system sorts these categories to make a final prediction.](image4)

The RAR pipeline uses a multimodal retriever and ranking with MLLMs to improve perception tasks [10].

The authors break down the multi-step reasoning process of causal inference into key preparation and formal solution steps [1]. The preparation steps include identifying the causal graph structure, determining the causal query type, formulating the query symbolically precisely, and extracting relevant data from the prompt [1]. ![The preparation phase involves extracting the causal graph, query type, formalizing the query, and gathering relevant data.](image5)

The authors divided causal inference into six key steps.

In weighted decoding, the weight influences the specificity and relatedness of the response [1, 2, 5]. At extreme weights, the model may generate nonsensical outputs or only produce rare or common tokens [1, 2].

For example, in the provided scenario:

*   **Wt -5.0**: The response is "Oh...", indicating a very generic and unrelated response.
*   **Wt 0.0**: The response is "That sounds like a lot of fun!", which is the baseline response.
*   **Wt 3.0**: The response extends the baseline by asking a question "That sounds like a lot of fun. How long have you been studying?".
*   **Wt 7.0**: The response becomes more specific but less coherent: "I majored in practising my spiritual full time philosophy test".
*   **Wt 10.0**: The response turns into gibberish: "Oh wow! Merna jean isa paino yi hao hui bu acara sya gila [...]" [5].

![The table shows how different weights affect the generated response quality and content.](image5)

Weighted decoding can control the semantic relatedness of the response, but extreme weights can lead to nonsensical output [2]. Weighted decoding influences the generated response, where higher weights can increase specificity but may sacrifice coherence [8, 9].

SenseBERT provides a supersense abstraction for the word "bass" in the sentence "Dan cooked a bass on the grill" [1].  SenseBERT abstracts the role of "bass" as food in the given sentence.
`Dan cooked a bass on the grill` is interpreted by SenseBERT as `[Person] [created] [food] on the [artifact]` ![SenseBERT predicts supersenses for words in sentences.](image1)
SenseBERT uses supersenses from WordNet as labels for sense prediction, and for words with multiple supersenses like ‘bass’ (noun.food, noun.animal, noun.artifact, noun.person), the model predicts any of these senses [2]. The model assigns semantically meaningful categories to the masked position, demonstrating its ability to predict a distribution over supersenses [3].  SenseBERT abstracts "bass" as "food" in the context of the given sentence.

Retrieval augmentation significantly enhances performance across various entity types and reduces hallucination, especially for torso-to-tail entities [5, 9]. Table 6 shows the impact of retrieval augmentation on accuracy and hallucination rates across Head, Torso, and Tail categories. ![Retrieval augmentation enhances accuracy and reduces hallucination rates across Head, Torso, and Tail categories.](image4)

For Head entities, accuracy improves from 24.4% without RA to 27.1% with RA, while hallucination decreases from 75.6% to 72.9%. For Torso entities, accuracy increases from 19.1% to 22.7%, and hallucination drops from 80.9% to 77.3%. The most significant improvement is seen in Tail entities, where accuracy surges from 6.8% to 12.6%, and hallucination is reduced from 93.2% to 87.4% [5]. This highlights that retrieval augmentation is particularly effective in addressing the challenge of hallucinations in long-tailed entities [5].

Retrieval Augmentation (RA) improves accuracy and reduces hallucination rates, with the most significant gains observed in Tail entities, followed by Torso and Head entities.

The 'Post-hoc Correction with External Feedback' strategy enhances output refinement by incorporating diverse natural language feedback and external knowledge sources [1, 5].  This approach uses a critic model and a refinement model after the initial output generation, allowing for detailed feedback and corrections [1].

The post-hoc correction with external feedback strategy involves using a language model to generate outputs, which are then evaluated by a critic model, and external models/tools such as knowledge bases, trained models, and search engines can enhance the critic model's evaluation and feedback, which is used to refine the outputs.

This strategy is illustrated in Figure 4(b), where a language model generates outputs, a critic model provides feedback based on external models and tools, and a refine model uses that feedback to improve the outputs. ![Post-hoc correction with external feedback uses a critic model and a refine model to improve outputs based on feedback from external models and tools.](image1)

Specifically, models like RARR, REFEED, and LLM-Augmenter prompt LLMs to question their outputs and then use an external retriever to search for relevant evidence to refine the outputs [6]. FACTOOL extends this by applying external knowledge to various tasks such as code generation and mathematical reasoning [6]. Therefore, Post-hoc Correction with External Feedback enables more informed and accurate refinements by leveraging external resources.

Tree Traversal and Collapsed Tree are two distinct strategies for querying within a tree-based structure [2]. The tree traversal method navigates the tree layer-by-layer, pruning and selecting the most relevant nodes at each level [2].  By contrast, the collapsed tree method assesses nodes across all layers simultaneously to identify the most relevant ones [2].

![Collapsed Tree Retrieval flattens the tree into a single layer for comparison, while Tree Traversal Retrieval traverses the tree layer-by-layer.](image2)

The collapsed tree approach searches for relevant information by considering all nodes in the tree simultaneously, flattening the multi-layered tree into a single layer for comparison [3].  The tree traversal method selects the top-k most relevant root nodes based on their cosine similarity to the query embedding and repeats the selection process until reaching the leaf nodes, concatenating text from all selected nodes [7]. By adjusting the depth and the number of nodes selected at each layer, tree traversal offers control over the specificity and breadth of information retrieved [9]. The collapsed tree approach consistently performs better because it searches through all the nodes simultaneously and retrieves information at the correct level of granularity for a given question [1].

![Collapsed tree retrieval performs better because it retrieves information at the correct level of granularity for a given question.](image5)

Tree Traversal navigates the tree layer by layer, while Collapsed Tree considers all nodes simultaneously to retrieve information.

The purpose of the combination layers in Figure 2 is to pool the output of the two towers, as stated in the text [4]. In practice, the masking is completely disabled in the combination layer so that it operates over all forward and backward states [4]. Figure 2, as referenced in the text, illustrates the fine-tuning approach using the pre-trained two-tower model for specific downstream tasks [5].
![Figure 2 illustrates the fine-tuning approach for specific downstream tasks.](image1)
The text also notes that disabling masking below the combination layer does not perform well [4]. Disabling masking at the combination layer allows access to the full context, including the token itself, which is beneficial for tasks that label each token, like NER [8]. Therefore, the purpose of the combination layers is to integrate information from both forward and backward states, with disabled masking to provide full contextual access.
![The combination layer fuses forward and backward context for token embeddings.](image2)
The combination layers serve to integrate information from both forward and backward states, facilitating contextual understanding for downstream tasks.

The most common error type in GPT-4V is perceptual errors [2]. These errors account for the largest portion of inaccuracies in the model [2]. Perceptual errors can further be divided into basic perceptual errors and domain-specific perceptual errors [2]. Basic perceptual errors involve failures in elementary visual interpretation [2]. Domain-specific perceptual errors often stem from a lack of specialized knowledge [5]. An example includes misidentifying the bone indicated by the arrow as the short pastern bone when it is actually the long pastern bone [3].
![The distribution of errors shows that perceptual errors are the most common at 35%.](image5)
Perceptual errors constitute the largest category of errors in GPT-4V's analysis, accounting for 35% of the errors [2].

The DETR model uses object queries as a key component in its decoder to produce final predictions. The overall DETR architecture contains a CNN backbone, an encoder-decoder transformer, and a feed forward network [2]. The transformer decoder transforms a set of    $N$ embeddings, which must be different to produce different results because the decoder is permutation-invariant [5]. These embeddings are learned positional encodings referred to as object queries, which are added to each attention layer [5]. The architecture of DETR is surprisingly simple, and it predicts all objects at once and is trained end-to-end [1].

The object queries are transformed into an output embedding by the decoder, and they are then independently decoded into box coordinates and class labels by a feed forward network, resulting in    $N$ final predictions [5]. ![The object detection process using DETR, involving CNN, transformer encoder-decoder, and bipartite matching loss.](image2)

The DETR model utilizes learned positional encodings known as object queries, which are essential for producing distinct object predictions through the transformer decoder and feed forward network [5].

QAC HECK system achieves a macro-F1 score of 55.67, 54.67, and 52.35 on HOVER two-hop, three- hop, and four-hop claims, respectively [9]. ![QACheck and other models performance on HOVER and FEVEROUS datasets.](image3)

ProgramFC performance in HOVER two-hop, three-hop, and four hop is 54.27, 54.18 and 52.88, respectively [6]. To determine the performance gap between ProgramFC and QAC Heck, we will calculate the average performance gap across the two-hop, three-hop, and four-hop claims.

For two-hop claims, the difference is 55.67 - 54.27 = 1.4.
For three-hop claims, the difference is 54.67 - 54.18 = 0.49.
For four-hop claims, the difference is 52.35 - 52.88 = -0.53.

Now, we calculate the average of these differences: (1.4 + 0.49 + (-0.53)) / 3 = 0.45333.

The average performance gap between ProgramFC and QAC Heck is approximately 0.45.

The Sythus pipeline involves a series of automated steps to generate instruction-response pairs, leveraging system messages, visual annotations, and in-context examples to guide language models like ChatGPT [2, 6].

First, the pipeline starts with system messages and visual annotations, providing the tone, style, and essential image information such as bounding boxes and image descriptions necessary for generating instruction-response pairs ![The first step of Sythus involves providing system messages and visual annotations to ChatGPT.](image1). Next, the process generates instruction-response pairs [6]. The pipeline incorporates a filtering mechanism to ensure the quality of the generated pairs [6]. Finally, the instruction-response pairs are translated into multiple languages, including Chinese, Japanese, Spanish, German, French, Korean, and Arabic [6].

The Sythus pipeline generates high-quality instruction-response pairs by incorporating system messages, visual annotations, filtering, and multi-language support.

The introduction of repetition control reduces question-asking [3]. When repetition control is introduced, question-asking is reduced; the $z=10$ setting, which should produce $100\%$ questions, now only produces $79.67\%$ questions [3].

Conditional training (CT) is effective to control question-asking, but when repetition control is introduced, question-asking is reduced, especially in settings meant to produce $100\%$ questions [3]. This is because the 'extrep bigram' feature discourages bigrams that have appeared in previous utterances, preventing the model from producing common question-asking bigrams [3]. To address this, a setting $z = 10 (boost)$ was introduced to allow necessary question-asking bigrams, yielding a $99.54\%$ question-asking rate [3].

![The graph shows how question-asking rate changes with repetition control.](image4)

The presence of repetition control reduces the frequency of question-asking in generated text.

The two methods to combine the long-term and short-term user representations for unified user representation are introduced in [2]. The first method, LSTUR-ini, uses the long-term user representation to initialize the hidden state of the GRU network in the short-term user representation model [4]. The second method, LSTUR-con, concatenates the long-term user representation with the short-term user representation as the final user representation [4].

Here are the illustrations of the two methods.
![LSTUR-ini uses long-term user representation to initialize the hidden state of the GRU network, while LSTUR-con concatenates long-term and short-term user representations.](image3)

In LSTUR-ini, the long-term user representation initializes the GRU network's hidden state in the short-term user representation model, while LSTUR-con concatenates both long-term and short-term user representations to form the final user representation.

The Iterative, Recursive, and Adaptive retrieval processes differ in how they refine searches and manage information within a Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) system.

Recursive retrieval refines search queries iteratively based on results from previous searches, enhancing search depth and relevance [1]. The recursive process uses a structured index to process and retrieve data in a hierarchical manner [5]. The process involves iterative refinement of search queries, adapting to user needs for specialized information, and continuous learning from user requirements [1].
![Recursive retrieval breaks down complex problems step by step.](image5)

Adaptive retrieval refines the RAG framework by enabling LLMs to determine the optimal moments and content for retrieval, enhancing the efficiency and relevance of sourced information [2]. Flexible orchestration in Modular RAG Flow allows for the evaluation of retrieval necessity based on different scenarios [3]. In contrast, iterative retrieval provides more context information, as seen in image5.

In summary, recursive retrieval iteratively refines searches, adaptive retrieval allows dynamic determination of retrieval timing and content, and iterative retrieval provides more context information.

Adversarial training can significantly enhance the performance of models, especially when the evaluation data consists of adversarial examples. When single-paragraph BERT is trained using standard distractors and then tested on adversarial distractors, the F1 accuracy drops from 67.08 to 46.84 [4].
![The table shows the impact of adversarial training on model performance based on the evaluation data.](image4)
However, when the model is retrained on distractors from the new distribution, its original accuracy can be somewhat recovered [2]. Specifically, when the model is retrained on the adversarially selected distractors, the accuracy increases to 60.10 F1 on the adversarial distractors [4]. This is further highlighted when filtering by entity type, where the original model's accuracy degrades significantly (drops to 40.73 F1), but the model trained on the adversarially selected distractors can recover most of its original accuracy (increases to 58.42 F1) [5]. Therefore, adversarial training improves model performance on adversarial evaluation data.

The inclusion of gold paragraphs and distractors significantly affects the F1 scores in multi-hop question answering models, and this has implications for model performance.

In the distractor setting, the single-paragraph BERT model achieves 67.08 F1, indicating that many HOTPOT QA questions are answerable with a single-hop model [1]. ![Single-paragraph BERT achieves 67.08 F1 in the distractor setting.](image3)

However, when adversarial distractors are introduced, the accuracy of the single-paragraph BERT model declines from 67.08 F1 to 46.84 F1 [4]. This suggests that the model's performance is sensitive to the distribution of distractors. But when the model is re-trained on the adversarial distractors, the accuracy increases to 60.10 F1 [4].

The open-domain setting is challenging for single-hop models, with single-paragraph BERT achieving only 38.06 F1 [3]. ![The table presents the F1 scores for different settings, including the distractor setting and open-domain settings.](image5) When additional gold paragraphs are given, the model achieves 53.12 F1 [10]. This demonstrates the significant effect of retrieving gold paragraphs [10].

Carefully chosen distractor paragraphs can induce questions that require multi-hop reasoning [7]. ![This image shows examples of different types of questions, including multi-hop questions.](image1) Stronger distractors may transform single-hop questions into multi-hop questions [5].

The inclusion of gold paragraphs improves F1 scores, while the nature and distribution of distractors can either hinder or enhance model performance, highlighting the importance of distractor selection and model training in multi-hop question answering.

The function of Word LSTM-B and Word LSTM-F are to process the sequence in both forward and backward directions to capture the context from both sides [9].

In one type of model, words are represented as a combination of a word embedding and a convolution over the characters of the word, followed by a Bi-LSTM layer to generate labels [9]. The character labels transformed into word labels via post processing [1].
![The LSTM processes the sequence bidirectionally to capture context.](image1)
The bi-directional LSTM enables the model to capture dependencies from both past and future contexts, enhancing its ability to accurately label each character.
In summary, Word LSTM-B and Word LSTM-F process the input sequence in both directions to understand the context around each element, which helps in more accurate predictions.

The relevance of word order in sentiment analysis tasks can be observed when LSTM models are trained on shuffled training sets [3]. LSTM's performance on the Yelp dataset with a shuffled training set closely mirrors SWEM results, suggesting that the main advantage of LSTM over SWEM is capturing word-order features [1]. This is further supported by the drop in results on the Yelp polarity dataset, indicating word order's importance for sentiment analysis, as depicted in ![LSTM model trained on shuffled training data showing comparable accuracies to the original dataset, particularly on Yahoo and SNLI datasets.](image1).

For sentiment analysis tasks, CNN and LSTM perform better than SWEM, implying that word-order information is beneficial for analyzing sentiment orientations [2]. The phrase "not really good" versus "really not good" illustrates how word order impacts sentiment differently, which CNN and LSTM can capture [2]. ![Examples of positive and negative reviews from Yelp, highlighting sentiment orientations.](image2)

Word-order information matters for sentiment analysis, where models like LSTM and CNN, which can capture this information, generally outperform models like SWEM that ignore word order.

Based on the data, the subtask error consistently has the lowest percentage across all hop counts, with 2% in 2-hop, 5% in 3-hop, and 2% in 4-hop claims.  Therefore, the sub-task errors are the least frequent type of semantic error in the HOVER dataset.

The Translation Ranking model takes a tuple as input and encodes each segment independently using a pre-trained cross-lingual encoder [10]. The model architecture is shown in Figure 2. ![Translation Ranking model architecture, which encodes segments independently and optimizes the embedding space using triplet margin loss.](image5)
The architecture receives four segments: the source, the reference, a "better" hypothesis, and a "worse" one [6]. These segments are independently encoded using a pre-trained cross-lingual encoder and a pooling layer on top [6]. The triplet margin loss is then used to optimize the resulting embedding space to minimize the distance between the "better" hypothesis and the "anchors" (source and reference) [6]. The Translation Ranking model encodes inputs independently and optimizes the embedding space to minimize the distance between a better hypothesis and its source and reference.

When additional gold paragraphs are given, the model achieves 53.12 F1, demonstrating the significant effect of failure to retrieve gold paragraphs [3]. The model achieves 39.12 F1 given 500 retrieved paragraphs, but achieves 53.12 F1 when additional two gold paragraphs are given [3]. The inclusion of a gold paragraph improves the F1 score in open-domain settings.

The paper introduces the CL ADDER dataset to test formal causal reasoning in LLMs, where questions are grounded in symbolic questions with ground truth answers derived by a causal inference engine [6]. The dataset covers various causal queries across the three rungs of the Ladder of Causation and considers several causal graphs [6].

To generate all the causal graphs and Causal Graph Template Elements (CGTEs), the paper iterates through commonly used ones within four nodes in the CI books [8].  `Common causal graphs with treatment-effect (X-Y) pairs`(). The introduction of repetition control reduces question-asking, especially at the highest control level [4]. In the z=10 setting, the model is expected to produce 100% questions; however, repetition control reduces this rate to 79.67% [4]. This is caused by the weighted decoding feature extrep bigram discouraging bigrams common in questions [4]. To fix this, the feature extrep bigram is not used during beam search, but used to rerank candidates after beam search in the setting z=10 (boost) [4]. This adjustment yields a 99.54% question-asking rate [4].

Conditional training effectively controls question-asking, achieving a range of question-asking rates from 1.40% to 97.72% by varying $z$ from 0 to 10 [4]. However, when repetition control is introduced, the question-asking rate is reduced; specifically, the $z=10$ setting, which should produce 100% questions, only produces 79.67% questions [4].

The adversarial transformation significantly diminishes BERT's performance, reducing it to levels comparable to random chance, and its peak performance dropped to 53% [3, 5].

Initially, BERT's peak performance on the Argument Reasoning Comprehension Task (ARCT) was 77%, close to the average untrained human baseline [1]. However, this performance was attributed to BERT exploiting statistical cues in the dataset [10].  

The major problem can be eliminated in ARCT. Since $R\wedge A\to\lnot C$, we can add a copy of each data point with the claim negated and the label inverted [3]. The following image shows an example of the original and adversarial data samples.

![The adversarial dataset involves negating the claim and inverting the label to eliminate statistical cues.](image4)

After applying the adversarial transformation, all models, including BERT, performed randomly [3]. The results for BERT Large on the adversarial test set with adversarial training and validation sets are shown below.

![BERT's performance on the adversarial test set reveals random accuracy.](image5)

With adversarial training, BERT's peak performance was reduced to 53%, with the mean and median around 50% [5]. This indicates the adversarial dataset successfully eliminated the statistical cues [5].  BERT has learned nothing about argument comprehension [9].

The example annotation in Table 1 provides information on the generative process of the Knowledge Graph Language Model (KGLM) [2].  The entities for most tokens are human-provided links, except for "1989", which is linked to "04-21-1989" by string matching [2]. The annotations denote which entities are new and related based on whether they are reachable by previously linked entities, though it makes mistakes due to missing links in Wikidata [2].

For example, the annotation in Table 1, as well as the variables of the KGLM’s generative process are both displayed in ![Table 1 displays an example annotation with variables in the KGLM generative process.](image2).

The KGLM model picks  Super Mario Land  as the parent entity, and then follows the  Publisher  relation to select  Nintendo  as the entity to render [4]. ![The image shows how Super Mario Land is related to other entities, such as Nintendo and Game Boy, through different relationships like Publisher and Platform.](image1). Multiple plausible reasons for  Game Boy  are included, such as it being the platform for  Super Mario Land  and manufactured by  Nintendo [2].  Each time an entity is encountered, all of the related entities in Wikidata are added as candidate dates for matching, and if one of these related entities is seen later in the document, the entity is identified as a parent for the later entity [6, 9].

Entities in the example annotation are represented with human-provided links, and their relationships are determined by reachability through previously linked entities and relations in Wikidata.

The 'Hard-to-contrast' strategy consistently outperforms other strategies on various datasets, as demonstrated in several figures. Figure 5 illustrates this on the OrganAM NIST dataset, where the hard-to-contrast strategy (red lines) performs better than other initial query strategies across all active learning cycles [1, 10].  Hard-to-contrast data consistently outperforms the others on Organ AM NIST, BloodMNIST , and PathMNIST , and steadily improves the model performances within the next active learning cycles [1].

The performance correlation between initial and later cycles is strong, with Pearson correlation coefficients showing statistical significance [1, 3, 4].  With each active learning querying strategy, the performance of the initial cycle (20 labeled images) and the last cycle (50 labeled images) are strongly correlated [3]. ![Hard-to-contrast queries lead to a greater spread within each cluster compared to easy-to-contrast ones.](image2)

Figure 1 illustrates the AUC scores achieved by models trained with different numbers of labeled images using various strategies, with 'Hard-to-contrast' generally maintaining a higher AUC [1]. ![Hard-to-Contrast strategy generally has a higher AUC than the other strategies in a](image1)

This outperformance by 'hard-to-contrast' has significant implications for initial query selection, as the initial query is consequential regardless of model initialization [4]. The Hard-to-contrast initial query strategy (red lines) outperforms other initial query strategies in every cycle of active learning [3, 7]. This is because selecting hard-to-contrast data contributes to optimal models and significantly outperforms random selection [8].  Results suggest that selecting easy-to-learn or hard-to-contrast data contribute to the optimal models [8].

In summary, the 'Hard-to-Contrast' querying strategy consistently outperforms other strategies in terms of AUC across different numbers of labeled images, making it a practical and effective solution for the cold start problem in active learning, improving model performance from the initial query onward.

Overall, the level of annotator agreement varies across different model comparisons involving Chameleon, ranging from unanimous agreement to disagreement, highlighting the challenges in relative evaluation [5, 6].

The MMMU benchmark distinguishes itself from existing benchmarks by its breadth and depth, offering unique challenges for evaluating large multimodal models [4, 5].

MMMU aims to cover college-level knowledge, including 30 image formats such as diagrams, tables, charts, and medical images, differing from prior benchmarks focused on daily knowledge and common sense. ![MMMU covers 30 image formats including diagrams, tables, charts, chemical structures, photos, paintings, geometric shapes, music sheets, medical images, etc.](image1)

Unlike previous benchmarks that typically require commonsense knowledge or simple reasoning, MMMU requires deliberate reasoning with college-level subject knowledge [5].  MMMU covers diverse image formats, from visual scenes to diagrams and tables, and features interleaved text-image inputs, requiring models to jointly understand the images and text, recall subject knowledge, and conduct complex reasoning [10].

![MMMU benchmark emphasizes breadth and depth in knowledge and reasoning compared to other benchmarks.](image3)

These characteristics mean that MMMU is designed to measure perception, knowledge, and reasoning skills in LMMs and evaluate how well models can perceive and understand information across different modalities [1]. It's designed to evaluate how well these models can not only perceive and understand information across different modalities but also apply reasoning with subject-specific knowledge to derive the solution [1]. MMMU introduces key challenges, including the need for expert-level visual perceptual abilities and deliberate reasoning with subject-specific knowledge, necessitating an advanced approach that integrates multimodal analysis with domain-specific knowledge [6].

The MMMU benchmark offers a more challenging and comprehensive evaluation of large multimodal models by emphasizing expert-level knowledge and reasoning across diverse subjects and image formats.

SenseBERT demonstrates improvements when using a 60K-token vocabulary compared to a 30K-token vocabulary with no Out-Of-Vocabulary (OOV) handling. As shown in table 1, both the $60K$ vocabulary method and the $average embedding$ method perform comparably on the SemEval supersense disambiguation task [5]. Furthermore,  both methods improve over the baseline of learning supersense information only for whole words in BERT’s original 30K-token vocabulary [5].

The  $60K$ vocabulary method enriches the vocabulary and the $average embedding$ method predicts a supersense from the average embeddings of the sub-word tokens comprising an OOV word [6]. During fine-tuning, when encountering an OOV word the model predicts the supersenses from the rightmost sub-word token in the 60 K vocabulary method and from the average of the sub-word tokens in the average embedding method [6].
![SemEval-SS Fine-tuned results for different vocabulary sizes and OOV handling methods](image3)
The SemEval-SS Fine-tuned score is 81.9 for the 30K no OOV, and 83 for the 60K no OOV [4].

Using a 60K-token vocabulary results in a performance improvement of 1.1 on the SemEval-SS Fine-tuned task compared to using a 30K-token vocabulary with no OOV handling.

The Bi-LSTM Utterance Encoder plays a crucial role in converting natural language input into a continuous vector representation within the system architecture [8].

Here's a breakdown of its function based on the provided quotes:

1.  **Encoding User Utterance**: The Bi-LSTM Utterance Encoder processes the user's input, which is in natural language format. It encodes this input into a continuous vector [8].

2.  **Hierarchical LSTM Network**: The system employs a hierarchical LSTM neural network to encode a dialogue with a sequence of turns [8].

3.  **Continuous Vector Representation**: User input in natural language is converted into a continuous vector using a bidirectional LSTM utterance encoder [8].

4.  **Input to Dialogue-Level LSTM**: The encoded user utterance, along with the encoding of the previous system action, serves as input to a dialogue-level LSTM [8].

5.  **Encoding Details**: The user utterance is encoded using a bidirectional LSTM, referred to as the utterance-level LSTM [6]. The user utterance vector is created by combining the last forward and backward LSTM states [6].

6. **Dialogue State Tracking**: Dialogue state tracking, or belief tracking, maintains the state of a conversation by accumulating evidence along the sequence of dialogue turns [7]. The dialogue state is maintained in a continuous form in the dialogue-level LSTM state [7].

7. **Bi-LSTM Utterance Encoder Overview**:
![Bi-LSTM Utterance Encoder encodes the natural language into vectors](image1)

In summary, the Bi-LSTM Utterance Encoder transforms the user's natural language input into a continuous vector representation that can be processed by subsequent components of the dialogue system.

The QAC HECK system manages the reasoning process by guiding the model to self-generate a series of questions vital for claim verification [6]. Figure 2 illustrates the general architecture of the system, which includes five principal modules [1].

The system utilizes a claim verifier, a question generator, a question-answering model, a validator, and a reasoner [1]. The claim verifier assesses whether sufficient information has been gathered to verify the claim. The question generator generates the next relevant question. The question-answering module answers the raised question, and the QA validator evaluates the usefulness of the generated question-answer pair [6].

The final step in the process is the reasoner, which outputs the final veracity label based on all collected contexts [6]. `![The diagram outlines the steps of claim verification using question-guided reasoning, starting with a claim and ending with a veracity label.](image3)`

The final step in the QAC HECK system, as depicted in Figure 2, is the reasoner module that outputs the final veracity label based on all collected contexts.

The DS-DST model uses BERT to encode dialog context and domain-slot pairs, then utilizes a slot gate to handle values, where cosine similarity is used to calculate the relevance score between the aggregated representation and a reference candidate [3, 1]. The architecture of the DS-DST model involves direct interactions between the dialog context and domain-slot pairs for DST, as shown in ![The DS-DST model architecture employs BERT to encode the dialog context and domain-slot pairs.](image3). For categorical slots, the model selects values from picklists based on contextual representation, while non-categorical slots use a two-way linear mapping to find text spans [3].

The model calculates the relevance score between the aggregated representation and a reference candidate using cosine similarity [1].
![The table presents joint accuracy results on MultiWOZ 2.1 test sets, comparing BERT-DST, DS-DST, ToD-BERT, and their variants.](image1)

The DS-DST model determines the matching between candidate values and the dialogue context by encoding the information using BERT and calculating cosine similarity scores.

The LOGIC-LM model solves a problem by translating it into a symbolic formulation using an LLM, performing inference with a deterministic solver, and then interpreting the result back into natural language [6, 2]. LOGIC-LM decomposes a logical reasoning problem into three stages: Problem Formulation, Symbolic Reasoning, and Result Interpretation [2].

First, the LLM converts the natural language problem into a symbolic formulation, identifying key elements [2]. As shown in the diagram, different problem types (deductive reasoning, first-order logic, constraint satisfaction, and analytical reasoning) are converted into symbolic formulations using a problem formulator. ![Different problem types are converted into symbolic formulations using a problem formulator.](image5)

Second, a deterministic symbolic solver performs inference on this formulation [2]. The symbolic reasoner, logic programming, first-order logic prover, and constraint optimization are used to perform inference based on the problem type. ![Symbolic reasoners, logic programming, first-order logic provers, and constraint optimization are used to perform inference based on the problem type.](image5)

Finally, a result interpreter explains the output and maps it to the correct answer [2].

Therefore, LOGIC-LM solves problems by converting them into symbolic language, reasoning using symbolic solvers, and interpreting the results back into natural language.

The automated pipeline "Sythus" is used for generating high-quality instruction-response pairs [5]. It builds upon the LLaVA framework and leverages ChatGPT for instruction-response pair generation [5]. System messages, visual annotations, and in-context examples serve as prompts for ChatGPT to maintain the quality of the generated pairs [5]. ![Sythus is an automated pipeline that leverages ChatGPT to generate high-quality instruction-response pairs.](image5)
The first step involves using a system message combined with a visual annotation [5]. The system message defines the tone and style, while the visual annotation provides image information such as bounding boxes and image descriptions [5]. Cold-start employs system messages and visual annotations to prompt ChatGPT [5].

The first step of cold start involves system messages combined with visual annotations as prompts for ChatGPT.

SenseBERT achieves state-of-the-art performance on the Word in Context (WiC) task, demonstrating a high level of lexical semantic awareness [3, 4]. A single SenseBERT LARGE model achieves a score of 72.14, improving BERT LARGE's score by 2.5 points [1].

SenseBERT outperforms vanilla BERT models on the WiC task [3]. SenseBERT BASE surpasses the performance of the larger BERT LARGE model [3].  ![SenseBERT's score on the WiC task is higher than other models.](image2)

The BiDAF model generally outperforms the FastQA model across both the WIKIHOP and MEDHOP datasets [3]. The iterative latent interactions in the BiDAF architecture potentially make it better suited to integrate information across documents, which is important for these tasks [3, 9]. However, both models improve significantly when given only relevant documents, indicating their ability to identify answers when plausible false candidates are limited [7].

For WIKIHOP, BiDAF achieves higher accuracy compared to FastQA, as demonstrated in the table ![BiDAF and FastQA performance on WIKIHOP and MEDHOP](image1).

In a gold chain setup with masked answers, BiDAF achieves up to 81.2%/85.7% on WIKIHOP, while FastQA shows a smaller increase [7]. ![BiDAF and FastQA performance on WIKIHOP and MEDHOP with gold chain setup](image2).

On MEDHOP, a similar trend is observed, where BiDAF generally outperforms FastQA, and masking drug mentions leads to performance drops [4]. This suggests that BiDAF is more effective at leveraging cross-document information compared to FastQA, especially in complex, multi-hop reasoning scenarios [10]. Overall, while both BiDAF and FastQA can integrate information across documents, BiDAF's architecture allows it to perform more effectively on WIKIHOP and MEDHOP datasets.

Based on the architecture of Chameleon, the green squares in the figure refer to the token embeddings. Chameleon utilizes a token-based approach for processing both text and images, which allows for a unified representation and reasoning across modalities [1, 5, 7].

Here's how the token-based approach works, according to the provided information:

1.  **Mixed-Modal Pre-Training:** The model takes both text and image prompts as input. For example, a text prompt like "What can I bake with this?" is paired with an image prompt ![The image prompt shows a banana and slices of bananas in a bowl.](image1). Both of these are tokenized and fed into the Mixed-Modal Auto-Regressive LM.
2.  **Mixed-Modal Generation:** After pre-training, the model can generate both text and images. In the example, the model outputs the text "Here is a recipe for banana bread" and an image of banana bread.

The green squares in the figure denote the token embeddings that are processed by the Mixed-Modal Auto-Regressive LM, supporting the generation of relevant outputs based on the input prompts.

In Fig 1, the green squares represent token embeddings.

The hierarchical CRF model leverages both character-level and word-level neural networks to capture different types of information [1]. The character-level network, which can be an RNN or CNN, is designed to capture subword information, including morphological variations and capitalization patterns [1]. The use of self-attention aims to improve robustness to word order differences [4].

The architecture of the model involves producing a representation for each word by concatenating its character representation with its word embedding [5]. A bi-directional LSTM is used for both character and word-level networks [5]. The word-level Bi-LSTM then models contextual dependency within each sentence [5]. The use of character-level information allows the model to perform well, especially in cross-lingual settings, as it gives access to character-level information [8].

![The model uses both word and character embeddings as input to the model to perform Named Entity Recognition.](image5)

The model might use both word-level and character-level embeddings as inputs to capture both word-specific semantics and subword-level features like morphology and capitalization.

The pre-processing step in object detection datasets, involving cropping and blurring, helps MLLMs focus on the relevant objects for identification [4]. Cropping focuses on image regions based on proposal bounding box coordinates and resizing the cropped region to a fixed proportion [4]. The pre-processing step contributes to the zero-shot recognition system by improving the model's ability to focus on and identify the relevant objects within an image [4].

To determine the angle in the right triangle, we can use the tangent function [2]. The tangent function relates the angle to the opposite and adjacent sides [2]. In the given right triangle, the opposite side is 4 and the adjacent side is 8.  ![The image depicts a right triangle with sides labeled 4 and 8, and the hypotenuse and one angle are marked with questions.](image4)
The tangent of the angle is calculated as tan(θ) = opposite/adjacent = 4/8 = 1/2 [2]. To find the angle θ, we take the inverse tangent (arctan) of 1/2 [2]. Thus, θ ≈ 26.57° [2].

The angle at the green arrow in the right triangle is approximately 26.57 degrees.

The most common functions used in data analysis, according to the analyzed data, are simple lookup and comparison, with simple lookup being slightly more prevalent.  This information is derived from a study of reasoning types involved in fact-checking claims [4]. The distribution of these functions is shown in the table. Simple lookup is used to retrieve the value for a specific cell, and comparison involves comparing two numbers. The study identifies 14 atomic reasoning types and analyzes their proportions in verifying claims [4]. These reasoning steps are essential for verifying whether a claim is supported, refuted, or cannot be verified based on the table data [2].

Here’s a breakdown of the most common functions and their distribution:

*   **Simple lookup**: This function retrieves the value for a specific cell and is the most common, accounting for 20.6% of reasoning steps.
*   **Comparison**: This involves comparing two numbers and accounts for 19.5% of reasoning steps.
*   **Closed-domain knowledge**: Extracting information from context sentences in the table caption or article accounts for 12.1% of reasoning steps.

![Simple lookup, comparison, and closed-domain knowledge are the most used functions in data analysis, as shown in the table.](image3)

The most common functions used in data analysis tasks are simple lookup and comparison.

Removing the abstract from the textual input to SPECTER and relying only on the title results in a substantial decrease in performance, while surprisingly, adding authors as an input hurts performance [10]. `![Removing the abstract significantly decreases performance, while adding authors hurts performance.](image4)` One possible explanation is that author names are sparse in the corpus, making it difficult for the model to infer document-level relatedness from them [10]. However, adding venues slightly decreases performance, except on document classification, where venues correlate highly [10]. Also, citation-based pretraining objective is critical for the performance of SPECTER, and removing this and using a vanilla SciBERT results in decreased performance on all tasks [8]. `![SPECTER outperforms SciBERT across all tasks.](image3)` Finally, using only easy negatives reduces performance on all tasks [2].

Inclusion or exclusion of specific features impacts the performance of the SPECTER model, where removing abstracts or adding author names negatively affects performance, while citation-based pretraining is critical.

The BERT model's performance varies depending on the data it is trained on and which components are considered [6]. On the original dataset, BERT achieves a peak test set accuracy of $77\%$ [5].

The analysis found that the $77\%$ test set accuracy of BERT can be attributed to the exploitation of spurious statistical cues [1]. By considering warrants (W) alone, BERT can achieve $71\%$ accuracy, and adding cues over reasons (R, W) and claims (C, W) accounts for the remaining six percentage points [2].

However, when evaluated on an adversarial dataset designed to eliminate these cues, BERT's peak performance drops significantly. ![BERT’s peak performance on the adversarial set reduced to 53%.](image4) Specifically, BERT's peak performance reduces to $53\%$, with the mean and median around $50\%$ [7]. This indicates that the adversarial dataset successfully eliminates the spurious cues, providing a more robust evaluation of machine argument comprehension [7].  On this adversarial dataset all models perform randomly, with BERT achieving a maximum test set accuracy of $53\%$ [3].

The BERT model's test performance is highly susceptible to spurious statistical cues in the dataset, with performance dropping to near-random levels on adversarial datasets designed to eliminate these cues.

According to the table, Recruiter A sent 375 InMails, with 8 accepted and 37 declined; Recruiter B sent 75 InMails, with 14 accepted and 11 declined ![The table shows Recruiter A and B profiles with number of profiles viewed, saved and InMails with Accepted, Declined, and response rate.](image4). To determine the total number of non-response InMails, we need to subtract the number of accepted and declined InMails from the total InMails sent by each recruiter.

For Recruiter A, non-response InMails = Total Sent - Accepted - Declined = 375 - 8 - 37 = 330
For Recruiter B, non-response InMails = Total Sent - Accepted - Declined = 75 - 14 - 11 = 50

Therefore, the total number of non-response InMails for Recruiter A is 330, and for Recruiter B is 50.
The total number of non-response InMails for Recruiter A and B from the given table is 380.

Bergen offers several museums that delve into its rich historical and cultural heritage. Old Bergen Museum is a living museum showcasing Bergen's history in the 19th and 20th centuries, featuring a collection of around 50 original wooden buildings [1]. The museum offers a nostalgic experience by showing how people dressed and lived at that time ![{People in period clothing at the Old Bergen Museum}](image1).

Bryggens Museum allows you to experience Bergen’s history at the UNESCO World Heritage site Bryggen [3]. This area consists of wooden buildings that are part of the city’s oldest section ![{A UNESCO logo, suggesting World Heritage Site}](image6).

Osterøy Museum, set in a beautiful cultural landscape, displays how people lived in the countryside outside Bergen [4]. The museum connects objects with the living cultural heritage through storytelling, textiles, costumes, weaving, and local building customs [4]. This is exemplified by the traditional architecture of the buildings at the museum ![{Traditional buildings in the cultural landscape of Osterøy Museum}](image2).

Haakon’s Hall, dating back to the 13th century, was the largest and most imposing building of the royal residency in Bergen [6]. It now serves as a living national cultural heritage site where visitors can imagine what being a king was like in the Middle Ages [6]. It represents a significant part of Bergen's royal history ![{Haakon's Hall, a royal banqueting hall from the 13th century}](image5).

These museums each offer unique insights into Bergen's historical and cultural heritage.

To achieve optimal washing quality, you need to carefully consider how you load the dishwasher. It is important to load the dishwasher correctly, as non-compliance can lead to poor washing quality ![Incorrect loading may reduce the washing quality](image3).

Start by loading the lower basket first, then the upper one [4]. The lower basket is ideal for large and difficult-to-clean items like pots, pans, lids, serving dishes, and bowls [6].  ![The lower basket is loaded with oven pot, small pot, soup plates and more](image1) Make sure that curved or recessed items are placed at an angle, so water can run off, and that all utensils are secure to prevent tipping [9].

The upper basket is designed for more delicate and lighter dishware like glasses and cups [9].  ![The upper basket is loaded with cups, saucers, glasses, mugs, glass bowl and dessert bowls](image4) Long and sharp cutlery should be positioned horizontally in the upper basket to avoid hazards [9].  Utensils should be stacked securely to prevent tipping [9].  Make sure that items do not lie inside one another or cover each other and glasses do not touch to avoid damage [9].

By loading the dishwasher with attention to these guidelines, you can ensure the spray arms rotate freely and that water reaches all surfaces, leading to better washing results [9].

To address a refrigerator and freezer that are both too warm, set the refrigerator control to 4 and the freezer control to B.

The input and output voltage specifications for the 8751H and related microcontrollers vary based on the pin and operating conditions.

For the 8751H, the input low voltage (VIL) has a maximum of 0.8V, while the input high voltage (VIH) has a minimum of 2.0V (except for XTAL2 and RST) ![The image shows the electrical characteristics including input and output voltages](image1). The minimum output high voltage (VOH) for Ports 1, 2, 3, ALE, and PSEN is 2.4V, while the maximum output low voltage (VOL) for Ports 1, 2, and 3 is 0.45V with IOL = 1.6mA.

The input high voltage to  $\overline{{\mathsf{E A}}}$ pin of 8751BH and 8752BH has a minimum of 4.5V and a maximum of 5.5V ![The image shows the input high voltage to  $\overline{{\mathsf{E A}}}$ pin of 8751BH and 8752BH](image1). The 8751H can tolerate  $-0.5\mathsf{v}$  to  $+\,\pmb{21.5V}$ on the  $\overline{{\mathsf{E A}}}/\mathsf{v}_{\mathsf{P\mathsf{P}}}$ Pin to  $\mathsf{v s s}$ [9].

The input and output voltage specifications vary based on the specific pin and model, so consulting the datasheet is crucial for design purposes.

NTU offers various avenues for students seeking medical assistance and support. Fullerton Healthcare Group operates the on-campus medical service, providing general outpatient medical and dental treatment, laboratory and x-ray investigations, and minor surgery [9]. Additionally, they offer immunization and travel medical advice [9]. For emotional and psychological support, students can access the Student Wellbeing Centre, which offers professional counseling with registered counselors experienced in a wide range of issues [5]. The center also conducts workshops and talks on topics like stress management and better learning strategies [6].

To further support students, the Student Wellbeing Centre runs the ‘Peer Helping Programme,’ where trained student volunteers offer friendship and support to peers facing emotional or psychological challenges [10]. To speak with a professional counselor, students can make an appointment online or call during office hours; consultations are free and confidential, and the center is located at the University Health Service [7].
![The Student Wellbeing Centre provides a comfortable and private space for counseling and support services.](image5)
NTU also provides insurance schemes like the Group Hospitalisation and Surgical Insurance and the Group Personal Accident Insurance to help eligible students with basic medical costs [2]. Moreover, there's the GPAI Scheme for undergraduates and full-time graduate students, offering basic coverage for accidental death or permanent disablement, as well as medical reimbursement for accidents [8].
![This image shows a list of Singapore Government/Restructured Hospitals along with their websites.](image1)
For medical assistance off-campus, several private clinics are located near NTU, and a comprehensive list of clinics in Singapore can be found at http://www.singhealth.com.sg/Patient Care/GP/Pages/Home.aspx [3].

NTU provides comprehensive medical and support services, including on-campus medical service, counseling, peer support programs, and insurance schemes, with additional options available at nearby private clinics.

To measure your wrist circumference, begin by positioning the ruler that comes with the watch through the buckle, about two fingers away from the bottom of your palm [5]. Then, pull the ruler until it touches your arm, ensuring it's not too tight, and record the position indicated by the arrow [7]. Based on the measurement, you can then select the appropriate strap size and fasten the nail buckle [4].

![A ruler is being used to measure wrist circumference.](image5)

The watch body should be placed in the middle of the back of your wrist, with the edge of the watch's body below the root of the ulnar styloid process [2]. The strap and airbag should be selected based on this scale value [1].  

![The orange part is being inserted into the watch strap.](image1)

Measuring your wrist circumference allows you to select the right strap and airbag [8, 10].

Therefore, you measure wrist circumference by using the provided ruler, placing it correctly on your wrist, and recording the measurement to select the appropriate strap.

The NMRC Dining Out is a formal event steeped in Naval tradition, celebrating Naval Medical research and development and honoring fallen comrades.

The Dining Out, also known as the Annual Mess Night, took place at the U.S. Naval Academy in Annapolis [4]. The President of the Mess, NMRC Commanding Officer Capt. John Sanders, commenced the evening [8]. ![Officers are formally dressed for the NMRC Dining Out.](image1)

The evening observed "strict Naval protocol" with traditions tracing back to the Vikings and the British Navy but also made "special references to the remarkable history of Naval Medical research" [9]. The traditions include the playing of the National Anthem [8], invocation, call to parade the beef, poems and odes [9]. The event also included the traditional mixing of the grog and formal toasting [10]. ![Officers are standing and speaking at the NMRC Dining Out with flags in the background.](image5)

Hospital Corpsman 1st Class Brian Knetsch presented the Prisoner of War/Missing in Action table to honor the memory of fallen or lost comrades [3]. Doll spoke about the history of Navy Medicine research and development [5].

The NMRC Dining Out is a tradition-rich event that celebrates Naval Medical research and honors those who have served.

NAMRU-3 has made significant contributions to medical research capacity building and disease surveillance efforts, while NSMRL focuses on submarine force and human factors research. NAMRU-3 is dedicated to enhancing medical capabilities in various countries, as seen through its work with the Ministry of Health laboratories and the Defense Threat Reduction Agency (DTRA) in Afghanistan [8]. This collaboration aims to improve the efficiency and synergy of U.S. government biodefense and disease surveillance efforts [8]. NAMRU-3's initial focus was on the Ministry of Public Health (MoPH) and the Afghan Public Health Institute, assessing the capacity of laboratory staff and facilities [3].  ![NAMRU-3 assessed capacity and capability of laboratory and staff in Afghanistan.](image3)
NAMRU-3 has also provided training for numerous diagnostic laboratories [2]. For instance, in 2011, they trained 160 Afghan scientists and technicians in laboratory operations, diagnostic procedures, and ethics related to U.S. select agents [1, 6]. NAMRU-3 also developed training modules for laboratory staff [10]. NAMRU-3 provided supplies and training to address gaps [5].

NSMRL, on the other hand, focuses on the submarine force and human factors within [4]. NSMRL is CSF’s primary human technology laboratory, researching physical and mental health and performance [4]. NSMRL conducts medical, psychological, and human performance research; provides reviews of human systems related projects; and develops innovative concepts for CSF [4]. NSMRL’s missions are aligned with submarine strategic direction [4]. ![A group of U.S. Navy personnel, possibly involved with the Naval Submarine Medical Research Laboratory.](image1)

These efforts support U.S. military operations by improving medical research capabilities, disease surveillance, and the health and performance of military personnel.

The Naval Medical Research Center (NMRC) contributes significantly to both international medical initiatives and local medical advancements through its various programs and collaborations. NAMRU-3 established hospital laboratories and provided training for diagnostic laboratories, implementing an acute febrile illness/diarrhea study [9]. ![NAMRU-3 researchers are working in a lab.](image1) In 2011, NAMRU-3 provided training for 160 Afghan scientists and technicians on laboratory operations, diagnostic procedures, and ethics [6]. A training plan was developed for 2012 based on needs and gaps identified by NAMRU-3 laboratory assessments, covering topics like parasitology, bacteriology, bioscience facility management, and more [1]. These efforts directly improve medical capabilities and knowledge in other countries.

The NMRC also supports local advancements, such as the Bone Marrow Research Directorate's work on DNA-based typing for marrow transplants, providing military contingency support for casualties with marrow toxic injury [3].  Following DoD donor drives, genetic testing is performed to match potential donors with patients [5]. ![Sailors aboard the USNS Mercy are posed for a group photo.](image5) Cmdr. Charmagne Beckett, a NMRC physician researcher, volunteered to deploy on the USNS Mercy, which conducts humanitarian missions [8]. The USNS Mercy Pacific Partnership missions began in 2004 as a humanitarian response to the catastrophic tsunami [8].

The NMRC supports international medical initiatives through training, laboratory establishment, and humanitarian missions, and advances local medicine through research in areas like bone marrow transplantation and support for military personnel.

The U.S. Naval Medical Research Units (NAMRU) engage in activities that support both military personnel and local communities by focusing on disease prevention, medical research, and capacity building [1, 2]. NAMRU-3 collaborates with the Armed Forces of Liberia (AFL) through vector control training efforts, demonstrating military-to-military engagements [7].

![Group photo of scientists from Kazakhstan who visited the Rickettsial Diseases Research Program laboratories at the Naval Medical Research Center for training.](image5)

NAMRU-3 is actively involved in medical research capacity building in Liberia, which is beneficial for a country recovering from civil war [2]. Navy biomedical researchers have been collaborating with the Liberian Institute of Biomedical Research (LIBR) on projects that focus on disease vector surveillance, detection of vector-borne viral pathogens such as malaria, and vector control [5]. These projects enhance Liberia's capability to independently expand vector-borne disease surveillance and detection to benefit both the Liberian Armed Forces and the entire population [5]. The Rickettsial Diseases Research Program provides training to individuals in regions endemic to rickettsial diseases, supporting both military and civilian personnel worldwide [6, 10]. The activities of the U.S. Naval Medical Research Units support both military personnel and local communities through medical research, disease prevention, and capacity building.

The Patient Condition Occurrence Frequency (PCOF) tool plays a significant role in military operations by providing a method for estimating patient occurrences and enhancing medical mission planning [3, 6]. The tool is designed to move beyond anecdotal planning estimates, offering a repeatable and organized method to estimate patient conditions expected during a contingency [2].
![PCOF generates probabilities of disease and injury types.](image1)
The PCOF tool generates tables showing the probabilities of disease and injury types typically sustained during military operations, including humanitarian assistance, disaster relief, and combat scenarios [10]. Using this accredited tool, planners can employ mission-centric data to inform decision-makers on patient conditions, improving healthcare simulations [6, 10].

The USNS Mercy Pacific Partnership 2012 focused on providing medical, dental, and veterinary care to host nations, as well as conducting subject-matter expert exchanges [6]. Over 49,000 patients received care, and over 900 surgeries were performed; additionally, veterinary services were provided to more than 7,000 animals [6]. Mercy staff also participated in over 60,000 hours of SMEEs on topics like first aid, nutrition, and disaster response [6].

![USNS Mercy conducted various humanitarian missions, including medical care, surgeries, and veterinary services.](image1)

The DoD Bone Marrow Program focuses on registering service members, family members, and DoD employees as potential marrow donors [8, 9].  Oral swabs are collected and sent to the C.W. Bill Young DoD Marrow Donor Program Donor Center and Laboratory for genetic testing [3].  The program had over 730,000 volunteers, with over 5,200 having donated marrow for patients needing transplants [9].
![A service member is providing an oral swab to register with the DoD Marrow Donor Program.](image3)

Both initiatives have significant humanitarian impacts, with the USNS Mercy providing direct medical and veterinary care and knowledge exchange to thousands in multiple nations [6].  The DoD Bone Marrow Program facilitates life-saving marrow transplants for patients with potentially fatal diseases [9]. The USNS Mercy provides direct care to a large number of individuals, while the Marrow Donor Program enables life-saving treatments for those with specific diseases requiring marrow transplants.
