In 2012, NAMRU-3 and USNS Mercy collaborated through training and humanitarian efforts to improve medical practices. NAMRU-3 researchers developed nine modules on various topics, including parasitology, bacteriology, and laboratory quality management system, based on identified needs and gaps [4]. Aboard the USNS Mercy, Cmdr. Charmagne Beckett supported the investigation and management of a shipboard outbreak [6].

The USNS Mercy Pacific Partnership missions began in 2004 as a response to the tsunami that devastated parts of Southeast Asia [10]. Missions were conducted in Indonesia, the Philippines, Vietnam, and Cambodia, and over 49,000 patients were treated [7].

![Sailors are participating in swab collection.](image5)

These missions were designed to strengthen bilateral relations with other nations, crucial to regional security and stability [10]. The USNS Mercy provided care and services to local populations during its mission activities [7]. In 2012, the USNS Mercy set sail with clinical staff to provide humanitarian assistance [1].

![Cmdr. Charmagne Beckett stands on a ship.](image2)

NAMRU-3 and the USNS Mercy improved medical practices through training and direct humanitarian efforts in 2012.

NAMRU units contribute to international health and defense efforts through various specialized activities and collaborations. For example, NAMRU-3 collaborates with the Armed Forces of Liberia (AFL) by conducting vector control training in partnership with LIBR [1]. They met with key collaborators in Monrovia to discuss this project, including the Minister of Health and Social Welfare and the Director of LIBR [6]. The Minister of Health expressed thanks for the collaboration at LIBR [3]. The Director of LIBR stated that this collaboration helps to restore capabilities that LIBR had before the war [5].
![The picture shows a group of people standing outside a building, likely involved in international health collaborations.](image1)
NAMRU-3’s work also extends to supporting U.S. war fighters by providing knowledge and tools to support themselves [9]. Vector surveillance training provided by NAMRU-3 improved the ability to protect soldiers and their families from disease [8]. Also, insecticide spraying for all base housing with surveillance and geospatial mapping helps determine the distribution of malaria-transmitting mosquitos [4].
![The picture depicts a formal gathering of individuals, symbolizing collaborative efforts in medical research and capacity building in Liberia.](image2)
These projects directly support war fighters and build local capacity, helping Liberia recover from a brutal civil war [9, 10]. All of this illustrates risk reduction with vector controls and anti-malarial prophylaxis [4].

NAMRU units contribute to international health and defense by providing training, conducting research, and building local capacity to address health challenges and support military operations.

NAMRU-3 has engaged in several key collaborations and activities in Liberia, aimed at building medical research capacity and supporting the country's recovery from civil war. NAMRU-3 has been actively involved in military-to-military engagements with the Armed Forces of Liberia (AFL) through vector control training, in collaboration with LIBR [1]. Since 2010, Navy biomedical researchers have been collaborating with the Liberian Institute of Biomedical Research (LIBR) on research projects funded by the Armed Forces Health Surveillance Center/Global Emerging Infections System (AFHSC-GEIS) [3].

These projects focus on disease vector surveillance, detection of vector-borne viral pathogens such as malaria, and vector control, enabling Liberia to independently expand its capabilities [3]. ![NAMRU-3 team members and key collaborators meet in Liberia.](image4)

NAMRU-3's activities extend to vector control with insecticide spraying and geospatial mapping to determine the distribution of malaria-transmitting mosquitoes [4]. The Minister of Health and Social Welfare praised NAMRU-3's capacity building engagements in Liberia, expressing specific thanks for the collaboration at LIBR and hoping for future projects [10]. This collaboration with NAMRU-3 is expected to open doors for future projects and attract other potential collaborators to LIBR [9]. NAMRU-3 is playing a vital role in medical research capacity building in Liberia, which is crucial for the country's recovery [5].

NAMRU-3 has significantly contributed to enhancing medical research capabilities and force health protection in Liberia through collaborations, training, and targeted research initiatives.

Char-magne Beckett volunteered on the hospital ship USNS Mercy.](image4)

NMRC's Bone Marrow Research Directorate also provides military contingency support for casualties with marrow toxic injury due to radiation or chemical warfare agents [8].

NMRC and its teams contribute significantly to medical research, public health capacity building, humanitarian aid, and military support.

NAMRU-3 played an important role in medical research capacity building in Liberia, which was recovering from a 14-year civil war [8]. NAMRU-3 collaborated with the Liberian Institute of Biomedical Research (LIBR) on projects focusing on disease vector surveillance, detection of vector-borne viral pathogens such as malaria, and vector control [6]. These projects helped Liberia expand its vector-borne disease surveillance and detection capabilities to benefit both the Liberian Armed Forces and the general population ![People from NAMRU-3 meet with key collaborators in Liberia.](image1)

NAMRU-3 provided training and equipment in vector surveillance, vector biology/identification, and vector control, which improved Liberia's ability to protect its soldiers and families from disease [1]. The collaboration with NAMRU-3 also helped restore capabilities that LIBR had lost before the war [2]. The Director of LIBR believed that the collaboration with NAMRU-3 would open doors for future projects and attract other potential collaborators to LIBR [4]. ![People from NAMRU-3 meet with key collaborators including the Minister of Health and Social Welfare.](image2)

NAMRU-3's projects in Liberia directly support war fighters and leave behind knowledge and tools for Liberia to support themselves in the future [9]. The collaboration included insecticide spraying and geospatial mapping to control malaria-transmitting mosquitoes, leading to no malaria infections in U.S troops since the start of the spraying [3]. This illustrates the risk reduction made possible with environmental vector controls and anti-malarial prophylaxis [3]. NAMRU-3 supported medical research capacity building in Liberia by focusing on vector-borne disease surveillance and detection, vector control, and providing training and equipment, in close collaboration with LIBR.

NAMRU-3 is actively involved in several collaborative efforts in Liberia to bolster medical research capacity. They partner with the Liberian Institute of Biomedical Research (LIBR) on research projects focusing on disease vector surveillance and detection of vector-borne viral pathogens like malaria [3]. These projects aim to expand Liberia's ability to independently monitor and detect vector-borne diseases for the benefit of both the Liberian Armed Forces and the general population [3].

NAMRU-3 also collaborates with the Armed Forces of Liberia (AFL) through vector control training efforts, again in collaboration with LIBR [2]. These engagements include insecticide spraying combined with surveillance and geospatial mapping to determine the distribution of malaria-transmitting mosquitoes, a project of particular interest to U.S. Marine Col. Vernon Graham [5].  ![NAMRU-3 team visited key collaborators in Liberia](image2)

The Minister of Health and Social Welfare has expressed high praise for NAMRU-3's capacity-building engagements in Liberia, specifically acknowledging the collaboration at LIBR [4].  This collaborative work underscores NAMRU-3's dedication to strengthening Liberia's medical research capabilities, especially in the crucial area of vector-borne disease control.

Through partnerships with LIBR and the AFL, NAMRU-3 is working to improve disease surveillance and vector control in Liberia.

The NMRC Dining Out event incorporates Naval traditions and tributes. A somber moment occurred when Hospital Corpsman 1st Class Brian Knetsch requested permission to present and explain the Prisoner of War/Missing in Action table in honor of their memory [2]. This highlights respect for fallen comrades.

![Hospital Corpsman 1st Class Brian Knetsch presented and explained the Prisoner of War/Missing in Action table.](image3)

The evening also followed strict Naval protocol, a tradition that reaches back to the Vikings and the British Navy [1]. This included traditions like the mixing of grog and formal toasts [3]. This adherence to naval tradition is captured in the presence of a ship's wheel, symbolizing naval heritage and leadership, during the event.

The ship's wheel displayed at the NMRC Dining Out event symbolizes naval heritage and leadership.

The Naval Submarine Medical Research Laboratory (NSMRL) serves as the primary human technology laboratory for the Commander, Submarine Forces (CSF) [7].

NSMRL's role encompasses medical, psychological, and human performance research, as well as objective reviews of human systems and innovative concept development for the CSF, as shown in this image ![Researchers work in a lab setting.](image5).

NSMRL is tasked to conduct medical, psychological and human performance research; provide independent, objective reviews of human systems related projects and technology proposed for CSF use; and develop new and innovative concepts for CSF that use human technology [7]. NSMRL functions as CSF's primary human technology lab, focusing on submariner health and performance, as well as diving medicine [7].

NAMRU-3 has been actively involved in bolstering Afghanistan's public health capabilities since 2006 [5]. A key aspect of this involvement has been the provision of extensive training to Afghan scientists and technicians. In 2011, NAMRU-3 trained 160 Afghan scientists and technicians in vital areas such as laboratory operations, diagnostic procedures, and research ethics [2]. A comprehensive training plan for 2012 was then developed based on needs identified through NAMRU-3 laboratory assessments [2, 7]. This plan included nine modules covering diverse topics such as parasitology, bacteriology, bioscience facility management, clinical epidemiology, biomedical equipment repair, laboratory quality management system, serology, molecular biology, and virology [7].

NAMRU-3's training initiatives extended to various aspects of laboratory management and quality control. They conducted workshops to train laboratory and administrative staff on proper procedures, inventory management, quality control, and standard operating procedures [9]. These efforts also included developing national laboratory biosafety and quality control plans [9]. In addition to laboratory skills, NAMRU-3 provided training in vector surveillance, biology/identification, and control, greatly improving the ability to protect soldiers and their families from disease, as expressed by Nador [6]. NAMRU-3 developed training materials specifically tailored to the Afghan context, considering cultural practices to ensure relevance and effectiveness [10].

![People are working in the lab setting.] (image4)

NAMRU-3 collaborated with the Defense Threat Reduction Agency (DTRA) Cooperative Biological Engagement Program (CBEP) to enhance the efficiency and synergy of biodefense and disease surveillance efforts in Afghanistan [4]. This collaborative approach aimed to maximize the impact of U.S. government initiatives in the region [4]. The training efforts primarily focused on the Ministry of Public Health (MoPH) and the Afghan Public Health Institute, starting with assessments of the Central Public Health Laboratory (CPHL) in Kabul before expanding to other facilities in Kabul and planning for other regions [3].

In summary, NAMRU-3 conducted comprehensive training activities in Afghanistan, covering laboratory operations, disease surveillance, and public health capacity building, tailored to the local context and needs.

The immune system targets malaria parasites through a process involving liver cells and CD8+ T cells. Pf schizont in liver cells are targeted by Pf peptide, leading to apoptosis and parasite death as illustrated here: ![The immune system targets malaria parasites through a process involving liver cells and CD8+ T cells.](image1)

The immune system targets malaria parasites by inducing apoptosis and death of the parasite within the liver cell.

The Naval Medical Research Center (NMRC) actively works to transfer technology and commercialize discoveries for the benefit of the warfighter, which often translates to civilian benefits as well [2, 5]. One example of this is the collaboration led by Lt. Roxanne Burrus focusing on evaluating the effects of changing demography and land use on malaria transmission which is important to the health of deployed war fighters and is also an important issue in light of the prevalence of malaria in developing countries [9].
![Lt. Roxanne Burrus leads a collaboration focusing on evaluating the effects of changing demography and land use on malaria transmission.](image2)
This malaria-focused collaboration exemplifies how military research addresses specific needs of the armed forces while simultaneously contributing to global health solutions [9]. This involves identifying antigens for potential vaccine candidates [9].
![This image shows the CD8+ T cell and Liver Cell in the process of apoptosis and death of parasite.](image1)
Furthermore, the Deployed Combat Casualty Research Team (DC2RT) started in Iraq in 2005 and transitioned to Afghanistan in 2010, embedding with medical assets and is focused on pre-hospital and en route care; hemorrhage and acute care; traumatic brain injury; and prevention, resilience and recovery [1, 6]. The JC2RT team prioritizes enrollment and conduct of approved protocols, recognizing that medical advances are often accelerated during war and hold the potential for decreasing morbidity and mortality associated with combat injuries [8].
![This image shows a team in front of a helicopter.](image4)
The NMRC's malaria vaccine research and the JC2RT team's work demonstrates a dual benefit, improving military healthcare while providing advancements applicable to civilian medical practices.

The Joint Combat Casualty Research Team (JC2RT) is a forward deployed unit in Afghanistan tasked with conducting combat-relevant research [10, 7]. JC2RT Team 13 prioritized approved protocols and processing of new protocols due to the anticipated troop drawdown [3]. ![JC2RT Team 13 members are standing in front of a helicopter in Afghanistan.](image3)
The JC2RT is tasked with overseeing, coordinating, facilitating, and conducting combat-relevant research in a deployed environment [10]. The JC2RT's mission includes systematically recording, collecting, validating, and analyzing data to accelerate medical advances during war [3]. ![Several people in uniform stand in front of a US Naval Medical Research Center sign.](image2)
The role of the JC2RT team in Afghanistan is to conduct combat-relevant research to accelerate medical advances and decrease morbidity and mortality associated with combat injuries.

The cell samples collected via oral swabs are sent to the C.W. Bill Young DoD Marrow Donor Program Donor Center and Laboratory where staff members perform genetic testing to match potential donors with patients [6]. The cotton swab is used to collect cell samples that enable genetic testing to find potential marrow donors [6].

Marketing Qualified Leads (MQLs) are leads ready to be qualified [2]. Sales Accepted Leads (SALs) are leads accepted by Sales. ![The image shows definitions and industry averages for database inquiries, MQLs, SALs, Opportunities and Opportunity-to-Sales.](image2)

The image shows the progression of leads through the funnel, including total leads, MQLs, SALs, Sales Qualified Leads (SQLs), and Sales Won Opportunities (SWOs). ![The image displays the trend and number of leads in different stages along with Lead->MQL, MQL->SAL, SAL->SQL, SQL->SWO conversion rate.](image3)

In general, MQLs converting into SALs is shown as 4% to 8% across the industry. ![The image shows the percentage of conversion from different lead types and an overview of sales following this model.](image5) However, according to image3, the conversion rate from MQL to SAL is about 1.50%. 

Therefore, the conversion rate from MQLs to SALs is lower than the industry average.

In 2006, healthcare faced several key challenges, and the adoption of specific IT applications saw notable shifts from 2005. Healthcare in 2006 lagged behind other businesses in IT adoption [3].
One of the main issues facing healthcare was the lack of financial support, which increased from 18% in 2005 to 20% in 2006, as shown in ![Lack of financial support was one of the major barriers to implementing IT in healthcare in 2006.](image4). Additionally, vendor's inability to effectively deliver products saw a significant increase from 12% to 18% from 2005 to 2006.

![The adoption of Electronic Medical Records saw an increase from 2005 to 2006.](image1) shows the most important applications. Electronic Medical Records saw an increase from 61% in 2005 to 62% in 2006, and Bar Coded Medication Management also increased from 55% to 58%. Finally, the top security concerns included internal breach of security which increased from 51% to 56% from 2005 to 2006, as shown in ![The primary security concern in healthcare was internal breaches of security in 2006.](image3).

In summary, the healthcare IT sector in 2006 saw increased challenges in financial support and vendor performance, alongside a greater focus on security and the adoption of electronic medical records.

Gestalt psychology emphasizes how individuals perceive the world by eliminating complexity to observe reality in a simplistic form [8]. Visual representations, like those in data presentation, are significantly influenced by this principle.

The CTBT training program presents participation statistics, as illustrated in ![The CTBT training program displays participation statistics including minutes watched, participants from different countries, clicks on lecture videos and lectures delivered](image4), which include the number of minutes watched online, the count of registered participants from various countries, the number of clicks on lecture videos, and the count of lectures delivered. This format allows for a clear understanding of the program's reach and engagement.

Conversely, the changes in weekend activities from 2005 to 2010 are depicted using a pie chart, showcasing how time allocation across different activities has shifted. ![The pie charts showing the changes in weekend activities from 2005 to 2010](image3) This representation highlights the proportional distribution of time spent on activities such as shopping, fitness, eating out, hobbies, and spending time with family and friends, providing a comparative view of how priorities have evolved over time.

The transformation of data into business value involves a multi-stage process, starting with data collection and progressing through analysis, decision-making, and action, ultimately leading to impact [6]. This progression is visualized in the analytics value chain, showing the flow from data to reporting, analysis, action, and finally, value ![The analytics value chain moves from data collection to reporting, analysis, action, and value creation.](image1).

Different levels of analytics contribute to this value creation, starting from standard reports and moving up to optimization [1]. These levels involve asking different questions at each stage, starting with "What happened?" and progressing to "What's the best that can happen?" ![Business Analytics progresses from standard reports to Optimisation.](image2). The journey involves pushing data through the "analytics value chain" to ensure that the analysis leads to decisions, actions, and measurable impact, rather than stopping partway [6]. For example, analytics is about impact [8].
The progression of data transformation includes several key steps: collecting the data, ensuring data quality, organizing the analyst team, performing data analysis, designing metrics, telling stories with data, conducting A/B testing, making decisions, and fostering a data-driven culture [10]. This process also ensures data and analytics are deeply embedded into processes and decisions [4].

In summary, the process of transforming data into business value advances through a structured analytics value chain and different levels of analytics, which ensures insights lead to impactful actions and improved business outcomes.

During meiosis I, homologous chromosomes separate, which reduces the chromosome number by half [4]. Prior to this separation, chromosomes coil and become compact, and homologous chromosomes come together as pairs via synapsis [1]. Each pair, now with four chromatids, is called a tetrad, and non-sister chromatids exchange genetic material through crossing over [1]. These stages, including tetrad formation and crossing over, occur before metaphase I.  ![Homologous chromosomes undergo crossing over and form tetrads during prophase I.](image5)
During metaphase I, the tetrads align along the metaphase plate, as shown in the illustration ![Tetrads align at the metaphase plate in Metaphase I.](image2)
The mitotic spindle, which is composed of microtubules, is required to divide the chromosomes [7]. ![Illustration shows chromosomes in tetrad formation during meiosis.](image1)

Key processes and features of metaphase I include the alignment of tetrads at the metaphase plate.

Binary fission in prokaryotic cells involves several key steps, as outlined in the provided information [4]. First, a single circular chromosome duplicates, and the copies begin to separate from each other [5].  Then, the cell elongates, and the chromosomal copies separate further [5]. Following elongation and chromosome separation, the plasma membrane grows inward at the midpoint to divide the cells [5].  ![The prokaryotic cell undergoes chromosome duplication.](image4)
These steps result in two identical cells arising from one cell [4].  ![Binary fission results in two identical daughter cells.](image5)

Binary fission in prokaryotic cells involves three main steps: chromosome duplication and separation, cell elongation, and plasma membrane division.

Mendelian inheritance explains the reappearance of traits in the F2 generation and the resulting phenotypic and genotypic ratios by the passing of heritable factors (genes) from parents to offspring [5, 7]. ![The image displays a monohybrid cross, starting with purple and white parental flowers, resulting in purple flowers in the F1 generation, and a 3:1 phenotypic ratio of purple to white flowers in the F2 generation.](image5)

Mendel's experiments with pea plants demonstrated that traits, such as flower color, are determined by these heritable factors, now known as genes [7]. These genes exist in different versions, or alleles, which account for variations in inherited characters [9].  The reappearance of the white flower trait in the F2 generation can be explained by the presence of a recessive allele [6].  As shown in the image, in the parental generation, you have purple flowers crossed with white flowers, and in the F1 generation, all plants have purple flowers. This demonstrates that the purple flower allele is dominant over the white flower allele [5]. However, in the F2 generation, the white flower trait reappears in one quarter of the offspring [5].

![The illustration showcases a monohybrid cross from P plants to F2 plants, depicting the genetic makeup and phenotypic ratios, highlighting the segregation of alleles during gamete formation.](image4) This reappearance occurs because the F1 generation, although displaying the dominant purple flower phenotype, carries both the dominant and recessive alleles (Pp) from the parental generation. When these F1 plants self-pollinate, the alleles segregate during gamete formation, leading to a genotypic ratio of 1 PP : 2 Pp : 1 pp in the F2 generation. This results in a phenotypic ratio of 3 purple : 1 white [5]. Therefore, Mendelian inheritance explains the observed phenotypic and genotypic ratios in the F2 generation through the segregation and recombination of alleles from the parental generation.

In a monohybrid cross, the parental generation involves crossing purple flowers with white flowers [10]. In the $\mathsf{F_{2}}$ generation, Mendel observed a specific ratio, where of the plants had purple flowers and  had white flowers [10].
This segregation leads to distinct genotypic and phenotypic ratios in the $\mathsf{F_{2}}$ generation, as illustrated in a cross where P plants with PP and pp alleles result in $\mathsf{F_{1}}$ plants with Pp alleles, and further crosses lead to the $\mathsf{F_{2}}$ generation [4].

The image illustrates the phenotypic outcomes for earlobe attachment based on genotype, where FF or Ff results in free earlobes (dominant trait), while ff results in attached earlobes (recessive trait) `![The image illustrates the phenotypic outcomes for earlobe attachment based on genotype, where FF or Ff results in free earlobes (dominant trait), while ff results in attached earlobes (recessive trait)](image1)`.

![This image represents homozygous and heterozygous genotypes with corresponding alleles.](image3)

The phenotypic ratio in the $\mathsf{F_{2}}$ generation is 3 purple : 1 white, while the genotypic ratio is 1 PP : 2 Pp : 1 pp `![This image shows the creation of gametes and F2 plants with the phenotypic ratio of 3 purple to 1 white, and a genotypic ratio of 1 PP : 2 Pp : 1 pp.](image4)`.

The phenotypic ratio in the $\mathsf{F_{2}}$ generation is 3:1 (purple to white), and the genotypic ratio is 1:2:1 (PP, Pp, pp).

The learning objectives for creating and embedding maps using Wikidata are structured across three modules, each focusing on different aspects of map creation and integration [9].

**Module 1**:
Focuses on understanding the steps to make basic flat and layered maps in Wikidata, based on geo-referenced items and SPARQL queries [9]. Module 1 covers the creation of various basic flat and clustered maps in Wikidata using SPARQL queries. Additionally, layered maps are made, where groups of items can be toggled on/off in the map [9].
![Module 1 focuses on basic flat and layered maps.](image4)

**Module 2**:
Deals with understanding the steps to embed maps in Wikimedia sites like Wikipedia, Wikimedia Commons, and Wikidata [9].
![Module 2 covers embedding maps in Wikimedia sites like Wikipedia and Wikidata.](image2)
After exploring maps in the Wikidata query interface, Module 2 teaches how to embed Wikidata-driven maps in other Wikimedia projects, such as Wikipedia and Commons. In addition to SPARQL, OpenStreetMap, GeoJSON, and the Mediawiki Kartographer extension are examined [9]. The Wikimedia Commons project utilizes embedded maps [2, 3].

**Module 3**:
Covers understanding the steps to create interactive, layered Wikidata-based off-Wiki maps [9].
![Module 3 focuses on creating Wikidata-based off-Wiki maps.](image3)
In Module 3, the steps for creating interactive, layered Wikidata-driven maps that can be used off-Wiki, i.e., in regular HTML pages, are taught. In addition to the tools and techniques from previous modules, some basic Python and Jupyter are used [9]. This Jupyter notebook shows step by step how to make a Wikidata-driven layered map that can be used off-Wiki [7]. An example of the data used is a Dutch Public Libraries map from Wikimedia Commons [10]. This module is also part of a map-making workshop [4].

The workshop teaches how to make both flat, clustered, layered, embedded, interactive, on-Wiki, and off-Wiki maps from sets of geo-referenced items in Wikidata [5].

The learning objectives are structured in three modules covering basic map creation, embedding maps in Wikimedia projects, and creating interactive off-Wiki maps.

The Wikidata map-making workshop aims to teach participants how to create various types of maps using Wikidata. The workshop is structured into three modules, each with specific learning objectives and tools.

Module 1 focuses on creating basic flat and layered maps using geo-referenced items and SPARQL queries.  ![Module 1 focuses on creating basic flat and layered maps in Wikidata.](image4) Participants will "start by making various basic flat and clustered maps in Wikidata using SPARQL queries" [8].
Module 2 covers embedding Wikidata-driven maps in Wikimedia projects, such as Wikipedia and Commons. ![Module 2 focuses on embedding maps into Wikimedia projects like Wikipedia, Wikimedia Commons, and Wikidata.](image3) This module uses OpenStreetMap, GeoJSON, and the Mediawiki Kar to graph er extension [8].
Module 3 teaches the creation of interactive, layered Wikidata-driven maps for use off-Wiki in regular HTML pages [8]. This module utilizes Python and Jupyter notebooks, with a Jupyter notebook providing step-by-step instructions on creating a layered map that can be used off-Wiki [6]. This module aims to "understand advanced steps to create Wikidata-based off-wiki maps" [image3].

To support these objectives, the workshop provides access to map-making resources, SPARQL examples, and Python code snippets [image1]. The workshop uses "basic Python, Jupyter" and other tools & techniques [8]. The workshop is designed to be approachable for beginners, offering examples and code snippets that can be adapted with basic SPARQL, Wikidata, and Python skills [9]. A Jupyter Notebook shows step by step how to make a Wikidata-driven layered map [7].

The workshop aims to equip participants with the skills to create flat, clustered, layered, embedded, interactive, on-Wiki, and off-Wiki maps from geo-referenced items in Wikidata [4].
In conclusion, the learning objectives involve creating different types of maps using Wikidata, supported by resources like SPARQL, Python, and Jupyter notebooks.

To settle into NTU as a new international student, follow these steps:

First, secure your housing by providing your arrival details online if you've been offered a place in campus housing, and collect your room key [8]. Contact the Office of Housing and Auxiliary Services (HAS) for any housing enquiries or visit their website [9]. For specific housing contact based on student status, please see the details here: ![{Housing contact details for different student categories}](image5)

Next, complete your registration with SAO-Student Support during office hours, bringing your passport, embarkation card, Letter of Admission/Enrolment, and receipts for any NTU’s Miscellaneous Fee payment [5].

For banking, OCBC bank has a branch on campus, and other banks are located near NTU at Jurong Point Shopping Centre [4]. Please see below for the name of the banks: ![{Details of the banks}](image2)

Set up your communication by signing up for a mobile line at Jurong Point Shopping Centre or a convenience store [1]. Singapore has three telecommunication companies [1]. Please see below for the name of the companies: ![{Telecommunication companies in Singapore}](image1)

Finally, get your network account details upon registration, which allows access to NTU computer network, Intranet portal iNTU, e-services, e-learning, Library databases and other computer resources [7].

Following these steps will ensure a smooth transition into life at NTU.

The 8751H microcontroller has specific power supply current and timing characteristics that differ from other devices.

The power supply current (Icc) varies between different microcontrollers; for the 8751H/8751H-8, it is 250 mA, while for the 8031AH/8051AHP it is 125 mA, and for the 8032AH/8052AH/8751BH/8752BH it is 175 mA ![The image presents the input and output parameters of the 8751H microcontroller, highlighting power supply current and voltage levels.](image1)

For the 8751H, the ALE Low to Valid Instruction In timing (TLLIV) has a maximum of 183 ns with a 12 MHz oscillator, whereas "All Others" have a maximum of 233 ns with a 12 MHz oscillator; similarly, PSEN Pulse Width (TPLPH) is 190 ns for 8751H and 215 ns for All Others ![The image provides timing specifications for different microcontroller operations, showing the timing differences between 8751H and other devices.](image5)

The power supply current and timing parameters for the 8751H microcontroller differ from other devices, as the 8751H exhibits higher power consumption and unique timing characteristics for ALE and PSEN signals.

The Wikidata map-making workshop is designed to teach participants how to create various types of maps using Wikidata and related tools. The workshop is divided into three modules, each with specific learning objectives [2, 8].

**Module 1** focuses on basic flat and layered maps. Participants will learn to make these maps using SPARQL queries and geo-referenced items in Wikidata. ![Module 1 teaches the basics of making flat and layered maps in Wikidata.](image1)

**Module 2** transitions to embedding maps in Wikimedia projects.  The focus is on embedding Wikidata-driven maps in other Wikimedia projects [8]. This involves understanding how to use OpenStreetMap, GeoJSON, and the Mediawiki Kartographer extension [8]. ![Module 2 focuses on embedding maps in Wikimedia projects like Wikipedia and Commons.](image4)

**Module 3** advances to interactive, layered off-Wiki maps. Participants will learn to create these maps for use in regular HTML pages, utilizing Python and Jupyter notebooks [8, 9]. ![Module 3 focuses on creating interactive, layered Wikidata-driven maps for use off-Wiki.](image4)

Each module builds upon the previous one, progressing from basic map creation to embedding and finally to creating interactive maps for external use [8]. The key difference lies in the complexity and application of the maps, moving from simple visualizations within Wikidata to sophisticated, interactive maps that can be used independently.

The utility derived from each hot dog consumed changes as more are eaten, illustrating the concept of diminishing marginal utility.

Initially, the first hot dog provides a utility of +10, but this decreases to +4 with the second, and eventually becomes negative [image4]. ![The table shows that the utility gained from each hot dog decreases with each additional consumption.](image4) This demonstrates that the enjoyment or satisfaction from consuming additional units of the same good decreases, influencing people to switch to another choice when enjoyment drops, as variety becomes important [9].
Similarly, after consuming 64 hotdogs the utility decreases from -40 to -45 for each addition hotdog [image5]. ![The table shows how the utility of consuming hot dogs decreases with each addition.](image5)

This change in utility implies that focusing on a single consumption activity is often not the best strategy [4]. Diminishing marginal utility changes preferences, indicating that when enjoyment from one choice drops, individuals should seek variety by switching to another option [9].  The power of intentional focus versus the dissipation of variety is a key consideration [2]. 

The change in utility with each additional hot dog consumed demonstrates the concept of diminishing marginal utility, which suggests consumers should seek variety to maximize overall satisfaction.

To achieve the best dishwashing results, it is important to load the dishwasher correctly, considering the type and placement of items. It is generally recommended to put larger and harder-to-clean items in the lower basket, placing serving dishes and lids on the sides to prevent blocking the spray arm [3].
![The image illustrates a dishwasher's upper basket loaded with cups, saucers, glasses, mugs, glass bowls, and dessert bowls.](image1)
The upper basket is designed for more delicate items like glasses and cups [10]. Hollow items should face downwards to prevent water collection, and items shouldn't cover each other to ensure thorough cleaning [10].  ![The image illustrates how cutlery such as soup spoons, forks, knives, teaspoons, dessert spoons, serving spoons, a serving fork, and a gravy ladle should be arranged in the dishwasher.](image4)
Sharp items should be positioned to avoid damaging the door seal, and knives and utensils with sharp points should face downwards or be placed horizontally for safety [9]. It’s important not to overload the dishwasher to ensure good cleaning results and reasonable energy consumption [10].
![The image shows how to arrange items such as an oven pot, dessert plates, dinner plates, soup plates, an oval platter, melamine dessert plates, melamine bowls, and a small pot in the lower basket of a dishwasher.](image5)
If the dishwasher is not loaded properly, the spray arms may not rotate freely, which results in items not getting properly cleaned [10].

Proper loading is essential for optimal wash performance and to prevent damage or injury.

The  $\overline{{\mathsf{E A}}}/\mathsf{v}_{\mathsf{P\mathsf{P}}}$ pin must not be allowed to go above the maximum specified VP P level of 21.5V for any amount of time, and glitches above that voltage level can cause permanent damage to the device [7].Normally  $\overline{{\mathsf{E A}}}/\mathsf{v}_{\mathsf{P\mathsf{P}}}$  is held at a logic high until just before ALE/PROG is to be pulsed [8]. Also, during programming, EA/Vpp is raised to Vpp, ALE/PROG is pulsed low, and then EA/Vpp is returned to a valid high voltage [8].

According to the programming and verification waveforms, the symbol at the bottom left corner indicates the voltage level of  $\overline{{\mathsf{E A}}}/\mathsf{v}_{\mathsf{P\mathsf{P}}}$ during programming. ![The programming section of the EPROM programming and verification waveforms shows the voltage level for the EA/VPP pin.](image5)

The voltage TGLGH is specified as 21V ± 0.5V in Figure 5. This shows the voltage level for  $\overline{{\mathsf{E A}}}/\mathsf{v}_{\mathsf{P\mathsf{P}}}$ [5]. Thus, the minimum voltage is $21 - 0.5 = 20.5$V.

The minimum voltage of the symbol at the bottom left corner in the Figure of EPROM programming and verification waveforms is 20.5.

During meiosis I, homologous chromosomes separate, whereas sister chromatids separate during meiosis II [7]. Meiosis I reduces the chromosome number by half, while meiosis II keeps the chromosome number the same [7].

Meiosis I includes stages such as prophase I, metaphase I, anaphase I and telophase I, during which homologous chromosomes separate as shown in image5, while meiosis II includes stages such as prophase II, metaphase II, anaphase II and telophase II as shown in image4. ![The image shows Anaphase II and Telophase II which are part of the stages of meiosis II.](image4)

The key distinction between meiosis I and meiosis II lies in the behavior of chromosomes: meiosis I separates homologous chromosomes, reducing the chromosome number by half, while meiosis II separates sister chromatids, maintaining the chromosome number, as shown in image3. ![The image shows sister chromatids separating, leading to the formation of haploid daughter cells.](image3)

In meiosis I, homologous chromosomes separate, reducing the chromosome number, and in meiosis II, sister chromatids separate, maintaining the chromosome number.

To program the Lock Bits (LBx) in the 875XBH, certain pin and signal configurations are required. The setup is similar to normal EPROM programming, but P2.6 is held at logic high [10]. Port0, Port 1, and pins P2.0-P2.3 can be in any state [10]. The other pins should be held at the "Security" levels [10].

The diagram illustrates a general setup for the 875XBH, with address and data inputs and control signals, but the specific configuration for the lock bits isn't detailed here. ![This image shows a general programming setup for the 875XBH.](image1)

Referring to the table of programming modes, when programming Lock Bits, RST should be 1, PSEN should be 0, ALE/PROG should be pulsed low, and EA/VPP should be at VPP, which is a higher voltage [3].  ![This image shows the pin configurations for programming various modes, including the lock bits, in the 875XBH.](image2)

The necessary pins and signal configurations for programming the lock bits involve setting P2.6 to logic high, keeping RST at 1, PSEN at 0, pulsing ALE/PROG low, and applying VPP to EA/VPP.

From 2005 to 2006, there was a slight increase in the adoption of Electronic Medical Records, Bar Coded Medication Management, and Computerized Practitioner Order Entry (CPOE) in healthcare settings, as shown in the image ![Adoption rates for Electronic Medical Records, Bar Coded Medication Management, and CPOE increased slightly from 2005 to 2006.](image2).

Simultaneously, the top security concerns shifted slightly, with "Internal Breach of Security" remaining a high concern and "HIPAA Compliance" becoming more of a concern in 2006 ![Internal Breach of Security and HIPAA Compliance were among the top security concerns in healthcare IT in 2005 and 2006.](image1). The trends in healthcare IT adoption show a gradual increase in key applications, while the barriers highlight the challenges of financial constraints, staffing, and vendor performance, all of which influence the pace of IT integration.

The Wikidata Map Making Workshop is structured into three modules, each with specific learning objectives and tools [1, 9].

Module 1 focuses on creating basic flat and layered maps in Wikidata using SPARQL queries, including how to toggle groups of items on/off in the map [1]. This module aims to help users "Understand steps to make basic flat and layered maps in Wikidata, based on geo referenced (P625) items and SPARQL queries" as shown in image3.  ![Module 1 focuses on creating basic flat and layered maps in Wikidata, based on geo-referenced items and SPARQL queries](image3)

Module 2 centers around embedding Wikidata-driven maps into Wikimedia projects like Wikipedia and Commons, utilizing OpenStreetMap, GeoJSON, and the Mediawiki Kar to graph er extension in addition to SPARQL [1]. Specifically, it is about "Understand steps to embed maps in Wikimedia sites like Wikipedia, Wikimedia Commons and Wikidata" as shown in image4.  ![Module 2 is about understanding steps to embed maps in Wikimedia sites](image4) An example of a map from Wikimedia Commons is the "Dutch Public Libraries map" [6]. Image1 depicts what a Dutch Public Libraries map looks like. ![The Dutch Public Libraries map shows the locations of libraries in the Netherlands, Belgium, and parts of Germany](image1)

Module 3 teaches the steps to create interactive, layered Wikidata-driven maps for use off-Wiki in regular HTML pages, using basic Python and Jupyter notebooks along with the tools from previous modules [1, 7]. According to image4, Module 3 aims to "Understand steps to create Wikidata-based off-Wiki maps".  ![Module 3 is about understanding steps to create Wikidata-based off-Wiki maps](image4)

The Wikidata Map Making Workshop modules progressively build skills from basic map creation to embedding maps in Wikimedia projects and creating interactive off-Wiki maps.

Reporting and analysis are integral components of the analytics value chain, facilitating the transformation of raw data into actionable insights and business value. The analytics value chain includes collection, analysis decisions,action,and finally to impact [4]. Partway along chain doesn'tcount, which highlight the importance of completing the entire chain to realize value from data.

Reporting, often associated with business intelligence, is descriptive and backward-looking, focusing on "What?" happened and raising questions, while analysis is prescriptive and forward-looking, answering "Why?" and providing recommendations. ![Reporting is backward-looking while analysis is forward-looking.](image1) The progression from data to information through reporting enables analysts to derive insights by answering questions [1]. Business intelligence, which typically involves standard reports, ad-hoc reports, query drilldown, and alerts, is often seen as a foundation for business analytics, which encompasses statistical analysis, forecasting, predictive modeling, and optimization. ![Levels of analytics shows progression from Business intelligence to business analytics.](image3)

The transition from reporting to analysis signifies a shift from simply describing past events to predicting future outcomes and optimizing business strategies.  The analysis step is crucial for deriving actionable insights from the reported data, enabling informed decisions and strategic actions. The reporting is to raise questions while the analysis is to answer questions [1]. To be successful in analytics insight and great research must lead to change [2].

Ultimately, the roles of reporting and analysis are essential in pushing data through the "analytics value chain," ensuring that the journey from collection to impact is complete [4]. Data leaders should actively promote data as a strategic asset to maximize its impact on all business functions [3].

Reporting and analysis work together within the analytics value chain to transform raw data into actionable insights, driving strategic business decisions and value creation.

Column formwork involves using support structures and molds to shape concrete into columns [8]. Here are some special forms of column formworks:

*   **Circular Column Formwork**: A circular column formwork is shown in image2. ![Circular column formwork consists of rolled sheet metal, stiffener ribs, and edge bolts.](image2) These are often prefabricated [5] and are used to create circular columns [1].

*   **Braced Column Formwork**: Column formwork bracing is used to withstand forces [4, 10]. Image5 illustrates a column form that is held by a prop tightened against a column clamp. ![Column formwork is shown with prop supports and hinged connections.](image5)

*   **Timber Sheathing with Clamps**: Timber sheathing tied with standard column clamps can be used, with infill pieces at the corners [9]. Alternatively, metal straps can be used without corner infills [9]. ![Column formwork is made using timber sheathing, a yoke, battens, bolts and wedges.](image1) Image1 illustrates timber sheathing with a yoke, battens, bolts and wedges.

These are some of the specialized column formwork options, each designed for specific construction needs and safety considerations.

Yes, 18 mm plywood or 25 mm boards, with studs are appropriate for timber formwork [1]. Timber formwork is a traditional formwork [9]. A standard plywood thickness onsite is 18mm and is sufficient for most pours [5].

However,if the form work is curved,a thinner plywood is used to facilitate bending [10].
![Timber formwork shows vertical supports held in place with adjustable props](image1)
Timber formwork commonly uses 18mm plywood and can be thinner for curved structures.

The Engine Control Unit (ECU) plays a central role in managing the engine system. The ECU controls the opening of the injectors [1]. It uses various engine sensors and a control module to regulate the injector valve opening and closing, which is part of the electronic fuel injection system [3]. The ECU also determines the amount of fuel and ignition timing needed for the engine to run, achieving this by reading values from sensor devices monitoring the engine [4].  ![ECU connects to various sensors and injectors](image5)
The engine control unit (ECU) is connected to different sensors for directions of information flow and injectors for the distribution of fuel.

In addition to fuel injection, the ECU manages the ignition timing to optimize power and fuel economy [6]. Moreover, it controls the idle speed by monitoring the engine RPM via the crankshaft position sensor, adjusting either a programmable throttle stop or an idle air bypass control step per motor [5].  ![Electronic Fuel Injection System uses sensors and control module to regulate the injector valve](image4)
This image shows electronic fuel injection system uses sensors and control module to regulate the injector valve.

In the depicted engine management system, the ECU controls fuel injection, manages ignition timing, and regulates idle speed to optimize engine performance and efficiency.

Binary fission is how prokaryotes reproduce, resulting in two identical cells from one [3, 4]. Here are the three steps of binary fission:

First, a single circular chromosome duplicates, and the copies begin to separate from each other [10].  ![Chromosome duplication occurs in the first step of binary fission.](image2)

Second, the cell elongates, and the chromosomal copies separate further [10, 1]. ![Cell elongation and further chromosome separation occur in the second step of binary fission.](image3)

Third, the plasma membrane grows inward at the midpoint to divide the cells [10]. ![The cell divides into two daughter cells in the third step of binary fission.](image4)

Binary fission involves chromosome duplication and separation, cell elongation, and division into two daughter cells.

In standard consumption economics, focusing is often bad [4]. `Variety is important because diminishing marginal utility changes preferences. When enjoyment drops we should switch to another choice` [3]. Image4 shows that in standard hot dog consumption, utility decreases with each hot dog consumed until it becomes negative.

![In standard hot dog consumption, utility decreases with each hot dog consumed until it becomes negative.](image4)

However, in competitive contexts, the cumulative effect of focus may be good [10]. Decision training becomes important because of the potential for competitive mastery resulting from focus [5]. Image5 illustrates this; while utility from each hot dog decreases in both standard and competitive eating, there's a significant spike in utility at the point where a competitive eater ties or wins a competition.

![Joey Chestnut tying Kobayashi in a hot dog eating competition results in a utility spike.](image5)

Therefore, while standard consumption economics highlights the importance of variety due to diminishing marginal utility, competitive mastery can lead to increased utility through focus and overcoming diminishing returns.

The processes of Needs Exploration and Elicitation Methods play a crucial role in addressing stakeholder needs in agile project management, primarily through active stakeholder participation and effective requirements envisioning.

Needs Exploration actively involves stakeholders to define requirements. `![Needs Exploration includes active stakeholder participation.](image2)` This includes "Active stakeholder participation" which helps in defining the high level requirements, which involves Split (A/B) testing, Detailed requirements specification, Acceptance test-driven development (ATDD) Just-in-time (JIT) model storming and Look-ahead modeling.

Elicitation methods focus on extracting and defining requirements effectively. The process facilitates "requirements envisioning and modeling"[1]. The image shows that to "Address Changing Stakeholder Needs", elicitation methods such as Just-in-time (JIT) model storming, Look-ahead modeling, All-hands demos and Iteration demos are used.

Thus, through active involvement and effective elicitation, stakeholder needs are addressed.

The cell cycle is an ordered sequence of events for cell division and consists of two main stages [4]. These stages are Interphase and the Mitotic phase [4]. ![The image shows interphase and mitotic phase cell cycle](image1)
Interphase involves the duplication of cell contents and consists of three sub-phases: G1 (growth and increase in cytoplasm), S (duplication of chromosomes), and G2 (growth and preparation for division) [7]. The mitotic phase includes the division of the nucleus (mitosis) and the division of the cytoplasm (cytokinesis) [10].

The main stages of the cell cycle are interphase, with its sub-phases G1, S, and G2, and the mitotic phase, which includes mitosis and cytokinesis.

The laptop features different types of USB ports, each with distinct capabilities. The laptop has USB 2.0, USB 3.1 Gen 1, and USB 3.1 Gen 2 ports [1, 3]. These ports are used to connect USB-compatible devices such as a keyboard, mouse, storage device, or printer [1, 3, 4].

The right side of the laptop contains a USB 3.1 connector [7]. There is also an "Always On" USB 3.1 connector Gen 1, which allows charging of mobile devices even when the computer is in sleep or hibernation mode [9].

![The left side of the laptop shows a USB-C connector and a USB-C Thunderbolt 3 compatible connector.](image1)

The USB-C connector supports both the USB Type-C standard and Thunderbolt 3 technology, enabling data transfer, device charging, and connection to external displays [6, 10].

![This image points out the audio connector, USB 3.1 connector, HDMI connector, and Ethernet connector.](image2)

In summary, the laptop has a variety of USB ports including USB 2.0, USB 3.1 Gen 1, USB 3.1 Gen 2, and USB-C with Thunderbolt 3, each offering different transfer speeds and functionalities.

In Pro mode, you can adjust the metering mode and focus mode to enhance photography in different scenarios [10]. To adjust the metering mode, you should touch the "M" icon [3]. To adjust the focus mode, you should touch the "AF" icon [1]. Pro mode's metering and focus modes enhance photography by providing tailored options for varied shooting conditions.

Lead scoring involves ranking a prospect's level of interest and sales readiness using a predetermined scoring system [1]. When the scores reach a predetermined threshold, the prospect is deemed Marketing Qualified and transferred to the sales team [1].

`![The image shows total leads, marketing qualified leads, sales accepted leads, sales qualified leads, sales won opportunities with conversion rates](image4)`

Image4 shows the conversion rates at various stages, including the progression from Marketing Qualified Leads (MQL) to Sales Accepted Leads (SAL).  The conversion rate from Lead to MQL is 52.07%, while the conversion rate from MQL to SAL is 1.50% in this example. This significant drop suggests a bottleneck between the marketing and sales teams.

![This image shows database, inquiries, marketing qualified leads, sales accepted leads, opportunities and opportunity-to-sale with their percentages](image5)

Image5 shows the conversion rates between different stages of the leads. The Marketing Qualified Leads(MQLs) is between 4% to 8%, and Sales Accepted Leads (SALs) is between 45% to 75%. This benchmark suggests there is a wide range of acceptable conversion rates between MQL and SAL, depending on the industry, target audience, and sales processes in place.

The difference in conversion rates between Image4 and Image5 highlights the importance of understanding the specific context and performance of each organization. The 1.50% conversion rate from MQL to SAL in Image4 may indicate issues such as poor lead quality from marketing, misalignment between marketing and sales criteria, or ineffective lead nurturing processes. A low conversion rate could point to inefficiencies in the handoff process, where leads that are considered qualified by marketing are not seen as valuable by sales. It could also mean that the criteria for MQL status are too broad, capturing leads that are not truly ready for sales engagement.

In conclusion, variations in MQL to SAL conversion rates across datasets indicate differences in lead quality, alignment between marketing and sales, and effectiveness of lead nurturing processes, thus, organizations should analyze their specific conversion metrics to identify and address inefficiencies.

To address potential dishwasher issues before seeking professional help, it is recommended to review troubleshooting tips [6, 8, 10]. For instance, if dishes aren't drying, it could be due to selecting the wrong program, which results in a lower washing temperature and decreased cleaning performance, or using cutlery with a low-quality coating that makes water drainage difficult `![If the dishes aren't drying it can be caused by selecting the wrong program or using cutlery with a low-quality coating.](image1)`.

If the dishes aren't clean, possible causes can be insufficient detergent, items blocking the spray arms, or a dirty or improperly fitted filter combination `![If the dishes aren't clean, there is insufficient detergent.](image5)`. Other problems include a stained tub interior potentially caused by detergent with colorant, white film from hard water minerals, or rust stains on cutlery if the items aren't corrosion resistant `![Stained tub interior can be caused by detergent with colorant.](image2)`. Additionally, the dishwasher might not start due to a blown fuse, power supply issues, low water pressure, or an improperly closed door, and suds in the tub can occur if you're using the wrong detergent `![The dishwasher might not start if there is a blown fuse.](image3)`.

Therefore, reviewing common problems such as selecting the wrong program, using low-quality cutlery, insufficient detergent, blocked spray arms, filter issues, and electrical or water supply problems can help you to solve some common problems by yourself.

For users with UL Listed and CSA safety approval, it is essential to use a proper power cord for the local power supply [9]. It is recommended to use an approved 3-core mains lead with earthing-contacts that conforms to the safety regulations of each country, ensuring it meets the proper ratings for voltage and ampere [9]. If there are any doubts regarding the appropriate power cord, consulting a qualified service personnel is advised [9]. ![The image shows the specifications for plug type, cord type, and minimum rating for plug and appliance couplers in the United States and Canada.](image2)
